narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson made an unannounced required annual inspection on 4/12/2022 at 1:00 PM. During the inspection, LPA met with Daryl Morales, Facility Administrator and Alice McGarvey, Facility Administrator Assistant who assisted with the inspection. Three staff were present at the beginning of the inspection and no clients are currently placed. The following items were reviewed for compliance during the inspection: V. Clients- This facility is a Crisis Resolution Center that assist in stabilizing clients and are typically in placement for 15-30 days. Parents of Clients continue to be their authorized representatives. Due to this type of program, client files meet the needs of this population, but are different from other standard child welfare placements. No violations were identified in the clients records. VI. Staff- The remaining 2 of 4 staff were interviewed and 4 files were reviewed. Administrator Certificate expires 11/15/2022. All four staff members had the appropriate criminal record clearances, current first aid & CPR certificates and valid drivers' licenses. LIC 9108 & 9052 were all signed and copies were present in the files. The four staff have varied amounts of training due to their varied length of employment. Yet, none were determined to be in violation or delinquent in training hours. VII. Core/Therapeutic Services- Trauma-Informed practices are implemented as needed. VIII. Special Health Care Needs- NA An exit interview was conducted with Alice McGarvey, Facility Administrator Assistant and a copy of all reports were provided via email. No violations were identified.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Cindy Johnson and Uchenna Ajaero made an unannounced required annual inspection on 3/29/2022 at 10:30 AM. During the inspection LPAs met with Daryl Morales, Facility Administrator who assisted with the inspection. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection or provided during the inspection: · Annual fees are current, but due on 4/2/2022. · Accreditation with CARF, expires 10/31/2022 · Personnel Roster/ LIC 500, Facility Sketch, LIC 308, 309, and 610C, and Board Meeting Minutes. LPAs Johnson and Ajaero conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection was 3 staff to 0 clients (due to the one youth being in school). The following was inspected and/or reviewed: I. Physical Plant Updated license was posted; Personal Rights and Activities calendars were posted. Facility telephone is working. All combined carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were tested and work. Fire Extinguishers were inspected on 2/2/2022. First Aid Kit was fully stocked. Medications were centrally stored, locked and inaccessible to clients. Office is locked and provides privacy. Laundry Facilities are available and operable. Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions are inaccessible and stored in the office and detached garage. Facility is free of vermin.

Kitchen- Refrigerator Temperature was slightly below 45 degrees F. Freezer Temperature appeared to be -5 degrees. Adequate nonperishable foods were present for at least one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum. Hot water temperatures ranged between 105-120 degrees F at three locations Menu was present and posted. Dining area has enough seating and furniture in good condition. Bathroom- 2 bathrooms (1 for clients and 1 for staff) Toilets, sink, bath and shower fixtures in good repair with no visible leaks. Adequate supply of soap and paper towels. Bedrooms- 3 bedrooms All bedrooms had the required linen, bedding and furnishings, which were in good repair. Common Room available has enough seating, furniture in good condition, not broke or damaged. Facility does not have any facility vehicles. Staff do not normally transport clients. Detached garage is kept locked and was inspected. II. Operations- Board Meeting Minutes were provided. III. Disaster Preparedness- Disaster and mass casualty plan was updated and available. Drills are conducted and documented monthly. Disaster preparedness supplies were verified. IV. Emergency Intervention- NA, not utilized. V. Clients- One client is currently placed. The one client was interviewed and file reviewed. VI. Staff- 2 staff were interviewed.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton made an unannounced annual inspection on 1/28/2025 at 10:30 AM and met with Connie Treacy, Case Manager who assisted with the inspection. LPA did advise the agency that the inspection is being completed with the use of the CARE Tool. LPA Shelton conducted a walk-through of the home inside and out. The house is under construction and there were no clients or staff present during the Physical Plant Inspection. This facility is a Crisis Resolution Center that assist in stabilizing clients and are typically in placement for 15-30 days. Parents of Clients continue to be their authorized representatives. Due to this type of program, client files meet the needs of this population, but are different from other standard child welfare placement's. However, due to the home being under construction there are no staff or clients placed in the home. LPA Shelton inspected and/or reviewed the following: · Postings of facility license and Personal Rights Poster were appropriately posted. · Carbon monoxide detectors and Smoke Detectors were present. · Common Room (living room) was available and under construction. · Dining area with enough seating for clients in care and under construction. · Two bathrooms were clean and in working order. . LPA observed Locked Facilities included a shed with equipment and other items. The following items were reviewed for compliance in the regional office prior to the facility inspection: Administrator Certificate for Connie Treacy is current and verified. Fees due were discussed and due on 4/2/25. 024. No citations were issued to the agency at the conclusion of the inspection.

On January 9th, 2025 The Department was notified that a staff member had been arrested for sexual relations with a minor who was not a current client at the facility. The Youth was a previous client of the facility but was not in care at the time of the arrest. Interviews revealed conflicting information. One interview revealed that while the Youth was in care, the Staff member gave the youth his phone number, and began following the Youth on Instagram, stating he could take photos of her to use for her profile. Additionally, while on walks with the Youth, the Staff member would make sexual innuendos. Interviews with staff revealed conflicting information. Four staff members were interviewed in addition to the Administrator and Administrator's Supervisor. Only one staff member interviewed stated that they did witness what could be considered an inappropriate interaction, when the staff member and Youth were tying each others shoes. This staff stated they reported it to the Administrator. The Administrator stated nothing was ever reported to her about the shoe tying incident. No other staff members mentioned hearing or seeing anything inappropriate between the Staff and Youth while she was in care. This Department has investigated the complaint alleging Staff had inappropriate relationship with minor. We have found the complaint to be Unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Exit interview conducted with Connie Treacy. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given.
investigation_findings: 13On Thursday, April 17th, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, made an unannounced investigation inspection at the Facility, to deliver findings for the allegation listed above. Between 1/22/25 and 4/9/25, LPA interviewed the Administrator (A1), the Administrator Supervisor (AS), four staff members (S2, S3, S4, S8), the Youth’s Probation Officer (PO), the Detective (D1), and the Youth (Y1). LPA attempted to interview the alleged staff perpetrator (S1) but was unsuccessful. It was alleged that a staff member had an inappropriate relationship with a minor. (Report continued on LIC 9099-C).

narrative: On Thursday, April 17th, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass arrived unannounced at the Facility for a Case Management inspection. LPA met with Connie Treacy who assisted with the inspection. On January 9th, 2025, LPA Crass received an incident report, and it was revealed that the Facility had temporarily transferred this location to their Rocklin location, because of repairs needing to be done on the Facility. The Administrator Supervisor stated he thought he had notified the Department, however upon record review, discovered he had accidentally forgotten to include Community Care Licensing in the email. A Type B citation is being given today for a violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06 Continuing Requirements, Section 80078(b), Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision on the attached LIC 809 D page. Exit interview conducted with Administrator Connie Treacy. A copy of this report and appeal rights were given.

The investigation revealed the following: According to Koinonia Family Services California Face Covering Requirement policies and procedures dated 8-24-20 indicates that face coverings are not required during counseling or crisis intervention due to the crucial need to rely on facial expressions or when able to maintain physical distancing from others. Interviews conducted with S4, S7, S8 indicted that mask are to be worn when prepping food, administering medication and when social distancing cannot be obtained in the house. S2 indicated that they can wear mask if they prefer and some will wear them when walking in the hallway. S3 indicated that mask are required for prepping food and administering medication but there is lead way when speaking to youth. S6 has indicated that face shields are available for employees to use opposed to face mask. California Department of Social Services Provider Information Notice 20-19 CRP states in part “Staff working at congregate care facilities are mandated to wear face coverings while at work, under the following circumstances:…Working in or walking through common areas, such as hallways, stairways, elevators and parking facilities; In any room or enclosed area where other people…are present when unable to physically distance”. S4, S5, S7 and S8 indicated during the interview that the facility is large enough to maintain social distancing inside the house. S8 also indicated that they can keep distance in the hallway because it’s a big facility. Based on the documents obtained and the interviews conducted the allegation that staff are not wearing masks in the facility is UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, appeal rights, and the LIC811 will be emailed to Katie Danner with a read receipt attached.

narrative: The investigation revealed the following: The facility administrator was aware of a positive Covid-19 employee. The administrator notified the administration office and facility staff. According to the Executive Director (S6) the positive Covid-19 employee was not reported to Community Care Licensing “because it didn’t cross their mind because there was no impact on site”. Although the staff test positive on November 21, 2020 their last day at work was November 18, 2020. Based on LPA’s interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The facility is cited on the attached Lic 9099D under the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter Number 1. An exit interview was conducted with Katie Danner, a copy of this report, appeal rights and the Lic 811 will be emailed to the facility with a read receipt.

deficiencies.description: 80061 Reporting Requirements. Each licensee shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required by the Department, including, but not limited to,…Epidemic outbreaks.  This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on records reviewed and interviews the positive Covid-19 employee was not reported to Community Care Licensing the next working day nor was a written report containing specific information submitted within seven days of the facility being notified.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will provide training on reporting requirements to include positive COVID-19 reporting. An outline of the training and attendance sheet, of staff responsible for reporting incidents to CCL, will be emailed to LPA Sullivan by 4/2/21.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cindy Johnson conducted a virtual complaint investigation tele-inspection with the above facility due to COVID-19 on 3/25/2021 at 2:00 PM to initiate a complaint investigation. LPA Johnson spoke with Diana MacNeil, Administrator and informed Ms.MacNeil this complaint investigation will be investigated by LPA Johnson for the allegations stated above. LPA Johnson informed Ms. MacNeil four photos were taken and provided to CCL showing overflowing waste management containers on the property. LPA Johnson showed the photos and discussed them with Ms. MacNeill. The facility has a white dumpster for green waste, 2 for recyclable waste and 3 cans for garbage. Both recyclable cans were overflowing with 3 extra bags on the ground. The likely circumstances that contributed to the overage were discussed and strategies used to deal with the occurrences. Ms. MacNeill reported the amount of facility garbage is usually maintained in the containers. Based on LPA's observation, photos, and interviews conducted, the complaint allegation is SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. The facility is cited on the attached LIC 9099D for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, 80087 (a) Buildings & Grounds. Exit interview was conducted. Reports were provided via email. Facility Signature will be on hardcopy. Appeal Rights provided.

deficiencies.description:
BUILDINGS & GROUNDS
Four photos were taken and provided on 3/22/2021 to CCL showing 2 overflowing recyclable cans and 3 additional bags on the ground of the property which exceeds waste management sanitation practices.This is not met as evidenced by Based on LPA's observation, photos, and interviews conducted, the facility exceeded waste management sanitation practices
which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
1. All staff with be retrained concerning proper waste management and containment. 
2. We will be requesting an additional recycling bin to accommodate for events or graduations that would cause need for more space to properly dispose of waste. 
3. Staff will maintain the area daily.

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed conflicting information as to whether what was dropped was a THC gummy, or a sexual enhancement drug. S6, the staff member who confiscated the package, stated it said “THC” on it, and felt like there was a gummy texture inside. S5, who is the staff member that dropped the item, stated it was BlueChew, a sexual enhancement pill, only prescribed for adults 18 and over. It was confirmed by all staff interviewed, that the staff member had brought a drug to work and did not realize it fell out of his bag, which allowed a minor to have access to the item. S5 stated, “I have no idea how it fell out of my bag”. This Department has investigated the allegation that a Facility staff allowed minor to have access to THC edibles. Based on interview, we have found that the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. A Type A citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 07, Section 80087(g) Buildings and Grounds, is being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted with Terri Anderson. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were given.
investigation_findings: 13On Thursday, February 6th, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brittany Crass, made an unannounced complaint investigation inspection at the Facility, to deliver findings for the allegation listed above. LPA met with Terri Anderson, who assisted with the inspection. LPA Burgess conducted the initial-10 day complaint investigation at the Facility, on 12/18/2024. Between 12/18/24 and 2/4/25, LPA interviewed the Administrator (S1), Administrator’s Assistant (S2), and five staff members (S3-S7). The minor was not interviewed as they have graduated from the program. It was alleged that on 12/4/2024, a staff member unknowingly dropped a small package which contained a THC gummy. It was alleged that a minor in the program picked up the package, asked what it was, and handed it to a different staff member, who confiscated it. (Continued on LIC 9099-C).

deficiencies.description:
Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, firearms and other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: On 12/4/24, a staff member unknowingly dropped either a THC gummy, or a sexual enhancement drug which allowed a youth to have access to the item.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: By end of day on 2/7/25, the Facility will schedule to retrain this staff member on their Roles and Responsibilities for providing care to clients. Facility will email LPA confirmation of when the training is scheduled.

facility_name: KOINONIA HOMES FOR TEENS-BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROGRAM
narrative: knowledge. During confidential interviews conducted, it was determined that youth, when they go outside on facility grounds for space or leave the facility during unauthorized absence(s), do find objects they can hide on their persons and return to the facility to cause self harm. While the facility does a superficial search of youth when returning from unauthorized absence(s) and do provide close supervision, youth are still successful in bringing in items without staff knowledge. The allegation related to supervision also indicates that due to the house recently switching from a one gender facility to gender-neutral, that the supervision would be negligent, allowing for additional issues related to youth interactions. During the course of the investigation, it was revealed that youth in care did engage in an inappropriate activity but staff denied this was due to a lack of supervision. Youth involved in the identified incident were not available to speak to licensing related to this incident. Regarding the allegation related to staff sharing other youths' information with youth in care, this is related to youth and staff having discussions about previous youth who were residents of the facility. Confidential interviews indicated that staff were good about keeping discussions about current youth away from the general population and refusing to discuss previous youth with current youth in care. It was further indicated that when youth brought up other youth for comparison, staff refuse to discuss personal information about other youth with youth in care and are trained to deflect these types of interactions. LPA Hill could not corroborate personal information was being discussed in the facility as reported. As a result of the information obtained, documentation received, and confidential interviews conducted, the allegations that staff did not ensure sharps are inaccessible, staff was not proving adequate supervision, and that staff were sharing other youths' information are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that while the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Exit interview was conducted with Ms. Anderson and documentation was provided, along with appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted a complaint inspection on 7/3/25 at 12:10 PM and met with Terri Anderson, Administrator to deliver findings on the complaint allegations as stated. LPA Hill informed NAME that the complaint investigation included an initial inspection to the facility on 4/15/25 where documentation was obtained including client roster, youth who had left the facility within the previous 60 days, Needs and Service Plans, and conducted interviews with youth present. Subsequent inspections were conducted on 6/5/25 and 6/6/25 where additional interviews were conducted. LPA Hill also contacted previous youth and/or their parent/guardian regarding experience(s) while residing in the facility. The allegation that staff did not ensure sharps are inaccessible and staff not proving adequate supervision are related to the youth in care having access to sharp items that they were using to self harm without staff

facility_name: KOINONIA HOMES FOR TEENS-BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROGRAM
met_with: Dustin Blum (Facility Manager) And Canaan Sampson (Administrator).
narrative: LPA Martinez conducted interviews and obtained record documents for review which included: Staff Roster and Schedule, Needs and Services Plan, Safety Plans, and Incident Reports for two youth in care. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility, and no deficiencies were observed. Confidential interviews were conducted with eight individuals, during the period of May 16, 2025, to June 11, 2025. Based on interviews conducted and records reviewed, it was determined that C1 and C2 required an increased level of supervision and monitoring to ensure their safety and prevent inappropriate sexual interactions. The investigation found that both youths had been placed on a "no social" plan intended to limit their contact with each other; however, due to insufficient staffing, this plan was not effectively enforced, and C1 and C2 continued to interact. Five out of eight staff interviewed reported difficulty in managing daily work duties, providing adequate care and supervision for all youth, and closely monitoring C1 and C2 due to ongoing staff shortages. On May 12, 2025, while two staff members were occupied with routine tasks, C1 and C2 locked themselves in a room and engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior. Staff were unable to access the room until C1 and C2 voluntarily unlocked the door. As a result of the investigation, it was concluded that C1 and C2 were not provided with the level of care and supervision necessary to ensure their safety and compliance with behavioral plans. Based on confidential interviews and documentation reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be substantiated. The facility will be cited under Title 22 Regulation 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. An exit interview was conducted with Dustin Blum (Facility Manager), and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Dustin Blum (Facility Manager) and Dustin Blum (Facility Manager) And Canaan Sampson (Facility Administrator).

facility_name: KOINONIA HOMES FOR TEENS-BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROGRAM
met_with: Dustin Blum (Facility Manager) And Canaan Sampson (Administrator)
narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Avelina Martinez arrived at this facility unannounced on August 22, 2025, at 1:00 PM to conduct a case management visit. LPA Martinez met with Dustin Blum (Facility Manager) And Canaan Sampson (Administrator) and explained the purpose of the visit. The purpose of today’s visit is to discuss the following deficiency: Needs and Services Plans. During the record review, it was determined that the facility failed to implement a Needs and Services Plan that addressed the sexualized behaviors of clients C1 and C2. As a result, C1 and C2 were not provided with the level of care and supervision necessary to meet their individual needs. The lack of appropriate planning contributed to C1 and C2 engaging in unsafe and inappropriate sexual behavior. The group home will be cited under Title 22, Regulation 84068.2 Needs and Services Plan. This deficiency is documented on the LIC 809D page. Other items discussed during case management: Staffing Shortage: Provide New hire plan Internal Changes:(Work Schedules): provide an updated LIC 500 Program Statement to reflect changes (If needed). Homes for Teens Director: Provide Plan for hiring a new Homes for Teens Director: Property Damage: Discussed repairs. Co-Ed Merge: Provide a copy of Merge letter that was given to parents. Facility Insurance: Provide a copy of facility insurance Continued...

LPA Martinez will continue to follow up on concerns. Staff agrees to email requested documents by September 05, 2025. An exit interview was conducted with Dustin Blum (Facility Manager) And Canaan Sampson (Administrator)., Title. A copy of the LIC 809 report, LIC 809D page, and appeal rights were provided to the facility at the conclusion of the visit.

On April 11, 2022 at approximately 09:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a visit at the facility for the purposes of initiating a 2 Year Required inspection. LPA met with the representative listed above and discussed the purpose of the visit. During the visit, a walk-through of the facility was conducted. The facility is currently vacant and the last client moved out approximately 2 years ago according to the Administrator. PHYSICAL PLANT A walk-through of the physical plant was conducted at approximately 10:00 AM. The facility is a single-story home situated in a quiet residential area. The exterior of the facility was observed to be well-maintained and in good repair. After entering the front door, there is a secured staff office towards the right which is also where medication, sharp objects, and chemicals are safely stored. Postings including the License, Emergency Disaster Plan, and Complaint hotline numbers were prominently placed for any potential clients. Towards the left, a living room and family room were observed. Both rooms were clean, in good repair, and furnished with furniture and entertainment items for potential clients. Moving further left, there is a kitchen and dining room. All kitchen cabinets and appliances were observed to be in good repair. No perishable food was observed due to the facility being vacant. There were a total of 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms for client use. All rooms were observed to be clean and furniture was observed to be in good repair. Mattresses were outfitted with mattress covers and linens were clean and tidy. Bathrooms were observed to have paper towel dispensers, trash bins with covered lids, and soap for potential client use. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be functional and a fire extinguisher was observed to have been serviced in the past year. In the backyard, there is a secure shed used for storing supplies. All indoor and outdoor passageways were free from obstruction. LPA advised that an annual continuation visit would need to be conducted. No deficiencies were observed or cited on this date.

On April 26, 2024, at 9:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted a visit at the facility for the purpose of an annual inspection. LPA met with Luis Tobar, Lead Counselor Supervisor (LCS) and discussed the purpose of the visit. This facility has a licensed capacity of 6 male clients. There were no clients present at the facility at the time of the visit. LPA together with LCS toured the facility. LPA observes postings, after entering the front door. Personal rights, weekly menu, emergency disaster, monthly activities, house rules, grievance/complaint box, complaint hot line number and facility sketch were prominently posted. There are 12 cameras installed in the following common areas: Outside the front entrance, on the outside side of the facility, on the outside rear entrance, in the living room, in the family room, and in the dining room. They are viewed from a monitor in the staff office. There are no bodies of water in the premises. The back yard was free of debris. There is a locked shed in the back yard used to store hand tools such as shovels and rakes. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be functional, and a fire extinguisher was observed. Sharp objects, chemicals, and medication were securely stored in the staff office. All indoor and outdoor passageways were free from obstruction. Food supplies both perishable and non-perishable were checked and found to be sufficient. The first aid kit is complete and accessible in the staff’s office. The water temperature was checked and tested within regulatory guidelines. LPA reviewed four (4) client files and three (3) staff files that were provided by Human Resources staff, Sheila Davis. A review of Guardian and Licensing Information System on 04/22/24, indicates that all facility staff associated with facility have DOJ, FBI, and child abuse index clearances. LPA interviewed one (1) staff at the facility. LPA were provided with current personnel record-LIC 500, register of clients, LIC 308 & 309. Based on the physical inspection of the facility and the records review, there are no violations of Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted with the facility representative and a copy of LIC 809, and LIC 811 were provided to the facility representative Luis Tobar.

On April 9, 2025 at 9:15 AM, LPA Gilbert Gutierrez made an unannounced visit to above facility to conduct an annual/random inspection and met Assistant Program Director (APD), Francisco Guerrero. Administrator Rosa Gamboa Mena, arrived shortly. The home has 5 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. There were no clients placed in the facility since December 23, 2024. LPA with APD Guerrero toured the facility and observed the following: a posted license, menu, emergency Disaster Plan, Children's Personal Rights. There was a complete first aid kit and extra towels and linens in the facility. The whole kitchen is under renovation currently. Two of the bedrooms have two single beds and two bedrooms with single beds. There was adequate drawer and closet spaces for clients' clothing. The smoke and carbon monoxide alarms were in working order. All active client files (when there are placements) will be kept in a filing cabinet with lock. The first aid kit, cleaning supplies, and knives were kept locked in cabinets inside the staff office. The water temperature was tested (110.5 degrees Fahrenheit) and found within regulatory guidelines. All walkways and hallways were unobstructed. There is no body of water in the premises. LPA reviewed two staff files and interviewed one staff. LPA also reviewed the last board minutes meeting. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. The staff meet the required qualification and/or experience requirements. An exit interview was conducted and copy of the LIC 809 and LIC 811 were provided to the administrator. No deficiency citation issued at the time of the inspection.

The first allegation was regarding an inappropriate restraint. Based upon interviews it has been determined that a client was placed in a restraint by staff in order to avoid the client hurting herself or hurting the staff member. Ultimately the restraint used served its intended purpose and in the end the restraint used was appropriate. However, prior to placing the client in a proper restraint, the staff member grabbed the client from behind and briefly held her in a choke hold in order to gain physical control while placing the child in an effective and appropriate hold. The staff member denied placing the child in a choke hold or grabbing her from behind. Witnesses stated they observed the interaction differently and stated the staff member did indeed inappropriately restrain the child briefly in his efforts to gain physical control. This poses an immediate risk to the safety and well being of the children in care. The second allegation was regarding a staff member kicking an object at or towards a client in care. During the same altercation in which an inappropriate hold was placed on a client, the staff member kicked the garbage can towards the client. The garbage can did not hit the client and the staff member stated he never intended to hit the client. In frustration over the conflict, the staff member kicked the can in anger and sent it flying into another room. Despite the fact that the object did not hit the client, it should never have been kicked and the staff member should have handled his frustration in a more appropriate fashion. The clients who witnessed the incident were intimidated by the behavior and it was clearly a violation of their personal rights. Based on LPA's interviews and document review, the preponderance of evidence has been met, therefore the two allegations above are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. Deficiencies were cited and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was provided to the Director.

met_with: Christie O'Neal, Administrator and Samira Hernandez, Facility Manager
narrative:
On April 18, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Herring conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility at 9:15 AM. LPA met with Samira Hernandez, Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual/Required inspection of the facility. The group home is licensed to serve four (4) male/female developmentally disabled clients, ages 10 - 17, ambulatory and non-ambulatory. Currently in placement are four(4) clients placed by Kern Regional Center (KRC) and San Bernardino county. Facility operates within license capacity and limitations. This facility is a one-story home with four (4) bedrooms, two (2) full bathrooms, kitchen, dining, living room and a den. Physical Plant The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are locked in a cabinet located in the garage. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three(3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in a cabinet by the dining area. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Facility has two(2) carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Facility provides basic laundry services. Room temperatures are maintained at 70 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 105 degrees F. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. Each client has his/her own bedroom. All beds are in good repair and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Operational Requirements Facility does not operate beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains a fire clearance. The licensee provides services identified in each child's Needs and Services Plan. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. (cont...)

Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least once every quarter per shift. The drills are documented and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan and register of clients with contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Emergency Intervention Plan Facility maintains a monthly log of each use of manual restraints that contains all required information. The log is available for review by the Department upon request. LPA observed documentation of Emergency Intervention Training and on-going training. Staffing LPA reviewed four (4) personnel records. All individuals subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and signed a Criminal Record Statement. Personnel records are maintained on the licensee, administrator and each employee. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Personnel records contain documentation of 24-hour initial training, and approximately 30-hour annual training in addition to CPR and First Aid. During this inspection, the following deficiencies were observed: - Facility's Disaster Plan does not contain procedures on storage and preservation of medications, including the storage of medications that require refrigeration. - Facility's Disaster Preparedness plan binder does not contain a needs and services plan for each client served by the facility. - The facility's range vent hood fan and lights are not operable. - Minutes of board of directors' meetings do not reflect required information as specified in 84063(a)(9). - Facility's Disaster Preparedness Plan does not contain Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication list for each client and procedures on storage and preservation of medication. - Three(3) out of four(4) personnel records do not contain documentation of facility manager training as specified in 84065(k). These pose a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to clients in care. Deficiency citations were issued. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility along with LIC 809Ds, LIC 811, LIC 9102s, and Appeal Rights.

met_with: Christie O'Neal, Administrator and Samira Hernandez, Facility Manager
narrative: On April 25, 2022, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Jean Herring arrived at the facility at approximately 1:10 PM for the purpose of conducting a Case Management - Annual Continuation inspection of the facility. LPA met with Christie O'Neal, Administrator and Samira Hernandez, Facility Manager. During today's inspection, LPA reviewed client records and interviewed two(2) staff members and one(1) client. Two(2) out of 4 clients are non-verbal and one(1) of the verbal clients was not available at the time of the interview. Client Records. LPA reviewed four(4) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to: Identification and Emergency Information; Admission Agreement; consent forms; needs and services plan and/or Individual Program Plan; medical assessment; TB test; dental, vision, medical, and psychological reports; safeguards for cash resources; personal property and valuables; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. LPA also inspected the clients' medications. During this inspection, LPA observed the following deficiencies: - All four(4) client records do not contain signed copies of the facility's policies and procedures regarding the client's removal and/or discharge, discipline and complaints. - NMD1 and NMD2's age exceptions both expired on 12/31/21. The facility was cited under California Code of Regulations Section 84070(c)(2), Section 84470(b)(2)(F) and 80024(a). A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility representative along with LIC 809Ds, LIC811 and Appeal Rights.

The LPA received inconsistent statements about whether Ref. #1 was left in soiled clothing at the facility or at school. There were statements from the facility that the client returned from school on three different occasions in soiled clothing. There were statements that Ref. #1 was sent to school with two sets of clothing. Contrarily, there were statements that Ref. #1 arrived at school with hardened feces in their diaper. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. The LPA was not provided any information regarding Ref. #1 not receiving an adequate amount of food. The LPA observed the facility menus and observed a sufficient amount of perishable and non-perishable foods at the facility. The LPA observed on Ref. #1's medical exams that Ref. #1 was being treated for weight loss. The medical exams do not indicate that Ref. #1 was diagnosed as malnourished. It is undetermined whether the weight loss was due to stress from personal home life. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. The LPA received inconsistent statements regarding Ref. #1 getting an adequate amount of water. There were statements from the authorized representative not recalling the water being an issue and that Ref. #1 drinks a lot of water. There were statements that Ref. #1's urine was dark and had an odor. The LPA did not observe notes on the medical exam regarding this issue. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation. The investigation revealed that the authorized representative and Service Coordinator had no observable concerns about the facility at this time. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint was provided to the facility representative.
investigation_findings: On May 10, 2022 at 2:45 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen McGee, delivered the findings of the complaint investigation to Facility Manager (FM), Virginia Garcia. On October 7, 2021, the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program (MPCRP), received a complaint with the above mentioned allegation. The LPA conducted confidential interviews that included, but were not limited to: the FM Samira Hernandez at the facility on October 15, 2021; and the authorized representative via telephone on April 29, 2021; the Service Coordinator via telephone on May 5, 2022. The LPA did not interview the client, Ref. #1, because Ref. #1 is non- verbal. The LPA reviewed the following documents: Individual Program Plan (IPP); Menus; Physicians Report; and Clinic Notes. The FM denied the injury, which was a scratch on the upper left thigh happening at the facility. The investigation revealed that the scratch was reported to the authorized representative. The LPA received inconsistent statements on the location as to where Ref. #1 sustained the scratch, whether at the facility or at school. The LPA was not provided information on the cause of the scratch. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegation.

Staff denied the alleged allegations further indicating that the facility is a hands-off facility and that any type of malice conduct by staff will not be tolerated. S1 indicated that her staff is trauma-informed and conducts themselves accordingly. Staff indicated that an incident did occur where C1’s hand was bumped while assisting S2 to prepare dinner. S2 further indicated that they (S2, and C1) bumped each other’s hands while trying to grab the same grocery bag, S2 apologized to C1, inspected C1’s hand, and no marks were observed. S2 denied making any threats or using foul language. C1 denied the allegations indicating that the staff is very supportive and provides whatever is needed. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed with the facility Administrator. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report along with the (LIC 811) was left with the Facility Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On July 26, 2022, at 7:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney, conducted a complaint inspection of the above STRTP Facility and met with the Facility Manager. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. On February 22, 2022, the California Department of Social Services Community Care Licensing Division received a complaint from Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegations: Staff caused injury to minor, staff threatened minor, and staff used foul language toward minor. The investigation of the above allegations was conducted by this LPA and it consisted of, but was not limited to a review of records, including the children’s needs and services plans, medical records, and interviews with 4 Staff members on 3/3/2022, and 1 of 4 Clients (C1) on 3/3/2022. (No statement was obtained from C2, C3, and C4 due to being non-verbal.) (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated July 26, 2022).

narrative:
On September 26 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert.Gutierrez conducted an unannounced required inspection to the facility at 9:00 AM. LPA met with Samira Hernandez, Facility Manager. The administrator arrived shortly. The facility is a one-story home with four (4) bedrooms, two (2) full bathrooms. Currently there are four(4) clients in placement. At the time of the inspection, all the clients were not present. The Facility Manager provided the roster of clients, Personnel Report, Emergency Disaster Plan and Client's Activity. Physical Plant LPA started the inspection at about 10:10 AM. LPA together with Samira Hernandez, Facility Manager, toured the facility. LPA observed the following: the posted license, emergency disaster plan, personnel schedule, client personal rights, and grievance procedure. The disinfectants, cleaning solutions, sharp objects are locked and inaccessible to clients. The facility maintains supplies of non-perishable foods for at least a week and fresh perishable foods for at least two days. Each bedroom has a single bed in good repair with clean sheets and linens and drawers and closet space for the client's clothing. There are extra linens, adequate towels, and hygiene supplies in the cabinet. Only one client sleeps in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is being used as a bedroom. The window screens are in good repair and free of dirt. There are lights in the rooms and throughout the facility. The faucets for client’s use deliver hot water at 105.1 degrees Fahrenheit. The fireplace has cover for client's safety. All medications are stored locked in a metal cabinet. There is a working telephone for clients to use. The first aid kit was complete and readily available. There are working smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. The delayed egress doors are working. All indoor and outdoor passageways are unobstructed

Staff Records At 11:00 AM, LPA reviewed five staff records. All staff subject to criminal records review have been fingerprinted and cleared. There is documentation of the required education and experience requirements and training in the personnel file. LPA interviewed two staff. Client Records At around 1:00 PM, LPA reviewed the client records. All client records are available to LPA to inspect, audit upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, IPP, medical assessment, safeguards for cash resources, personal property, personal rights forms, and medication administration records. No verbal client available for interview at the time of inspection. A deficiency citation is issued at the time of the inspection. A copy of the LIC 809, LIC 809C LIC 809D were provided to the administrator.

On 4/26/23 at 08:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell conducted an announced Office Visit in order to review component II with the Licensee. During the Pre-Licensing Inspection at the above listed facility, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell conducted a Face-to-Face, Component 2 Meeting with the applicant, Steve Zamarripa, Rebekah Norton, and his management team. The purpose of the meeting is to discuss the La Ventana Treatment Programs group home application, which had been submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL) on February 6, 2023. The proposed facility will provide care and supervision for 6 ambulatory only children, ages 12 through 17 years old. LPA reviewed/discussed the children/staff forms that are required and to be maintained in the facility so that they are available for inspection. LPA informed licensee that the original Plan of Operation and Program Statement were reviewed and the following revisions will be required prior to the application being approved. The following matters were discussed: Licensing forms that need to be amended and updated (Surety Bond, LIC610, and LIC503) Staffing requirements for Facility Manager and for all staff working with youth (CACI clearance required) Facility shutoff valves need to be indicated on facility sketch

The following revisions have been requested: · Organizational feedback- add page numbers to all documents as well as a clearer breakdown of the subsections within each tab · Facility manager position does not include required specifications · Tab21/B5- Personnel Policies o Most language is copied directly from the regs and isn’t completely applicable as some language reads “placing agencies” and “regional center”, however, La Ventana does not work with DCFS/Probation and only accepts private pay clients o Hiring practices- all employees will be “requested” to fill out… this language should read “required” o Hiring practices- “DSS Guardian clearance certificate”- need to include the Child Abuse Clearance Index (CACI) due to working with children. Need to include grievance policy for staff to file a complaint. o Abuse reporting- remove information related to adults “ child/adult protective agencies.” See last line of page- “or, an adult discloses an incident that appears to constitute abuse”. There’s a paragraph about “domestic violence” that does not apply. There should be language about submitting an SIR to CCL. There is language about “client abuse/child abuse” but the reporting requirement for adults/children are different. · Staff/client ratio- reg pulled from adult programs · Tab22/B6- In service training o Medication observation policy (steps 1-16) o Include PMAR regs/policy · Tab23/ B7- Facility program description o “client admitted with a primary diagnosis including but not limited to” list of disorders include one specifically applied to individuals over 18.

o Groups offered- “Alumni Groups” uncleared persons cannot enter the facility · Tab24/ B8- Rules of Discipline/personal rights o Discipline policies and Procedures section: “client refuses to take a random drug screen”- not allowed o THE “POLICY” is the reg copied and pasted but includes additional language reflected by (g) and (h) o Revise Complaint procedure- “La Ventana shall develop…” · Tab 25/ B9- Admission policies o Title: Admission policies- Policies within this section are not relevant to the program, and regulations are copied and pasted. o Procedure section: (c) “before a child can be admitted to a community treatment facility…” o (9) “certification that a child is emotionally disturbed”? o (11) “authorization from a placing county’s intra agency…” o Title: Intake Procedures o Admission form is for Adults Program (most likely) and reflects language related to having client pay the amount owed as well as other language related to treatment of adults. Includes language about “understood that client may be subject to random drug screens.” Medication is described as being observed and not administered. There is language about “giving notice of eviction to the client for non-payment of the rate for basic services.” o Title: Runaway Plan- § Policy includes being automatically drug tested- not allowed o Copied from “Emergency intervention for Group Homes” regulation

o Title: Needs and services plan (a)(1) a needs and services plan is not required for children who are placed in the facility on an emergency basis and who will remain in placement for less than seven days as documented in the childs record…”- this does not apply this this group home model. · Title: Personal rights- language included related to “community treatment facility” when facility is classified as a group home. o The regulation pasted into the manual is from the Community Treatment facility section of the regs o Title: Personal rights: (b) “each facility shall provide each school aged child placed in foster care…” this doesn’t apply. o Discharge procedures- reg is copied and pasted from the community treatment facility regs (84168.5) The Applicant has been informed that all revisions must be submitted to CCL within 30 days of this meeting. If this information is not received by May 26, 2023 this application will be considered withdrawn. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with the Applicant.

On 4/26/23, at 8:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Nancy O’Connell conducted an announced prelicensing inspection at the above-lised facility. Licensing staff was met by Steve Zamarripa Licensee, Facility Administrator (FA) Rebeka Norton, Nursing Director, Facilities Director, and COO. The facility is two-story home which contains fours bedrooms (three upstairs, one downstairs), and 6.5 bathrooms. The home has a fully equipped kitchen and a spacious living room that can be utilized as a multipurpose room. The frontyard, and backyard was observed to be secure, free of obstructions, and neat. The facility maintains one facility vehicle that seats 8 people and insurance/registration were observed to be current. There are plenty of charged fire extinguishers through the facility. Carbon monoxide detectors were tested and fully functions. Detergents and cleaning supplies were observed to be locked and inaccessible to minors. Medication closet was observed to be secured and inaccessible to minors. Facility files will be maintained within the staff office. LPAs observed the following during inspection: Kitchen: equipped with a stove, microwave, oven, refrigerator, plenty of cabinet space, and enough plates/cups/utensils for all clients. Trashcans are covered. Dining Room: there is a dining table adjacent to the kitchen with enough seating for 8 people Living Room: the living room is a large open space that functions as a area for relaxation, plenty of seating for 10+ people, tv, a non-functional fireplace, and access to the backyard. Upstairs Hallway: the hallway upstairs has a linen closet and maintains enough linen and towels for all residents. There is a charged fire extinguisher and carbon monoxide detector in this space. Continued on LIC809C

Bathrooms- there are 6.5 bathrooms through the facility, each with operational plumbing and running water that meets temperature requirements Bedroom #1 upstairs: will be occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There is adequate closet and drawer space, and there is a desk available. The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #2 upstairs: occupied by two clients with two twin size beds, dressed with clean linens, on each side of the room. There is adequate closet and drawer space. The bedroom does not serve as a passageway to any other part of the facility. Bedroom #3 downstairs: the room will be occupied by two clients and maintain two twin beds, with drawer space, and an attached bathroom. Extra activity room- there is a small room upstairs that is only large enough for one client. Licensee communicates that it will be converted to a activity room. Laundry: located in the garage area and equipped with a washer and dryer in working order, and plenty of cabinet space. Laundry detergents and cleaning supplies are kept in locked cabinet across from the laundry appliances and are inaccessible to clients without supervision. This area also functions as a group room and has 8 armchairs available fo seating, or to conduct groups. Backyard - there is an enclosed fence that extends around the perimeter of the facility that meets height requirements. There is no body of water on the premises. The yard appeared clean and orderly with no hazards. Medication station- medications are stored in a locked cabinet, in a closet close to the kitchen. The policy for medication administration is posted on the inside of the door. Medication boxes were kept locked with a combination lock and Licensee agrees to obtain and utilize a lock and key for meds. Staff office- this office is located on the first floor near the kitchen and has computers, desks, chairs, and an additional bathroom. This space will be utilized for staff to conduct administrative duties, and where client records will be stored. LPA observed that doors do not lock and Licensee agrees to change doors in order to ensure area is secured. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations, there are two deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed and emailed to the licensee.

On July 17, 2024 at 10:15 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection at the above listed facility. A health and risk assessment was conducted. LPA met with Carla Fernandez Program Director. (S1) who granted access to the facility. The facility is seeking a license to provide care and supervision for six (6) female clients ages 12-17, ambulatory only. Currently there are four (4) clients in placement. The facility can be accessed through front entrance in the door. There is a facility vehicle that seats 8 people and insurance/registration were observed to be current and in good operating conditions. There is no body of water on the premises and the Licensee ensured that there are not firearms or dangerous weapons on the facility. There are no cameras observed and other is Ring Door Bell at the front door entrance. The Group Home Overview: This is a 2-story home located in a cul-de-sac residential neighborhood. The facility consists three (3) bedrooms one downstairs and two (2) upstairs and 6.5 bathrooms. The home has a fully equipped kitchen and a spacious living room that is also utilized as a multipurpose room. Outdoor Area - there is an enclosed fence that extends around the perimeter of the facility that meets regulation for the height. The Patio space is free of hazard materials and debris. The passageways and porches are unobstructed. LPA observed patio furniture and outdoor recreational equipment, mounted basket ball hoop, Ping-Pong and Foosball table and a punching bag. The side house stores the electrical utilities, shut-off valves for gas and water, there are two (2)a tank-less Hot Water Heaters and central heat and air conditioning unit. Bedroom#1 (located on first floor): is occupied by two (2) clients. It is equipped with two (2) twin size beds, two (2) end tables, dresser drawers, ample lighting, a closet, and an adjoining bathroom. The bedroom has a connecting door that leads outside to the backyard and is not in use and locked. Upstairs hallway bathroom: There are three (3) bathrooms observed with toilet, shower, and sink.

Bedroom #2: is occupied with two (2) clients, equipped with two twin (2) size beds, two (2) end tables, dresser drawers, ample lighting, and a closet. This room maintains a door that leads to upstairs attic. This door is locked and inaccessible to the clients. Bathrooms- there are 6.5 bathrooms throughout the facility, each is equipped with one (1) toilet, one (1) sink , bathtub and a shower observed to be in good condition. The water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Extra activity room upstairs- there is a small room upstairs between bedrooms #2 and #3, The therapy room is utilized for the clinical team. Clients files and records are stored in the room in a locked closet. This room also has an bathroom. Laundry room: Is located in the classroom area, enclosed behind two (2) doors, equipped with a Samsung Washer and Dryer unit in good condition and ample cabinet space. The laundry detergents and cleaning supplies were observed to be locked and inaccessible to clients. Medication station- is located on the 1st floor adjacent to the main staff office, observed to be secured and is inaccessible to clients. Classroom: located on 1st floor, equipped with 7 desks and 7 chairs, a large computer monitor, bookshelves/books, cabinet storage space. There is also a full size bathroom. Staff office- this office is located on the first floor near the kitchen and has computers, desks, chairs, office supplies, nursing supplies. The office is utilized for staff to conduct administrative duties. This office has an adjoining bathroom. The Facility files are maintained in the staff office. All posting requirements were met,(i.e food menu (posted in the kitchen and common area); (regulations, personal rights (posted at the entrance); facility sketch. LPA confirmed that all staff currently listed on the LIC500 have an approved criminal background clearance. The LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Facilities are posted on the wall at the entrance. LPA observed hard wired interconnected combined smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector; tested to be operable. LPA observed several fully charged fire extinguishers mounted on the walls throughout the facility, up stairs down stairs. External door sensors were observed on doors leading to outside of facility. The staff accompanies clients to local recreational facilities in the facility vehicle. LIC 809 PAGE 2 OF 3

Clients are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. The facility will operate within license conditions and limitations including capacity limitations. Facility personnel are instructed to report violations of personal rights and will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Licensee will report client injuries requiring medical treatment. LPA reviewed entire CARE Tool with Administrator and provided information related to department resources such as accessing PINs, quarterly provider meetings, and regulatory requirements. LPA interviewed four (4) clients currently in placement. LPA interviewed three (3) on duty staff. LPA reviewed four (4) clients records. LPA three (3) staff records. PER California Code Regulation, TITLE 22, DIVISION 6, CHAPTERS 1, General Licensing Regulations. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA concluded the Post License Continuation Inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility with Carla Fernandez Program Director. LIC 809 PAGE 3 OF 3

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced inspection visit to the home on 4/8/21 beginning at 10:30 AM. LPA was joined by Valley Mountain Regional Center’s Community Service Liaison (CSL), Rukaiyah Jones. At the time of arrival, there was one staff (DSP) present with two Clients (C1 and C2). LPA and CSL met initially with the DSP and explained today's inspection was to conduct a Case Management visit. Within ten minutes, the Administrator arrived. LPA and CSL met with the Administrator and explained today's Case Management inspection was to follow up on the Default Decision and Order that was served in December of 2020 and went into effect on January 11, 2021. LPA also explained that this was a follow up to a complain investigation to interview staff. On today’s date, LPA and CSL spoke with and interviewed the Administrator, Staff DSP, and C2 . A Health and Safety inspection of the home was completed. No deficiencies were cited on today’s date. Exit interview conducted with the Administrator. The Administrator gave verbal permission for DSP, Eva Lopez, to sign the report as Administrator had to leave. DSP signed this report and a copy was emailed to the Administrator.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shoua Xiong conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection to the facility on 4/1/21 beginning at 10:30 AM. Due to COVID-19, this Case Management was conducted telephonically. LPA spoke with the Administrator, Anthony Johnson, and explained that the purpose of the call was to discuss the Default Decision and Order that was served by CDSS on December 31, 2020, which went into effect January 11, 2021 regarding staff S1. LPA notified Administrator that the Motion to Set Aside and Vacate Default Decision and Order has been denied. LPA inquired about Staff S1's presence in the facility. Administrator confirmed that S1 does not reside at the facility and is no longer an employee of the facility. Administrator stated that S1 stopped working at the facility before the Default Decision and Order even went into effect. No deficiencies were cited on today's date. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report was emailed to the Administrator with a request for a signature and electronic return of the document.

During confidential interviews regarding the allegation that the facility is not accommodating visitors, RP stated the facility was not allowing visitations, citing excuses including the COVID pandemic. However, RP stated that clients would go out to places such as the grocery stores. RP stated that they had called the facility a few days after the initial allegation to talk about visitations with AD again and AD invited RP to go visit. However, RP stated they did not go to the facility that day because they weren’t feeling well. In an interview with AD, they stated that they have never denied visitors to the facility. AD stated that prior to COVID, although the facility was under no obligation to do so, staff would transport Client C1 to their parent’s (BM) residence for a visit. AD stated that with COVID, staff are not transporting and staying with C1 for home visits with BM. AD stated BM is welcomed to visit the facility any time and staff can accommodate and designate areas to be sanitized before and after each visit. In interviews with Staff S1-S3, consistent statements were made that visitations at the facility has never been denied. S1-S3 also made consistent statements that BM will request staff to transport C1 to their residence for visits, which staff did in the past. S3 shared their opinion on how the facility can even accommodate visitations by using the garage which has been fixed so that visitors can sit in there and have the doors open for air flow. However, S3 stated they did not know the facility’s visitation policy. During interviews regarding the allegation that the facility is not returning calls from authorized representative promptly, RP named a prior administrator who RP stated would not return her phone calls for days. RP stated the facility does not communicate with her. In an interview with AD, he stated that he is committed to returning phone calls and has never had issues of not returning a person’s phone calls and even keeps a call log to document incoming calls. In interviews with Staff, S1 stated that they take down messages and write everything down on a call log to ensure that calls are being answered and returned. S2 stated they do not know of any staff who purposely does not return calls or voicemails left on the machine but does admit that sometimes, the voice mailbox gets full if staff forgets to delete old messages. S2 stated that sometimes clients have TV or music on loud and staff can’t hear phone ring. S2 stated the prior Administrator had issues with lack of responding to emails but that the current administrator (AD) does communicate in a timely manner with telephone, text, and responds even better with emails. Staff S3 stated they always check the phone for missed calls or voicemail upon the start of their shift and makes sure to return the calls. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No title 22 regulations were cited during today’s inspection. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights, was left with the Administrator, Anthony Johnson.

narrative:
On 10/31/23, at 09:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA Goldie was greeted at the door by staff, Ludwig Wimmer. Staff Wimmer,(S1), assisted LPA Goldie with the inspection. Two staff and no clients were present in the home at arrival. S1 stated the 4 clients are due home between 2:30 PM and 4:00 PM LPA Goldie observed the following during the inspection of this single story home: The yard is clean.. All screens are in good repair. Window in bedroom one has safely been repaired with a new window 3 inches short and wood covering temporarily installed. A replacement window is on order with Delta Glass. The garage contained an additional two refrigerators, outdoor equipment and and additional games. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Sharps are inaccessible to clients as required. Centrally stored medications secured along with 3 first aid kits were observed. The facility has 2 single occupancy bedrooms and one dual bedroom for clients in care. The bedrooms have required furniture and closet space. Adequate supply of linens and bedding were observed in linen closet. The dining room has a large table with 6 chairs to accommodate all clients and staff. LPA observed carbon monoxide/ smoke detectors in place and tested. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. Appropriate forms posted in view included license, Client register, and Emergency Disaster Plan. Kitchen observed to have 2 days of non-perishables and 5 days of non-perishables. Temperature was a comfortable 68 degrees. Water temperature measured 107.6 degrees, within compliant range of 105 degrees and 120 degrees. Hygiene supplies were observed in bathroom. LPA completed 3 staff interviews and observed 3 clients during today's inspection. LPA conducted record review of 4 staff files. During inspection, 5 Title 22 Type B violations were cited. Two technical violations and one technical assistance were given. These are not deficiencies.

The following Care Tool domains were completed: Physical Plant, Operations, Disaster Preparedness and Staffing. Exit interview was conducted with Program Administrator at 04:40 PM and a copy of report along with appeal rights were provided.

The Department has investigated the complaint that a child sustained unexplained injuries while in care. LPA Shelton investigated this complaint by reviewing client records, body check log, and behavior log, conducting confidential interviews with staff, maintenance worker, C1’s school Principal and the Administrator between 2/2/2024 and 2/12/2024. LPA Shelton attempted to interview two clients; however, they did not have the ability to communicate verbally and only observed. Based on confidential interviews with the school principal, administrator, manager, maintenance worker staff and observing two clients. LPA learned that some of the clients in the home have self-injurious behaviors (SIB). All of those interviewed deemed that the scratches on C1’s neck were caused by SIB. The Administrator informed LPA that the injury C1 sustained was from C1 scratching self in the shower. Two staff members noticed the injury when C1 exited the bathroom after a shower. C1 became excited in the shower. LPA Shelton interviewed the school principal and discussed the behavior log and body check log at the clients' school, and they corroborated the client has SIB, as did C1’s Individual Program Plans (IPP). This agency has investigated the complaint that the child sustained unexplained injuries while in care. Based on the investigation, observation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint findings are UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were left with the Manager.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton conducted a visit to the home on 2/26/2024 at 9:50 AM, and LPA spoke with the Manager to deliver findings of the investigation on the complaint allegation as stated. LPA Shelton informed the complaint investigation included a tour of the home on 2/2/2024. The initial 10-day complaint inspection was conducted on 2/2/2024 which, included a Physical Plant Inspection of the home and obtaining of relevant documents: Needs and Service Plan, C1’s Individual Program Plan (IPP), Behavior Log, Body Check Log related to the client, LIC 500 including staff contact information with schedule for current month, and case notes for C1. Continued LIC9099C

met_with: Kyndra Washington Lead Anthony Johnson Administrator
narrative:
On 11/08/24, at 08:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA Goldie was greeted at the door by lead staff, Kyndra Washington (S5). S5 called Administrator, Anthony Johnson to notify him of the inspection and called an additional staff member to come in. S5 stated the Administrator would arrive within thirty minutes. One staff and a client are present in the home at arrival. S5 stated the other two clients are at school and will arrive home between 02:30 PM and 03:00 PM. LPA Goldie observed the following during the inspection of this single story home: Documentation required posted on bulletin board in living room included Facility License, Emergency Disaster plan and current Group Home Administrator Certificate, Grievance forms were observed to be accessible to residents in living room. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The spacious living room includes seating for residents and staff as well as guests to engage with one another. Sharps are inaccessible to clients as required in the closet adjacent to the office.. Locked and centrally stored medications along with a complete first aid kit were observed. The facility has two single occupancy and one dual bedrooms. Linens and storage space are compliant. Bedroom number 1 and number 2 did not have lighting present. Administrator stated they were removed due to behaviors. The water tested in the kitchen measured 107 degrees which is in the compliance range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees. The dining room has a large table with chairs to accommodate all clients. Carbon monoxide detector and smoke detectors were tested and active. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. Kitchen observed to have 2 days of perishables and 5 days of non-perishables. Temperature was a comfortable 72 degrees. Hygiene supplies were observed in closet along with additional linens and towels. Continued on LIC809C

LPA Connie Goldie did a review of LIC 500 and compared it to the Guardian roster. During review, it was observed that four staff, S1, S2, S3 and S4 are not cleared and are working. LPA advised the Administrator that these staff need to be removed from the schedule until they are background cleared. Administrator stated understanding the urgency of this violation and stated they would be removed from the schedule immediately until clearance is received. LPA completed the following Care Tools Domains today- Physical Plant, Operational Requirements and Disaster Preparedness. 1 Type A and 5 Type B Title 22 violations are being cited during today's inspection. A Civil Penalty is being issued for Criminal Background Clearance for four staff. Additionally, 3 Technical Violations are being issued. These are not deficiencies. LPA will return to complete Annual inspection on a later date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of reports along with appeal rights were discussed and provided to facility staff, Kyndra Washington.

Personnel Requirements

(d) The licensee shall designate at least one facility manager to be present at the facility at all times when children are present

narrative: On 07/23/2025, at 11:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, Connie Goldie made an unannounced case management inspection and met with Kyndra Washington, Facility Manager who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of the inspection was to follow-up on observations LPA Goldie made during inspection on 07/18/2025. During inspection made on 07/18/2025, LPA Goldie met a staff member, S1, who had been on staff since 07/09/2025. S1 was in ratio as staff. It was identified that S1 has no previous experience providing direct supervision to persons with developmental disabilities and has not completed an Orientation. Additionally, facility manager, Ludwig Wimmer, was unable to locate S1's personnel file and a copy of current month's staff schedule. LPA reviewed the facility's Program Statement and learned that minimum requirement for position of Direct Support Professional, position S1 holds, is six months previous experience. The facility is being cited for three Title 22 deficiencies. See LIC 809D. A copy of this report along with appeal rights were discussed and provided to facility staff.
