met_with: Hector Vega Facility Manager Anthony Johnson Administrator
narrative:
Regarding the allegation, “Facility staff do not maintain accurate records for minors in care”, Record review conducted on 06/05/2025 of C1’s file had missing required documentation, C1’s current IPP and face sheet were not included in the file and were supplied to LPA on 06/06/2025 via email. A witness (W1) stated that they are “asked for information, such as correspondence about a new doctor or insurance change, that has already been provided weeks and even months afterwards.” A Regional Center staff stated that record requests are late and there is concern about organization. Two of five staff members stated that C1’s documentation is put in C1’s bedroom or the office. One staff member stated that an IPP has been misplaced in another client’s file. Two staff members stated that client documentation is placed in youth files. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation(s) is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 Article 6 84070(b) Children’s Records are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D.” An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.

The Department investigated the allegations, “Facility staff are not meeting minor’s personal hygiene needs” and “Facility staff are not meeting minor’s toileting needs.” Five of five staff corroborate that youth in care are showered daily, 1-2 times a day and that C1 showered in the morning and in the evening. The staff were consistent in statements of C1’s personal hygiene routine process which included monitored showering with prompting, teeth brushing, applying lotion and self-dressing by C1. It was stated that C1 preferred showers and did shower both in the stand-alone shower and the bathtub with a shower and that staff would ensure that the water temperature was warm. C1 would communicate if the temperature was too cold or too warm but, would play with the knob afterwards. C1 is incontinent but was in the process of toilet training and did have many accidents. Staff collaborated that C1 was checked every 30- 60 minutes and was cleaned and changed as needed. If C1 had an accident, it was stated that he would shower afterwards, and clothes/ sheets were laundered. C1 was unable to be interviewed due to limited verbal skills but, was observed to be wearing clean clothes, and well-groomed on unannounced visit on 06/05/2025. Record review of bathroom logs are consistent with staff statements. Regional Center staff also communicate C1’s hygiene needs appeared to be met when they visited. Based on the investigation, records reviewed, and interviews conducted, the complaint finding is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of all reports and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the facility.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Connie Goldie arrived at the facility to conduct an unannounced complaint investigation inspection on 07/29/2025 at 12:45PM. LPA Goldie spoke with Hector Vega, Facility Manager and Anthony Johnson Administrator to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation and allegation stated above. LPA Connie Goldie conducted this investigation.The initial 10-day complaint investigation inspections were conducted by LPA Goldie at the facility on 06/05/2025. LPA Goldie reviewed youth file (C1), conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and outside and interviewed staff, S1. LPA attempted to interview C1 who has limited verbal communication. LPA Goldie obtained the following documentation: Client roster, May 2025 staff schedule, C1’s face sheet, Individualized Program Plan, May 2025 bathroom logs, and g-tube removal documentation. During the investigation, eight confidential interviews were conducted between 06/05/2025 and 07/25/2025. Continued on LIC9099C

narrative: On August 20, 2025 at approximately 12:30pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tatyana Shulz arrived at the Labara Family Care Home for the purposes of conducting a wellness check of the clients in care due to the facility being newly placed on their caseload. LPA was greeted by Hector Vega, Facility Manager who granted LPA access. LPA conducted a tour of the inside and outside of the facility where LPA observed the following deficiencies. Outside portion of the living rooms double paned window is broken and not boarded up. Staff toilet is inoperable. Living room outlet does not have a cover. While on sight LPA witnessed staff cover the broken window with a board and covered the outlet with an ottoman until repairs can be made. Work orders have been placed and the facility has been cited for Buildings and Grounds on LIC809D. This case management will remain open, until a follow up inspection is conducted to ensure the facility is in full compliance. An exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was left with Ludwig Wimmer, Facility Manager.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Les Inouye conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection to the Group Home (GH) via televisit, (in accordance with PIN 20-05-CRP) and met with Melissa Muncrief. Based on interviews conducted and documentation provided it has been determined The Last Resort has failed to provide documentation for a current certified administrator on staff. Based on the LPA’s observations, interviews and records review which were conducted, there is a preponderance of evidence to substantiate a violation of regulation based on Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5 and are being cited on the attached LIC 809D A copy of the report and Appeal Rights was provided to the FFA.

On 02/24/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a case management inspection to consult with the facility. Met by Board of Directors President Melissa Muncrief. Due to restrictions of COVID-19, this inspection was conducted by teleinspection with a copy of the report scanned to Ms. Muncrief with a request for signature and a scan back on this date. During a physical plant inspection, the facility had snacks locked in the cupboard. There was fruit available and all clients stated that they could have snacks whenever they were requested. The facility manager was advised during inspection to unlock the snacks. The facility does not have a current Administrator as the prior Administrator quit employment. The facility is interviewing potential candidates at this time. Facility may need a waiver for the bed type used to include springs with the mattress. There are no deficiencies cited at this time.

investigation_findings: 13On 02/24/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a follow up complaint investigation with The Last Resort. This LPA met with Board of Directors President Melissa Muncrief. The purpose of the follow up is to provide the outcome of the investigation. Due to restrictions of Covid-19, the followup was conducted by teleinspection with a scan of the documents to Ms. Muncrief on this date with a request for signature and a scan back on this date. Clients and staff were interviewed. In addition, documents were obtained and an inspection of the physical plant was conducted. Client and staff interviews are conflicting with the cleanliness of the facility, whether the staff allow the clients to have inappropriate relations and behaviors, if the staff have unethical interactions with the clients and if the staff give the residents cigarettes. Therefore, the complaint is unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was scanned to Ms. Muncrief. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date.

13On 02/24/2021, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Melikian conducted a follow up complaint investigation with The Last Resort. This LPA met with Board of Directors President Melissa Muncrief. The purpose of the follow up is to provide the outcome of the investigation. Due to restrictions of Covid-19, the followup was conducted by teleinspection with a scan of the documents to Ms. Muncrief on this date with a request for signature and a scan back on this date. Clients and staff were interviewed. In addition, documents were obtained and an inspection of the physical plant was conducted. Resident (#1) did not have the appropriate documentation for the facility to administer psychotropic medication and the required form was not used for psychotropic medication. In addition, law enforcement contacts were not properly reported to the Department. The faciliy did have a sufficient amount of qualified staff, however, they were lacking in training requirements. Based on the above, the complaint is substantiated. Exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was scanned to Ms. Muncrief. Deficiency on the attached page.

deficiencies.description:
84070(b) Children's Records.A copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child's parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication, as defined in Section 84001(p)(4).
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on documents inspected, resident (#1) did not have the appropriate documentation to administer psychotropic medication which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility requested parental authorization and resident was transferred out shortly after. Facility will request authorizations for psychotropic medications at time of intake when appropriate. Deficiency cleared on this date.

deficiencies.description:
84061(i) Reporting Requirements.
The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or a report containing all the information required in LIC 624-LE, regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child residing in the facility.  
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on calls for service obtained from the local law enforcement agency and a review of documents submitted to the Department, there were contacts with law enforcement which were not reported which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee conducted an all staff training on reporting requirements and will forward the documentation to CCL on or before 2/25/2021.

deficiencies.description:
84065(j) Personnel Requirements.
Notwithstanding Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), all child care staff shall complete a minimum of 20 hours of annual training, except as specified in (2) below. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on a review of personnel training records, staff did not meet the minimum training hours or types of training required which poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will schedule the appropriate trainings for personnel that satisfy the intent of the regaulation. Documentation will be forwarded to CCL on or before 03/24/2021.

narrative: Complaint Specialist C.K. Kinney(CS) traveled to the facility to conduct a Case Management inspection to ensure the facility is no longer in operation. No deficiencies observed or cited during this inspection. Copy of this report left with S1 at conclusion of inspection.

On Monday June 21, 2021 at 11:49 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes conducted an annual inspection of the facility. At time of inspection LPA met with House Administrator Alan Kana. The facility was toured inside and out with house administrator Alan Kana. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. There were no clients present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than one client in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the clients bathroom was measured to be 105 degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in cabinet in garage. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the garage. The First Aid Kit is located in the staff office and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in each bedroom were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector is located in the hallway and was operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by house administrator Alan Kana. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Continue next page

Four client and seven staff files were reviewed during the inspection and noted to have documents required per regulations in file. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice, FBI and Child Abuse Index clearances. LPA requested updated copies of LIC 500, LIC 309, LIC 308, LIC 400, and LIC 402 to be emailed to LPA. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report, was reviewed and given to house administrator Alan Kana.

investigation_findings: 13On October 24, 2023, at 2:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with Facility Group Home Administrator Alan Kana, to deliver the finding of the above allegation. LPA Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an inspection of the facility on April 17, 2023. During the investigation, LPA Anderson interviewed one client (C2), one witness, and four Staff (S1-S4). LPA Anderson attempted to interview several clients; however, LPA was unsuccessful with the interviews due to the clients having limited speech or being unavailable for interviews. LPA reviewed Client 1 (C1)’s Individual Program Plan (IPP) as well as Special Incident Reports. On April 7, 2023, the Department received a complaint alleging staff restrain resident. More specifically, it was reported that staff strapped C1 on the toilet for a long period of time with a gait belt. Interviews revealed conflicting statements.

narrative: Regarding the allegation that staff strangled minor resulting in injuries, confidential interviews revealed that S1 threw C1 in C1’s room resulting in C1 sustaining scratches and bruises on C1’s shin. However, confidential interviews reported that S1 acted appropriately during the incident with C1 to gain control of C1 and protect the safety of the other clients in the home. When C1 AWOLed from the facility, S1 quickly attempted to follow C1, contacted C1’s family and called local officials. In regard to the allegation that staff handled minor in a rough manner, confidential interview reported that staff was hitting and placed hands on C1 choking. However, confidential interviews reported that S1 used verbal redirection and positive reinforcer towards C1 when C1 was upset and began charging and threatening staff. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Regarding allegation that staff speak inappropriately to minors, confidential interviews revealed S1 called C1 derogatory name. However, S1 denied calling C1 a derogatory name. Other confidential witnesses didn’t provide relevant information or support the allegation. Regarding the allegation that staff misuse minor's cash resources, confidential interviews revealed that the staff was taking all C1’s money because C1 had zero dollars in C1’s account. However, confidential interviews revealed that everything purchased for C1 has to get approved by the managers and accountant’s supervisor and vice president of financial. LPA couldn’t verify the information. Based on interview and record review, the allegation S1 strangled C1 resulting in injuries; S1 handled C1 in a rough manner; staff speaks inappropriately to C1; and S1 misuse C1’s cash resources. may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Shonda Simmons, House Manager.
investigation_findings: 13On July 12, 2024, at 11:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with House Manager Shonda Simmons, to deliver finding of the above allegation. The investigation was conducted by Senior Special Investigator Angelica Medina of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Branch. Senior Special Investigators Angelica Medina interviewed five staff, two clients and several witnesses. The investigation included a review of San Diego Sheriff’s Investigative report and Rady’s Childrens Hospital medical report. The Department received a complaint on October 13, 2023, alleging staff strangled minor resulting in injuries; staff handled minor in a rough manner; staff speak inappropriately to minor; and staff misuse minor's cash resources.

narrative:
On August 21, 2024, at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPAs) Abby Saeteurn and Carol Anderson conducted an unannounced Annual Required Inspection. LPA Saeteurn and Anderson met with the Facility Group Home Administrator Alan Kana. LPAs toured the interior and exterior. Currently, there are three clients residing at this facility at this time. LPA Saeteurn interviewed two clients. LPA Saeteurn interviewed two staff. The facility is a four-bedroom and a two-bathroom facility, and it is set up as follows: • Bedroom 1 has 1 queen bed, all appropriate furnishing and sleeps one client. • Bedroom 2 has 1 full bed, all appropriate furnishings and sleeps one client. • Bedroom 3 has 1 queen bed, all appropriate furnishing, and sleeps and one client • Bedroom 4 has 1 full bed, all appropriate furnishing and sleeps one client. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Medications were locked in the cabinet in staff office. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the garage. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in the garage. The facility had two first aid kits. One kit was in the medication cabinet with all required items and the other one accessible on the top of the cabinet.

There were no guns or weapons as stated by the administrator. Hot water temperature was reading at 105 degrees. Smoke detector was tested and operable. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan, Facility Sketch and Title 22 Personal Rights were posted at this time. LPA Saeteurn inspected the facility vehicle, which was in operable conditions, registered and with insurance coverage. The backyard is fully fenced, covered patio with patio furniture. LPA Saeteurn reviewed five staff files and two client files. All the required documentation in the files. LPA Saeteurn requested updated copies of LIC 309, LIC 308, LIC 400, and LIC 402 to be emailed to LPA Anderson. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to Facility Administrator Alan Kana.

It was reported that S2 disclosed information about the client’s behavior and disability. It was also reported S2 was involved in a physical altercation with the client, resulting in S2’s arm being dislocated. In reference to the allegation that staff engaged in a physical altercation with a minor, confidential interviews revealed that staff at the facility have not engaged in physical altercations with clients in care. Additionally, confidential interviews also disclosed that when client’s behavior escalate, staff will talk ro clients and give them time and space to themselves. Confidential interviews did not corroborate any incidents or issues in which S2 engaged in a physical altercation with a client. Confidential interviews described S2 as “nice” to both staff and clients. A review of a Special Incident Report (SIR) submitted to CCL, did, however, reveal there was an incident on November 16, 2023, in which a client dislocated a staff member’s arm after experiencing behavioral dysregulation and expressing suicidal ideation and intent to harm others; however, the report did not indicate it was the named client. The Special Incident report did not reveal which staff had their arm dislocated and did not indicate it was a result of a physical altercation. In reference to the allegation that staff disclosed personal information about a minor while in care, a confidential interview revealed there was previously a client in care in the facility with a similar name. Confidential interviews and a review of pertinent facility records confirmed there is not a resident at the facility and there have been no former clients placed in the facility with the reported name. Confidential interviews revealed staff have not been seen or heard disclosing information about clients in care, and a confidential interview indicated that staff will only discuss information relating to clients in the facility in a private setting. Based on interviews and records review, the allegations that staff engaged in a physical altercation with a minor and staff disclosed personal information about a minor while in care are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Shonda Simmons, Facility Manager. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Shonda Simmons, Facility Manager, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

narrative: On 11/12/21 at 11AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Maureen Lee and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARES inspection tool was used to complete the inspection. The facility is a regional center facility with developmentally disabled residents. The facility has been approved for licensure as an Adult Residential Facility (ARF) and will close the group home within the next two weeks. The facility was observed to be clean and in good repair. Beds have clean linens and mattress pads. There are no hazards on site. Room temperature measured within permitted range at 74 F. At 11:15AM, the hot water measured 124.7 F. Licensee turned down the water heater, and hot water measured 111.2 F at 12:14PM, within permitted range. At 11:15AM, some dead ants were observed on the kitchen pantry shelf, but there was no evidence of active infestation or live insects, and all food stored were cans which were sealed and safe from contamination. Licensee immediately cleared out and wiped down the pantry and ensured all foods were uncontaminated. Staff are cleared and associated to the facility. There are no issues that require follow-up. No deficiencies are being cited. LPA advises that the facility post the emergency disaster plan, per California Code of Regulations, Section 80023. Licensee will need to update the plan for the transition to ARF, but LPA advises that a version of this form be visibly posted at all times. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Maureen Lee, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall arrived at the facility unannounced for a Post-Licensing visit and to review recent incident reports sent to the department. Far Northern Regional Center worker (FNRC) Kathy Bogue was also present at the facility. When LPA arrived, four house staff were present for 2 clients, and two more staff and one more client arrived within minutes. LPA met with House Staff "Vic" for a few minutes before the Administrators named above arrived promptly. LPA received a tour of the home. Facility was clean, and the office with records and medications was locked and organized. Each client had a separate bedroom, with appropriate dresser and closet space, and bed linens. A daily schedule of activities was reviewed, and client charts were available for reference. Kitchen was clean. Backyard was nicely landscaped with chairs, a swing, and a garden area for clients. No deficiencies noted in the physical plant or file review. LPA reviewed recent General Event Reports (GER's) with administrators (AD). FNRC provided LPA with Individualized Program Plan (IPP) for each of the youth in the home. FNRC indicated her youth has excelled in the home, and his behaviors have diminished. He seems happy. AD described the activities available to the youth, and the alternative interventions implemented before utilizing restraints. Staff indicated they are learning to recognize client triggers to diffuse difficult behaviors before they become aggressive. LPA asked what would happen if restraints were not used. Staff and FNRC indicated one client has a history of severe self-injury and gave himself a concussion in the past. Another client is known to attack staff. The facility has lost staff who quit, following being attacked by a client. One female staff at the facility indicated she obtained a bad black eye from client who punched her. LPA asked if clients were able to understand the concept of time. (It was referenced in the GER that clients needed to be safe for 20-30 minutes before earning back privileges.) Staff said the client may not comprehend time. It was suggested a timer with a visual cue be obtained, and FNRC said she would acquire one for the facility to use. The facility uses a Token Economy System for each youth, designed alongside Advanced Crisis Services (ACS). LPA reviewed the role of licensing and exchanged contact information, concluding the interview and tour. A copy of this report was provided to the administrators.

Continued from 9099 Out of 10 staff files reviewed, 3 did not have current CPR and First Aid. LPA observed the client's psychotropic medication logs were not written on separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Records. LPA observed staff initial training was not present in their files. Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5, Article 06, Section 84065: Personnel Requirements (h) The licensee shall develop, maintain, and implement a written plan for the supervision, evaluation, and training of all child care staff. Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 06, Section 84065(j)(7) Annual training is in addition to first aid and CPR training, and other training. Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5 Article 06. Continuing Requirements 84070 Children's Records (13) A separate log for each psychotropic medication prescribed to the child. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this LIC-9099 report, the LIC-9099C, and LIC-9099D was provided to the administrator. Appeal Rights were provided.

On April 16, 2021, due to COVID-19, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hillary Hall, conducted an announced pre-licensing tele-inspection via Microsoft Teams for the above facility. LPA met with the facility Administrator, Jeff Curtis and Jamie Murray for the tele-inspection. Jeff gave the LPA a tour of the facility via Microsoft Teams. The facility home is located in a residential area of Redding, CA. The home is not yet furnished, but Jeff reported the furnishings have been purchased, and they are awaiting vendorization from the Regional Center. LPA viewed every room. The house appears clean, organized, and with additional safety precautions in mind for the intended population. The facility has posted Client Personal Rights and the Complaint brochure. The facility has phone service. There is a storage room that holds cabinets that will store client files. The facility has working bathrooms. There is a full kitchen with working appliances. There are no knives being stored in the kitchen at this time. There is a first aid kit located in the kitchen area as well. The facility has working fire extinguishers smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detector. Emergency Disaster Plans and Evacuation Map are posted. No deficiencies were noted during the pre-licensing inspection. LPA recommends licensure approval, and a provisional license will be issued so the facility can begin operation, pending approval of their Program Statement. A post-licensing inspection will be completed within 90-days of this date to determine permanent licensure. A copy of this report been sent to the facility.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of a Case Management Inspection regarding a record review. LPA met with Cory Ranberg, Administrator. During a record review, prior to the Annual Required Inspection on 5/01/24, LPA Kellie McKinley found no Serious Incident Reports (SIRs) had been received from the facility in recent months. LPA McKinley discussed with Cory Ranberg, Administrator that the Department has not received SIRs from the facility from July 2023 to May 2024. According to the Administrator, staff have been submitting SIRs to the Regional Center, but they did not know SIRs had to be submitted to the Department. LPA McKinley informed the Administrator that the facility must submit all SIRs to the Department timely. LPA McKinley provided the email for where reports need to be sent. The Administrator agreed and stated that reports would be sent going forward. On 5/28/24, LPA Vue received an email from the Administrator which included 13 SIRs. Administrator indicated he had updated management of the proper procedures for reporting to the Department. The facility is being issued a citation for violating Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1 Section 80061(b): Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1)… a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency’s next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2)… shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. A signed copy of this LIC 809 report and LIC 809D were provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurrence…of any of the events specified in (1)… a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency’s next working day during its normal business hours. ....  (2)…within seven days following the occurrence of such event.….. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on records review, the facility did not submit SIR’s as required from July 2023-May 2024, which poses a potential risk to the health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: New hires, hired staff and managers will be train on regulations of reporting and requirements. Facility will provide proof of training of topic, signature and date. The facility will add a line to their SIR that specifies the date the SIR was sent to the Department and via email proof.

It is alleged that a staff member inappropriately spoke to a client in care. Interviews provided consistent information that a staff did speak to a client inappropriately while attempting to get the client to use the restroom before bed. The facility submitted an SIR describing the interaction with the client and staff member. The staff in question admitted they may have made a mistake with the client. Based on LPA’s observations, interviews which were conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be Substantiated. On June 2, 2022, at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a pre-licensing inspection. LGTC - Willow Glen has submitted an application for a Group Home license, for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12-17. This inspection was conducted with Eugene Tilman and Azhar Sultanova and included observation of the following: The facility is a one story home. The home includes three client bedrooms; one bedroom is single occupancy room; one large bedroom will have a capacity of three (applicant will request a waiver; one ADA compliant bathroom and one and a half additional client bathrooms; kitchen and living room; a therapy office; a private space to meet with clients; a staff office. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked in the closet; locked and centrally stored medication room/cabinet observed; observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; food storage space observed; emergency foods observed; nonperishable foods observed; perishable foods will be bought as soon as licensed and have a placement; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; all smoke detectors were tested by a fire inspector and appear to be in proper working order; carbon monoxide detector observed; fire extinguishers are properly charged; appropriate forms are posted in view of facility clients; and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility or on premises. All staff and client files are electronic and available to Community Care Licensing (CCL). LGTC - Willow Glen's Plan of Operation and Program Statement review will be completed by 6/3/22. LPA Pavia will notify applicant of licensure status, at that time.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA’s) Shikya Belfield and Lisa Schlembach conducted an unannounced inspection on 11/4/2022 at 10:30 am and met with Azhar Sultanova , who assisted with the inspection. The facility is licensed for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12 -17. There is currently one client residing in the facility. During this inspection, the entire facility was toured. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions. There is adequate indoor activity space and materials. Chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet. Locked cabinet where centrally stored medications are kept was observed. During a review of the medication log, LPA Belfield observed that the facility does not have a centrally stored medication destruction form in the medication binder however the client file has the necessary information required to describe the storage, dosage, discontinuance etc. of the prescribed medication. Adequate storage space observed. Individual beds are in good repair, clean mattresses and pillows observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. Adequate food storage space observed. Supply of two days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods observed upon inspection. Weekly menu is posted in the kitchen. Licensee shared an electronic copy of the activity schedule for clients. Facility has a dietary technician that buys and prepare all meals, and provide it to the facility. Fire extinguishers was observed as well as the facility license, client rights, and emergency disaster plan, that were posted.

LPA Belfield reviewed one client file C1 (See LIC 811 dated 11/4/22) which was current and complete. Licensee Azhar will provide LPA with copies of staff files by then end of business today 11/4/2022. Due to technical issues with LPA's computer a review of the facility roster was not able to be obtained however, LPA will review this and go over any necessary information needed with Licensee. The department received a denial letter for S1 ( see LIC 811 dated 11/4/2022) and this was discussed with the Licensee and this individual does not work in or at the facility, but was the previous listed Licensee. This facility uses an electronic system for maintaining all files and records for staff and clients. narrative:
On July 11, 2023, at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection. LPA met with Taylor Stead, VP of Operations for San Diego, Caitlyn Bottom, Group Home Administrator, Jacob Kagel, Program Manager/Facility Manager and Alyssa Retuya Compliance Coordinator. The facility is four bedrooms, three and half bathroom’s single-family home, with attached garage. The applicant is applying for a group home with the capacity of six ambulatory clients' ages 12-17 years old. LPA inspected the interior and exterior of the facility. Living room, dining room, kitchen area, laundry room, staff offices, group therapy rooms, and art therapy classroom. Staff offices are located throughout the facility. Medications and first aid kit with first aid manual will be locked in the medication room in locked cabinets in the nursing office. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be locked in hall closet in the laundry room. Sharp knives will be locked in the hall closet in living room hallway. Hot water temperature was reading in the bathroom sink 115 degrees F. Bedroom set up upstairs as follows: Bedroom 1: designated for two clients, two full beds, two night stands, closet space and two dress drawer for each client, with shared bathroom inside bedroom #1. Bedroom 2: designated for two clients, two full beds, two night stands, closet space and two dress drawers for each client, with shared bathroom inside bedroom #2. Bedroom 3: designated for one client, one full bed, two night stand, closet space and one eight cubic feet dress drawers, with bathroom inside bedroom #3. Bedroom 4: designated for one client, one full bed, two night stand, closet space and one eight cubic feet dress drawer, with bathroom inside bedroom #4. Staff office is located upstairs.

Fire clearance was approved. Smoke detectors are operating and fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. Clients will be allowed to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The staff and client files will be electronically stored on computer database and will be accessible for Community Care Licensing (CCL) to review at any time. Personal Rights, Emergency Disaster Plan and Facility Sketch. Per Taylor Stead, VP of Operations for San Diego, there are no weapons in the facility. Also, per Taylor Stead cameras will be installed at another date and time. The Backyard is set up as follows: Facility has a pool covered with Katchakid Pool Safety Net; there is no fence surrounding the pool. LPA will verify if a fence needs to surround the pool area. The backyard is fully fenced. Also, patio furniture. Large grassy area. The applicant has been informed that the address to this facility is available to the public. All Incident Reports (IRs) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the applicant on this date. Upon managers final review, the license will be provided. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report was discussed left with Taylor Stead, VP of Operations for San Diego

Regarding the allegation that staff did not adequately supervise minor(s) resulting in minor inappropriately touching other minor(s) while in care, confidential interviews revealed that C1 and C2 were challenging C3 in a playful game. Confidential interviews revealed C3 physically picked up C1 without C1’s consent and C1 was touched inappropriately. However, conflicting confidential interviews revealed that C1 and C2 made up the story that C3 touched C1 and C2 inappropriately. Regarding the allegation that staff did not report incidents regarding minor in care, as necessary, confidential interviews revealed that staff wrote up incidents involving C1 and reported the incidents to C1’s authorized representative. However, conflicting confidential interviews revealed that C1’s authorized representative did not receive reports of incidents that occurred while C1 was placed at the facility. Regarding the allegation that staff did not adequately supervise minor in care resulting in minor watching inappropriate content while in care, confidential interviews revealed that C1 turned to television channel that had vulgar language and explicit images. However, confidential interviews revealed that staff immediately turned the television to a channel that was suitable for general viewing with appropriate content. Regarding the allegation that staff did not adequately supervise minor in care resulting in minor communicating with unauthorized adult(s) while in care, confidential interviews revealed that C1 contacted their biological mother although C1 is forbidding was forbidden to have any contact with biological mother. However, confidential interviews revealed that staff was not provided an unapproved or approved contact telephone list for C1, so staff was not aware that C1 was not allowed to contact their biological mother.

Based on interviews and documentation reviewed, the allegations that staff did not adequately supervise C1 and C2 resulting in C1 and C2 being inappropriately touched by C3 while in care, staff did not report incidents regarding C1 in care, as necessary; staff did not adequately supervise C1 in care resulting in C1 watching inappropriate television shows, and staff did not adequately supervise C1 in care resulting in C1 communicating with biological mother despite there being a no contact order in place forbidding C1 communicating with biological mother, may have occurred, however, the allegations are not supported or proven by the evidence gathered; therefore, the allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Caitlyn Sarwan, Clinical Director.
investigation_findings: 13On November 1, 2024, at 12:00PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson arrived at Lightfully Firefly at 1280 Santa Fe Drive, Encinitas, California,92024, to deliver the findings of the above allegations. Lightfully- Firefly #374690057 located at 2460 Vista Lago Terrace, Escondido, CA 92029, the facility closed on 6/13/24 due to change relocation. LPA met with Caitlyn Sarwan, Clinical Director. LPA initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 1/09/2024 at 12:00PM, and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, interviews were completed with witnesses and staff. LPA attempted to interview Client 1 (C1), Client 2 (C2), Client 3 (C3). LPA was unsuccessful at attempts to interview clients. In addition, LPA reviewed C1 and C2’s files and other pertinent documents. LPA reviewed law enforcement police report as well as incident report. On January 8, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging staff did not adequately supervise minor(s) resulting in minor inappropriately touching other minor(s) while in care, staff did not report incidents regarding minor in care as necessary, staff did not adequately supervise minor in care resulting in minor watching inappropriate content while in care, staff did not adequately supervise minor in care resulting in minor communicating with unauthorized adult(s) while in cares revealed that C1 and C2 made up the story that C3 touched C1 and C2 inappropriately.

narrative: behaviors; it was reported that while C1 was in care at the facility, C1 was sexually assaulted (no details provided) by C2 on more than one occasion. It was further reported that these incidents would never have occurred if C1 and C2 had been properly supervised. Confidential interviews reported that on one occasion, C2 “digitally penetrated” C1, but that C2 stopped when C1 asked C2 to stop. Confidential interviews reported that on another occasion, C2 snuck into C1’s room and engaged in kissing and touching behaviors with C1. Confidential interviews reported that S1 was in charge of supervising C1 and C2 on at least one of these occasions. Reviews of pertinent documents revealed that S1 admitted to being deficient in terms of properly supervising C1 and C2 on one of these occasions which directly resulted in one or more of these incidents occurring. An additional document review revealed that the facility terminated S1’s employment after S1’s admitted to the incident. Based on confidential interviews and a review of pertinent documentation, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the allegation that staff did not prevent C1 and C2 from engaging in inappropriate behaviors is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. 80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs (see LIC 9099D) An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report (LIC 9099), deficiencies page (LIC 9099D) and appeal rights were explained and given to Director Caitlyn Sarwan.

The facility listed on the LIC 802 complaint has been closed since 06/13/2024. During the investigation, LPA Anderson obtained documents pertinent to the investigation. In addition, LPA Choi reviewed those pertinent documents and interviewed Client 1 (C1). deficiencies.description:
Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06,
80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and reviews of documents, the facility's staff did not provide adequate supervision leading to a sexual interaction between C1 and C2; which poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility had already terminated S1’s employment, prior to this complaint investigation being generated. The facility also stated that all direct care staff were provided with follow-up training regarding appropriate supervision of clients. LPA has already obtained S1's termination of employment document. The facility has agreed to provide LPA with the follow-up training regarding supervision, that was mentioned in the Special Incident Report associated to this complaint, and submit it no later than the close of business day 7/30/2025.

narrative:
On August 12,2022 at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson conducted a pre-licensing visit. This applicant is applying for a group home with the capacity of 6 ambulatory clients for adolescent children ages 12-17 years old. The applicant will be receiving private pay clients only. LPA met with Taylor Stead, Vice President of Operations, San Diego, Stephanie Thompson, Facility Administrator/Director of Clinical Operations The facility is a two story house with seven bedrooms, six bathrooms, and two car garage. The facility is set up as follows: First Floor: Front door entry, living room, dining room, kitchen area, pantry, one bathroom, therapy room, staff’s office. Second Floor: The bedrooms are set up as follows: Bedroom 1: designated for one client, one full bed, one dresser drawer, night stand, closet space, night lamp and bathroom. Bedroom 2: designated for two clients, two full beds, two dresser drawers, two night stands, closet space, two night lamps. Bedroom 3: designated for one client, one full bed, one dresser drawer, one night stand, closet space, one night lamp. Bedroom 4: designated for two clients, two full beds, two dresser drawers, two night stands, closet space, two night lamps and bathroom.

Laundry room area is located upstairs, one bathroom located in the hallway, staff’s workstation is located in the hallway and nursing station. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. The hot water in was measured to be 111 degrees Fahrenheit. Balcony area: There will be a home school on site, Arts and Crafts room with bathroom. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and were observed to be in working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The facility does not have cameras. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the home. Cleansers/chemicals will be stored locked in staff’s office. Sharp knives will be inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen cabinet. The following required forms were posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, and California “See Something Say Something Poster”. Clients and staff files will be stored in the electronic database will always be available to Community Care Licensing as requested. Backyard: Group room, fire pit and adequate patio furnishing. The fire clearance has been approved. The applicant has been informed that the address to this facility is available to the public. All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the applicant on this date. The applicant was provided with an updated Facility Personnel Report Summary at the time of this visit and understands that once the license is approved, all employees and volunteers shall have an approved criminal record clearance for Community Care Licensing and be associated to this facility. All documents have been received according to Title 22 regulations. Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility is ready for license. Exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was given to Taylor Stead, Vice President of Operations

On July 24, 2023, at 8:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia conducted a pre-licensing inspection. Lightfully - Shimmer has submitted an application for a Group Home license, for a capacity of 6 ambulatory children, ages 12-17. This inspection was conducted with Clodagh Rafferty and included observation of the following: The main living facility is a two story home. The first floor includes one (1) restroom, nurse's office, group therapy room, living room, dining room, storage closet and kitchen. The second floor includes four (4) client bedrooms, three (3) restrooms, staff office and storage closets. The backyard includes three (3) detached garages being utilized for staff office with kitchen, therapy room and art/school room. There is a 500 gallon well in the backyard that provides drinking water for the facility. The facility and grounds are in good repair, and free of obstructions; chemicals are stored and locked in the closet; locked and centrally stored medication room/cabinets observed; observed medication logs and discussed procedures for psychotropic medications; first aid kit complete; individual beds are in good repair; food storage space observed; emergency foods observed; perishable foods and nonperishable foods will be bought as soon as licensed and clients are placed; private chef to start and post menu once facility receives clients; sharps will be locked in kitchen cabinet; dining room equipped with tables and chairs accommodating all clients; all smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were tested and appear to be in proper working order; fire extinguishers are throughout the house and are properly charged; there is no pool on the premises; and, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility or on premises.

All client and staff files are electronic and available to Community Care Licensing (CCL). The following items will be addressed and pictures emailed to LPA Pavia: - front water fountain (no water) will be filled or covered - Personal Rights (direct verbiage) will be posted in common area - complaint procedures will be posted in common area - emergency exit sign for 2nd floor double doors leading to balcony - lattice or other covering will be placed around 500 gallon well - request waiver for slatted bed bases (no box spring needed) - 84088(c)(1) All staff will be fingerprint cleared prior to working at this facility location. This facility is ready for licensure once the above has been addressed.

narrative:
On Wednesday October 20, 2021 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced inspection to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Administrator Alona Quintos, and Assistant Administrator Julienne Baris. The facility has a census of four clients. One client was present during LPA Mendoza inspection, and during inspection another two arrived. LPA was unable to interview clients due to all three clients being non-verbal. However, LPA observed clients to be in good spirit. LPA interviewed both staff members during todays inspection. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no pools or bodies of water. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked in the garage. Per Administrator there are no firearms in the facility. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. At 1:33 PM the water temperature measured 97 degrees, the administrator adjusted the heater, and at 3 PM the water measured 114 degrees . The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. Medications are locked and were all inspected. All medication binders were complete. The facility has Personal Rights and Emergency Disaster Plans are posted and in clear view. At 1:40 PM, LPA Mendoza reviewed all 4 client files, and all files were complete. LPA advised the facility for the clients that are unable to sign any LIC forms because of their developmental disability to include a note in the signature line. [PLEASE CONT. TO LIC 809-C...]

At 2:12 PM LPA Mendoza reviewed six staff files and all files were complete. Staff training hours meet the minimum requirements. A review of Guardian Background Check System printed on October 19, 2021 indicate that all facility staff have clearances. LPA obtained a copy of LIC 500, LIC 610, and copy of the Administrators certificate. No deficiencies were observed today. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

On Thursday March 24, 2022 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced inspection to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Administrator Alona Quintos. Later in the inspection, Assistant Administrator, Julienne Baris arrived. The facility has a census of four clients, and all clients were at school. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There are no pools or bodies of water. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked in the garage. Per Administrator there are no firearms in the facility. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. The water temperature measured 114 degrees. The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. Medications are locked and were all inspected. All medication binders were complete. The facility has their license posted in a prominent area, Personal Rights and Emergency Disaster Plans are also posted and in clear view. At 9:30 AM, LPA Mendoza reviewed all 4 client files, and all files were complete. However, three clients are currently over the age of 18. (C1) (please refer to LIC 811, for confidential names, dated 03/24/22. ) will be turning 21 years old this year, and (C2) will be 23 on 3/28/22. LPA reminded the facility per Welfare and Institution Code 11710 (a) "Child with special health care needs" means a child, or a person who is 22 years of age or younger who is completing a publicly funded education program..." The Administrator informed LPA Mendoza that there Assistant Administrator will be opening an adult facility and is currently is the process. [Please refer to LIC 809-C for continuation page..

LPA Mendoza is requesting the facility to submit an age exception to CCL for (C1) and (C2) no later than Friday 4/1/22. Also, reminded the facility that they shall develop a plan on having all clients out of the facility before there 22nd birthday, and if not the facility must submit an age exception before the clients 22nd birthday. LPA Mendoza reviewed all six staff files and all files were complete. All staff meet the required training requirements. An exit interview was conducted and the facility was issued one technical violation. A copy of the report will be emailed to the Administrator.

On 3/16/23 at 1PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Alona Quintos and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct this inspection. At arrival, all residents were at school. Administrator indicated that all three residents are nonverbal. One resident returned before end of visit, and LPA observed resident to be dressed in clean, well-fitting clothes, to be provided a snack, and to be closely supervised by present staff. LPA interviewed two staff. LPA also reviewed 5 staff files, all 3 resident files, and inspected the facility site and grounds. LPA observed the facility to be clean and organized, no safety hazards, chemicals locked and inaccessible, bedrooms clean, beds with mattress protectors and mattress pads, organized storage for residents, kitchen clean and food in good quantity and quality and properly stored. All files reviewed were complete. Medications are stored and logged correctly. Resident money is recorded and maintained appropriately. Staff were knowledgeable of facility policies and reporting requirements. The CARE Inspection Tool and LPA did not find any deficiencies at this visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

LPAs met with Administrator Alona Quintos who helped facilitate the inspection. At arrival, all residents were at school. Administrator indicated that the two residents are nonverbal. One resident returned before end of visit, and LPA observed resident to be dressed in clean, well-fitting clothes, and to be closely supervised by present staff. At the start of the inspection LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility, inside and out. LPAs observed centrally stored medications maintained in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 70 degrees. Hot water temperature measures at 106 degrees. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan and has conducted a biannual review of the Emergency Intervention Plan. Five records of personnel/ staff members were reviewed to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. All personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. On March 21, 2025 at 10:25AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Will Ea and Mariah Hawkins conducted an unannounced required annual inspection of the facility. LPAs met with Administrator Alona Quintos and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPAs inspected 5 staff files and observed all to be complete. LPAs observed both clients in care upon their return from school. Both clients were dressed in clean, well-fitting clothing and appeared comfortable around staff. LPAs observed staff to be attentive to clients. LPAs toured the facility site and observed no hazards. The facility is maintained in safe and sanitary condition. On Thursday October 28, 2021 Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Isabel Mendoza made an unannounced annual required inspection to this facility. LPA met with Administrator (Maria Baris), Assistant Administrator (Elizabeth Franco), and House Manager (Melissa Ferreras). The facility consists of six bedrooms (four single rooms for clients, one staff bedroom and one staff office), and three bathrooms. The facility is licensed for a capacity of 4, and currently three clients are in care. No clients were in care during today's inspection. At 9:21 AM LPA did a walk thru the facility is clean, safe and sanitary and in good repair. All passageways are unobstructed. There is an outdoor space for the clients, and no hazards or broken items. There are no pools or bodies of water. All disinfectants, cleaning solutions and poisons are locked in cabinet in the garage. Per Administrator Maria there are no firearms in the facility. The inspected bedrooms were furnished accordingly. The kitchen is clean and sanitary. Sharp objects are locked away. Water temperature measured 105 degrees. The facility has sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply. Personal Rights and Emergency Disaster Plans are posted and in clear view in the dining room. Medications are located in a locked cabinet in the staff office. LPA inspected all medications and found no issues. LPA inspected MAR binder and advised the facility to use LIC 622 B to ensure that the psychotropic MAR has all required items on each MAR. Currently, the MAR is missing quantity prescribed, and number of refills. However, all this information is listed on the facilities Centrally Stored Medication Log. The Administrator and House Manager confirmed that the facility will start using CCL's Psychotropic (MAR) effective 11/1/21. [PLEASE CONT. TO LIC 809-C...]

At 9:50 AM LPA Mendoza reviewed all 3 client files and during file review LPA was unable to locate a written authorization of the child's parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication. The facility confirmed that they do not have this on file and will contact all authorized representatives. At 10:41 AM LPA Mendoza reviewed (10) staff files and all files were complete. All staff training hours meet the minimum requirements. All staff are showing association to the facility. During inspection, LPA interviewed all three staff members. LPA obtained copies of the following documents: LIC 610 Emergency Disaster Plan, LIC 500, LIC 308, LIC 309, and Maria's Group Home Administrator Certificate. No deficiencies were cited during todays inspection, but (2) Technical Violations 84070(b)(12) Children Record's, and 84070(b)(13)( C) Children Record's were issued. A copy of the report was left with the Administrator.

met_with: Licensee Maria Barris, Administrator Melissa Ferreras, and Lead Staff Maricris Valenzuela
narrative: On 10/28/22 at 11:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Maria Barris, Administrator Melissa Ferreras, and Lead Staff Maricris Valenzuela and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool to conduct this inspection. LPA conducted a tour, interviews of staff, an observation of present resident, and a review of facility, personnel, and resident records. Three of the four residents were still at school at the end of the visit. The facility is clean and kitchen and bathrooms are organized and sanitary. Food is of good quality, within date, and in a quantity to meet the needs of residents in care. Residents medications and prescribed supplements are stored in a central location where inaccessible to residents. Medication records reflect accurate administration and storage. Sharp and/or dangerous items and chemicals are kept locked and inaccessible to residents. The facility has the license, emergency plan, personal rights, food menu, and activity schedule posted. Bedrooms are clean, and each resident has their own room with their own bed, each with clean linens and mattress pad, and ample personal storage. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are functioning. All staff have clearances associated to the facility and have valid first aid and emergency intervention certificates as well as have received required hours of annual training. The tool found no deficiencies. No citations were issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee Maria Barris, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On the above date, an unannounced annual inspection was conducted by LPA (Licensing Program Analyst) Celeste Aparicio and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lidia Tinoco at Liza's Home And met with Administrator Melissa Ferreras. LPA inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications are maintained in a locked cabinet. Sharps and Toxic chemicals are kept locked. The facility has a written emergency disaster plan. All facility smoke detectors were tested and appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. There is at least one-week supply of nonperishable and a two-day supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 76 degrees. Facility has cameras in common areas of the facility. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Administrator is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 12 direct care staff. 4 records of personnel/ staff members were reviewed to ensure staff meet regulatory requirements. All personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances or exemptions. Personnel Files are maintained on-site. 4 records of clients were reviewed. Interviews with clients were not conducted as they are non-verbal. Inspection included an overview of required Core Services and Supports and based upon inspection of facility records and interviews of staff, Licensee appears to be meeting requirements. There were no deficiencies to be cited on this date.

On 10/15/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection. LPA met with Administrator Melissa Ferreras and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool and conducted a tour of the facility site, review of 5 personnel records and 4 resident records, and confidential interviews with 2 staff members. All 4 residents in care are nonverbal. LPA observed the residents' condition and interactions with staff. LPA observed the facility to be clean and well organized. Kitchen and bathrooms are sanitary. The facility is currently at the licensed capacity of 4 residents, and each resident has their own bedroom with individual beds and plenty of storage for personal items. The rooms and common spaces are nicely decorated and furnished with activity sets and toys appropriate for the served population. Medications, sharps, and chemicals are stored where inaccessible to the residents. Cameras are posted in public spaces, and the licensee recently submitted program statement revisions with surveillance camera procedures, as requested. LPA observed personnel and resident records to be complete. Staff have full background clearances, valid intervention and first aid training certifications, and have completed their annual training hours. Residents' records contain current emergency contact information, complete care plans, and accurate medication and cash records. LPA observed interviewed staff to be knoweldgeable of facility policies, mandated reporting, and intervention procedures. LPA observed residents to each be provided 1:1 supervision, to be dressed in well-fitting, appropriate, and clean clothes, and to appear comfortable in care, showing no hesitation around staff or in responding to staff guidance. No deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA’s observations and interviews, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to Administrator Melissa Ferreras.

On 8/28/23 at 10:00 AM, CCL met with listed facility to discuss facility types. The following were in attendance: Carolyn Flynn- Licensing Program Manager Alyssa Ng - Licensing Program Analyst Anne Marie Randolph- Administrator Tiffany Tran - Facility Manager Carolynn Gray- Co-Founder The purpose of the meeting is to discuss the current facility type and how it applies to their current program. Anne who is the Administrator described the facility as a safe and no cost respite to youth in crisis. Youth are eligible if they are a Alameda County resident, 8-17 years old, not in foster care, and or probation. Youth can stay up to 48 judicial hours. CCL went through the different facility types and found that most of the facilities do not fall under what Malabar wants. CCL stated that they will discuss this further and get back to the facility when they have an answer/response. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Anne Randolph with read receipt. Administrator Anne Randolph will sign and return to LPA Ng over email.

On 10/22/24 at 11:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Shikya Belfield made an unannounced annual/required inspection to above listed facility and met with Administrator Anne Randolph. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 0 clients. During this inspection, 0 clients and one staff were present in the home. LPA Belfield toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied and has three double occupancy bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom were clean and furnished with hygiene supplies. The thermostat measured 71 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in the staff office. Extra linens are located in a cabinet in the hallway. The weekly menu was posted in the kitchen. LPA observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors and fire extinguisher are in working order and were up to date in being serviced. There are no bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA Belfield interviewed one staff and 0 clients. Clients in care are not placed for more than 48 judicial hours so therefore no client interviews or file reviews were done. During a review of the facility files the board meeting minutes were not present. Administrator to submit copies of the most two recent board meeting minutes to LPA Belfield by end of business 10/24/24. At that time the inspection will be concluded. There were no violations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six cited during this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Anne Randolph.

LPA obtained statements from five (5) clients, (1 of the five being the alleged victim) and Five (5) staff. LPA obtained written letters from a client indicating her support from S1 and how well she is benefiting from the program; a thread of emails from S1 and the RP communication issues and concerns regarding C5’s treatment plan and clinical diagnosis, informed RP of evidence of S1 communicating with her via email. The interviewed client’s statements were congruent to S1’s Multi-Family Group Therapy sessions were intense and that S1 tone of voice was loud, firm and confronting, but was not directed toward C5 or any other client; neither was it deemed to be intimidating manner that trigger an uncomfortable environment for clients to obtain proper treatment. LPA confirmed that the clients did not have an issue with S1 being “Loud” and identified her tone as form of caring gesture. LPA observed the clients at the facility appeared to comfortable in placement. LPA obtain numerous emails of from RP communicating with S1 regarding C5’s treatment. RP did not identify any other client other than C5 that reportedly had issues and concerns about the treatment of other clients. However C5 denied that the allegations occurred and did not have any issues or concerns to report other than she was pleased with placement and did not have an issue with S1’s tone of voice and stated that S1 "Cares Loud". LPA obtained several emails of communication with RP and various documents: C5 Progress in treatment, Discharge/Transfer Summary and a Hillcrest Adolescent Treatment Center Family Agreement: Digitally Signature/s, timestamp in agreement by: Dated 05/01/2021; C5’s Clinical Treatment Plan that included clinical diagnosis (Dated 05/11-and 05/19/2021; Progress Notes; and emails communication between S1 and RP. C5 was discharged prior to expectation to successful in achieve all treatment goals. LPA assessed that Marks House Clinical Treatment Team, Administration and Management Team assess all client needs and provide services to ensure that clients have the necessary tools and interventions in place to treat specific diagnosis. Although the allegations may have happened are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has determined that the allegations Personal Rights are unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and the finding can be changed. Per California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 5 (GROUP HOMES), There are no deficiencies noted or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
