narrative:
On 09/21/2021 9:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced to MARKS HOUSE for the purpose to conduct the Annual/Required licensing Inspection. LPA met with the Program Administrator, who granted access into the home, and who provided a tour of the entire physical plant inside and out. The facility is licensed to care for up to six (6) Male and Female children, ages 12-17 years, Ambulatory only. The facility acquired The National Accreditation through Commission on Accreditation of Rehabilitation Facilities (CARF) valid through 11/30/2022. The is a swimming pool (8 feet pool) that meets regulations. Staff confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. Group Home Overview: This is a (2) two-story Group Home facility. There is three (3) car garage that has been converted in a game room and supply room with eleven (11) tall cabinets and eight (8) drawers for over stock toiletries, arts and craft. It has an extra freezer and a refrigerator, Ping-Pong table and an Air hockey table. There are total of four (4) operable fire places throughout the facility. All are were observed to be secure screens, glass doors and a gas key locked device. The Location of the fire places are in the “Oval office”, main living room, entertainment and the master bedroom and a outside fire pit. Bedroom/ Bathrooms: All Located on the 2nd Floor of the facility. There is a total of four (4) bedrooms, (2 single, and 2 double occupancy bedrooms); equipped with Queen size beds in each room. LPA observed that each bedroom has its own, bathroom. Bedroom #4: The “Vegas Room” identified as the Master Bedroom is currently unoccupied. It is to be utilized in the event of an emergency and or crisis (i.e Quarantine room and or a separation room). The bedroom is equipped with a one (1) Queen sized bed, comfortable mattress, clean lines, a blanket, and pillows. It is equipped with 2 walk-in closets a storage closet, and a large vanity mirror. There is adequate lighting, ample drawer and closet space, the windows are slide locked with vertical shades; observed to be in good condition.

This bedroom is equipped with its own a full-size walk-in bathroom, which has 2 entry doors; 1 door has access to a sink, toilet, and shower, and the 2nd door has access to a bathtub a toilet, a Bidet, jacuzzi tube and a double shower. The shower has 2 doors, that joins both sides of the master bathroom. LPA observed the balcony a double glass door with access to a balcony. The door is not used for an exit and always remains locked. The Director will ensure to inform LPA when this room is being utilized an (SIR) Special Incident Report will be documented and submitted. Bedroom # 3 –Currently occupied by one (1) child. There is one (1) Queen size beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows. There is one (1) walk in closets. There is adequate lighting and the windows are slide locked with vertical shades observed to be in good condition. There is ample drawer and closet space. This bedroom is equipped with its own a full-size walk-in bathroom with a sink, toilet, and shower and tub. Bedroom # 2 –Currently occupied by one (1) child. There are (2) Queen size beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows. There is one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows are slide locked with vertical shades observed to be in good condition. There is ample drawer and closet space. This bedroom is equipped with its own a full-size walk-in bathroom with a sink, toilet, and shower, tube. Bedroom # 1 – Currently occupied by one (1) child. There are (2) Queen size beds, comfortable mattresses, linen, blankets and pillows. There is one (1) walk in closet. There is adequate lighting and the windows are slide locked with vertical shades observed to be in good condition. There is ample drawer and closet space. This bedroom is equipped with its own a full-size walk-in bathroom with a sink, toilet, and shower, tube. Group Home Overview continued: There is one main office, 1 therapy; a living room, dining room, kitchen, breakfast area, family room, laundry area, and a large backyard. LPA Gray observed 8 interior and 7 exterior cameras on the premises. LPA observed the camera monitor in a staff office on the lower level that monitors a view of the front door only. Facility has submitting camera waiver. There are 2 staircases that have access to the 2nd level of the home. There are no security bars on the windows. LPA observed carbon Monoxide alarms, located on each floor were observed and functional in the home. LPA observed five (5) fully charged fire extinguishers located throughout the facility. Water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Page 2 of 4

Upper Level: Two (2) closets were observed in the hallway; 1 closet was observed to be empty, and 1 closet was observed to be locked and observed ample stored hygiene supplies and feminine products. The Nurses Station was locked, located inside the Group Therapy Room. Group Therapy Room: equipped with adequate furniture in good repair. There is a walk-in closet designated as the Nursing station. LPA observed a large orange First Aid kit complete with scissors, tweezers, thermometer, gauzes, antiseptic and 1st Aid Manual. There is also a small refrigerator for storage of client medication that requires refrigeration. There is additional Group Therapy Room: used for yoga, meditation, breathing technique therapy. Individual & Family Therapy Room: located near the front entry staircase and is equipped with a desk, two (2) chairs and two (2) dressers. Lower Level: Located at the entrance there is a staff closet and a 1/2 bath: The closet is equipped with a fingerprint clock-in/out system for staff. Living Room: with securely covered fireplace with plenty of seating that has access to the backyard. Dining Room: equipped with a large table with twelve (12) chairs. There is a total of twelve (12) chairs in the main dining room; and the kitchen table has three (3) chair and two (2) high chairs. Kitchen: LPA observed the monthly/weekly menu posted on the wall. The kitchen. equipped with a refrigerator, 2 ovens, a five (5) functional gas burners, and an island that is not used for kitchen supplied other than knives and forks. The is plenty of cabinet space. The knives and sharp objects are stored in a locked drawer space within one of the lower kitchen cabinets. Chemicals and cleaning solutions are kept in locked cabinets located in the garage. A monthly/ weekly menu was observed and posted in the kitchen and food service adequate for breakfast, and snacks, lunch and dinner. Meals are prepared by a Private Chef. Breakfast area: is equipped with a table and six (6) chairs. LPA observed a control panel for the pool/spa, equipped with an intercom system that is non-functional. Family Room: equipped with a secure cover on the fireplace, and plenty of clean furniture in good repair. Grievance procedure, and Emergency Disaster Plan postings were observed to be posted here. Laundry area: equipped with a washer and dryer, and plenty of cabinet space where a fully charged fire extinguisher, and extra clean linens were observed. The laundry detergent is locked in a locked supply room and will distributed to the clients individually according to the load of their laundry. LPA observed a Laundry Chute that is used for towels and some bedding. Page 3 of 4

School: Equipped with a portable air-conditioning, fully charged fire extinguisher, smoke alarm, 7 tables, 10 chairs, a printer, and whiteboard. Licensee reported that each client shall have access to his/her own laptop during school hours. When laptops are not in use, laptops are stored in the nursing station. Exterior: The large outdoor activity space is free of obstructions. There are three (3) lounge large patio spaces; equipped with a ceiling fans cover outdoor furniture; The backyard is equipped with an outdoor gas fireplace that has a screen that covers the fireplace, which consists of fake logs; 3/4 bathroom attached to the home; a built-in BBQ island with a small refrigerator and sink; a tennis court with a basketball court with a mounted hoop. A large detached air-conditioned building used as a pool/therapy room equipped with 1 large couch, 1/2-bathroom, closet space, a small kitchen with a small refrigerator, dishwasher, and sink; a locked wine cellar that is used only for storage, POOL: Located in the backyard, there is a fenced and gated pool on the premises that meets regulations. There is a bridge with rope railings crosses that leads to the Waterfall/Koi Pond that has been inspected and with an approved net covering. Licensee will ensure that individual supervising children in the pool area is Water Safety trained. This facility has no alarms active to alert when doors or windows have been opened. Facility appears to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. All posting requirements and Emergency Plan were met. Children will be accorded personal rights. The facility current License, Mental Health Certification; Ombudsperson Grievances and Personal Rights; are posted on the wall. Children are not restricted to make phones calls based on the court and or authorized representative. There is a private room available for the clients to make phones calls and the Phone Call Log is kept in the clients file. LPA observed the child’s Needs and Services plans kept in the client’s chart; (filed electronic medical records). Some outside extracurricular activities and social events that take persons into public or crowded places have been restricted. Alternate activities have been implemented based the compliance of the client. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA will return to the facility at a later date to complete the inspection tool (i.e Staff Records review, Staff and client interviews and include information regarding the Emergency Preparedness.) LPA-Gray concluded the inspection and a copy of this report was left at the facility with the Program Administrator on 09/21/2021. Page 4 of 4

On 09/23/2021 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA') Rosslyn Gray, made an announced visit to MARKS HOUSE GROUP HOME. LPA conducted a Case Management-Annual Continuation Inspection. LPA met with the Program Director, identified as Staff #1(S1), who granted access to the facility and provided the requested information. LPA reviewed following during the inspection: Clients Records Review: S1 displayed clients files electronically stored in the facilities online Portal with Kipuworks.com LPA reviewed three (3) clients records currently in placement according to the observed Census. Staff Records Review: S1 displayed Ten (10) active employees files stored electronically in S-Drive. LPA viewed the details of the information in the Staff records provided by S1. LPA ensured to thoroughly review the records of active primary staff; Program Director/Administrator, Primary Therapist, Clinical Director, Office Manager, Licensed Vocational Nurse and Five (5) Program Assistants. LPA conducted a confidential interview with five (5) on duty staff and three (3) clients that currently in placement were present. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA concluded the Annual Inspection. An Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility with the Program Administrator.

Documents evidence and records obtained indicate a weekly schedule of therapeutic activities including records of signature participation. Records obtained indicate that the facility followed proper discharge protocol. Evidence obtained show that the authorized representative was provided with medical records including treatment plans and delivered upon request. Due to lack of evidence and conflicting statements obtained during the investigation, LPA determines that the allegation of Neglect and Lack of supervision and three (3) allegations of Personal Rights are Unsubstantiated at this time meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.
investigation_findings: 13On August 26, 2022, at 3:45 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to conclude the investigation and to deliver the findings. LPA conducted a Health and safety risk assessment upon arriving at the facility. During the investigation, LPA-Gray interviewed and accounted for all available relevant parties; and gathered pertinent information in reference to the allegations. The Licensee denied the allegations. Based on confidential interviews and review of documentary evidence there is no evidence or witnesses to support that the facility staff did not prevent minor from engaging in inappropriate behaviors, that the minor was not provided therapy in a timely manner, and that the staff did not follow proper discharge protocol and staff did not provide minors authorized representative with medical records. Documentary interviews were congruent that staff provided proper interventions, utilizing methods of crisis communication and therapy to redirect to prevent inappropriate behaviors such as self-harm.

deficiencies.description: Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event. Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required by the Department, including, but not limited to, those specified in this section.(D)Any injury to any client which requires medical treatment. This requirement is not met as evidence by: Staff did not report client’s self-injury behavior to licensing or notify minors authorized representative of injuries in a timely manner which poses a potential risk to the health and safety risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
A written plan of correction shall be submitted to LPA Gray no later than September 2, 2022. 
The POC should indicate in detail how staff will submit an Unusual Incident/Injury Reports timely.

On February 21, 2024, at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to Marks House for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Investigation. LPA met with Administrator/Christine Tonoli. A health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The department received an Incident Report dated October 17, 2023. The Incident Report disclosed that Child #1 (C1) was found face down in shower. Incident report further indicated that C1 missed two doses of medication due to prescription not being available. During the investigation process, LPA conducted interviews, requested copies of Medication Administration Records (MAR) for Child #1 (C1), Incident Report, Staff #1 (S1) disciplinary action document, and medication administration protocols. Based on the information obtained during this visit, additional investigation is needed. Appeal Rights were issued, and a copy of this report was left at the facility Based on the information obtained during this visit, additional investigation is needed. Appeal Rights were issued, and a copy of this report was left at the Facility Administrator/Christine Tonoli.

On March 1, 2024, at 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, Rosslyn Gray made an unannounced visit to Marks House for the purpose of concluding a Case Management Investigation. LPA met with Program Director Dominique Baker. A health and safety assessment were conducted prior to entering the facility. The department received an Incident Report dated October 17, 2023. The Incident Report disclosed that Child #1 (C1) was found face down in shower and C1 missed two doses of medication. During the investigation process, LPA conducted interviews, obtained copies of C1 Medication Administration Records (MAR) C1, Incident Reports, Staff 7 (S7) documented disciplinary action, previous and current medication administration protocols. Statements indicated that medication was on back-order at the local pharmacy. Documentary evidence indicated that C1 medication ran out on October 16, 2023. Statements and documented evidence indicated that S7 did not refill C1 medication. C1 missed two doses of medication. Medication refill was not until received October 17, 2023. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80078(a) Providing Care and Supervision. Medication was not refilled timely. C1 missed two doses of medication and experienced a medical emergency. A copy of this report and the Appeal Rights was provided to the Licensee. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Program Director Dominique Baker

deficiencies.description: Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Staff 7 did not complete C1 medication timely. C1 missed two doses of medication and experienced a medical emergency. This poses an immediate health and safety risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The POC has been discussed with the Facility Administrator and with the Program Director. The facility conducted an internal investigation, implemented disciplinary action against the staff S7 and since has been terminated. LPA obtained the current protocol for administration of medication that include ensuring medication remain in stock and refills are up to date. The Facility will submit a written plan of correction regarding policy and procedure to ensure all staff will provide proper care and supervision for all children and require all staff who administer medication receive refresher training that meet the needs of the children.

narrative: On September 05, 2024, at 10:30AM Rosslyn Gray, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management – Incident investigation. LPA met with Dominique Baker- Program Director and a health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The department received an Unusual Incident/Injury Report (LIC 624) dated August 20 2024. The Incident Report disclosed that Child 1 (C1) reported to Staff 1 (S1) that she stole the keys and took a mouthful of Benadryl. C1 was rushed to the Emergency room at Los Robles Regional Medical Center in Thousand Oaks. C1's vitals were reported fine and was given a bed in the Emergency Room and was put under an 8 hour observation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed Dominique Baker- Program Director requested Personnel Report, client roster, C1's Discharge Summary, Hospital Discharge report, and authorized representative contact information. Based on the information obtained during this visit, additional investigation is needed. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted with Dominique Baker- Program Director and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

On September 25, 2024, at 11:00 AM Rosslyn Gray, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management – Incident investigation. LPA met with Gina Mc Auley Executive Director and a health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The department received an Unusual Incident/Injury Report (LIC 624) dated August 20, 2024. The Incident Report disclosed that Child 1 (C1) reported to Staff 1 (S1) that she stole the keys and took a mouthful of Benadryl. C1 was rushed to the Emergency room at Los Robles Regional Medical Center in Thousand Oaks. C1's vitals were reported fine and was given a bed in the Emergency Room and was put under an 8-hour observation. During the investigation, LPA interviewed staff, obtained the Personnel Report, client roster, resignation letters, Psychiatric Discharge/Aftercare report, Program Assistant Job Summary, and the facilities Master Nursing Manual-Hillcrest . C1 disclosed to S1 that she stole the facility keys from facility computer bag, unlocked the entrance door to the medication room and took a hand full of Benadryl. There was not an internal investigation conducted. C1 received medical attention, was placed on a hold, discharged to their parents, transported back to the facility and readmitted back into program. S1 counted the number of remaining Benadryl but there was no records of a previous medication count to determine the number Benadryl C1 ingested. There was no evidence of an addendum received regarding the outcome medical attention from the emergency room at Los Robles Regional Medical Center, neither when C1 was readmitted at the facility. The facility is cited for violation of California Code and Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, Regulation 80075 (k) (1) Health Related Services as evidence by; C1 gained access to the medication room and ingested a hand full of Benadryl. An exit interview was conducted with Gina Mc Auley Executive Director and a copy of this report and Appeal Rights was left at the facility.

facility_name: MC ALISTER INSTITUTE GROUP HOME EAST
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Veronica Whitaker and Licensing Program Manager (LPM), Angela King conducted a case management inspection on August 23, 2022, at 11:00 AM, based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1538.7. During this inspection, 8 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 3 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated 8/23/22). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed, Minutes from the Board of Directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the treatment plan, youth case plans, and personal safety plan, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPM Angela King observed training records showing staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Yuriko Grijalva, Program Manager.

facility_name: MC ALISTER INSTITUTE GROUP HOME EAST
narrative:
On September 01, 2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Marisol Lopez and LPA Eduardo Barragan conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility above. LPA's met with Program Representative (P1) Sharayah Horne and Patrick Foley Youth Service Director. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA's inspected the facility inside and out with facility representative. The group home has the capacity of six ambulatory clients and there was a census of four clients at the time of inspection. LPA's inspected the physical plant, operational requirements, disaster preparedness, emergency intervention plan and reviewed four of four client files (C1-C4) (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 09/01/2022) and three of three staff files (S1-S3). LPA conducted two of two staff interviews (S1-S2) and all clients(C1-C4) refused interviews. The client and staff files are maintained off-site and were readily available. The facility residence is a single story home with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, staff office, kitchen and living room area. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. All hazardous items have been properly locked and made inaccessible to clients. The hot water was measured at 115.0 to be within the regulatory requirements. The medications, sharps, and first aid are stored in the staff office in the locked closet and locked in a cabinet. Toxic chemicals are locked in a cabinet in the garage. The facility's smoke detectors in the hallway and all bedrooms were checked and operable. A dual carbon monoxide detector located in the kitchen/common area was checked and operable. There is at least one week supply of nonperishable, snacks, and a 2 day supply of perishable foods. The monthly menu is posted on the refrigerator. Personal Hygiene, wash clothes and extra towels are available for client use. The facility is maintained clean and there were no exit obstructions or potential hazards. (See continuation form LIC 809-C dated 09/01/22)

Based on record review, the licensee did not comply as 1 out of 4 client's do not have a copy of the current court order, or written authorization of the child's parent or guardian, for each psychotropic medication and each licensee shall have and maintain on file a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. The facility is being issued a citation in accordance with the Title 22, CCR 84070(b)(12) Children's Records; CCR 80023(a) Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan. An exit interview was conducted, and this report, appeal rights and LIC 811 was reviewed with Youth Service Director Patrick Foley and a copy of this report was provided.

facility_name: MCALISTER INSTITUTE ADOLESCENT GROUP HOME SOUTH
narrative: On August 31, 2022, at 11:20 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Eduardo Barragan conducted an unannounced case management visit at McAlister Institute Adolescent Group Home South to discuss an incident that occurred on August 29, 2022. LPA Barragan met with Adrianna Caballero, Director. An incident was discussed where three clients assaulted a staff member. (Please see 811 for confidential names list.) The Licensee informed LPA Barragan that nothing like this had occurred before. The Licensee stated that the three clients living in the home never showed any type of physical aggression towards staff. The Licensee stated that the three clients weren't even friends while residing at the facility up until the day before this incident occurred. The Licensee stated that the incident occurred around 9:12 PM. At the time of the incident there was only the three clients residing in the home and one staff member. The Licensee stated that they were in ratio when the incident occurred, due to them being three clients to one staff during night hours. The Licensee stated that they will provide LPA Barragan with the video of the incident once they obtain access to it. Currently the video is downloading in segments however, their IT is fixing the issue at the moment. LPA Barragan provided his email to the Licensee. LPA Barragan and the Licensee discussed that a safety plan needs to be implemented for staff prior to excepting any new clients. LPA Barragan and the Licensee discussed that this saftey plan would need to elaborate night shift hours as well due to this incident occurring at night. The License stated that they will submit this plan to Community Care Licensing (CCL) by 09/02/2022. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was printed and provided to Adrianna Caballero, Director.

narrative: On December 23, 2024, at 4:25 PM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Phillip Emrhein, Administrator of McAlister Institute Group Home to deliver a case management deficiencies report. According to information obtained during the course of an investigation conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL), the facility did not report multiple incidents to CCL. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, it was revealed that the following incidents were not reported to CCL. During May 2024, multiple clients reported that a staff member was allowing clients to miss planned addiction recovery meetings, providing nicotine vapes to clients, and was not preventing or reporting clients using other substances such as marijuana and Xanax. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, 88361(b)(1)(E) Reporting Requirements. A copy of the report was discussed and provided along with appeal rights to Phillip Emrhein, Administrator.

narrative: ...CONTINUED Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that facility management became aware of the alleged incidents involving S1 and that management terminated S1 immediately thereafter. A confidential interview indicated that S1 also brought alcohol to the facility for clients when S1 was the only staff working. Confidential interviews indicated that S1 provided marijuana to at least one client in care, and a review of client drug and alcohol test results confirmed that the client had marijuana in their system. Confidential interviews and a review of outside source records indicated that pictures of clients and staff drinking alcohol at the beach were taken and posted on S1’s social media. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegations that Staff gave alcohol to minors in care is substantiated because the preponderance of evidence has been met. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care, and the facility will be cited for violating Health and Safety Code, Division 2, Chapter 3, Article 5, Section 1550(c). An exit interview was conducted, and a plan of correction was developed with Phillip Emrhein, Administrator. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Phillip Emrhein, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On December 23, 2024, at 4:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Phillip Emrhein, Administrator of McAlister Institute Group Home to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegation. LPA Salem initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 8/7/2024 at 1:25 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Salem interviewed Clients (C1-C7) and Staff (S1-S9). LPA Salem obtained and reviewed pertinent records. On July 28, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that Staff (S1 and S2) gave alcohol to minors (C2, C3, and another unnamed client) in care. It was reported that S1 and S2 bought clients alcohol on multiple occasions and took the clients to drink at the park instead of attending planned outings to addiction recovery meetings. Confidential interviews corroborated this information and indicated that S1 and S2 provided alcohol to four clients in care (C1-C3). CONTINUED...

facility_name: MCALISTER INSTITUTE ADOLESCENT GROUP HOME SOUTH
narrative:
...CONTINUED A conflicting confidential interview indicated that only S1 drove clients while under the influence. Confidential interviews indicated that S1 told the clients they were also taking medication, such as Percocet or Xanax, before driving clients but was not seen taking anything besides alcohol. Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that S1 lost the company car keys during one of the incidents when S1 was intoxicated while with the clients. Confidential interviews indicated that S1 often appeared tired and “zoned out” while working in the facility but was not seen sleeping at work. CCL also received the allegation that Staff (unnamed) does not keep the facility free from substances. It was reported that clients in care have continued access to substances. A review of the facility’s program statement reveals that a primary goal of the facility is to provide a safe environment for clients, which includes keeping clients separated from drug and/or alcohol use and supported in recovery and abstinence. Confidential interviews indicated that after returning from the outings intoxicated, the clients (C1-C3) and staff (S1 and S2) brought alcohol back into the facility and hid it in the clients’ rooms while the other staff were in the back office. A confidential interview indicated that S1 also purchased alcohol and brought it back to the facility for clients to consume when S1 and S2 were the only staff working. A confidential interview indicated that staff did not search clients’ rooms during the time they had alcohol. Confidential interviews and records review indicated that S1 was previously admonished and demoted for allegations that former clients made involving S1 not reporting drug use in the facility. A confidential interview indicated that, during that time, S1 also witnessed a client using a marijuana vape pen and did not confiscate it or report it to S1’s supervisor. Confidential interviews indicated that former clients were able to sneak contraband into the facility because staff do not search clients upon admission. Conflicting confidential interviews indicated that staff search clients’ possessions upon admission, as well as use a metal detecting wand to search the clients’ person. CCL also received the allegation that Staff (unnamed) do not ensure that children (unnamed) are following their needs and services plan. It was reported that staff were taking clients to the park to hang out with friends rather than taking the clients to addiction recovery meetings. A review of needs and services plans for clients involved in the above incidents revealed that clients would maintain sobriety by, in part, attending daily addiction recovery meetings for the duration of their stay in the program. Confidential interviews indicated that while S1 and S2 were taking the clients to drink, the clients were scheduled to be attending nightly recovery meetings. CONTINUED...

...CONTINUED Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that S1 also allowed former clients to miss addiction recovery meetings, despite these clients’ needs and services plan including daily attendance in recovery meetings. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the allegations that Staff conduct poses a risk to children in care and Staff does not keep the facility free from substances pose an immediate and Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care, and the allegation that Staff do not ensure that children are following their needs and services plan poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The allegations are substantiated because the preponderance of evidence has been met and the facility will be cited for violating California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80078(a), Section 80022(k), and Chapter 5, Section 84078(b). An exit interview was conducted, and a plan of correction was developed with Phillip Emrhein, Administrator. An exit interview was conducted and a signed copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Phillip Emrhein, Administrator.
investigation_findings: 13On December 23, 2024, 3:30 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem met with Phillip Emrhein, Administrator of McAlister Institute Group Home to deliver the findings for the above-stated allegations. LPA Salem initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on 7/17/2024 at 1:35 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA Salem interviewed Clients (C1-C7) and Staff (S1-S9). LPA Salem obtained and reviewed pertinent records. On July 8, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that Staff (unnamed) conduct poses a risk to children (unnamed) in care. It was reported that a staff member was drunk while working at the facility and drove away with facility keys, as well as fell asleep at work after taking a pill. Confidential interviews and records reviewed indicated that S1 and S2 drank alcohol while on outings with clients (C1-C3), and that S1 and S2 drove clients in the facility car while under the influence. CONTINUED...

deficiencies.description:
Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the licensee did not provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the needs of 3 of 4 clients in care (C1-C3), which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to persons in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Per administrator, Staff (S1 and S2) involved in the allegation have been terminated. Additionally, LPA Salem will be sent proof of S1 and S2 being terminated by 12/24/24.

narrative: On October 21, 2022, at 9:00AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection at McKinley Group Home (GH) and met with Patricia White and Dustin Vander Haar. The purpose of the inspection was stated to the facility representative. LPA Flores conducted a walk-through the facility with Dustin Vander Haar. The GH will use 6 cottages to house all the clients that the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) will place with the GH, once licensed. The cottages are Whittier, Kiwanis, Campbell, Gregory, Bashor, and Wood. LPA Flores observed that the cottages are not ready to receive the children due to upgrades and renovations that are taken place throughout the facility. LPA Flores observed that the music and weight room, that was previously in Cottages Kingsley and Fox, were moved to a different area and they are completed finished and ready for its use. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On November 03, 2022, at 9:15AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection at McKinley Group Home (GH) and met with Dustin Vander Haar. The purpose of the inspection was stated to the facility representative. LPA Flores conducted a walk-through out and inside the facility with Dustin Vander Haar. Cottages Kiwanis and Whittier are ready to house children that the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) will place with the GH under the Unaccompanied Undocumented Minors (UUM) program. Cottages Campbell and Gregory are still under construction with renovations and upgrades pending to be completed, according to the facility representative both cottages will be ready by third week of November 2022. The GH will decrease the capacity of the GH to 40 children that will be housed in the 4 Cottages mentioned above. LPA Flores informed the facility representative that a new LIC200 with a Board resolution is needed to make the change. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

On November 16, 2022, at 9:15AM, Humberto Flores, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), conducted an announced Pre-Licensing Inspection at McKinley Group Home (GH) and met with Dustin Vander Haar. The purpose of the inspection was stated to the facility representative. LPA Flores conducted a walk-through out and inside Cottages Campbell and Gregory with Dustin Vander Haar. Both Cottages are ready to house children that the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) will place with the GH under the Unaccompanied Undocumented Minors (UUM) program. LPA Flores inspected all the rooms where a total of 20 children will be housed. The smoke detector and carbon monoxide detector where tested and operable. The water temperature was at 107F in Campbell Cottage and at 107F in Gregory Cottage. Cottages Kiwanis and Whittier were inspected on 11/03/2022 and are ready to house the clients from the UUM program. The GH representative stated that the facility is still in the process to obtain a Board Resolution authorizing to reduce the capacity from 60 to 40 children, the resolution will be submitted to Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) along with an Application for A Community Care Facility LIC200.

cont.#2 LPA Flores informed the GH representative that once the resolution is obtained, a new Fire Clearance request will be sent by CCLD to the local fire authority requesting to conduct an inspection, in order to obtain a Fire Clearance. LPA Flores stated that once the Fire Clearance is obtained, the GH will be ready for licensure. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

The facility is moving the Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) youth from Cottage Fox and Cottage Kingsley to Cottage Bashor and Cottage Wood. Cottage Fox and Cottage Kingsley will house clients. LPA conducted a walk-through inside and out Cottage Kingsley and Cottage Fox. Cottage Kingsley has 8 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms used for clients. Each bedroom will have a twin size bed, dresser, office table, and locker closet. Cottage Kingsley has a common area with couches, wall mounted TV, dining table, and kitchen appliances. All staff and storage rooms have a lock. Cottage has (2) camera's facing the common area, (2) camera's facing the hallway, and (2) camera's facing the outside patio. Cottage has (2) fire extinguishers that were last serviced on January 05, 2023. Entering the staff office leads into Cottage Fox. Cottage Fox's layout is parallel and identical to Cottage Kingsley. Cottage Fox has the same number of rooms along with cameras. Cottage Fox has 8 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms used for clients. Each bedroom will have a twin size bed, dresser, office table, and locker closet. Cottage Fox has a common area with couches, wall mounted TV, dining table, and kitchen appliances. This cottage has rooms designed for staff along with staff restrooms. This cottage also has a locked laundry room which will also be used for client linen, and storage of medication. All staff and storage rooms have a lock. Cottage Fox has (2) fire extinguishers that were last serviced on January 05, 2023.

The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors for both cottages were tested and operable. Fire alarm for both Cottages were tested and was in working order. The facility is increasing their capacity from 40-60. LIC 200 was submitted to CCL. Both Cottages are ready to house clients. A copy of this report was provided to the facility representative. On 09/01/2023 at 8:55 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Noubar Yerkatyan made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of a case management inspection. The purpose of the inspection is to follow-up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on 07/28/2023, (see confidential names list). The SIR indicated on 07/28/2023, staff (S1) used inappropriate Spanish to address client (C1). LPA conducted interviews with (1) client and (6) staff. All interviews revealed that S1 used inappropriate Spanish words to address C1 in the cottage. Witnesses were interviewed and all statements were consistent. Facility gave S1 their first written warning and provided training. There is evidence to prove that S1 failed to meet Title 22 Regulations. Therefore, a deficiency is being issued. Appeal Rights were given. A copy of LIC 809, 809-D, and 811 was provided to above facility representative.

narrative:

LPA met with facility Administrator, Patricia White. LPA and Ms. White toured the facility. LPA obtained and reviewed the following updated documentation: LIC 500 Personnel and Client Roster, LIC 610 C Emergency Disaster Plan, Board of Directors report, Employee Grievance Policy/ Grievance Procedures, Crisis Prevention Intervention Training's, Emergency Preparedness: Disaster and Mass Casualties Drills, Emergency Evacuation Routes, Facility Monthly Activities Calendar, Emergency Intervention Plan, and Complaint Procedures. The facility was in full compliance with 7 applicable areas of the Compliance and Regulatory Enforcement (CARE) tools for Children’s Residential Licenses. Entering the staff office leads into Cottage Kingsley. Cottage Kingsley has 8 bedrooms with 10 beds in total. All bedrooms have a twin-size bed, dresser, office table, and locker closet. Cottage has common area with couches, TV, dining table, and kitchen appliances. Cottage has rooms designed for staff along with staff restrooms. Client restrooms were all in working order. LPA toured the nursing station and facility cafeteria as well. Nursing station has multiple offices with a treatment room and medication room. Both the treatment and medication rooms contained locked cabinets of medications. Attached to the cafeteria was a large auditorium with tables, chairs, and a stage for entertainment. On 08/30/2024 at 12:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joseph Louis Vargas conducted an unannounced visit to the above facility for a case management inspection. LPA Vargas met with the Program Director Ms. Marti. The inspection was to follow up on a Special Incident Report (SIR) received by the Department on 08/12/2024 (refer to Confidential Names List dated 08/30/2024). The SIR read that on 05/25/2024, staff (S1) allowed a client (C1) to utilize S1's cellular phone to watch/play a gaming video. The cellular phone was being mirrored, projected to the common area wall near the kitchen and dining area. C1 while in control of S1's cellular phone, a Message Media Service (MMS) was allegedly received. That is when the client opened the MMS application and briefly displayed a photo image of two persons engaging in sex. LPA Vargas obtained and reviewed security video evidence with no audio and supports the incident on 5/25/2024. There were no other clients who saw the image that was being projected on the cottage wall. Staff #1 did not report the incident on 05/25/2024. The Facility Program Director became aware of the incident on 08/12/2024 after a client reported the incident after the fact, which included a review of video footage in the cottage on 5/25/2024. The facility submitted a late Special Incident Report on 08/12/2024. Following a review of the deficiency cited per Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 06. Continuing Requirements of the California Code of Regulations, and listed on the LIC 809-D on page 2 of this report, including the Confidential Names List (LIC811) . An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the reports and the Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative.

deficiencies.description: Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required.....Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours. .....This requirement is not met as evidence by interviews and documentary evidence of a late Special Incident Report submitted to CCL on 08/12/2024 as a result that staff did not report an unusual incident.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The Program Director reminded staff working at the facility on 08/13/2024 about Boundaries, Phone Usage, and Code of Conduct, that addresses staff personal cell phones and any personal devices are not accessible to the clients (youths). A copy of the memo (email) was provided to LPA Vargas. The staff identified in the report is no longer associated to the facility. No further action is needed at this time.

narrative: On 08/14/2024, The Department received a complaint alleging that a staff worker at the facility intentionally showed the client a pornographic image, the client was allegedly propositioned for sex by a staff worker, and the staff worker was observed kissing another client. The reported incidents disclosed were said to have occurred on or about 5/25/2024. The staff worker (S1) identified in the report has denied the allegations. S1 explained that on 5/25/2024, she allowed a client to have access to her personal cellular phone that was being projected on the wall in the cottage dining room so that the client could play games or watch videos. S1 disclosed that she received a multimedia message service (MMS) on her phone that contained an adult content image of two persons engaging in having sex while the client was using her cellular phone, and that is when the client accessed the MMS and briefly displayed the image on the wall for one to two seconds. S1 denied that it was intentional but an accident. S1 denied propositioning the same client who had access to her phone. S1 has denied kissing any clients at the facility. Staff (2-5) denied witnessing S1 engage inappropriately with clients. In confidential interviews with the clients, and facility staff workers, one individual identified as other, including a review of the facility security video could not corroborate the allegations. Based on the information gathered during interviews and documentary evidence, it cannot be determined whether the allegations occurred. Therefore, the above allegations are determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the facility representative and copies of all licensing reports were provided after the inspection. An exit interview was conducted and the Appeal rights were given and explained. No deficiencies were cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On 08/28/2024 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joseph Vargas conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint. LPA met with Ms. Marti, Administrator. During the course of the investigation, LPA conducted telephonic interviews and in-person visits with Facility Administrator, one staff, one client on 8/16/2024, one staff, once client on 8/19/2024, two staff's, six clients on 8/20/2024, made multiple attempts, with the last one on 8/27/2024 to contact the Federal Field Specialist (FFS). During the inspection LPA requested for review and obtained copy of the staff and client facility roster reports, special incident reports, and security video footage from the facility as part of my investigation for my review.

narrative:
On November 06, 2024, at 09:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Christopher J. Williams and LPA Gilbert Gutierrez arrived unannounced at Mckinley Youth Center for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection. LPAs met with Nadine Gonzalez, Assistant Director. A tour of the facility was conducted, and LPAs reviewed the following domains in the Compliance And Regulation Enforcement (CARE) Tool: Physical Plant, Operational Requirements, Disaster Preparedness, and Core/Therapeutic Services. Physical Plant: The license is posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions are locked in a closet and sharps are locked in the office. Facility has non-perishable foods for at least one week and perishable foods for at least two days. Facility provides at least three (3) meals per day. Medications are centrally stored and locked in cabinets, located in the laundry room of each cottage. All kitchen, food preparation, and storage areas are kept clean and free of rodents and other vermin. Each cottage has one or more carbon monoxide detectors in the facility. Each facility cottage provides basic laundry services for the clients. Room temperatures are maintained at 72 degrees F. The hot water temperature was within the required range of 105 to 120 degrees. All toilets, hand washing and bathing facilities are maintained in safe and sanitary operating condition and meet the requirements. No more than 2 children share a bedroom each cottage. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs and a clean mattress; and supplied with pillows which are clean and in good repair. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Continue on next page....

Continue.... Disaster Preparedness Plan: Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least every month for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan (If applicable) for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. Operations: Facility maintains a current, written plan of operation that meets licensing standards. Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. Facility maintains and implements written complaint procedures, and the procedures are posted in a publicly accessible location in the facility. The board of directors regularly conducts meetings to review and discuss the Group Home operations. Cash resources are kept on the facility premises in a locked and secure location. Core/Therapeutic Services: Facility provides core services and supports to children and unaccompanied - minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and unaccompanied-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency. An exit interview was conducted by LPA, and a signed copy of this report, LIC809, LIC9102TA, LIC811 (Confidential Names List) were provided to the facility representative.

On November 07, 2024, at 9:48 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Christopher J. Williams arrived unannounced at Mckinley Youth Center Group Home for the purpose of continuing / completing an Annual / Required inspection. LPA met with Marissa Marti, Director of UCS and Nadine Gonzalez, Assistant Director. Client Records: LPA continued the inspection by reviewing five (5) client records and interviewing 2 clients. All client records were available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records reviewed included, but not limited to, consent forms, assessment and safety plans, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessments; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. An exit interview was conducted by LPA, and a signed copy of this report - LIC809, and a LIC811 (Confidential Names List) were provided to the facility representative.

On 11/8/24 the Department received a complaint alleging facility staff are not ensuring that client’s dental needs are being met; facility staff are discriminating against clients in care and facility staff yell at the clients in care. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, facility staff indicated clients are not denied medical attention. Staff indicted client was taken to dentist on October 28, 2024, and has a follow up appointment in November 2024. The facility staff indicated clients are not discriminated against and all clients are treated equally. The facility staff indicated staff does not yell or scream at the clients. Confidential interviews could not corroborate the allegations due to contradicting statements being made during interviews. Clients interviewed indicated staff treats all clients equally and clients are not discriminated against by the staff. Clients indicated staff does not yell or scream at clients. LPA reviewed dental exam forms that indicated client was taken to the dentist on October 28, 2024. The other agency’s investigative report indicated facility staff reported that due to client being considered an unaccompanied minor, client has private insurance and is technically not allowed to be seen by a dentist within sixty days of arrival. Client however was able to see a dentist twice within a two-week period. There were no safety threats identified and the child is not in immediate danger of serious harm. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegations is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.
investigation_findings: 13On February 24, 2025, at 11:30 AM Licensing Program Analyst Larry Cabral (LPA) conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint allegations. LPA Cabral met with the facility Assistant Director Nadine Gonzalez. During the investigation, LPA Cabral interviewed one facility staff (S1) and one client (C1) on 11/14/24. LPA interviewed three facility staff (S2, S3, S4) and four clients (C2, C3, C4, C5) 1/17/25 (see Confidential Names Form LIC 811 dated February 24, 2025). LPA reviewed incident reports, dental exam forms, health services report and email to health nurse. LPA reviewed the other agency’s investigative report and response notice on 2/6/25.

narrative: Due to the LPA being unable to interview Ref. #1 and #2, the LPA was unable to obtain information regarding the allegations about the staff failing to intervene in an altercation between residents and staff treating residents unfairly. The LPA was unable to corroborate the allegations. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that an alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies to be cited regarding these allegations. A copy of this complaint along with the appeal rights were emailed to Ms. Gonzalez.
investigation_findings: 13On December 16, 2020, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), emailed the investigative findings of the complaint investigation to Administrator, Nancy Gonzalez. On August 31, 2020, the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Regional Office (RO) received a complaint with the above mentioned allegations. The investigation included confidential interviews that consisted of, but were not limited to: two staff, CEO Sabrina Kyser via telephone on September 3, 2020 and the Administrator via telephone on November 12, 2020; two County Social Workers (CSW) via telephone on October 19, 2020 and October 20, 2020. The LPA was unable to locate and interview clients, Ref. #1 and #2 (see Confidential Names, LIC 811 dated December 15, 2020). On November 12, 2020 the Administrator provided the LPA with a virtual tour via FaceTime in order for the LPA to inspect the food supply and physical plant for mold. The LPA observed that facility maintains a refrigerator in the kitchen, as well as in the garage along with a freezer and shelf storage. The LPA observed more than a weeks supply of nonperishable food and more than two days worth of perishable food. The LPA observed no mold in or surrounding the bathtub as reported.

narrative:
Continued from pg.1 of LIC 9099 There was no corroborating information obtained through the interviews and review of records to confirm the allegation. Based on the interviews and records reviewed, the allegation is found Unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation. The facility closed effective 1/19/2021. Therefore, the LIC 9099, LIC 9099-C and LIC 811 reports will be mailed to the last known address of the Licensee.

Continued from Pg.1 of LIC 9099-A It was alleged that facility staff did not ensure that residents received adequate food. LPA Mundo conducted a tele-inspection on 9/17/2020 at 3:33 pm. LPA Mundo observed the facility did not have enough perishable food for 3 days and the non-perishable food available was not enough to make complete meals. S1 stated that the facility normally does the grocery shopping weekly on Thursdays. S1 stated that a facility member was doing the grocery shopping at the time of this tele-inspection. LPA Mundo requested grocery receipts for the period of 7/2020-9/17/2020. The facility did not provide LPA Mundo with grocery receipts. Based on interviews, record reviews and the facility tele-inspection, it was determined that the facility did not ensure that residents received adequate food. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of evidence to prove that the facility failed to meet Interim Licensing Standards Version 3. Therefore, the above allegation is Substantiated. The facility closed effective 1/19/2021. Therefore, the LIC 9099-A and LIC 9099-C reports will be mailed to the last known address of the Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On 4/16/2021 at 2:34 pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jenny Mundo concluded the complaint investigation for the Group Home (GH). During the course of the investigation, LPA Mundo conducted interviews with 1 facility staff (S1) and 1 foster child (C1) on 9/17/2020 via telephone (see Confidential Names form LIC 811 dated 4/16/2021). LPA Mundo also reviewed documents on 9/23/2020 including but not limited to placement agency reports and the facility’s Special Incident Reports (SIRs) for the period of August and September 2020, and staff training for 2020. It was alleged that facility staff handle youth in a physical aggressive manner. Statements obtained from the confidential interviews did not provide sufficient information to corroborate the allegation. S1 denied the allegation. The facility residents refused to give a statement and LPA Mundo was unable to make contact with other facility staff.

deficiencies.description:
In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply:
All food shall be safe and of the quality and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews, record reviews and the facility tele-inspection, it was determined that the facility did not ensure that residents received adequate food which posed a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Due to facility closure effective 1/19/2021, there is no POC at this time.

narrative: Staff denied the alleged allegations and further indicated that all clients are treated equally and are held accountable for their actions. Staff further indicated that on some occasions staff has raised their voice at clients to redirect and prevent altercations among clients. Staff further disclosed that no client’s personal belongings are taken away unless it is prohibited by their CSW and documented. On some occasion’s clients have asked staff to secure certain items such as phones or tablets which are locked up in the office and are returned upon the client’s request. C1 indicated that male staff would often say provocative comments and that the female staff would talk down to her daily due to being Caucasian. C1 also indicated that staff didn’t cook any food, nor did they provide clients with snacks. Information obtained from C2 and C3 denied the alleged allegations further indicating that staff treated all clients equally and made clients accountable for their actions. C2 and C3 denied hearing any male staff member make any inappropriate comments toward any client and further disclosed that the male staff worked in the office and the female staff worked on the floor taking care of the clients. C2 and C3 indicated that they were provided three meals everyday with healthy snacks such as fruits, granola bars and yogurt. Therefore, based on the information received, the above allegations are determined to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred, therefore the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Appeal Rights, LIC9099 and LIC811 were provided via mail to last known address on the licensee due to the above facility being closed on 1/9/2021. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On April 29, 2021, at 12:45 p.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Winston Moroney, attempted to conduct a teleconference inspection to the above Group Home but was unable to contact the Facility Administrator. The purpose of the teleconference was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. On November 18, 2020, the California Department of Social Services Community Care Licensing Division received a complaint from Centralized Complaint and Information Bureau (CCIB) with the following allegations: Facility staff spoke inappropriately to youth in care, Facility staff did not allow youth access to personal belongings, Facility staff did not keep the facility clean, Facility staff did not provide a good quality of food, Facility staff did not provide youth with snacks, Facility staff did not ensure that youth had adequate clothing, Facility staff did not seek medical attention in a timely manner. The investigation to the above allegations was conducted by this LPA and it consisted of, but not limited to a review of records, including the children needs and services plans, medical records and interviews with 2 staff members on 11/30/2020, 3 Clients C1 on 4/27/2021, C2 on 4/28/21 and C3 on 4/27/21. (Reference Confidential Names Form LIC 811, dated April 29, 2021).

facility_name: MICHAEL'S YOUTH TREATMENT HOME FOR BOYS
met_with: Gabriela Bacerra Facility Manager, Ruby Barajas Program Administrator.
narrative:
On December 13, 2022 at 8:55 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Jessica Peete and Sarah Lo conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Michael’s Youth Treatment Home for Boys Group Home. LPA’s were met at the facility by Facility Manager Gabriela Becerra and Administrator Ruby Barajas. LPA’s began a physical plant inspection at 9:30 AM assisted by the Facility Manager and Administrator.. The facility is two stories; a physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Kitchen, dining room, living room refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, one staff bathroom, one staff office, two client bathrooms, and three client bedrooms (B1-B3) Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there is one client per bed. Each client room has the appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses are in good repair. Extra linens are stored in the hall closet. Additionally, there is adequate drawer space for each client’s belongings. Cleansers, chemicals, and cooking knives are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are locked in the downstairs closet. Cooking knives are in a locked in the staff office. Upon inspection the first aid kit was complete and located in the staff office. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of food and a variety of snacks for clients. LPA observed a minimum seven day non-perishable and a two day perishable supply of food. Additionally, LPA observed the following postings: facility license, grievance procedures, personal rights, Ombudsman poster, visitation policies, and current menu. Age appropriate games and books were observed for client’s recreation time. The facility’s outside grounds were also inspected and found to be clean, well maintained, and free of observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, and all exits were free from obstruction. LPA observed the facility pool, in the backyard, to be inaccessible clients. The fence around the pool has a self-latching gate and measured over five feet tall. The pool is clean and well maintained. (Continued on LIC 809 C )

The facility has an operable carbon monoxide detectors and smoke detectors located throughout the facility. The fire extinguishers were properly charged, serviced, and located in the kitchen and upstairs hallway. Medications were centrally stored locked inside of the staff office. The washer and dryer are located inside the facility, next to the garage, and accessible to clients with staff assistance. Per Facility Manager’s statement clients are supervised while they do their own laundry and LPA observed detergents are kept locked. The facility has one vehicle used to transport clients to appointments and recreational activities. The vehicle was observed to be in safe operating condition. At 9:47 AM, LPA observed, client bathroom one had two sinks. Water in sink one measured 136.2 degrees Fahrenheit and sink two measured 133.7 degrees Fahrenheit. The water in client bathroom two measured 133.5 degrees Fahrenheit. At 9:52 AM the LPA’s observed the trash cans in both client bathrooms were missing lids; this was corrected during the visit. At 10:00 AM, LPA observed window screens were missing from all three client bedrooms. The licensee was cited for the following deficiencies: Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR) 80088(e)(1)… Hot water temperature controls shall be maintained to automatically regulate temperature of hot water …used by clients to attain a hot water temperature of not less than 105 degrees F (40.5 degrees C) and not more than 120 degrees F (48.8 degrees C). CCR 80088(f)(1) …(1) All containers, including movable bins, used for storage of solid wastes shall have tight-fitting covers kept on the containers; shall be in good repair, shall be leakproof and rodent-proof. CCR 80088(b) All window screens shall be in good repair and be free of insects, dirt and other debris. At 10:20 AM, assisted by the Facility Manager and Administrator LPA’s began review of the Disaster Preparedness, Operational Requirements, Emergency Interventions. At 10:30 AM, LPA’s observed the licensee’s disaster plan did not include documentation of quarterly emergency drills, and there were no procedures addressing the storage and preservation of medications. The licensee was cited with the following technical violations of the Health and Safety Code (HSC): HSC 1565(c) A facility shall conduct a drill at least quarterly for each shift… (Continued on LIC 809 C)

HSC 1565(a)(7)(E) A facility shall have an emergency and disaster plan that shall include… (7) Procedures that address…(E) Storage and preservation of medications… At 11:15 AM LPA observed the licensee had not trained staff on emergency interventions. Per Facility Managers statement, staff was last trained in May 2021. The Facility Manager stated a training is scheduled for 12/16/2022. The licensee was cited with the following technical violations: CCR 84365(d) The licensee must maintain a written record of the facility staff training. CCR 84365(d)(1) … Documentation of training received must be maintained in the personnel record for each staff member… CCR 84365(d)(1)(A) The licensee must maintain a written record of the facility staff training. (1) Documentation of training received must be maintained in the personnel record for each staff member and must include: (A) Dates, hours, and description of the training completed. CCR 84365(d)(1)(B) The licensee must maintain a written record of the facility staff training… (1) Documentation of training received… must include: (B) Name and training certificate of the instructor who provided the training. CCR 84365(d)(1)(C) The licensee must maintain a written record of the facility staff training… (1) Documentation of training received… must include: (C) Certification from the instructor that the staff member has successfully completed the competency test. CCR 84365(e) Facility personnel must receive on-going training to maintain certification (Continued on LIC 809 C)

At 12:30 PM LPA’s began the review of five staff files ( S1-S5). The licensee was cited for the following technical violations regarding staff training (CCR) 84065(i)(3)(V) …new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training… (3) Training shall include, at a minimum, all of the following topics… (V) A child’s right to receive sexual and reproductive health care and information. CCR 84065(i)(3)(W …new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training… (3) Training shall include, at a minimum, all the following topics…(W) A child’s right to have their sensitive health information kept confidential. CCR 84065(i)(3)(X) …. new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training… (3) Training shall include, at a minimum, all of the following topics… (X) The duties and responsibilities of the assigned case management worker and the licensee to ensure that children can obtain sexual and reproductive health services and information. CCR 84065(i)(3)(Y)… new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training… (3) Training shall include, at a minimum, all of the following topics… (Y) Guidance about how to engage and talk with children about healthy sexual development and reproductive and sexual health in a manner that is medically accurate, age or developmentally appropriate, trauma informed, and strengths based. CCR 84065(i)(3)(Z) … new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training… (3) Training shall include, at a minimum, all of the following topics… (Z) Information about current contraception methods and how to select and provide appropriate referral resources and materials for information and service delivery. During the record review LPA observed staff was hired prior to the effective date of the regulation 10-01-2022. However, the licensee has not updated staff training to include the required information as cited above. (Continued on LIC 809 C)

At 1:30 PM LPA observed the licensee could not provide documentation regarding staff training. The following deficiencies were cited: CCR 84065(i)… new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training. CCR 84065(i)(1)(C)(4) Successful completion of job shadowing shall be verified by a statement completed by the experienced facility personnel…. CCR 84065(i)(1)(D) Within 7 calendar days of completion of the 8 hour training, the administrator or administrator's designee shall assess if each child care staff understands and can apply the training. CCR 84065(i)(1)(D)(2) Within 7 calendar days of completion of the 8 hour training, the administrator or administrator's designee shall assess if each child care staff understands and can apply the training. (2) The assessment shall be documented in each child care staff personnel record. CCR 84065(i)(2)… new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training as specified in (1) and (2) below: (2) Sixteen hours of training shall be completed by new child care staff within 90 days of hire. CCR 84065(i)(2)(A)… new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training… (A) New child care staff who work a maximum of 20 hours per week shall complete the additional minimum 16 hours of training within 180 days of hire. CCR 84065(i)(2)(B)… new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training…(B) Within 30 days of completion of the 16 hour training, the administrator or administrator's designee shall assess if each newly hired child care staff understands and can apply the training. CCR 84065(i)(2)(B)(2)… new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training…(B) Within 30 days of completion of the 16 hour training, the administrator or administrator's designee shall assess if each newly hired child care staff understands and can apply the training. (2) The assessment shall be documented in each child care staff personnel record (Continued on LIC 809 C)

CCR 84065(j)(1)… all child care staff shall complete a minimum of 20 hours of annual training… CCR 84065(j)(1)(A)… all child care staff shall complete a minimum of 20 hours of annual training…(A) At least 5 hours of the annual training shall consist of course work from an entity other than the group home… CCR 84065(j)(2)… newly hired child care staff, hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 16 hours of annual training within the first 12 months of employment, for a total of 40 hours of initial and annual training… CCR 84065(j)(2)(A)… newly hired child care staff, hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 16 hours of annual training within the first 12 months of employment, for a total of 40 hours of initial and annual training… (A) At least 4 hours of the annual training shall consist of course work from an entity other than the group home…or other direct training provided by a qualified individual…who is not affiliated with the group home licensee. CCR 84065(j)(4)(A) A portion of this training shall address oversight and monitoring of psychotropic medications for children in foster care and related topics specified in Section 16501.4(d) of the Welfare and Institutions Code. Based on observations, made during the inspection, deficiencies are being cited, see the LIC 809 D. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to complete the inspection at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights was provided/emailed to Administrator Ruby Barajas.

deficiencies.title:
