(i) Notwithstanding Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16-hour training as specified in (1) and (2) below

facility_name: MICHAEL'S YOUTH TREATMENT HOME FOR BOYS
met_with: Gabriela Bacerra Facility Manager, Ruby Barajas Program Administrator.
narrative:
On December 15, 2022 at 9:33 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA’s) Jessica Peete and Linda Haynes conducted an unannounced continuation visit at Michael’s Youth Treatment Home for Boys Group Home. LPA’s were met at the facility by Facility Manager Gabriela Becerra and Administrator Ruby Barajas. LPA Peete visited the facility on 12/13/2022 to complete inspection of the Physical Plant, Disaster Preparedness, Operational Requirements, and Emergency Interventions. At 9:50 AM assisted by the Facility Manager, LPA began review of three client files (C1-C3) At 10:20 AM LPA provided the licensee technical assistance in connection with Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR) 84077(a)(2) … Provision of an allowance to all children no less frequently than once per month…Per Facility Manager and Administrator statement. Client’s participation in the program is thirty days or less. The licensee was advised that if the clients are in care longer than thirty days; they must be given an allowance. At 10:50 AM LPA observed the licensee did not have Needs and Services Plans for clients in care. Per Facility Manager and Administrator’s statement client’s participation in the program is thirty days or less. Licensee was advised that clients in care, longer than thirty days, are required to have a needs and services plan that address their needs as listed below. The licensee was provided with technical assistance in connection with following Title 22 California Code of Regulations (CCR): CCR 84068.2(a)… Social work staff shall obtain the information specified in Section 84070, and shall develop an individual needs and services plan for the child… CCR 84068.2(b) The needs and services plan shall identify the child's needs in the following areas: CCR 84068.2(b)(1) The needs and services plan shall identify the child's needs in the following areas: (1) Reason for placement. (Continued on LIC 809 C)

CCR 84068.2(b)(2) The needs and services plan shall identify the child's needs in the following areas: (2) Education. CCR (b) The needs and services plan shall identify the child's needs in the following areas: (2) Education. (A) If the information specified in Section 84070(b)(4) is not available, the plan shall specify a method for determining such needs. CCR 84068.2(b)(5) (b) The needs and services plan shall identify the child's needs in the following areas: (5) Ability to manage his/her own money, including the maximum amount of money the child shall be permitted to have in his/her possession at any one time. CCR 84068.2(c) The needs and services plan shall include the following information regarding services necessary to meet the child's needs: CCR 84068.2(c)(1) The needs and services plan shall include the following information regarding services necessary to meet the child's needs: (1) Types of services necessary. At 11:15 AM , LPA observed the licensee did not have documentation pertaining to bedroom sharing arrangements, to be maintained in each client rerecord. The licensee was provided with technical assistance in connection with CCR 84087(e) in every situation where children share a bedroom, the licensee shall document that the bedroom sharing arrangement ensures the health and safety of each child and that the children are compatible… This documentation shall be maintained in the child's record. At 11:25 AM, LPA measured the hot water in both client bathrooms. Bathroom one, sink one, measured 119.4 degrees Fahrenheit. Sink two measured 118.2 degrees Fahrenheit. Bathroom two measured 117.3 degrees Fahrenheit. LPA Haynes conducted two staff interviews and three client interviews. Based on observations, from today’s visit, no deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were given to Administrator Ruby Barajas. This is an amended report of a report that was originally issued on 12/15/2022

Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report and the amended report were provided to Facility Manager Gabriela Becerra.

facility_name: MICHAEL'S YOUTH TREATMENT HOME FOR BOYS
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Sethany Yem conducted a case management inspection on 5/15/24 at 10:30am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 2 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, 5/15/24). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, and progress notes, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Yem observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. Licensing Program Corina Carrillo conducted a case management inspection March 14, 2023 at 3:00PM based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 4 out of 4 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 8 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 4 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, March 14, 2023.) The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Carrillo observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Jaquia Wynn.

narrative: On November 5, 2024, at 9:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Dawn Segura met with Samual Justice, Compliance Specialist and William Mara via Microsoft Teams for a Component II orientation. LPA went over application revisions and discussed the application process prior to licensure. LPA confirmed that they have received fire clearance and criminal background clearances, and a pre-licensing inspection will be scheduled once the applicant’s revisions are approved by the Department. A copy of this report was sent to Samual Justice, Compliance Specialist for signature. The original signed copy will be placed in the facility file.

On December 5, 2024, at 1:55 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacob Salem conducted an announced visit to the above facility and met with Mission Prep Health Care Aja Chavez, Administrator for the purpose of conducting a pre-licensing inspection. LPA and the applicants toured the facility inside and out. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve six ambulatory clients ages 12 to 17. LPA conducted component III of the orientation process and reviewed with the applicants Licensing requirements. The home is a one-story building with three client bedrooms and three client bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Client) has two twin beds and will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #2 (Client) has two twin beds and will sleep two clients. · Bedroom #3 (Client) has two twin beds and will sleep two client. · Kitchen and dining area, multiple family room areas, a laundry room, staff office and storage closet, backyard/patio and pool area with large slide, attached two car garage. The Emergency Disaster Plan and Personal Rights are posted in the front hallway of the home. The license will be posted as soon as it is issued. The client bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients will share a room, no room commonly used for other purposes will be used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate closet space for the clients’ belongings. Client mattresses, blankets, pillows, and linens are clean and in good repair. There are smoke/carbon monoxide detectors inside all three bedrooms and throughout the common areas of the facility. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors were tested and are working properly. After adjusting the central water heater, client bathrooms have working faucets measured to run at 116.4 and 105.4, and there are signs above the client sinks to warn of hot water. The showers and toilets in client bathrooms are in clean and operating condition. There are additional bath towels and basic toiletries stored in the home. CONTINUED...

...CONTINUED The kitchen is clean and well maintained with adequate utensils, dishware, and appliances for food storage and preparation. The kitchen contains perishable and non-perishable food supplies ready for clients to consume upon entry into the program. There is a trash can for storage of solid waste in the kitchen with a tight-fitting lid. The home’s central air conditioning module was located by the front entrance of the home and the home is kept at a comfortable temperature. There are multiple spacious living room areas located through the home with sofas and chairs and reading material for clients to use for relaxation or visitation from family and friends. There is also an educational room and adjacent office, which can be used for visitation and confidential interviews. The facility has supplies and appliances necessary for laundering clients' personal clothing. The home is well lit and passageways are free from obstructions. The backyard consists of a patio and yard area, and window screens around the facility were inspected and in good repair. There is a covered swimming pool in the lower patio and large slide. A first aid kit is readily accessible and located in the staff office cabinet, as well as throughout the home. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. Harmful cleaning supplies are locked in garage closet, medication is kept locked in the staff office,, and knives are locked in the kitchen cupboard. The facility has telephone service on the premises and provisions for making confidential calls. The client’s files will be kept on file electronically, and there are provisions for confidential interviews with clients. The facility has a Emergency and Disaster Plan, which contains all the required procedures, such as provision of emergency power, storage and preservation of medications, and the location of utility shut off valves. The facility has demonstrated compliance with Title 22, Division 6 of the California Code of Regulations. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Aja Chavez, Administrator of Mission Prep Healthcare.

All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher are properly charged and serviced. There are 13 cameras located in the exterior of the facility. CONTINUED....

LPA observed the following items posted: Grievance Procedures, Facility Sketch, Meal Menu, Emergency Disaster Plan, If you See something Say something, Youth Bill of Rights, House Rules, Community Safety Rules, and Emotional Safety Rules. Facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with a mesh fence. The enclosure was measured to be 5 feet with a self-latching gate that swings outward. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Staff files and client files are maintained electronically and accessible for LPA review. LPA virtually reviewed five out of five client files (C1-C5) and five out of five staff files (S1-S5). LPA conducted two of two staff interviews and was unable to conduct client interviews due to clients going on an outing. Based on today's inspection there are no deficiencies cited at this point. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this signed report was provided to Hilda Soriano, Administrator.

On January 26, 2023 at 9 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) JoAunne Griffin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting the Component III and Pre-Licensing inspection. LPA and LPM were met by Aja Chavez, Administrator and William Mara, Director of Business Systems and allowed access into the facility and conducted the tour of the facility. The facility will be licensed to care for six clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility layout is as follows: The facility has a large common living room with a sectional and two chairs. There is a book shelf and a non-operable fireplace that is covered. The dining room has a large table with 10 chairs. There is a double door that leads to the backyard and also a garage access door. The kitchen is equipped with a stove, in wall range with a microwave above, a dishwashing machine and a large refrigerator filled with perishable foods. There is a large pantry and an adjacent cupboard filled with non-perishable foods and snacks. The sharp knives are kept in a locked cabinet below the kitchen sink. The large group room is located adjacent to the living room. There is a large table and several chairs and also has a covered fire place and a TV mounted to the wall. The medication room is double locked and inaccessible to clients and contains a locked cabinet with six individual boxes for the clients medication storage. There is also a refrigerator to store medications. There is a safe which will contain the keys for the medication cabinet. There is a hazardous waste container and a container for sharps and supplies for first aid emergencies. Continued on 809-C

Bedroom #1 contains two beds, two night stands, 1 desk and a large built in cabinet that has dresser drawers and closet space for two clients. There is a large sliding glass door that gives access to the backyard and also a door to access the Bathroom #1. Bedroom #2 has two beds, a closet that contains dresser drawers and closet space for two clients and a desk. Bedroom #3 has two beds, a large closet, two dresser drawers, two night stands, and a desk. Bathroom #2 is located in the room with a sink, toilet, and shower. The bathroom has an access door that leads to the backyard. There are five fire extinguishers located in the facility and were serviced January 18, 2023. The laundry room is located in the hallway and is equipped with a washer and dryer and detergent is and cleaning solutions are locked in cabinet. There is a locked door that contains the hot water heater. The laundry room is kept locked and inaccessible to children in care. The upstairs will only be used for therapy and school. Therapy room #1 has individual seating for family therapy. There is a covered fire place and patio access through a sliding glass door. There is a full bathroom with a toilet, shower and tub. The sink is located right outside of the bathroom. There is a large first aid kit mounted to the wall. Therapy room #2 has two chairs. There is a school room with a large table with seating for all the clients and teachers. The table has 6 computers and there is a sliding glass door with patio access. Outdoor area was observed to be clean and free of debris and hazards. The Backyard has two seating areas. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There is a tankless water heater mounted to the wall and below it are the shut off valves for the home. Above the restraining wall is a hill that has some small debris that was pointed out to Administrator, Aja Chavez as possible hazards. The backyard wraps around the home and leads to the front yard. The garage is a large three car garage that has some personal vehicles in them and there is an additional garage next to that. The front of the home has a long driveway from the street and a large area for additional parking. There are no cameras attached to the home at the time of this visit. The facility vehicle is a Toyota Sienna Van with current registration and insurance. There is a first aid and fire extinguisher located in the trunk of the vehicle. Facility has one or more functioning carbon monoxide and smoke detectors that meet statutory requirements. There were no guns or weapons in the home. Linen closet located in the hallway. Central air and heating unit and all windows had screens and in good repair. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator, Aja Chavez.

On May 5, 2023 at 1pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management investigation. LPA was met by Program Manager, Naomi Tapia and allowed into the facility. On March 16, 2023, an Incident Report was received indicating an altercation between Child #1 and Staff #1. The police were called and Child #1 was temporarily detained and Staff #1 was ultimately terminated. Child #1 was released from the officers and placed back into the facility at the scene. LPA conducted interview with staff. Statements indicated that Staff #1 stated, "you're forced to be here and I'm paid to be here so I'm going to be the one calling the shots." (SIR Dated 3/16/2023) This is a violation of the clients Personal Rights. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80072(a)(1) Personal Rights. Staff #1 spoke inappropriately to Child #1.

On August 8, 2023, at 10 AM, an Informal Meeting was conducted at the El Segundo Children's Residential Program Office to discuss compliance issues with Mission Prep Healthcare Group Home representatives. Present at the Informal Meeting were the following individuals: Aja Chavez-Administrator -via Microsoft Teams Billy Mara – Vice President of Compliance Ted Guastello – CEO – via Microsoft Teams Fernanada Perez Clinical Director Kellee Coleman – Regional Manager JoAunne Griffin – Licensing Program Manager Donald Martin – Licensing Program Analyst Jhane Hayne – Licensing Program Analyst Deborah Lee – Licensing Program Analyst The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the following: 1. Intake Process 2. Staff Training 3. Care and Supervision/Staffing 4. Reporting Requirements 4. Community Concerns Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) explained that the goal for this meeting is to review the recent Incident Reports, complaints and community concerns received for Mission Prep Group Home located at 2 Oceanaire Drive and 28111 Palos Verdes E, Rancho Palos Verdes, CA 90275. During this Informal Meeting Regional Manager, Kellee Coleman discussed the Incident Reports sent to CCLD regarding client health and safety incidents. Licensee was informed of their responsibility to ensure that they can meet the needs of the minors and to take appropriate measures if they are unable to meet the needs of the minors. Cont 809-C

Intake Process: Facility representatives were asked to update Program Statement. Facility representatives will identify acceptance criteria. Facility representatives will obtain thorough background regarding aggressive behaviors. Facility will also update policies and procedures in Program Statement regarding discharge and emergency discharge practices. Updates should indicate what will occur if the child’s parent or representative is not immediately responsive or available to discharge from the hospital and child must return to the facility. Program Statement revisions should indicate what provisions are made if the minor is self-harming. Program Statement should indicate revisions regarding clinical staff oversight during night shift. Facility representatives plan to meet with Del Amo Hospital and build towards a collaborative relationship. Facility representatives will conduct Quality Assurance to ensure clients are not being discharged for reasons that were disclosed during intake. Staff Training: Facility representatives indicated that Google Keeps is currently being utilized to ensure that treatment and safety plan is being communicated to Direct care staff. Facility is working to build a bridge with minors and staff. Facility representatives will be providing trauma informed care to Direct care staff. Facility representatives have identified that incidents have taken place during night hours. Facility representatives have implemented clinical staff being present during this time to assist with coping skills and de-escalation. Facility has implemented less time for free time. Minors are being offered yoga classes, equine therapy, outings in the community and more therapeutic services. Facility staff are building a rapport with minors and involving them in the program. Care and Supervision/Staffing: All staff will receive a refresher CPI training. Facility representatives will review search policies and procedures to ensure that blanket policy is not present. Facility representatives have had exterior cameras installed and alarms on exit doors. Cont 809-C2

Reporting Requirements: Facility representatives were advised to submit Incident Report of initial incident within 24 hours and addendum within seven days. Re-construct Incident report to mirror CCL’s Incident report Incident Report should indicate what happened prior to the incident, during and how the incident concluded. Details of the Incident Report should indicate the name of staff involved. Quality Assurance should be implemented to identify patterns, staff training needs and updates to treatment and safety plans. Facility representatives have identified trends within reports and have implemented changes to activities provided and staff training. Community Concerns: Facility representative will provide a current LIC 500 indicating the days and hours administrator will be present at each facility. Facility representatives will complete and submit a Neighborhood Complaint Form identifying the days and hours administrator is available. Facility representative indicated that they have been in contact with neighbors at both locations and the President of the Homeowner Association (HOA) and has provided them with contact information to share concerns. Facility representative indicated that a staff has been designated to conduct community outreach as an effort to mend relationships with neighbors and mitigate future situations. Facility representative have sent letters to neighbors of pending application locations and has provided information pertaining to program and services that will be provided. Facility representative indicated that counsel has advised that Mission Prep Healthcare Group Home is exempt from business license. Facility representative discussed Off-Site Day School possibility. Regional Manager will follow up regarding policy surrounding Off-Site activities. CCLD is recommending assistance from the Technical Support Program (TSP) in the areas of intake processes and incident reporting. It has also been recommended that facility representatives follow up with their counsel regarding the City of Rancho Palos Verdes to apply for a business license. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was given to the licensee at the end of the Office Meeting.

Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove or disprove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegation is Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies being cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13REPORT AMENDED FROM 05/19/2023, TO CORRECT LANGUAGE On August 4, at 11:30pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of concluding complaint investigation. LPA met with Administrator, Aja Chavez and was allowed into the facility. A risk and health assessment were conducted. During the investigation, interviews were conducted, and documents were obtained.The interviews did not produce corroborating evidence to support said allegation. Interviews revealed inconsistent statements and no witnesses to suggest allegation occurred. There was no evidence that facility staff did not provide adequate supervision to a minor in care. Statements and documentary evidence were consistent that facility was in staff-client ratio. Staff maintained sight of client on foot and in vehicle. incident report showed that staff followed and documented the elopement of Child #1 until he was apprehended by the police. Cont 9099-C

narrative: Facility staff was unable to provide documentation of communication with hospital staff. C#1 was released to the care of biological mother after being hospitalized for 72 hours. Facility cited for violation 80078(a)(2) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s need. Facility staff did not provide contact information or communicate with hospital staff regarding discharge plan for C#1. A copy of this report will be left with Administrator, Aja Chavez.
investigation_findings: 13On July 7, 2023, at 12pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of delivering findings for the above complaint investigation. LPA met with Administrator, Aja Chavez and was allowed into the facility. During the investigation of the allegation of staff are not communicating to medical professional's regarding minor's hospital release, LPA conducted interviews. The confidential interviews indicated that C#1 was hospitalized for evaluation and upon discharge bed was closed. There was no evidence that staff spoke with a hospital representative regarding C#1 discharge plan. There was no evidence that facility staff provided contact information to the hospital representative to be contacted once C#1 discharge from hospital. Cont 909-C

deficiencies.description: 80078(a)(2) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client’s need. Facility staff did not provide contact information or communicate with hospital staff regarding discharge plan for C#1. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews facility staff did not provide contact information or communicate with hospital staff regarding discharge plan for C#1. This poses an immediate health and safety risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee is responsible for clients until someone claims repsponsibility for clients in care. Licensee will update the discharge procedures to reflect a discharge plan that discribes the facilitys responsibility once clients are admitted to a higher level of care.

On 1/30/25 LPA Reagan Cohen and LPM Lakescia Smith arrived at Mission Prep Healthcare at 2:40 for the purpose of an unannounced case management deficiency inspection and met with Administrator Kevin Perez. While reviewing the staff schedule LPA & LPM noticed that staff Jana Anaya was listed on the schedule but was missing clearance on guardian. Administrator admitted that staff has worked at he facility without being cleared. LPA and LPM informed Administrator that the facility would be cited. The following deficiency is being cited for violating of California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6 Regulation 80019 (e) (2) criminal record clearance. (see page 809 D) Exit interview completed, appeal rights issued, and a copy of this report was given to the Administrator.

Based on the SIR of the incident, interview evidence from witnesses and staff, and photo evidence, LPA concludes that the incident did happen and that a client did AWOL from the facility without staff supervision and resulting in inappropriate behavior in the community. Based on the available information LPA gathered from interviews and observation, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegation of “Staff did not adequately supervise minor resulting in inappropriate behavior in the community” is found to be substantiated. An exit interview was conducted, during which LPA provided the Administrator with a copy of this report and a copy of their appeal rights.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/2/25 at 3:59 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen arrived at the above facility and met with Lorenzo Mejia Program Manager for the purpose of delivering complaint findings regarding the above allegation. LPA interviewed involved staff, clients, and witnesses. All staff admitted that there was an incident where C1 AWOLed from the facility on 1/18/25. No staff were present during the client's alleged interactions with the neighboring community. An SIR of the incident was made at the time and has been given to LPA. LPA was unable to get in contact with C1. Interview and photo evidence from neighbors show the client walking around the area, interacting with workers who were on the roof of a house. Neighbor testimony states that the client was walking around the area and threw objects at houses in the community.

deficiencies.description:
Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision “The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the client's needs.”
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interview evidence, records review, and photo evidence, Staff did not adequately supervise a client, resulting in inappropriate behavior in the community, which poses a potential personal rights risk to the client in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Administrator will review LIS 80078 “Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision.” Administrator will develop in writing a facility procedure that will provide clients supervision even when they AWOL, to prevent further similar issues from happening. Administrator will retrain staff on care and supervision techniques and facility procedures, and provide LPA with proof of training.

On April 18, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management investigation. LPA was met by Program Manager, Naomi Tapia and allowed into the facility. On March 16, 2023, an Incident Report was received indicating an altercation between Child #1 and Staff #1. The police was called and Child #1 was temporarily detained and Staff #1 was ultimately terminated. LPA conducted interviews and views with staff and clients. LPA still needs to interview additional staff to conclude this Case Management investigation. No deficiencies were cited at the time of the visit.

On May 22, 2023 at 11am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Post-Licensing inspection. LPA was met by Clinical Case Manager, Kailey Stapel (S4) and allowed access into the facility and conducted the tour of the facility. The facility is licensed to care for six clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility layout is as follows: The facility has a large common living room. There is a long couch and an additional seating area under the window. There is a book shelf and a wall mounted TV. There is a double door that leads to the backyard. The dining room has a large table with 10 chairs. There is a double door that leads to the backyard. There is a fireplace with a cover behind the table. Note: The cover must remain in place. The kitchen is equipped with a stove, in wall range with a microwave above, a dishwashing machine and a large refrigerator filled with perishable foods. There are two cupboards filled with non-perishable foods and snacks. The sharp knives are kept in a locked cabinet below the island. A daily food menu is also posted in the kitchen. The large group room is located adjacent to the living room. There is a couch and other seating. There is a glass double door that leads to the backyard. The medication room is double locked and inaccessible to clients and contains a locked cabinet with six individual boxes for the clients medication storage. A nurse is in the medication room at all times. There is also a refrigerator to store medications. There is a safe which will contain the keys for the medication cabinet. There is a hazardous waste container and a container for sharps and supplies for first aid emergencies. The facility Provisional License, Personal Rights, and Mass Casualty lists are posted by the front door. Note: S4 was informed that a Grievance form and lock box needs to be posted and accessible for client use. Continued on 809-C

There is an office next to the medication room for the Administrator. There is a staff bathroom with a sink and a toilet that is clean and in good working condition. There is a locked closet that contains cleaning supplies. Bedroom #1 contains two beds, two night stands, 1 desk and a large dresser and closet space for two clients. Bedroom #2 has two beds, a closet that contains dresser drawers and closet space for two clients and a desk. Bedroom #3 has two beds, a large closet, one night stand, and a desk. Bathroom #2 is located in the hallway and has a sink, toilet, and shower. There are six fire extinguishers located in the facility and were serviced January 24, 2023. In the hallway is a first aid kit mounted to the wall. The laundry room is located next to the Administrators office and is equipped with a washer and dryer and detergent is and cleaning solutions are locked in cabinet. The laundry room is kept locked and inaccessible to children in care. There is a door that leads to the garage. There is a school room with a large table with seating for all the clients and teachers. The table has 6 computers and there is a sliding glass door with patio access. There is also a a therapy room and full bathroom located inside of the school for clients use. The Backyard is very large. It has an upstairs area that contains a large table with 8 chairs, an outside therapy area and a covered fire pit. Downstairs has a shed which has been converted into a therapy room. The backyard wraps around the home and leads to the front yard. On the side of the house is a locked cabinet containing the shut off valves. Next to it is a closet that contains the water heater. The garage is a two car garage that contains workout equipment. . Outdoor area was observed to be clean and free of debris and hazards. There is a ring camera doorbell that is currently not operable. There are no cameras attached to the home at the time of this visit. The facility vehicle Facility has one or more functioning carbon monoxide and smoke detectors that meet statutory requirements. There were no guns or weapons in the home. Linen closet located in the hallway. Central air and heating unit and all windows had screens and in good repair. LPA reviewed all staff and client files for both facilities via zoom with Program Manager, Naomi Tapia (S2). There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the visit.

On July 13, 2023 at 1pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Incident investigation. LPA met with Program Manager, Naomi Tapia and was allowed into the facility. On LPA arrived at the facility and was informed that clients in care were relocated to an unlicensed location due to plumbing issues at the above facility. There was no evidence of documentation submitted to the department regarding the relocation of clients in care. During the investigation process, LPA conducted interviews, observed clients in care at unlicensed location and advised facility staff of reporting requirements. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Reporting Requirements - Section 80061(a). Facility staff did not submit incident report notifying the department of relocation of children in care.

deficiencies.description: Reporting Requirements 80061(a)	Each licensee or applicant shall furnish to the licensing agency reports as required by the Department, including, but not limited to, those specified in this section. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and observation the facility staff did not submit incident report indicating that clients in care were relocated to unlicensed location. This poses an immediate Health and Safety risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: LPA and LPM have conducted a Zoom meeting with Facility management and discussed Reporting Issues. POC will be cleared by LPA.

narrative: On August 4, 2023, at 1:00pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management – Incident inspection. On September 28, 2023 at 9am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a Case Management inspection for the new sensors installed on the facility doors and windows. LPA met with Community Coordinator, Josue Ramos-Ortiz and was allowed into the facility. In attendance with LPA is Rudy Monroy and Shaunna Hunter, Code Enforcement Officers from the city of Rancho Palos Verdes. The Group room Living room, Dining room and Group room sliding glass doors all have sensors that sound when the door is open and closed. The front door, door that leads to the garage and the back door which is located in the classroom area, also have sensors that alert when the door is opened and closed. There is a central wall unit in the kitchen area and one in the medication room where you can control the system and the sensors can be heard. Bedroom #1, #2 & #3 all have sensors on the windows that sound off if the window is opened and closed. In the backyard the existing fence surrounding the property and been extended in the backyard behind the shed to ensure more privacy to the facility. There are 7 cameras installed to the exterior of the facility. Two are located in the front of the home. Two are located on the sides of the home and Three are located in the back of the facility. The cameras are facing away from the home and only capture the yard and the walkways. There were no sensors added to the outside shed room. No deficiencies were cited at the time of the visit.

On August 6, 2024 at 11am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Donald Martin made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Inspection. LPA spoke with Administrator, Fernanada Perez-Rios. A health and safety assessment was conducted. During the course of investigating a complaint received on 5/10/2024, statements and video footage indicated that law enforcement and paramedics arrived at the facility to address a matter on 5/4/2023. There is no evidence that this incident involving law enforcement was reported to the department per requirements. Facility cited for 80061 (i)(1) Reporting Requirements. Facility did not report incident involving law enforcement to the department. Report has been left with Administrator, Fernanda Perez-Rios.

deficiencies.description:
80061 (i)(1) Reporting Requirements
The licensee shall submit reports to the Department, using form LIC 624-LE or a report containing all the information... regarding any incident that involves law enforcement contact with a child residing in the facility. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and video footage the licensee did not report an incident at the facility which involved Law Enforcement.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee will submit a staff sign off sheet stating that training on reporting requirements has been conducted with all facility staff. This is due by August 30, 2024.

narrative: Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred; therefore, the above allegations are Unsubstantiated. There are no deficiencies being cited at this time.
investigation_findings: 13On August 6, 2024 at 10am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility and spoke with Administrator, Fernanda Perez-Rios. The purpose of this inspection was to deliver findings for the above complaint allegations. A health and safety inspection was conducted. During the investigation the allegations for staff are not properly supervising minors in care and staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for minors, interviews were conducted, documents were obtained, and video footage was reviewed. The interviews did not produce corroborating evidence to support allegations. Interviews revealed inconsistent statements and no witnesses to suggest allegations occurred. Review of video footage revealed that a client left the facility on an unauthorized absence and was followed by a staff on foot. There was no evidence that staff did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for clients. Statements indicated that clients felt safe while residing in the facility.

narrative:
On July 16, 2025, at 10:15 a.m., Erika Butler-Williams Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management – Incident investigation pertaining to Special Incident Report. LPA met with Residential Supervisor, Vanessa Napoles, and a health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The department received an Incident Report dated June 20, 2025. The Incident Report disclosed that on June 16, 2025 , Child 1 (C1) disclosed that they were physically abused, and inappropriately touched by Staff 1 (S1). C1 disclosed that Staff 2 (S2) snapped C1 bra. C1 also disclosed that Staff (3) speaks in a tone that amounts to emotional distress. During the investigation, LPA interviewed two staff and three clients, reviewed Personnel Report, client roster, C1 Needs and Services Plan, Placement Agreement, and internal investigation notes. Statements indicated that clients in care are not physically disciplined. There were no statements that staff speak to clients in care inappropriately. Statements consistently indicated that after an outing involving clients at another facility being caught stealing from a store, clients in care are required to snap their bras, empty their pockets and

pull up their pants legs to show that no items were taken while on an outing. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80022 (k) Plan of Operation. Based on review of Program Statement their is no indication that clients in care will be required snap their bras, empty their pockets and pull up their pants legs to show that no items were taken while on an outing. Exit interview was conducted with Vanessa Napoles. Appeal Rights were issued, and a copy of this report will be emailed to Vanessa Napoles@ vanessa.napoles@missionprephealthcare.com

On September 26, 2023 at 11:30am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility. The purpose of the visit is to conduct a Component III and Pre-Licensing inspection. LPA was met by Aja Chavez, Administrator and William Mara, Director of Business Systems and allowed access into the facility and conducted the tour of the facility. The facility will be licensed to care for six clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility layout is as follows: The entry way leads to the group room which has a large couch and chairs. There is a covered fireplace. Aja Chavez informed LPA that the fireplaces have been capped and will be inaccessible to clients in care. Next to the group room is the dining area with enough seating for clients and staff. Parallel to the dining room is the kitchen. The kitchen has a stove and microwave in the island. The burners are in good working condition. There is an oven, coffee maker, covered trash can and water dispenser in the kitchen as well. The laundry area has a washer and dryer. Above the washer and dryer are locked cabinets that contain cleaning supplies and bedding. In this hallway are more locked cabinets containing cleaning supplies. There is a therapy room outside of the laundry room that has a locked closet for supplies. There is a living room area with two small couches and two chairs. There is a tv on the wall and a locked closet with supplies. There is a bathroom for staff use that is in good working condition. The medication room has a locked cabinet and refrigerator for the clients medication. Attached to the wall in the medication room is a locked cabinet that contains all the facility keys. Cont 809-C

Bedroom #1 has two beds, a large closet and two small tables with lamps. LPA informed Administrator, Aja Chavez that a dresser is needed for room #1. There is a full bathroom inside the room that is in good working condition. Bedroom #2 & #3 have two twin beds, a closet, two small tables with lamps and dressers. There is an additional therapy room across from bedroom three that is inaccessible to clients without staff. Upstairs is a large therapy room that has desks and a large bathroom. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors are in good working order and the fire extinguishers are up to date until July 2025. The backyard has large seating area for clients and a swimming pool. The swimming pool is surrounded by a self latching fence that will stay locked when not in use. The pool is covered by a large suicide net. There is a walk way on the side of the home that leads to the front of the house where the shut off valves are located. The front of the home has a large driveway with enough parking for 8-10 cars. There is a detached garage which contains a game table and workout equipment. There is a locked cabinet with cleaning supplies. The van is a Toyota Sienna with current registration and insurance. There is a first aid kit and fire extinguisher in the trunk. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator, Aja Chavez.

On August 22, 2024, at 12:20 PM, Cheri Wilkerson, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) and JoAunne Griffin, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management – Incident investigation. LPA met with Nyaa Davis, Program Manager and Taylor Adams, Supervisor. A health and safety assessment was conducted prior to entering facility. The department received an Unusual Incident/Injury Report (LIC 624LE) dated June 29, 2024. The Incident Report disclosed that Staff 1 (S1) left the facility around 8 PM, leaving six (6) children in care unattended for 10 minutes. During the investigation, LPA interviewed two staff, requested and reviewed Personnel Report, client roster, and S1 termination documentation received via email. Based on the information obtained during this visit, evidence indicated that S1 was hired on May 5, 2024 as a Community Coordinator I. S1 engaged in a verbal altercation with children in care. S1 sent a mass message to Mission Prep Healthcare staff indicating that S1 quits and left the children in care unattended. S1 voluntarily terminated on June 29, 2024. Continued on LIC 809-C

Facility cited for violation of California Code and Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, Regulation 84065.2 Personnel Duties, 84072 Personal Rights. Evidence indicated that S1 left children unattended and spoke inappropriately to children during verbal altercation. Exit interview was conducted with Taylor Adams, Supervisor. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights will be emailed to taylor.adams@missionprephealthcare.com and Nyaa.davis@missionprephealthcare.com.

deficiencies.description:
Section 84065.2 Personal Duties
(b) child care staff shall perform the following duties:(1) supervision, protection, and care of children individually and in groups at all times. This requirement was not met as evidence by 
statements and documentary evidence which indicated that S1 left children unattended. This poses a health and safety risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Plan of correction was discussed, S1 voluntarily terminated on June 29, 2024.Staffing changes were implemented. LPA request personl rights training and sign in sheet be submitted by September 5, 2024. Documents will be submitted via email to: cheri.wilkerson@dss.ca.gov

Section 84072 Personal Rights
(d)	The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care...

(1)	To live in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home where they are treated with respect. This requirement was not met as evidence by 
statements indicated that S1 engaged in a veral altercation with children in care. This poses a health and safety risk to children in care.

narrative:
On October 21,2024 at 11am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting an Annual inspection to convert the provisional license to permanent. LPA was met by Program Manager, Nyaa Davis and was allowed access into and conducted the tour of the facility. The facility is licensed to care for six clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility layout is as follows : The entry way leads to the group room which has a large couch and chairs. There is a covered fireplace. The fireplaces have been capped and will be inaccessible to clients in care. Next to the group room is the dining area with seating for clients and staff. Parallel to the dining room is the kitchen. The kitchen has a stove and microwave in the island. The burners are in good working condition. There is an oven, coffee maker, covered trash can and water dispenser in the kitchen as well. There is a locked cabinet that contains the sharp utensils. The laundry area has a washer and dryer. Above the washer and dryer are locked cabinets that contain cleaning supplies and bedding. In this hallway are more locked cabinets containing cleaning supplies. There is a therapy room outside of the laundry room that has a locked closet for supplies. There is a living room area with two small couches and two chairs. There is a tv on the wall and a locked closet with supplies. There is a bathroom for staff use that is in good working condition. The medication room has a locked cabinet and refrigerator for the clients medication. Attached to the wall in the medication room is a locked cabinet that contains all the facility keys. Cont 809-C

Bedroom #1 has two beds, a large closet, two small tables with lamps and a dresser. Note: The window was broken and a work order has been placed to repair it. Clients have been moved out of the room until repair is completed. There is a full bathroom inside the room that is in good working condition. Bedroom #2 & #3 have two twin beds, a closet, two small tables with lamps and dressers. There is a full bathroom in the hallway in good working condition that will be used for bedroom #2 & #3. There is an additional therapy room across from bedroom three that is inaccessible to clients without staff. Upstairs is a large therapy room that has desks and a large bathroom. There is a locked Nursing station that is inaccessible to clients. This room is off limits to clients without staff. No signal system is in place. There is a fire alarm pull station upstairs and downstairs. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors are in good working order and the fire extinguishers are up to date until August 2026. The backyard has large seating area for clients and a swimming pool. The swimming pool is surrounded by a self latching fence that will stay locked when not in use. The pool is covered by a large suicide net. There is a walk way on the side of the home that leads to the front of the house where the shut off valves are located. The front of the home has a large driveway with enough parking for 8-10 cars. There is a detached garage which contains a game table and workout equipment. There is a locked cabinet with cleaning supplies. The van is a Toyota Sienna with current registration and insurance. There is a first aid kit and fire extinguisher in the trunk. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 84077(a)(2) Personal Services. Staff and client interviews indicated that children in care are not provided an allowance at least once month. There were no deficiencies cited at the time of the inspection.

On March 1, 2024 at 10am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Post Licensing inspection. LPA was met by Experiential Supervisor, Kailey Stapel and was allowed access into and conducted the tour of the facility. The facility is licensed to care for six clients, ages 12-17 years, ambulatory only. The facility layout is as follows : The Living Room has a large seating area that lines the living room walls. There is a fireplace that is covered, but the gas is capped and is inaccessible to clients in care. There is a book shelf with books and games for clients use. There is a TV attached to the wall. The dining room has a table with enough seating for staff and clients. There is another covered fireplace with the gas capped and will be inaccessible to clients in care. The kitchen is adjacent to the dining room and has a large stove with working burners, a microwave, coffee maker, covered trash can and refrigerator. The sharps are in a locked drawer that only staff and the chef have access to. All fire extinguishers are serviced until July 2025. The medication room has a double locked cabinet for clients medication and a locked refrigerator for medication that needs to be refrigerated. There is a locked cabinet were the facility keys are kept attached to the wall. Bedroom 1 and 2 have two twin beds, a desk, two small desks with lamps and a closet with cubbies for the clients clothing. Bedroom 3 has two full sized beds, a desk, two small desks with lamps and two dressers for the clients clothing. There is a large bathroom inside of the room that has a locked linen closet filled with linen for the clients. Continued on 809-C

Upstairs: There is a large room with a table and a large couch that lines the rooms walls. This room is used for groups and some individual therapy. The access to this room downstairs has a locked door and is inaccessible to clients in care unless they are accompanied by a staff. There is no signal system. There is a bathroom located downstairs under the stairwell for staff use only. The bathroom in the hallway will be used for clients in room 1 and 2. There are two sinks, toilet and large shower all in good working condition. Also in the hallway is a Therapy room that can be locked and is inaccessible to clients in care. There are two sliding glass doors leading out to the backyard from the living room and the dining room. All doors and windows have door sensors on them to indicate when they have been opened and closed. The backyard has a large table with seating for clients in care. There is a swimming pool with a net fence that has a self latching door. This door is unlocked but will be kept locked when not in use. There is a suicide safety net that also covers the entire pool and jacuzzi. There is a Therapy room outside next to the pool that has a bathroom. On the side of the house is the shut off valves for the electricity. There is an air conditioning unit and a walkway that leads to the front of the house where the water shut off valves are located. The garage has three refrigerators for extra food storage, a pool table and exercise equipment for the clients use. There is a locked cabinet with cleaning supplies. The facility Van is a Toyota Sienna with current registration and insurance. There is a fire extinguisher and first aid kit in the trunk. There are two fire alarm pull switches. One is located on the wall downstairs and one is located upstairs. The smoke/carbon monoxide detectors are operable. All fire extinguishers are serviced until July 2025. LPA will return to do staff and client interviews. There are no deficiencies being sited at the time of the visit.
