Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward arrived at the facility at 9:30 AM to investigate complaint #34-CR-20250404092738. There was no one present at the facility so LPA contacted the corporate phone number to request that a person be sent to the location. At about 11:00 AM Ray-Philip Genaldo & Kailey Stapel arrived. LPA explained the reason for the visit and was informed that LPA Kenrick Ellis had already conducted the 10 Day-inspection on 04/11/2025. LPA contacted LPA Ellis and verified that he had conducted the 10 day response visit. LPA Jones-Steward thanked Mr. Genaldo & Ms. Stapel for their time and apologized for the mis-communication.

On 04/23/2025 at 11:00 AM, Component II of the application process for MK Behavioral Adolescent Health, located at 6260 Laurel Canyon Blvd., North Hollywood CA 91606, was held at the California Department of Social Services, Community Care Licensing Division - Children’s Residential Program - Regional Office in El Segundo. Present were Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dennis Jarmin, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Enrique Hernandez, and applicant Lillit Yegeiazaryan including Brent Bowers and Administrator, Luca Havik. The purpose of the Component II meeting was to review the submitted application and Program Statement, address outstanding items, and resolve any concerns. The following application forms were discussed: · Designation of Administrative Responsibility (LIC 308) · Criminal Record Exemption Request Transfer (LIC 9188) · Facility Sketch (LIC 999) · The sketch must include dimensions and designate the use of all rooms. It must show door and window exits and indicate emergency exit routes corresponding to the LIC 610/LIC 610A Emergency Disaster Plan. Rooms designated for non-ambulatory clients/residents and staff should be identified. · LIC 404 · Fire Inspection Report

Program Statement Discussion and Updates Required: · Program Philosophy, Goals, and Methods · Admission & Intake Procedures · Needs & Service Plans · Discharge & Removal Procedures · Visitation Policy · House Rules & Discipline · Behavior Management & Crisis Intervention · Medical, Psychiatric & Dental Care · Education & IEP Coordination · Staffing, Training, and Supervision · Emergency Preparedness · Health Sanitation Practices · Additional Compliance Considerations The applicant was advised that all revisions and corrections to the application and Program Statement are due by May 9, 2025. A Pre-Licensing Inspection is scheduled for May 14, 2025, 10:00 AM. A copy of this report will be provided to the applicant, Lillit Yegiazaryan.

On May 14, 2025, at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Dennis Jarmin with LPA Aimee Moratalla conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at MK Adolescent Behavioral Health, located at 11044 McBroom St. Sunland CA 91040. LPA met with applicant, Lilit Yegiarzan, GH Administrator-Luca Havik, and GH Consultant-Brent Bowers. At the time of the visit, there were no children in placement. The facility is seeking licenses to provide care for ambulatory minors between the ages of 12 through 17 Males only. As there were no children in placement, no client interviews were conducted, and no client files were available for review. The only interviews conducted was with the applicant and Administrator. Facility Overview: The 2 story home was clean, organized, and free from safety hazards. It includes 5 bedrooms, 4 full bathrooms and 1/2 bath, a living room, a dining/family room, a kitchen, a laundry room, and a family/recreational room. There is no body of water on the property, and it’s fenced in, fully covered and inaccessible. There are several closets available throughout the home. Living Room: The living room has a large sectional sofa. There are 7 fire extinguisher mounted on the wall throughout the home. The non-operable fireplace is enclosed with safety cover; however, the applicant was advised to ensure that the fireplace is in accessible. The home has central air and heat with 4 carbon monoxide monitor that is operable.

Kitchen: The kitchen is clean and well maintained. It includes one refrigerator/freezer, a large oven, with five working burners and a hood that is maintained regularly, a microwave, and a toaster. Garage and Backyard: The detached garage is used for storage and remains locked. The backyard is spacious, clean, and free of hazards. It features a play area and outside cameras were identified. Health and Safety Compliance: The home is equipped with 11 smoke detectors in all required areas, and all were tested and operational. There are 4 surveillance cameras for the outside perimeter. The property has central heating and air conditioning. Gas, water, and power shut-off valves and all valves are located in the back area of the home. Facility Vehicle: LPAs observed a 2023 Ford Transit Van parked on-site. The vehicle registration is valid but licensee was asked to provide a copy of the registration and the license plate once received. Vehicle is insured by Progressive, with the next renewal scheduled for September 2025. COMP III - After the Pre-licensing, LPA Jarmin with LPA Moratalla conducted the COMPONENT III with the applicant, administrator and consultant. Exit Interview: An exit interview was conducted with administrator. A copy of this report will be emailed and provided.

On 12/13/21 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager Jackie Ruan and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARES Inspection Tool to complete the inspection. The facility is clean, well-maintained, and in safe condition. Residents have individual beds with clean linens and mattress pads. Food is of the quality and quantity necessary to meet the needs of residents in care. The facility is operating in accordance with the license. The following items were observed that need to be addressed: 1) Staff S1 and S2 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 12/13/21) files were missing 1st Aid / CPR certificates. 2) Staff S1 and S2 files were missing LIC 508 Criminal Record Statement. 3) Quarterly disaster drills need to be conducted, documented, and that documentation maintained on site. 4) Resident R1 file / P&I Binder is missing LIC 405 Record of Resident's Safeguarded Cash Resources, and Residents R1 and R2 files are missing LIC 621 Resident Personal Property and Valuables. 5) Residents R1, R2, and R3 files are missing LIC 627B Consent for Emergency Medical Treatment. 6) Residents R2 and R3 files are missing LIC 602 Physician's Report and TB test. Residents were recently placed, but just over 30 days ago. Licensee stated there have been challenges with insurance and finding an available local doctor. Licensee agreed to place residents' most current medical assessment from their previous placement in their files while awaiting appointments. There is one citation, of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Section 80075 Health Related Services and five technical advisories of CCR Sections 80066, 80070, 84070, and 80069 and Health and Safety Code Section 1565. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Jackie Ruan, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Facility Manager Jackie Ruan; Administrator Rod Nubla
narrative: On 10/13/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a required annual inspection at the facility. LPA met with Facility Manager Jackie Ruan and Administrator Rod Nubla and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA toured the facility site, interviewed two staff and two residents, and reviewed facility records. LPA observed the facility to be clean and organized. There is a large supply of food within date, and no expired or spoiled foods were observed. Kitchen and bathroom spaces are maintained in sanitary condition. The room temperature and hot water temperature are maintained at safe and comfortable temperatures within the permitted ranges. Bedrooms are tidy and offer individual beds with clean linens and ample storage space. The facility has multiple activity spaces, which are decorated and maintained in safe condition. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, no deficiencies were observed. A continuation inspection is required to complete the file review portion of the inspection. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Jackie Ruan, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 12/12/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a POC visit at the facility. LPA met with Facility Manager Jackie Leonard and over the phone with Administrator Rod Nubla and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA's visit was regarding 5 citations issued on 10/31/23, for which plans of correction (POCs) were developed and each due 11/30/23. See LIC 809 Case Management (Annual Continuation), dated 10/31/23. LPA confirmed with the administrator that the POCs had not been completed. LPA was unable to verify completion of the POCs during today's visit due in part to files not being available for review. LPA reviewed available files and discussed the corrections that are still needed with Facility Manager. LPA is assessing a civil penalty for late POC, pursuant to California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80054, of $100 per day beginning the POC due date for each POC not completed. The civil penalty comes to $1,200 each for 5 late POCs, totalling $6,000. LPA advises that this is an accruing penalty and the POCs should be submitted by the end of today (12/12/23) to avoid additional penalty. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, an additional copy of the 10/31/23 report was provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager Jackie Leonard, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. LPA also emailed the report to Administrator Rod Nubla prior to exiting the facility.

On 10/31/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management annual continuation inspection. See LIC 809 Annual/Required, dated 10/13/23. LPA met with Facility Manager Jackie Ruan and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA inspected five resident records and five personnel records. See LIC 811 Confidential Names. Using the CARE Inspection Tool, LPA observed that five resident records were missing LIC 613B personal rights forms, four resident files were missing property and valuables records, one resident file was missing a medical consent form, and one resident file was missing a physician's report (medical assessment and TB test result). Additionally, three residents' ages exceed the facility's licensed age range, and LPA advises that age exception requests be submitted for each resident, as identified on the LIC 811. LPA also observed that the complete personnel files for S1, S2, and S3 were not available for review during the initial visit and this continuation visit, so LPA was unable to verify the LIC 501, LIC 503, LIC 9052, 1st aid certification, intervention training certification, and initial and annual training completion. LPA is issuing 5 citations of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Sections 80066 Personnel Records, 80070 Client Records, 84070 Children's Records, 80069 Client Medical Assessments, and 84072 Personal Rights. See attached LIC 809-D pages. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was provided to Facility Manager Jackie Ruan, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.title: At admission, each child, and his/her authorized representative, shall be personally advised of and given a copy of the child’s rights as specified in Subsection d below

narrative:
On 10-21-22 10:25 AM, Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Annual/Random inspection at listed facility. LPA's met with Jackie Ruan, Lead Staff and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call and mask wearing. The Group Home is licensed to serve six clients. Present during the inspection were two staff and one client. At 12:20 PM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed four bedrooms and two bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be NUMBER 111.1 degrees, which is in range. The thermostat read 68 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in the kitchen cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed two staff and one client. Staff and clients interacted together peacefully. At 12:45 LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At 10:30 AM LPA Karkazis reviewed client and staff files. Client files were in order. There was a deficiency with Staff Files, staff 2 did not have form LIC 503, Health Screening. In addition, the deficiency of emergency drills shall be documented and the documentation maintained in the facility for at least one year, was not present in file review. continued on 809-C

At this time, there were deficiencies cited, Title 22 Group Home Regulations 80066(a)(10) Health Screen Form, and a Technical Violation 80023(d)(2) documenting and storing drills at facility for one year An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Rod Nubla, Administrator

On 10/23/24 at 10:45am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at listed facility. LPA met with Jackie Ruan, Lead Staff. The Group Home is licensed to serve 6 clients ages 6-17. Present during the inspection were 4 staff and 2 clients. At 11:00am, LPA Pierotti reviewed client and staff files. LPA reviewed 4 client files and found that C1 was missing Admission Agreement and Personal Rights form, C3 was missing Consent Forms, and C4 was missing Admission Agreement and Personal Rights form. LPA reviewed 6 staff files and found that S2 was missing LIC198 and LIC503, S3 was missing LIC198, S4 was missing LIC198, S5 was missing LIC198 and LIC503, and S6 was missing LIC198. LPA also observed S3, S5, and S6 did not have background clearance. The facility is being cited for California Code of Regulation 80018(e)(1) Criminal Record Clearance, with civil penalties. At 12:30pm, LPA Pierotti toured the facility. LPA Pierotti observed 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. The thermostat read 73 degrees which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. The facility is in good repair and clean. At 1:00pm, Rod Nubla, Administrator, joined the inspection. LPA and Administrator went over the missing documents for client and staff files. Continue on LIC812

The required Annual Inspection was unable to be completed today. LPA Pierotti will return to the facility at a later date to complete the inspection. At 2:45pm, Rod Nubla had to leave. LPA finished today's inspection with Lead Staff. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and copy of this report was given to Lead Staff, whose signature confirms receipt.

SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Oquendo on 5/6/21 at 12:30PM. LPA spoke with licensee - Rod Nubla, who also sent the requested file documents for review. This inspection was conducted via FaceTime due to COVID19 restrictions on conducting on-site inspections at licensed facilities. LPA viewed the medications, which were locked in a cabinet, located inside the locked staff office. Facility has a capacity of six, with one child in placement. This child is currently prescribed three psychotropic medications and is non-verbal. This facility previously received an SB 484 inspection in 2018. No deficiencies were cited during that inspection but an advisory note was issued to the licensee. LPA conducted exit interview and requested additional documents from the Licensee.

... training, and the facility administrator/licensee is a certified ProAct instructor. Based on confidential interview, staff do received in-house informal training during staff meetings, but this training is not clearly reflected in the staff training logs. Additionally, not all staff have a current training log. It is not clear if in-house training was provided to meet the annual training requirements for staff, as they are not well documented. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. Due to the challenges of providing training during the pandemic, LPA is issuing a technical advisory per Title 22 Section 84066 Personnel Records, referencing Section 84065 Personnel Requirements. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager Jomar Dela Peña, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/19/21 at 10AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to deliver complaint investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager Jomar Dela Peña and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA conducted screening call with Licensee prior to visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing, hand hygiene, and social distancing. During investigation, confidential interviews with staff and youth's authorized representative and record reviews were conducted. Based on report, the allegation pertain to nonverbal resident R1's (See LIC 811 Confidential Names) medication and to an incident in which R1 was kneed in the groin by staff. It was determined that the medication was managed and administration documented correctly and that the incident was not one of abuse. However, it is not clear if the incident may have been the result of a lack of training. Based on LPA's review of staff training, staff have not received their full amount of annual training, and some have received only 4 hours of training in 2020. It is reported that this is due to the pandemic. Training titles do not include behavioral intervention (manual restraints) or medication management. Staff do have current CPR

narrative:
On Friday 9/3/21 at 9:25AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Rod Nubla and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. LPA used the Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. There are six children in care, and five children were at school. There are seven staff, and two staff are present, plus Licensee. LPA toured the facility site and observed: -- The facility site and grounds are clean, free of debris and hazards, and is well-maintained. -- Food is properly stored, is fresh and within date, and meets the 7-day nonperishable, 2-day perishable mandate to meet the needs of residents in care. The kitchen is stocked with utensils and dishware. -- Medications, sharps, and chemicals are all locked and inaccessible to residents in care. A razor was found in the cabinet in the hallway resident bathroom. Licensee stated residents are able to shave but are watched and assisted by staff, and per their care plans, no residents have self-harm behaviors involving sharp items. -- The smoke detectors were tested and are functioning. -- The first aid kit was centrally stored and contained all required items. -- Hot water and room temperature were maintained within permitted ranges, at 115.9 F and 69 F, respectively. LPA inspected the facility files and observed: -- The client files are complete and contain all required documentation. Medication records are complete and indicate consistent and proper administration of medications. [CONTINUED NEXT PAGE]

-- LPA observed that the inventory of belongings were old (from 2017) and not current, or were missing. LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Section 80070, that the facility update the inventories and ensure current records are maintained. -- LPA observed that the medication records were well organized, but the psychotropic medications, while logged separately, were not logged on a separate sheet. LPA advised that Licensee begin using the LIC 622B, or variation of, to log psychotropic medications. -- The staff files are complete and contain all required documentation. All staff are cleared and associated to the facility. Staff have current first aid training certificates. -- LPA observed that the training documentation does not reflect that the 20 hour annual training requirement, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84065, was met for 2020. Licensee stated that it has been a challenge to obtain training from outside agencies but training in the form of team meetings with Licensee and with behaviorist have been conducted in-house. LPA advised that Licensee develop an in-house training template to document in-house trainings. -- LPA observed that staff S1 (See LIC 811 Confidential Names, dated 9/3/21) was cleared and associated to the sister facility also under Licensee but not to this facility. S1 works at the other facility and has only been working at this facility temporarily. However, as S1 has been working at this facility for at least a few months, LPA advises, per CCR, Title 22, Section 80019, that S1's clearance be transferred to this facility. -- The license, menu, emergency plan, and personal rights are posted in visible locations in the facility. -- LPA observed that the complaint procedures were not posted in the facility. LPA advises, per CCR, Title 22, Section 84072.2, that Licensee print and post the complaint procedures in the facility in a location visible to residents, authorized representatives, and visitors. LPA conducted resident observation and staff interviews: -- Resident present during visit appeared happy and was being engaged by attentive staff and participating in activities with staff. -- Staff are knowledgeable about the needs of residents in care, program procedures, and mandated reporter status. There are no citations. Six advisories were provided. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Rod Nubla, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/13/22 at 3:16PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility regarding an incident report that was submitted to the Licensing agency. LPA met with Lead Staff Jomar Delapena and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call with Licensee Rod Nubla. During visit, LPA interviewed three staff and attempted interviews with involved residents. LPA reviewed resident records and obtained relevant resident documents and authorized representative contact information. Further investigation is needed at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Lead Staff Jomar Delapena, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

An unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng on 5/31/2022 at 11:15AM. During the inspection, LPA Ng met with Rod Nubla, Administrator and inspected the facility inside and out. LPA reviewed 6 of child’s records on site at the facility at 12:00 PM. LPA reviewed 3 of staff personnel files on site at the facility at 2:00 PM. LPA reviewed 6 of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records at 12:00 PM. LPA interviewed 2 of staff on site at 11:36 AM. LPA interviewed 0 of children currently taking psychotropic medication at 2:30 PM. Four clients were at school and two were on a community outing. All clients are non-verbal and unable to answer or understand interview questions. Therefore, LPA did not interview clients. LPA conducted exit interview with Rod Nubla, Administrator at 2:30 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Rod Nubla, Administrator upon completion. LPA did however, issue a Technical Assistance in regards to staff document maintenance. LPA conducted exit interview and left a copy of the report with the Administrator at 2:45 PM.

On 7/13/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility regarding an incident report that was submitted to the Licensing agency. LPA met with Lead Staff Jomar Delapena and Cesar Redota and informed of the purpose of the visit. An initial visit was made on 4/13/22. Based on confidential interviews with staff and LPA's observation at the facility, the residents involved in the inappropriate behavior at night while they were roommates have been separated into different rooms and are monitored by staff during the day to ensure no further inappropriate behavior, and there have been no similar incidents since. During visit, LPA observed the residents to all be engaged and interact well with each other with no evidence of any discomfort or inappropriate behavior between residents. There are no deficiencies cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left with Lead Staff Jomar Delapena, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

met_with: Lead Staff Cesar Redota and Jomar Delapena
narrative: On 7/13/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility to issue a citation for a deficiency observed during a visit at the facility. LPA met with Lead Staff Cesar Redota and Jomar Delapena and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA spoke to Administrator Rod Nubla over the phone. Rod approved for Jomar and Cesar to represent facility for today's visit. Rod confirmed that Lead Staff Jomar and Cesar are not facility managers and that there was no LIC 308 Designation of Facility Responsibility for any staff as no staff had been designated a facility manager. LPA did not observe these forms in the file. LPA is issuing a citation of Health and Safety Code 1522.4(a)(3). See attached LIC 809-D. During visit, a youth in care called 911, and staff did not respond to the emergency personnel's requests to speak to a staff member. The youth had the phone on the speaker setting, so as youth approached LPA, LPA could overhear. LPA directed staff that the speaker was requesting to speak to a staff, and staff continued to not respond. Staff did not understand LPA's direction. LPA requested the phone from the youth and spoke to the emergency personnel on behalf of the facility. Afterward, LPA spoke to staff, and staff stated that the youth has called 911 multiple times before and is to be monitored while on the youth's personal phone to ensure youth does not unintentionally call 911. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80065(a). See attached LIC 809-D. During visit, LPA toured the facility and observed there were three beds in the garage. Based on confidential interviews, all beds are being used by staff. LPA observed dressers and cabinets with staff clothing and belongings next to the beds in the garage. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Section 84087(b)(4)(A). See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Lead Staff Jomar Delapena, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

investigation_findings: 13At 1:45PM on 12/7/2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Karmen Balhotra made an unannounced complaint inspection to the facility listed above. The reason for the inspection is to notify the facility listed above. LPA met with Rod Nubla, Administratror who helped facilitate the inspection. Over the course of the investigation, LPA conducted confidential interviews and a file review for the allegation listed above. Evidence obtained revealed that the allegation of minor sustained an injury while in care is unsubstantiated. Evidence revealed that an incident took place in July of 2022 which resulted in client falling from the facility van and onto the pavement below directly on their back during a client behavior. In addition, evidence revealed that client was being seen by their physician regarding a rash that was on their back. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the allegations above occurred. At this time, no California Code of Regulations are being cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be emailed to Administrator.

narrative:
On 5.24.2023 at 1:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced inspection to conduct an annual required inspection. LPA met with Rod Nubla, Administrator. Facility has census of six clients. Two clients came home at 1:15 PM. Safety precautions were used such as temperature reading, sanitizing of the hands, mask wearing, and social distancing. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct the inspection. The facility and grounds are clean, tidy, and free of obstructions. There are no hazards on the premises and no firearms, per Administrator. There were three client bedrooms and one staff bedroom. All bedrooms are double occupancy, and beds have clean linens and mattress pads. There is enough storage for residents' personal belongings. Food is of good quality, within date, and stored properly. First aid kit was observed to be complete. Room temperature was 72 degrees and was maintained at a comfortable temperature within permitted range. Water temperature measured at 120.4 which is in the permitted range. Both clients who were home were non-verbal. Residents present during visit appeared happy and was being engaged by attentive staff and participating in activities with staff. LPA conducted two staff interviews. At 2:30 PM, LPA Ng toured the backyard. The backyard has a wooden fence. A swing set was located in the middle of backyard. A wooden gazebo was located on the side of the backyard. No open bodies or water or hazards were present. All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client and staff has their own separate binder of all required documents. All staff and client records were observed to be complete except for the following : -------CONTINUE TO 809C----------

LPA Ng reviewed medication logs for all six clients. LPA Ng noticed that the psychotropic medication did not have their own separate log. LPA advises per CCR regulation, 84070(b)(13), Children's Records. Please see 809D. All but one client in the home are all over 18. Clients ages are 22, 21, 21,21,19, and 17. LPA advises facility to submit a Adult Residential application. LPA advises per CCR regulation, 80010(a), Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status. Administrator discussed the process of converting to an Adult Residential Facility. Administrator will let LPA know the timeline and give monthly updates. At this time, 1 deficiency was cited and a technical violation was given. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rod Nubla, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 2/13/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit. LPA met with Facility Manager George Pastera and informed of the purpose of the visit. During an investigation at the facility, LPA became aware of an area in which technical assistance may be beneficial. See LIC 9102 dated 2/13/24. investigation_findings: 13On 2/13/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a follow-up complaint investigation visit in order to deliver investigation findings. LPA met with Facility Manager George Pastera and Administrator Rod Nubla and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential record review, observation, and interviews with staff, case workers, and other witnesses, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur. Therefore, the finding is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Facility Manager George Pastera, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On 4/3/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit in order to follow-up on a submitted incident report. LPA met with Administrator Rod Nubla and informed of the purpose of the visit. The incident in question is one where a resident exited the facility through their bedroom window around 2AM, and staff became aware when the resident was returned to the facility by police around 2:55AM. LPA discussed the incident with Administrator, who stated running away has been a trend in behavior for the resident at the facility and at school. The resident's quarterly care plan indicates "AWOL" is a targeted behavior. The plan does not specify a requirement for bedroom checks at night. Administrator stated they will be planning on scheduling a meeting with the resident's regional center case manager to discuss enhancing supervision, including hourly bedroom checks at night. At this time, evidence does not confirm that a deficiency or violation resulted in this incident occurring. No citations were issued at today's visit. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rod Nubla, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/3/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit. LPA met with Administrator Rod Nubla and informed of the purpose of the visit. The purpose of the visit was to give notice of area(s) in which technical support may be beneficial. During an investigation at the facility, LPA observed that the medication records for a resident in care had not been updated to include a new medication in the centrally stored medication log, and a medication administration record had not been prepared for the medication. LPA reviewed the records with Administrator at today's visit. The records reflected that the medication had been administered first on 3/21/24 morning, but no records were observed on 3/21/24 around noon reflecting administration or storage of the medication. All records were complete as of today. LPA is advising that the facility ensure all staff are trained to update medication storage records upon receipt of the medication and to prepare medication administration records prior to administration. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Administrator Rod Nubla, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

LPAs found that the facility had no clients that met SB484 Psychotropic Medications inspection criteria. LPAs reviewed the locked medication and centrally stored medication binders. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility. LPAs observed no deficiencies. LPAs conducted an exit interview with Rod Nubla, Administrator at 11:45am whose signature confirms the receipt of this document.

investigation_findings: 13On 7/10/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver findings for the investigation of the above complaint allegation. LPA met with Lead Staff Joey Dela Pena and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews, observations, and record review, including review of police investigation report and interviews with alleged victim and suspect, it was alleged that a staff member hit a resident with an open hand on the face. The preponderance of evidence reflects that this incident did occur. Therefore, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and the above allegation is found to be substantiated. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072 Personal Rights. See LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Lead Staff Joey Dela Pena.

deficiencies.description:
84072(d)(19) To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, exploitation, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on observation, interview, and record review, licensee did not ensure environment free of abuse or intimidation due to staff hitting resident, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to retrain all staff on anger management and working as a team, including switching out with another staff member when growing frustrated.  The training guide, certificate if applicable, and list of attendees will be submitted to LPA as evidence of completion.

narrative:
On February 4, 2021 at 2:10 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Charmetha White made an announced tele-visit to Morada Home for the purpose of conducting a Post-Licensing Inspection visit. LPA met with Administrator, Abiola Quadri who provided a virtual tour of the facility via Google Duo. This facility is licensed to provide care and supervision to four (4) ambulatory, developmentally disabled male and female clients ages 7 -17 years old. The census today is three (3) clients. The home was observed to be set-up as follows: This is a single story home with three (3) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, living room, dinning area, kitchen, laundry area, detached garage, an office, and a backyard. Living room: is equipped with 3 sofas, a mounted TV, and a fireplace with a locked screen. Dining area: is equipped with a table and four (4) chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a stove with five (5) burners all working at this time. A microwave mounted above the stove, a dishwasher, and a refrigerator/freezer. The home was observed to have two days of perishable food and one week of nonperishable food supplies. Clients are provided nutritious snacks between meals. Trash can had a lid. Sharp knives are kept in a locked safe on the kitchen counter top. Medications that do not require refrigeration are kept in a locked kitchen cabinet. There are no clients that require refrigerated medications. Laundry Area: is located along the hallway. There are two locked cabinets in the laundry area, one contains extra hygiene products for the clients and one contains laundry detergent and cleaning supplies. All cleaning solutions are made inaccessible to the clients. Office: is located off the backyard and it is kept locked. The office is equipped with a desk, one (1) chair, and two (2) file cabinets. Client and staff files are stored in the office. Report continued on LIC 809C.

Bedroom #1: Is occupied by Client #1 and the room is equipped with one twin size bed. The room has adequate drawers, closet space, lighting, and a window. Bedroom #2: Is occupied by Client #2 and the room is equipped with one twin size bed. The room has adequate drawers, closet space, lighting, and a window. Bedroom #3: Is occupied by Client #3. The room is equipped with two twin size beds. The room has adequate drawers, closet space, lighting, and a window. This room also contains bathroom #2. Bathrooms: Bathroom #1 is located along the hallway. Bathroom #2 is located inside of bedroom #3. Both bathrooms were checked and observed to be in good repair and working order. The home is equipped with 2 regulation fire extinguishers. Smoke alarms and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. The first aid kit was checked and found to be complete. There are no swimming pools or bodies of water on the premises. No weapons are at the facility. Overall LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Passageways and open porches are unobstructed. The front and back yards were inspected and found be clear of hazards and debris. The facility has a Grey 2010 Toyota Sienna, clean and in good repair to transport clients. Current automobile insurance is with Infinity Insurance Company. Children in care are supervised and protected at all times. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. Children can contact the licensing agency or Foster Care Ombudsman person in confidence without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children attend school, extracurricular, cultural and personal enrichment activities. Facility was reminded to report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Facility reports client injuries requiring medical treatment. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: was Current and available for review. Emergency Disaster Mass Casualty Plan: Designation/staff assignments current. Facility operates within license conditions & limitations including capacity limitations. All posting requirements were met. The home is within Title 22 regulation standards at this time. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was emailed to Administrator.

investigation_findings: 13On October 12, 2021 at 1pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Donald Martin conducted a follow-up complaint inspection and spoke to Oneisha James, Facility Administrator. The purpose of the inspection was to provide findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations for facility staff physically abused group home child, facility staff made inappropriate comments to group home child and facility staff denied group home child food as a form of punishment, LPA conducted interviews. The interviews did not produce corroborating evidence to support said allegations. Interviews revealed inconsistent statements and no witnesses to suggest allegations occurred. There was no evidence that facility staff physically abused the group home child. The police stated that there was no physical evidence of bruising on the child during the visit. Cont. 9099-C

13On October 15, 2021 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmetha White arrived at the above location for the purpose of concluding the investigation and to deliver findings on the above allegations. LPA met with Facility Administrator, Oneisha James and discussed the findings. During the course of this investigation, LPA interviewed pertinent parties and reviewed records. Interviews and records did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegations. Staff denied the allegations. Staff stated they have never witnessed any staff smoking marijuana in the presence of minors. However, Staff #1 did confirm a staff was terminated for bringing marijuana to the facility. Staff stated none of the staff have ever pushed or physically abused any of the minors in care. Children interviewed stated the staff treat them fine and that staff do not push or hit them. Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection March 16, 2023, at 10:28 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection, 5 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 3 out of 3 youth files were reviewed. 2 out of 9 Direct Care Staff and 1 out of 3 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated March 16, 2023). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Administrator Abiola Quadri.

narrative: A1 stole personal identifying information of approximately several individuals to file 72 fraudulent unemployment insurance and 19 fraudulent disability insurance claims from 2020 until present. A1 caused over $800,000 in unemployment insurance losses and over $200,000 in disability insurance losses to the State of California. Information obtained revealed in part that A1 pleaded guilty to fraudulently using stolen personal identifying information to file for unemployment insurance and disability insurance claims through Employment Development Department. Based on record review and confidential interviews, the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Therefore, the allegation that Licensee/Board member (A1) was arrested for COVID Insurance fraud and identity theft is substantiated. This poses an immediate health, safety, and personal rights risk of harm to children placed in care. The facility is issued citation in accordance with Health and Safety Code section 1558 Persons prohibited from employment; dismissal or removal. (See page LIC9099-D for cited deficiency). An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, and appeal rights were provided to Facility Administrator via email.
investigation_findings: 13On 5/21/2025 at 2:15 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Regina Martin arrived at Morada Home and met with Zerlene Graham, Facility Representative/Manager to deliver investigation findings concerning the above-mentioned allegation. Also present via telephone was Oneisha James, Facility Administrator. On 11/7/2024, Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD), received a complaint alleging conduct inimical as a Facility Board member was reportedly arrested for COVID Insurance fraud and identity theft. The allegation was referred to CCLD Investigations Branch, Investigator Dennis Seng. The investigation revealed, based on facility file review, and interviews conducted with pertinent parties, there was enough evidence to prove the alleged. Confidential interviews with the Department of Homeland Security Special Agent, Employment Development Department State Investigator and the United States Postal Service Office of Inspector General as well as review of corresponding reports from outside agencies found corroborating evidence that Adult (A1) was arrested for Unemployment Insurance and Disability Insurance Fraud. (Continued on page LIC9099-C)
