At 1:05PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Madi Fremont and AmyLe Tran met with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a COVID-19 Technical Assistance Case Management Inspection. LPAs met with Licensee and Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, Morning Star Behaviorist Consultant Leatrice Tomlinson, Assistant Administrator Irma Battung, Assistant Administrator Gilbert Battung, and California Department of Public Health (San Bernardino) Health Facilities Evaluator Nurse Emma Erickson. Currently in care are 5 clients. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 11/04/2020) The specific purpose of this inspection was for the home to receive guidance on visitation policies and Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) usage in the facility. LPAs asked Nurse Emma Erickson to provide the facility with guidance on creating a safety plan for visitation in the facility to ensure the safety of all clients and staff. LPA Fremont informed Ms. Erickson that the father of C1 and C2 (hereafter referred to as P1) is willing to get a COVID-19 test and quarantine until results come, there is no court order restricting P1 from visiting C1 and C2, and C1 and C2 share their own bedroom. Based on this information, LPA asked Ms. Erickson to guide the facility in creating a plan for P1 to safely visit C1 and C2 either in the backyard, front yard, or in their shared bedroom while also ensuring social distancing the safety of all staff and clients.Ms. Erickson advised that the best course of action for visitation is to continue to have visits through the front screen door or backyard window so social distancing can be maintained. Ms. Erickson also advised that if there is physical contact made, the clients will need to quarantine in the home for 14 days and have a staff member assigned to quarantine with them to provide care, or have the parent take their child home for the duration of COVID-19. LPA Fremont advised the Licensee to utilize pre-screening calls with the families to ensure that no symptoms are present, and no contact has been made with a COVID-19 positive person before a visit. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Pre-screening questions can include: 1. Have you experienced any symptoms of COVID-19 in the last 14 days? 2. Have you come in contact with anyone experiencing symptoms or anyone who has tested positive in the last 14 days? 3. Have you been placed under quarantine order by a medical professional in the last 30 days? 4. Are you currently being evaluated by a medical professional for symptoms of COVID-19? LPA Fremont requested the following points to be addressed in the visitation plan for C1 and C2: 1. Schedule for visitation for each family, including procedure for keeping the rest of the clients and staff separate from the visitation space. 2. Procedure for family entry to the front yard or back yard 3. Procedure for visiting through the front screen door or the backyard window, including physical barriers that will be put in place to ensure the safety of all clients and staff 4. Behavioral/emotional effects/barriers/obstacles that each child could face as a result of modified visitation procedures 5. De-escalation techniques for each child 6. Use of PPE for both parents and clients 7. Pre-screening calls with families prior to visits that confirm the absence of symptoms, including a contact screening. 8. Procedures for if physical contact is accidentally made, including but not limited to parent bringing their child home for quarantine. 9. A statement that all procedures are subject to change based on changing directive from Contra Costa County Public Health Department. 10. The Licensee may request a negative COVID-19 test before visitation, to be documented on printed test results from a primary care provider for all family members. A plan for refusal of testing must be put in place. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

Regarding PPE, LPAs requested that Ms. Erickson provide the Licensee with guidance on staff mask usage while in the home. Because not all staff of the facility live in the home 24/7, and some staff come in and out of the home to go to the grocery store, appointments, etc., LPA Fremont strongly encouraged the Licensee to require mask usage at all times for all staff in the facility - not just for the safety of the clients but the safety of other staff. Ms. Erickson agreed that masks should be mandated at all times for all staff while in the home At this time, no deficiencies are being cited. The Licensee will have until 5PM on 11/12/2020 to submit a plan for P1 to visit C1 and C2 at the home, and will also submit any new visitation plans for C3, C4, and C5 no later than 5PM on Monday, 11/30/2020. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung with read receipt due to COVID-19 precautions.

At 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Madi Fremont and AmyLe Tran met with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Case Management Inspection. LPAs met with Administrator/Licensee Reggieanne Villar-Battung, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were Assistant Administrator Irma Battung, Morning Star Behavioral Consultant Leatrice Tomlinson, and California Department of Public Health Nurse Barbie Henson. Currently in care are 5 ambulatory clients. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 11/12/2020) The specific purpose of this Case Management inspection was for the facility to receive guidance from Ms. Henson on creating visitation plans for their clients that are within safety guidelines for COVID-19. LPA Fremont inquired about the status of the visitation plan for C1 and C2, which was requested on 10/04/2020, with a deadline for submittal today, 11/12/2020 at 5PM. LPA Fremont invited the licensee to voice any concerns they may have about the plan to Ms. Henson, or ask any questions they may have regarding visitation. In consultation with Ms. Henson, the home has been advised to add to their visitation guidelines extra safety measures, including but not limited to limited physical touch (hug hello and hug goodbye), and using distractive techniques to keep C1 and C2 from pulling on Personal Protective Equipment (PPE). Parents will also be required to adhere to a time limit on visitation, to obtain a negative COVID-19 test within a specified timeframe (to be determined), and to wear full PPE (provided by the home) that is donned at the home, and doffed out of the home. This plan will be submitted no later than 5PM on Monday, 11/16/2020. LPA Fremont will present this visitation plan to Contra Costa County Department of Public Health to get approval before implementing the plan and presenting it to the parents. At this time, no deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung due to COVID-19 precautions.

At 1:53PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a virtual Case Management Inspection regarding an incident that occurred at the home on 11/20/2020. LPA met with Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung, who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 5 ambulatory clients. (See LIC811 - Confidential Names dated 12/10/2020) On 11/24/2020, LPA Fremont received a Serious Incident Report (SIR) from Admin. which described an incident involving C1 on 11/20/2020. During a neighborhood walk to a park nearby, C1 was escalated in behavior and threw herself on the ground where she started hitting her head. Staff and clients were picked up in the facility vehicle and taken back to the home, where C1 was monitored through the weekend. A bruise was observed on C1's forehead, as well as a client's chin being red. LPA Fremont conducted a confidential interview with S1, the named supervisor on the aforementioned SIR. LPA Fremont will triage this incident with supervisor, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, and the incident will be revisited at a later date. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee to be signed and returned.

At 2:03PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met virtually with the home above over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting an announced Case Management Inspection. The purpose of this Case Management Inspection was to address additional incidents that were discovered during Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives' record reviews and interviews. LPA met with Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were Morning Star Behavioral Consultant Leatrice Tomlinson, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, and LPA AmyLe Tran, East Bay Regional Center (RCEB) Case Manager Teena Decay, RCEB Case Manager Supervisor Ian Mendoza, and RCEB Quality Assurance Specialist Derrick Levingston. Currently in care are 5 clients. On 11/14/2020, LPA Fremont received a Serious Incident Report (SIR) from S1, which described an incident involving C1 on 11/20/2020. During a neighborhood walk to a nearby park with clients and staff, C1 started escalating in behavior, so staff decided it was time to head back to the home. On the way back, C1 threw herself onto the ground and started hitting her head against the concrete sidewalk. A bruise was observed on C1's forehead, as well as redness on her chin. Upon review of this SIR, it was discovered that this incident was not reported to C1's primary care provider or their authorized representative. On 12/10/2020 at 1:53PM, LPA Fremont conducted a confidential interview with S1 to follow-up on the incident. LPA Fremont asked S1 if this incident was reported to the primary care provider or C1's parent, and S1 responded it was not something they would report to either party because it was C1's typical behavior to bang her head. S1 also stated that they did not usually report incidents to the parent unless the parent was directly involved in the incident. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

In a document titled "Clarification of Reporting Requirements for Unusual Incidents Including Client Absences" released by CCL and submitted to LPA Fremont by S1 on 12/30/2020 at 2:58PM, it is stated, "With regard to severely emotionally disturbed clients in high level group homes, incidents which involve this clientele must be measured against the standards explained in this guide and not simply disregarded as their 'usual behavior.'" Based on the information gathered, including interviews and review of facility records, the licensee did not report to a child's authorized representative an unusual incident which threatened the physical safety of a client because they saw it as the client's normal behavior. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061(f) - Reporting Requirements. In addition, based on interview with S1 and review of the SIR submitted on 11/24/2020 regarding this incident, C1 hit their head on the concrete sidewalk hard enough to leave a bruise, but the licensee did not seek medical advice for this client's head injury from their medical provider and staff did not obtain appropriate medical information to observe signs and symptoms of a concussion. A deficiency is being cited per CCR, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80075(a) - Health Related Services. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. On 12/10/2020, during a virtual complaint investigation with the home, LPA Fremont requested several documents to be turned in for the investigation no later than 5PM on 12/14/2020. LPA Fremont emailed S1 on 12/10/2020 at 3:15PM to remind S1 of the requested documents and the deadline for submittal. S1 responded at 3:54PM and 4:18PM to inquire why LPA Fremont was investigating the allegations of the complaint opened that day, stating that another LPA had already investigated and found the complaint to be unfounded, and asked LPA Fremont for a copy of the old complaint report. On 12/10/2020 at 6:34PM, S1 responded to LPA Fremont again, asking why LPA Fremont has requested to tour the facility's staff room during the inspection earlier that day, and inquired if it was a new policy. On 12/14/2020 at 3:57PM, LPA Fremont sent an email to S1 to remind them of the previously agreed-upon deadline to submit requested complaint documents (12/14/2020 at 5PM), and attached the regulation 80044(c)(1) - Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency to provide technical assistance to S1. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

S1 responded to LPA Fremont on 12/14/2020 at 4:22PM and 4:49PM, stating both times that the home's printer/scanner wasn't working, and the printer was jammed. S1 submitted two of the requested documents at 5:10PM, and one at 5:49PM on 12/14/2020. S1 emailed LPA Fremont again on 12/14/2020 at 8:08PM and 8:48PM. In both emails, S1 asked again why LPA Fremont was investigating this new complaint received on 12/02/2020, stating that the allegation "Neglect/Lack of Care and Supervision" could not be true and asked for an explanation of how the clients could have been neglected. On 12/15/2020 at 10:09AM, LPA Fremont responded, again referencing regulation section 80044(c)(1) - Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency to provide technical assistance, and asked that S1 submit the remaining documents that were due the day before. S1 submitted the final requested document on 12/15/2020 at 4:57PM. The document submitted on 12/15/2020 was not the correct document LPA had requested, and LPA Fremont sent S1 clarifications on 12/17/2020 at 10:24AM, 2:01PM, and again on 12/21/2020 at 1:55PM, asking that the correct document be submitted as soon as possible as the deadline had already passed. The document requested was the facility's procedure for writing incident reports and guidelines for which kind of incidents were reportable. S1 responded on 12/21/2020 at 2:17PM, stating, "It's a very busy time of year right now with Christmas in a few days, I'm sure we have something written down from SIR trainings I've been to. Despite the pandemic, we are celebrating with the group home decorated, gifts for the kids, and a nice Christmas meal together, so my time is very limited around this time. I will email the info soon." On 12/28/2020 at 2:22PM, LPA Fremont emailed S1 to ask again for the correct documentation that was originally requested on 12/10/2020 and due on 12/14/2020. S1 turned in the correct documentation on 12/30/2020 at 2:58PM. During an unrelated complaint investigation on 01/06/2021, LPAs Fremont and Tran requested documentation to be used in their investigation, to be turned in no later that 5PM on 01/08/2021, a deadline which was agreed upon by S1. On 01/08/2021 at 4:44PM, S1 emailed LPAs Fremont and Tran stating it was her husband's birthday that day and scanning the documents was taking longer than expected. S1 submitted the requested documents on 01/08/2021 at 11:53PM and 11:57PM. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

On 01/11/2021 at 3:07PM, LPA Tran emailed S1 requesting contact information for the group home staff. LPA Tran did not get a response from S1 until 01/27/2021 at 5:45PM, at which time S1 stated, "Hi Amy, I saw this email a few weeks ago but couldn't find it when I was ready to send you the contact information. Do you still need it? I haven't heard from you." LPA Fremont emailed S1 on 01/28/2021 at 7:47AM, confirming that the documentation was still needed for ongoing complaint investigations, and asked for it to be submitted by the end of business hours the same day. S1 submitted the requested documentation on 01/28/2021 at 7:37PM. On 02/05/2021 at 2:06PM, LPA Fremont emailed S1 to request additional documentation of S2's administrator and facility manager qualifications. The deadline to submit was set for 02/09/2021 at 5PM. S1 responded at 3:53PM on 02/05/2021 to confirm the deadline. LPA Fremont sent a email to S1 on 02/09/2021 at 2:09PM to remind them of the deadline for submitting requested documents. S1 responded to LPA Fremont on 02/09/2021 at 4:34PM, stating that they were gathering the paperwork. S1 inquired why CCL was asking for owner's paperwork, also asking if this was a new policy. S1 turned in the requested documentation on 02/09/2021 at 5:35PM, after the agreed-upon deadline. Based on the information gathered, the Licensee did not make client records available for inspection by the licensing agency by repeatedly missing previously agreed-upon deadlines to submit documents. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80070(d) - Client Records. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. Additionally, based on multiple interactions with the Licensee/Administrator, as well as investigations into complaints received for the facility, the Licensee/Administrator has repeatedly shown a lack of knowledge and ability to comply with applicable law and regulation, including but not limited to: Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency, Reporting Requirements, Administrator Duties, Personal Rights, Client Records, Health Related Services, and Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. A deficiency is being cited per CCR, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80064(a)(3) Administrator Qualifications and Duties. . Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

On 01/05/2021, LPA Fremont received an email that detailed how on 01/10/2019, during Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) therapy that was held in the garage with C2, C2 bolted into the house to take some of C1's snack, causing the garage door to swing open and hit a filing cabinet inside the house. In this email it is detailed that in response to this incident, S2 locked C2 and her therapist in the garage from inside the house, stating they were a liability to the other clients and staff. During an interview with this witness on 01/07/2021 at 10:34AM, LPA Fremont asked them to describe this incident in more detail. This witness stated that the home had offered the garage for C2's ABA therapy, and that it quickly became unsafe for C2 to have therapy in this room. This witness confirmed that on 01/10/2019, C2 had eloped from the garage into the kitchen, and S2 had locked them in the garage after stating they were a safety concern to the other clients. This witness also stated that the garage was cold, unsafe, and cluttered, relating that there were tools such as a ladder, staple gun, and hammer out and accessible to clients, and small items on the floor that could have been swallowed. This witness also related that ABA services were discontinued at the home shortly after the locked door incident, due to safety concerns. Based on the information gathered, a client was locked in the garage of the facility to prevent them from entering the house during their in-house therapy service. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072(d)(14) - Personal Rights. Additionally, due to the presence and accessibility of items such as a ladder, staple gun, hammer, and small items that could have been swallowed by C2 during ABA therapy, a deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 7, Section 80087(g) – Buildings and Grounds. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. Finally, on 10/08/2020 at 1:30PM, representatives of CCL, Regional Center of the East Bay, and Morning Star Group Home met virtually on Microsoft Teams to discuss the home’s “no visitors” policy during the COVID-19 pandemic due to repeated complaints from a parent. (continued on LIC809-C)

During this meeting, an agreement was reached that the home would modify its visitation policy to allow for safe visitation from parents and other authorized representatives. The home raised concerns about this decision, and requested that another meeting be planned with a Contra Costa County Department of Public Health Nurse to go over safety guidelines. On 11/04/2020 at 1:05PM, LPAs Fremont and Tran conducted a virtual technical assistance case management inspection with the home, as well as with San Bernardino County Department of Public Health Nurse Emma Erickson, to discuss the home’s visitation plan. Due to the shortage of nurses at that time, CCL was not able to schedule a nurse from Contra Costa County. During this meeting, all parties discussed barriers and challenges to visitation, and a decision was made that the home would still need to modify their visitation plan to allow for safe visitation by parents and other authorized representatives. During this meeting, the Licensee requested another meeting with a nurse from Contra Costa County as they did not want to rely on advice from a nurse who resided in a different county where COVID-19 guidelines may be different. LPAs Fremont and Tran assured the Licensee they would do their best to schedule a nurse from the home’s resident county. On 11/12/2020 at 1:30PM, LPAs Fremont and Tran met again with the home, and with California Department of Public Health Infectious Disease Consultant and Fresno County Department of Public Nurse Barbie Henson, to provide further technical assistance on creating a safe visitation plan. Again, LPAs were not able to schedule a nurse from Contra Costa County due to the limited availability of public health nurses due to the COVID-19 pandemic. After LPAs and the Licensee provided Nurse Henson with an in-depth description of the client’s behaviors and possible challenges to safe visitation, Nurse Henson recommended that the home make revisions to their visitation plan to allow safe visitation with limited physical touch between clients and parents at the group home. At this time, the home’s behavioral consultant voiced concerns that there should not be any physical touch, but conceded that a hug at the beginning and end of the visit would be fine given the visitors would be in full PPE. At the end of this visit, the Licensee requested that LPA Fremont contact the Contra Costa County Department of Public Health directly to run Nurse Henson’s plan revisions by a public health doctor from the home’s resident county, and LPA obliged. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

On 11/17/2020 at 9:46AM, LPA Fremont contacted Contra Costa County Department of Public Health directly, and received an email address to contact with inquiries. LPA Fremont described the situation in detail, including the client’s developmental disabilities and behaviors, and the parameters of the proposed plan for visitation. On 11/17/2020 at 3:50PM, LPA Fremont received a response from Sara Levin, MD, Deputy Health Officer of Contra Costa Health Services. Dr. Levin agreed that given the extensive safety precautions outlined in the proposed plan, limited physical touch would not be an issue, and if physical touch did occur, it would not be necessary to send clients home to quarantine for 14 days because of the extensive safety precautions in place. LPA Fremont presented this information to the licensee, and the final draft of the home’s visitation plan was submitted over email on 11/19/2020 at 5:08PM. Upon review of this plan, it was noted by CCL that the Licensee used varying information from each public health representative to create this plan, and relied on advice that was the most restrictive and would allow the home to continue not to allow visitation. The home ultimately rejected advice from Infectious Disease Nurse Barbie Henson for the reason that she does not reside in Contra Costa County, yet the plan also references more restrictive advice from Nurse Emma Erickson, who also does not reside in Contra Costa County. Although the previously agreed-upon safety guidelines were approved by Dr. Sara Levin of Contra Costa County, the home continued to reject this advice for safe visitation. After this plan was submitted, visitation discussions were temporarily put on hold. On 01/06/2021, during a virtual Complaint Investigation Inspection with the home regarding a complaint received on 01/04/2021, LPAs Fremont and Tran requested that a copy of the home’s visitor sign-in sheet with temperature check be submitted for the investigation. This document was never submitted by the Licensee, and S1 stated this was because LPAs Fremont and Tran were the only people who had used the home’s visitor sign-in sheet and visitor temperature check log since March 2020 when the COVID-19 Pandemic started, because no other visitors were allowed to enter the home. (continued on LIC809-C)

This is contradicted by a photo of the home’s Christmas Party on 12/24/2020, submitted to CCL over the course of this investigation. This photo shows S1’s two young daughters, who are not residents or staff of the home, in the facility and in close proximity to clients in care. Additionally, over the course of investigations into complaints received on 10/19/2020, 12/02/2020, and 01/04/2021, CCL representatives have witnessed S1’s daughters in the home during several virtual inspections. Based on the information above, the home has gone against its own COVID-19 visitation plan by allowing visitors into the home without obtaining a negative COVID-19 test, without having temperature checked upon entry to the facility as is required by CDPH, CCLD, and CDC guidance, and without having a symptom screening before entry. Simultaneously, the home has continued to not allow parents to visit their children at the home due to concerns of the COVID-19 pandemic. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072(d)(5) – Personal Rights. Please see the attached LIC809-D for details. At this time, seven (7) deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung with read receipt, to be signed and returned for the home’s facility file no later than 5PM on Monday, 03/22/2021.

deficiencies.title: Client Records
deficiencies.description: (d) All client records shall be available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit, and copy upon demand during normal business hours.

deficiencies.title: Buildings and Grounds
deficiencies.description: (g) Disinfectants, cleaning solutions, poisons, firearms, and other items that could pose a danger if readily available to clients shall be stored where inaccessible to clients.

narrative: At 2:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above virtually over Microsoft Teams for the purpose of conducting a Regional Office-initiated Office Meeting. The purpose of this meeting was to go over Plans of Correction (POCs) for recent deficiencies cited for the home and the home's Noncompliance Plan issued on 03/18/2021 to ensure the licensee is in full understanding of what will be expected over the next two years of their Noncompliance Plan. LPA Fremont met with Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong, and LPA AmyLe Tran. Currently in care are 5 clients. LPA Fremont started this meeting by going over POCs issued for 3 complaints closed on 02/12/2021 and a case management on 03/18/2021. LPA Fremont asked the licensee if they had any questions or concerns about the POCs issued. LPA Fremont and LPM Wong reiterated that if POC due dates were not met, there is the possibility for Failure to Correct Civil Penalties to be assessed. This process was explained to the licensee. Next, LPA Fremont went over the home's Noncompliance Plan issued on 03/18/2021, and asked the Licensee if they had any questions, concerns, and if they were in full understanding of the requirements laid out in the plan. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung to be signed and returned over email no later than 5PM on Monday, 03/29/2021.

Allegation #1: Licensee is denying services ordered by a healthcare professional and in a client's needs and services plan. On 10/23/2020 at 12:03PM, LPA received a report from W1 from the Sunnyvale Development and Behavior Clinic at Lucile Packard Children's Hospital at Stanford University. This report is dated 05/30/2019 and details the medically necessary need for C2 to received her Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) therapy. In this report, it is stated, "Children with Autism Spectrum Disorder benefit from ABA therapy. It is imperative that teachers, group home providers, and parents address C2's significant communication deficits and behavior challenges in a consistent manner in all settings so that she is able to successfully integrate new skills. This includes the use of her AAC or communication device..." This report also states that it is recommended that C2 continue medically necessary ABA therapy, and that the group home staff should receive training on how to assist with this service. Interviews with W1 on 10/23/2020 at 9:24AM and W2 on 11/20/2020 at 10:07AM both reiterate that ABA therapy was a medical necessity for C1 and C2. W2 added that both C1 and C2 have regressed heavily since COVID-19 started in March 2020 because they aren't able to receive their service. W1 also stated that the purpose of integrating ABA into the group home was for C1 and C2 to get better and to be able to be placed back in their parent's home. Upon review of the home's Plan of Operation/Program Statement by LPA Fremont on 11/05/2020, it was found that the home cites ABA therapy as a source of behavioral procedures that are used in the home including discipline policies. In interviews with S1 on 10/27/2020 at 11:07AM and S2 on 10/27/2020 at 11:52AM, both S1 and S2 stated the reason ABA had stopped being offered in the home was because the service was taking up too much space in the home, there were too many people coming into the home, the therapy resulted in too many unwanted behaviors, and the service was a distraction and disruptive to the other clients in care. S2 stated they did not see the benefit of having the therapy and any results seen in C1 and C2 were not due to ABA, but due to work done by the home and its staff. These statements from S1 and S2 are corroborated by interviews with W1 on 10/23/2020 at 9:24AM, W2 on 11/20/2020 at 10:07AM, T5 on 01/07/2021 at 10:34AM, W4 on 01/27/2021 at 3:35PM, and W3 on 01/27/2021 at 10:25AM. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

All interviewees stated that the reason S1 and S2 gave for not wanting ABA in the home was that it was too many people and it was disruptive to the other clients in care. When asked if C1 and C2 were given a space in the home for ABA, W2 stated that they were confined to one bedroom or the garage, and being in the same space caused C1 and C2 to trigger each other and it didn't work out. W2 stated that at that time, there was a free bedroom at the home on weekdays that could have been used for another space to solve this problem, however S2 had stated the room was completely taken and could not be used. When asked if the group home staff participated in this therapy, W2 stated they tried to get the staff involved, however S1 did not agree and S2 told her they had 5 kids in care and couldn't handle it. In September 2019, Regional Center of the East Bay (RCEB) came to a decision that medically necessary services were required to be offered at group homes. W1 and W2 both stated that when this was communicated to the group home, the group home send out eviction notices for C1 and C2. Both eviction notices were not followed through on, as RCEB did not agree with the evictions. After it was decided that ABA therapy could not be held at the group home, therapy was moved to C1 and C2's father's house, and he would pick up the clients from the group home after school every day to receive their service. This lasted until COVID-19 hit in March 2020, and services were discontinued. When COVID-19 hit, the ABA therapy service, JUVO, and RCEB offered extra training to the group home to be able to hold ABA virtually, however the group home staff refused because they stated they already had enough training and didn't need any more. Additionally, in an interview with T5 on 01/07/2021 at 10:34AM, T5 stated they never felt welcome in the home when they arrived for ABA. T5 also stated that part of ABA was to potty train C1 and C2, and learn how to use their talker devices. T5 stated that the home was never on board with potty training because they saw it as easier to keep the clients in diapers to avoid accidents. This is corroborated by a follow-up interview with W2 on 12/03/2020 at 3PM, who stated the group home was not meeting the client's toileting needs. T5 stated C1 would come to ABA at her father's house without her talker device, or would have it but it didn't have battery life, and the home expressed they did not want to have the talkers fixed when they were broken, giving the reason they did not need to use the talkers to effectively communicate with the clients. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

This is corroborated by interviews with W1 on 01/15/2021 at 2:14PM, T2 on 11/18/2020 at 4:01PM, T1 on 01/26/2021 at 11:14AM, and T4 on 01/27/2021 at 2:07PM, who all stated that the group home is reluctant to utilize the talker devices with C1 and C2 because they believe they can communicate with the clients without the devices. T2 and T4 both stated that S1 has repeatedly cited technical issues as the reason for not using the devices, but S1 will not follow up or answer correspondence from the school district about getting the devices fixed. C1's IEP progress report also corroborates these statements, stating that without the talker, C1 has no way to effectively communicate with teachers or peers without assistance from the group home staff. Finally, T4 stated she was told by the group home that it was a liability to have the talker devices in the home, and the group home sent the devices back to the school district. Based on the information gathered, including records review and interviews, there is a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation "Licensee is denying services ordered by a healthcare professional and in client's needs and services plan." Therefore, the allegation is found to be substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 7, Section 84078(b) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Allegation #2: Facility did not have enough staff to meet the needs of the clients. In an interview with S1 on 10/27/2020 at 11:07AM, S2 stated that the group home as 5 staff on duty at all times, and C1, C2, and other clients are all on 1:1 supervision, with the exception of one client who is higher functioning and does not require 1:1 supervision. In an interview with W2 on 11/20/2020 at 10:07AM, W2 stated that all clients in the home except for one are on 1:1 supervision, meaning that each client has a staff with them at all times, except when they are sleeping, to assist with Activities of Daily Living (ADLs). W2 stated that the home was investigated by RCEB in September of 2019 for being short-staffed, and that staff schedules submitted to RCEB do not match staff schedules submitted to Community Care Licensing (CCL). W2 stated that S1 and S2 have repeatedly expressed that the home is overwhelmed with 5 clients. W1 also stated that before COVID-19, they had traveled to the home and found 1 or 2 staff in the home supervising 5 clients. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

These statements are corroborated by interviews with W2 on 12/03/2020 at 3PM, T1 on 01/26/2021 at 11:14AM, T4 on 01/27/2021 at 2:07AM, W3 on 01/27/2021 at 10:25AM, and W4 on 01/27/2021 at 3:35PM. W2 stated the group home does not have enough staff to meet the needs of its clients, specifically toilet training, communication, social skills, and education. T1 stated S2 has indicated to them that the home struggles to get all 5 of their clients online and on devices for school because they do not have enough staff. T4 stated the group home does not have enough staff to meet the educational needs of the clients. W4 stated that the home was understaffed at times, and they were informed S1 and S2 had to make up for coverage frequently. W3 stated that when ABA was being held in the home, staff had attempted to assist with the service but were unable to because the home was short-staffed. Finally, C1 and C2's 2020-21 IEP progress reports both not that staff are not available to help with online learning, and staff are not available to help with 1:1 activities for C1. Based on the information gathered, including interviews and records review, there is a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation "Facility did not have enough staff to meet the needs of the clients." Therefore, the allegation is found to be substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84065.5(c) - Staff/Child Ratios. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Allegation #3: Clients denied care and supervision for a week. In interviews with S1 on 10/27/2020 at 11:07AM and S2 on 10/27/2020 at 11:52AM, both staff were asked about camps that clients had attended in the past. S1 and S2 both stated that in the past, the clients had attended a camp for special needs kids in San Jose, CA, which was paid for by the parents. When asked what would happen if a client could not attend, S1 stated the clients would stay at the group home with staff, and S2 stated the clients could either stay at the group home or go home to their parents for the week. When asked what staff would do if clients weren't present in the home for those weeks, S1 stated staff were given the week off to have their own time, and S2 stated that staff stayed at the home on standby in case a client needed to be picked up from camp. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

In an interview with W1 on 10/23/2020 at 9:24AM, W1 stated they were aware that C1 and C2 attended the camp once, and then stayed home with their parent the next year because it was too expensive for their parent to send them to camp. W1 also stated that the home instructed C1 and C2's parent to come pick them up for that week because no staff would be present at the home to watch them. This is corroborated by interviews with W2 on 11/20/2020 at 10:07AM, W3 on 01/29/2021 at 10:59AM, and W4 on 01/29/2021 at 11:23AM. W2 stated C1 and C2 went home with their parent for a week because they were told no staff would be present at the home, and it created a problem with payroll requests being submitted to RCEB when no staff were present providing care. W3 and W4 both stated that C1 and C2 could not afford to go to the camp in 2018, and S1 told their parent to take them home for the week because no staff would be at the home. Both W3 and W4 stated that during this specific week, staff were out of the home for a 3-4 day vacation in Los Angeles, CA, and staff received sick leave pay for these days off. Based on the information gathered, including interviews and records review, there is a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation "Clients denied care and supervision for a week." Therefore, the allegation is found to be substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80065(a) - Personnel Requirements. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Allegation #4: Facility did not provide appropriate clothing for clients. In interviews with S1 and S2 on 10/27/2020, both staff stated that clients in care are dressed appropriately by staff at the home, and they buy clothes for each client when they grow out of old ones. This is contradicted by interviews with T2 on 11/18/2020 at 4:01PM, W2 on 11/20/2020 at 10:07AM, and W3 on 01/27/2021 at 10:25AM. T2 stated that there was a period of time before COVID-19 when the group home would send C1 to school every day without a warm jacket. T2 stated this happened so often that they bought C1 a winter coat to use during recess and to keep at school so she could play outdoors and be warm, and T2 sent C1 home with the jacket to keep at the end of the school year. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

W2 stated in the past they have received emails from teachers that C1 and C2 were not dressed properly or their clothes did not fit properly, for example pants were too short or clothes were too tight. W2 also stated C1 and C2 are often dressed in clothing that is not appropriate for children of their age. W3 stated they recall a teacher reaching out because C1's clothes were too small for her. Based on the information gathered, including interviews, there is a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation "Facility did not provide appropriate clothing for clients." Therefore, the allegation is found to be substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072(d)(6)(A) - Personal Rights. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Allegation #5: Facility did not respond to responsible party in a prompt manner. In interviews with S1 and S2 on 10/27/2020 at 11:07AM and 11:52AM respectively, both staff were asked what the average turnaround time is for them to answer correspondence from clients' representatives. S1 responded it depends on the day and what they have going on, and that if they are on the road or busy, they tend to forget and come back to things later. S2 stated they try their best to respond right away, however they have 5 kids with different needs, and it becomes challenging. In response to LPA's inquiry regarding an overlooked email from C1's teacher about returning to in-person schooling, S1 stated that sometimes it looks like emails are marked as read so they don't open them, but that she eventually responded "no" to C1's teacher about returning to in-person schooling. This is corroborated by an interview with W1 on 10/23/2020 at 9:24AM, who stated C1's principal and teacher had reached out to the group home regarding C1 returning to in-person schooling starting 10/26/2020, and they they had not received a response from the group home until after the deadline to enroll had passed. In interviews with T1 on 11/17/2020 at 4PM, T2 on 11/18/2020 at 4:01PM, T3 on 11/19/2020 at 2:30PM, W2 on 12/03/2020 at 3PM, and a follow-up interview with T1 on 01/26/2021 at 11:14AM, all interviewees reported issues with the group home's communication. T1 stated that when they first started corresponding with the group home regarding C2's schooling, 6 days was the longest time her correspondence went unanswered. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

T3 stated they often send updates, questions, and other correspondence to the group home, and either receive sporadic responses or no responses at all. T2 stated they do not expect to get an answer from S1 for recent emails sent, and that prior to two weeks before their interview, all correspondence went unanswered. W2 stated there has been an ongoing issue with communication between the group home and C1 and C2's parent, as well as their teachers. W2 stated the reason for unanswered correspondence was never communicated to them by the group home, and that RCEB has continuously reminded the group home of their duty to respond to responsible parties. W2 added that C1 and C2's teachers, as well as one of their school principals has called the group home regarding the clients' school attendance, however they have never received a response to their calls. In T1's follow-up interview, they stated that they have not heard back about any inquiries into getting the clients' talkers fixed, and for general emails, they do not expect to get a response from the group home. Based on the information gathered, including interviews and review of records, there is a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation "Facility did not respond to responsible party in a prompt manner." Therefore, the allegation is found to be substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84072(d)(4) - Personal Rights. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Allegation #6: Facility is not making accommodations for a child's schooling needs. In interviews with S1 and S2 on 10/27/2020 at 11:07AM and 11:52AM respectively, both staff stated virtual schooling has been overwhelming and challenging due to having 5 clients in care that go to different schools. S1 stated that there have been technology challenges, as well as communication barriers as all of the group home staff have English as a second language. S2 stated that if a client starts to show they are done for the day, they turn off the virtual school to avoid escalated behavior. Both S1 and S2 stated that a lot of the time when they sign on to Zoom for school, no one else is signed on so they turn it off. Both staff cited Wifi issues as another reason for the clients not signing on to virtual school. Finally, when asked about missing school assignments, S1 stated she was not aware of any clients having missing schoolwork. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

In interviews with W1 on 11/10/2020 at 10:52AM, T1 on 01/17/2021 at 4PM, T2 on 11/18/2021 at 4:01PM, T3 on 11/19/2020 at 2:30PM, and W2 on 12/03/2020 at 3PM, all interviewees voiced ongoing issues with C1 and C2's school attendance and performance since the COVID-19 Pandemic started in March 2020. W1 stated that in a phone call with C2's teacher on 11/09/2020, the teacher reported C2 had several weeks of missing assignments, and that C2 was not being signed on to virtual school until 11AM daily, although school starts at 8:05AM. W1 reported that C2's teacher had also expressed concern for C1 and C2's attendance with the group home staff, and staff had responded that they were late for class every day because they were sleeping. T1 reported that C2 is usually signed on every day at around 11-11:30AM, just in time for music and activities. T1 stated C2 often did not have any staff sitting with her during virtual learning to help with the technology and prompting, and that C2 would just sit in front of the screen and smile. T1 also expressed concern that C1 and C2 will not meet their Individual Education Plan (IEP) goals, especially because they have never attended 1:1 speech or occupational therapy (OT) since the school year started. This is corroborated by T3, who stated that C2 has never attended individual OT, and that she doesn't see C2 in class enough to comment on missing work, stating, "The fact that she hasn't joined sessions until very recently is concerning. It takes a lot of consistency to show progress and develop skills for her IEP." T3 also stated they are concerned that C1 and C2 have not consistently been accessing their education since the pandemic started. T3 stated at the beginning of the pandemic, they sent home interactive assignments for C1 and C2 to complete, and the assignments were never completed or turned in. T3 had a meeting with the group home to discuss ways to get C1 doing their work, and the group home told T3 they could not commit to the activities to work with C1 because it was too difficult to get her to complete virtual assignments. T3 reiterated that neither C1 nor C2 has shown up at all to individual speech therapy, which the school worked out for the two clients to have together to make it easier for the group home to get them online. T3 reported that staff have only started being present with C1 and C2 during group speech within the two weeks prior to their interview. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

Finally, T3 reported that the group home is not supporting C1 and C2 educationally or pushing them out of their comfort zone with their education, and she is worried about C1 regressing. W2 had similar concerns that the group home is not supporting C1 and C2's education and their needs are not being met. In an interview with T4 on 01/27/2021 at 2:07PM, T4 stated the group home does not say "no" to C1, and they don't require her to use her talker at the home, which is hindering the school's ability to work with her on it. T4 also stated that the group home did not want C1's talker back after having it fixed, which is hindering C1's IEP goals because she has no way to effectively communicate with her teachers. T4 went on to explain that the group home has expressed they will only commit C1 to 1-1.5 hours of school per day, and if she is having a bad day they will call it quits early or not sign on at all. At the beginning of the year, C1 was never in attendance for virtual learning, and the group home gave T4 the reason that they didn't want the teachers to see what was going on in the home or see the other clients, and that it was a privacy issue for them. T4 stated the home has also instructed her not to talk to C1 during virtual learning because it sets off C1's behaviors. Additionally, T4 stated the only time a caregiver is online with C1 is if there is a technology issue, and T4 will text the caregivers to come help C1. T4 ended their interview by stating the group home does not make C1 do things she doesn't want to do, they don't say no to her, and it is going to be an issue when C1 eventually returns to in-person schooling and the teachers can't give her everything she wants. All of the above is corroborated by C1 and C2's IEP progress reports and attendance records, submitted to LPAs over the course of this investigation. C1's attendance record for the fall semester states that between the dates of 08/14/2020 and 11/06/2020, there were a total of 65 instruction days, and C1 was absent for 26 of them, equaling a 40% attendance rate. All of these absences were unexcused. In C2's IEP progress report cites a similar trend. Of the total 83 days of instruction for fall semester, C2 was absent for 23 of them. In C1's IEP progress report, it is noted that 7/7 goals have minimal progress to report because "C1 does not have her communication device for school because the group home does not encourage her to use it. They have returned the device to school. " C1's progress report also states, "C1 has not attended any weekly speech therapy sessions this year due to remote learning so there is no progress to report......" (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

"....Staff in the group home indicates that they are not available for 1:1 activities needed to support tabletop material that would be less preferred. They do not make demands on their client that may trigger her, C1 has scheduled weekly OT sessions, attendance to sessions on Google Meet has been minimal." On the majority of C1's IEP goals, there is a comment stating "Regression is expected." C2's IEP progress report has a common repeated comment on her IEP goals that states, "C2 has only attended school virtually inconsistently for short periods of time. There is no data to report on at this time." For C2's speech therapy progress, it is stated, "Progress is unable to be reported as C2 has not participated in speech sessions since the 2020-21 school year started. She has attended sporadically but has not had a person with her to facilitate communication." Based on the information gathered, including interviews and records review, there is a preponderance of evidence to support the allegation "Facility is not making accommodations for a child's schooling needs." Therefore, the allegation is found to be substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 7, Section 84078(d) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. At this time, pertaining to these 6 allegations, 6 deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung with read receipt, to be signed and returned over email for the home's facility file no later than 11:59PM on Tuesday, 02/16/2020.

deficiencies.description:
84078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of facility records, the licensee is denying C1 and C2's medically necessary Applied Behavior Analysis therapy, which was ordered by a healthcare professional and is in the clients' needs and services plan. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will submit a plan to train facility staff on assisting with virtual ABA in the home in conjunction with RCEB and JUVO, and a plan to integrate ABA back into the facility's service plan by 11:59PM on Tuesday, 02/16/2021.

deficiencies.description:
84065.5 Staff/Child Ratios: (c) If the children require special care and supervision because of age, problem behavior, or other factors, the number of on-duty child care staff shall be increased. 

This requirements was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of facility records that show 4 out of 5 clients in care require special care and supervision, the licensee did not have enough staff to meet the needs of the clients in care. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will submit a plan to ensure facility has adequate staffing at all times to meet the needs and care of the clients by 11:59PM on Tuesday 02/16/2021.

deficiencies.description:
80065 Personnel Requirements: (a) Facility personnel shall be competent to provide the services necessary to meet individual client needs and shall, at all times, be employed in numbers necessary to meet such needs. 

This requirement was not met as evidence by: Based on interviews and review of facility records, in a recent year while other clients were away at camp, the licensee required C1 and C2's parent to take them home for the week so staff could go on vacation, denying the clients care, services, and supervision for a week. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a plan to ensure staff coverage at all times to meet the needs of the clients and provide care and supervision as needed. This plan will be submitted by 11:59PM on Tuesday 02/16/2021.

deficiencies.description:
84072 Personal Rights: (d) [...] In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights (6) To be provided and allowed to possess and use adequate personal items [...] which includes their own (A) Clothing items, provided the clothes are age-appropriate. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews with teachers and authorized representatives, C1 and C2 have often been observed in clothing that is too small, too big, or is not weather or age appropriate. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a plan to inventory each clients' clothing every 6 months to ensure that all clothing is age and weather appropriate and fits the clients properly. This will be submitted by 11:59PM on Tuesday 02/16/2021.

deficiencies.description:
84072 Personal Rights: (d) [...] In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights (4) To have communication to the facility from his/her relatives and/or authorized representative(s) answered promptly and completely.

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of records from 2019-2021 that show correspondence from C1 and C2's representatives frequently goes unanswered, the facility did not respond to a responsible party in a prompt manner. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee will submit a plan that outlines the duties of each administrator/assitant administrator and names one staff that will be in charge of all communication with authorized representatives, to be turned in by 11:59PM on Tuesday 02/16/2021.

deficiencies.description:
84078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (d) The licensee shall ensure each child's attendance at an educational program in accordance with state law. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of C1 and C2's 2020-21 IEP progress reports, the facility is not making accommodations for a child's schooling needs by not ensuring C1 and C2 are present and have their 1:1 staff with them for all virtual learning sessions. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a schedule of all 5 clients' virtual classes that includes the name of each 1:1 staff assigned to each client. The licensee will also submit a plan to initiate communication with C1 and C2's teachers to get their talker devices fixed. To be submitted by 11:59PM on Tuesday 02/16/2021.

narrative:
On 12/10/2020, LPA Fremont met with S1 over Microsoft Teams to notify them of these allegations, to request documentation related to the complaint, and to conduct an interview with S1. In an interview with S1 on 12/10/2020 at 1:05PM, S1 stated that both C1 and C2 are bathed twice daily, morning and night, and S1 stated that both clients have Self-Injurious Behaviors (SIBs) as part of their behaviors related to their Autism. S1 clarified that since COVID-19 hit in March 2020, both clients have had a significant decrease in the frequency of their SIBs. When asked if injuries sustained during SIB incidents are reported to a client's authorized representatives, S1 stated, "If it needs to be reported, we would report it. If it is unusual we would report it. If it is just a scratch, we don't report it, unless there is a bruise." When asked if injuries sustained outside of the home are reported, S1 stated, "we would report it. A bruise doesn't come out until hours later or the next day, but C1 and C2 are so light-complexioned so we see it right away and report it." This is corroborated by an interview with W1 on 12/14/2020 at 10:31AM, who stated that unknown bruises get reported to the clients' schools and parents to keep the circle of communication open and honest. S1 then stated that bruises, scrapes, and scratches would not be reported if they did not seem serious. LPA inquired with S1 about a CPS investigation at the facility on 01/15/2020, regarding unknown bruises and scrapes found on C1. S1 stated she and other staff checked C1 and C2 day and night, and hadn't noticed any injuries. S1 reiterated several times she never saw any bruises or scratches on C1 during the CPS investigation, and thought the CPS agent was testing her. This is contradicted by a series of text messages S1 sent to C1's parent on 01/15/2020 at 5:35PM, which were sent to report C1's bruises and scratches, and describe the shape and location of each injury. These text messages were sent to C1's parent before the CPS agent arrived at the group home to conduct their investigation on 01/15/2020 at approximately 6:45PM. LPA asked S1 if the bruises could have been the result of an interaction between C1 and her parent, and inquired if the parent was in town and took care of C1 and C2 in the days leading up to the discovery of C1's injuries. S1 stated she was sure the father was in town all week, and that the bruises could have been sustained at C1's dentist appointment on 01/15/2020. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

This is contradicted by a screenshot of C1's father's flight schedules submitted to LPA Fremont on 12/17/2020 at 12:20PM, which show the father was out of town for work from the dates of 01/10/2020 to 01/14/2020. This is also contradicted by C1's dental appointment visit summary from 01/15/2020, which do not report any injury or behavior that could have caused C1's injuries. Finally, LPA asked S1 if any bruises or scratches were noted on C1 during bath time in the days leading up to the discovery of her injuries, and S1 stated, "The bruises showed up later, or before, I can't remember. I think it was scratches maybe on the back or maybe...I don't know." Consumer Notes submitted to LPA Fremont by S1 on 12/14/2020 at 5:10PM show that between the dates of 01/01/2020 and 01/14/2020, C1 did not have any target behaviors, and no bruises or scratches were noted on C1's body. An entry on 01/15/2020 does not note any bruises or scratches on C1's body. An evening entry on 01/15/2020 notes, "Staff shower C1 and notice a bruise on back of her body, lot of red scratches reported to administrator." An additional evening entry on 01/15/2020 states a CPS agent came to the home at 6:45PM to conduct an investigation. Interviews with W1 on 12/14/2020 at 10:31AM and T1 on 01/07/2021 at 10:34AM both confirm that C1 was found to have a series of large, finger shaped bruises around C1's left breast, a large bruise on her upper back near her shoulder, and bruises and scratches with swelling on the medial portion of C1's thighs. T1 also stated that when she discovered C1's bruises, C1 tried to hide them from her and seemed embarrassed and uncomfortable. T1 stated in her interview that there was no doubt C1's injuries should have been reported to CPS and C1's authorized representative. This is supported by an interview with T2 on 01/12/2021 at 1:37PM, who also stated there was no doubt the injuries should have been reported to CPS and the child's authorized representatives. Based on interviews and records review, the timeline of events for this incident are as follows: 1. C1's father is out of town from 01/10/2020 to 01/14/2020. C1 and C2 do not have Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) therapy between 01/09/2020 and 01/12/2020, and their grandmother picks them up for ABA therapy on 01/13/2020. No injuries are noted during this time period. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

2. The father returns from their business trip on 01/14/2020, and picks up C1 for ABA therapy at his apartment between 3 and 3:15PM. 3. During ABA on 01/14/2020, while teaching C1 about showering and picking out clothing, T1 discovers C1's injuries and reports them to the father. T1 calls T2 to confirm reporting requirement. 4. In the early morning on 01/15/2020, T2 instructs T1 to make a CPS report for C1's injuries. T1 makes the report in the early morning. 5. At approximately 4:30PM, CPS investigator W3 contacts the group home to inform them of the investigation and set up a meeting time at the group home. 6. At 5:30PM, S1 writes an incident report regarding C1's injuries, and notes that East Bay Regional Center, CCLD, and the father are notified. 7. At 5:35PM, S1 contacts the father over text message to inform him of C1's injuries and asks if they were sustained at the dentist earlier that day on 01/15/2020. 8. At 6:45PM, W3 travels to the group home and conducts a CPS investigation into C1's injuries. S1 later notes in her interview with LPA Fremont on 12/02/2020 that she did not notice any injuries on C1 during this visit. Finally, it was discovered that 5 incident reports dated between June 2020 and September 2020 were not submitted to Regional Center or CCLD until 10/30/2020. The timing of submittal of these reports violates CCLD's requirements that Incident Reports be submitted to the licensing Agency within 7 days of the occurrence of the incident. LPA was contacted by W2 on 11/20/2020 at 12:31PM, who confirmed that they had not received these incident reports until 10/30/2020. W2 stated that when they inquired with the home about incident reports being submitted months after the incidents, S1 and S2 stated that they had not had time to submit the reports due to COVID-19. The dates of these 5 incidents are a follows: 1. Two incident reports for incidents on 06/15/2020, written on 10/30/2020 and submitted to CCLD and Regional Center on 10/30/2020. 2. Two incident reports for incidents on 08/14/2020, written on 10/30/2020 and submitted to CCLD and Regional Center on 10/30/2020. 3. One incident report for an incident on 09/20/2020, marked as written on 02/19/2020 and submitted to CCLD and Regional Center on 10/30/2020. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

Based on the information gathered, including interviews, review of facility records, and review of records submitted by the reporting party, there is a preponderance of evidence to support that a lack of care and supervision resulted in C1 sustaining unknown injuries that went unnoticed by staff while in care at the facility. Therefore, the allegation "Neglect/Lack of Care and Supervision resulting in a client sustaining unknown bruises" is substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80078(a) - Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. Additionally, based on interviews and review of facility records, including incident reports, there is a preponderance of evidence to support that the Licensee did not report an incident in a timely manner. Therefore, the allegation "Reporting Requirements: The Licensee did not report an incident in a timely manner" is substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80061(b)(1)(E) - Reporting Requirements. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. At this time, two deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights discussed and provided, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee Reggieanne Villar-Battung with read receipt, to sign and return over email for the home's facility file no later than 11:59PM on Tuesday, 02/16/2021.

This complaint was assigned to LPA Fremont on 12/02/2020. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

deficiencies.description:
80078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (a) The licensee shall provide care and supervision as necessary to meet the needs of the clients. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and records review, a lack of care and supervision resulted in C1 sustaining unknown bruises and scratches that went unnoticed and undocumented by staff while in care at the home, and which warranted a CPS investigation at the home on 01/15/2020. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a plan to re-train all staff on providing care and supervision and will create a body check form to be used during bath time to note any injuries on clients. To be submitted by 11:59PM on Tuesday 02/16/2021.

deficiencies.description:
80061 Reporting Requirements: (b) Upon the occurence, during the operation of the facility, any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the next working day during its normal business hours. In addition, a written report [...] shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such an incident. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on records review, between the months of June 2020 and December 2020, the Licensee did not report incidents to the Licensing Agency or Regional Center in a prompt manner consistent with the timeframe specified in this regulation. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a plan to re-train all staff on Reporting Requirements as specified in CCR sections 80061 and 84061. To be submitted by 11:59PM on Monday, 03/15/2021.
