narrative:
During an announced 10-Day Complaint Investigation Inspection with the facility on 01/06/2021 at 2:00PM, LPAs Madi Fremont and AmyLe Tran notified the facility about the complaint, and conducted an interview with S1 regarding the allegation. LPA's inquired about which staff were living in the home at the time, and S1 initially responded 3 staff were live-in, then later changed her answer to 4 staff, as she had forgotten about one of them. LPAs asked S1 to clarify how many staff were living in the home, and she stated that there were 5 staff living in the home, plus her and her three family members (Assistant Administrators) who work at the home but did not reside in the home, for a total of 9 staff. S1 also stated that the live-in staff routinely traveled outside of the home to run errands, pick up groceries, and pick up donations for the home. LPAs asked if the staff were routinely getting tested for COVID-19, and S1 responded that they would get tested if they experienced symptoms, but no one had been tested yet because no staff had experienced symptoms of COVID-19. This is corroborated by interviews with W3 on 01/27/2021 at 3:10PM, and W4 on 01/29/2021 at 2:33PM, who both stated staff are not being tested for COVID-19. LPAs asked if the home was allowing any visitors at that time, and S1 stated they were not accepting any visitors since March of 2020 due to COVID-19. LPAs asked for a copy of the home's visitor sign-in sheet with temperature check, and S1 stated that the LPAs were the only visitors that had come to the home since March 2020, when they traveled there to open an unrelated complaint on 10/27/2020. When asked what the home did to celebrate the recent holidays, S1 stated that the home had a Christmas Party with clients and staff at the facility. LPA Fremont asked S1 to clarify who was in attendance at this party, and S1 reiterated it was just clients and staff present at the party. These statements by S1 are contradicted by a photo submitted to LPAs Fremont and Tran on 12/25/2020 at 10:51PM, which shows S1's two daughters, who are not residents or staff of the home, in close proximity to the clients of the home. This is also contradicted by a statement from W2 on 01/07/02021 at 12:38PM, who stated they travelled to the group home on 12/24/2020 at approximately 5:00PM to drop of Christmas gifts for a client. W2 stated that upon their arrival at the group home, S2 greeted them at the door. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

When S2 opened the front door, W2 looked inside the home and observed a large gathering of approximately 12-15 people, adults and children, in one room together. W2 stated that they knew the staff of the home well and did not recognize several of the adults who were inside the house. W2 also observed S1's daughters inside and in close proximity to the clients. This is corroborated by an interview with W3 on 01/27/2021 at 3:10PM, who stated that S1's daughters were present at the Christmas Party on 12/24/2020. On 10/27/2020 during a visit to the home for an unrelated matter, LPAs Fremont and Tran provided S1 and S2 with CCLD Provider Information Notices (PINs) that detailed the use of masks in residential facilities. LPA Fremont strongly encouraged the home to require the use of masks for all staff. On 11/04/2020 during a virtual Case Management Inspection to discuss the facility's COVID-19 visitation plan with California Department of Public Health (CDPH) Nurse Emma Erickson, LPA Fremont and Nurse Erickson strongly encouraged S1 to enforce mask usage in the home, due to concerns from parents. On 11/12/2020 during a Case Management Inspection to discuss the home's visitation policy with CDPH Nurse Barbie Henson, Nurse Henson strongly encouraged the use of masks in the home. During this meeting, due to repeated concerns from parents, LPA Fremont warned the Licensee that action would be taken by CCLD if masks were not mandated in the home, as LPAs had asked on several occasions which staff were live-in, and had not yet received a definitive answer. During S1's interview on 01/06/2021, LPAs inquired if staff at the home are required to wear masks while in the facility, to which S1 responded they were required to wear masks in the home in keeping with Contra Costa County Department of Public Health COVID-19 guidelines. This is contradicted by the following: 1. During an unrelated Complaint Investigation Inspection at the home on 10/27/2020, LPAs Fremont and Tran were greeted at the front door by S2. Both LPAs observed that S2 did not have a mask on, and does not reside at the group home. S2 put on a mask when LPAs entered the home. 2. A photo taken on 07/23/2020, submitted to LPA Fremont on 10/27/2020 at 3:16PM. This photo shows staff without masks in close proximity to clients of the home during C2's birthday party. One of the staff shown in the photo does not reside in the home. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

3. A video taken on 09/27/2020 and submitted to LPA Fremont on 10/27/2020 at 3:19PM, which shows staff without a mask in close proximity to C1. 4. A video taken on 11/26/2020 and submitted to LPA Fremont on 11/30/2020 at 3:40PM which shows staff without masks in close proximity to clients of the home. 5. An interview with T2 on 01/26/2021 at 11:14AM, in which T2 stated she observed staff of the home without masks 25-30% of the time. T2 stated that when the staff did wear their masks, they either had them under their noses or under their chins. 6. 3 photos submitted to LPA Fremont on 01/27/2021 at 11:45AM, which show C1 with staff during C1's 1:1 session at 9:40AM on 01/27/2021. In these photos, the staff is not wearing a mask and is in close proximity to C1. 7. 1 photo submitted to LPA Fremont on 01/28/2021 at 10:12AM, which shows C1 in her morning 1:1 sessions with staff in close proximity with her mask under her chin. T2 and T2's teaching aid both reported that the staff was coughing throughout the session. 8. 1 photo submitted to LPA Fremont on 01/28/2021 at 10:16AM, which shows C1 in her 1:1 class from 01/27. In this photo we can see staff without a mask in close proximity to C1, and a male staff in the background without a mask and in close proximity to a male client. On 01/06/2021, LPA Tran asked S1 how she was ensuring that her non live-in staff were being safe and following COVID-19 safety protocol outside of the home, and S1 responded that she and her three relatives (Assistant Administrators of the home) practiced social distancing inside and outside of the facility and remained at least 6 feet away from all clients at all times. This is contradicted by two photos submitted to LPA Fremont on 12/24/2020 at 6PM, which show C2 in close proximity and in contact with S1, with C1 standing next to them. This photo also shows one of S1's daughters on S1's lap, and the other daughter standing next to the group. The second photo shows staff without a mask in close proximity to clients and in the same gathering space as S1's daughters. While S1 and her children are wearing masks in these photos, this goes against the facility's COVID-19 Visitation Plan, submitted to LPA Fremont on 11/09/2020. In this plan, the facility maintains that visitors must test negative within 7 days of coming to the home, visitors must remain 6 feet apart from clients, and if physical contact occurs with a client, the client will be sent home to quarantine for 14 days and may only return after showing a negative COVID-19 test. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

This Christmas Party held by the home, as well as their use of PPE in the home and the presence of unauthorized visitors are in violation of several CCLD, CDPH, and Contra Costa County Department of Public Health (CCCDPH) Safety Guidelines related to COVID-19. LPA Fremont has sourced the following documents from the CCCDPH, CDPH, and CCLD websites: 1. In a CCCDPH document titled "Holidays and COVID-19," it is stated that residents of the county should not gather with other households, all gatherings should take place outdoors, and residents and staff should wear masks around people that are not from their household. 2. A document titled "Regional Stay At Home Order" released by CA Governor Gavin Newsom on 12/03/2020 stated that all gatherings with members of other households are prohibited, taking effect on 12/05/2020. 3. A document released by Contra Costa County on 11/12/2020 titled "Memo Re: Long-Term Care Facilities and Residential Care Facilities Guidance for Visitation, Activities, and Outings Based on County Tier" states that all indoor and in-room gatherings are prohibited for counties in the Purple Tier, which Contra Costa County was in at the time and remains in at this time. 4. A document released by Contra Costa County on 06/26/2020 titled "Order of the Health Officer of Contra Costa County" which states that all visitors not working in the facility shall submit to a temperature screening prior to entering the facility. This document also states that all staff members shall cover their nose and mouth with a face covering while in the facility, and all staff members and visitors to the facility should stay at least 6 feet apart from other persons. 5. A document released by CDPH on 11/13/2020 titled "CDPH Guidance for Prevention of COVID-19 Transmission for Gatherings" which states that the likelihood of transmission of COVID-19 increases with laughing, singing, loud talking, and difficulty maintaining social distancing, gatherings must be held outdoors for counties in the Purple Tier, gathering space must be large enough that everyone can maintain at least 6 feet of distance from those not from their household, and face coverings must be worn, with the exception limited to eating. (CONTINUED ON LIC9099-C)

6. A combined PIN and All County Letter (ACL) released by Governor Newsom on 08/13/2020 titled "PIN 20-19-CRP/ACL: Clarification of the State's Face Covering Order in Children's Residential Facilities" which states children and staff are to wear face coverings when members of the public are present. This document also stated that masks are required when staff are interacting with members of the public in any room or enclosed area where other people (excluding healthy members of their own household) are present and unable to physically distance. This document states that providers are strongly encouraged to stay up to date on the specific mandates of their local health departments relating to face covering and social distancing, and to follow accordingly. 7. PIN 20-27-CCLD released on 11/23/2020 titled "Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) Infection Control Guidance for Celebrations and Outings" which states that face coverings are required, a distance of 6 feet should be maintained from all other people who aren't part of your household, and to plan activities that limit mixing between different households. 8. PIN 20-12-CRP Released on 06/22/2020 titled "Public Health Guidance Related to COVID-19 for Home-Based Care and Congregate Care Facilities in Child Welfare Practice" which advises planning activities that do not require close physical contact, advises against planning large group activities, advises to eliminate family style meals and avoiding congregating, and states that each group activity should be limited to 10 total people, including staff. Based on the information gathered, including LPA observations, interviews, and records review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the allegation "Facility did not provide a safe environment for clients in care" is found to be substantiated. A deficiency is being cited per California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Article 6, Section 84065.2 (b)(1) - Personnel Duties. Please see the attached LIC9099-D for details. At this time, one deficiency is being cited regarding this complaint. An exit interview was conducted, Appeal Rights provided and discussed, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee Reggieanne Villar-Battung to be signed and returned for the facility's file no later than 11:59PM on Tuesday, 02/16/2021.

deficiencies.description:
84065.2 Personnel Duties: (b) Child care staff shall perform the following duties (1) Supervision, protection, and care of children individually and in groups at all times. 

This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on LPA observations and photo and video evidence submitted to CCL between 10/2020 and 01/2021 that show the facility is not following CCL, County, and State COVID-19 Safety protocols, the licensee did not ensure that their staff were providing protection of clients individually and in groups at all times. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The licensee shall submit a plan to train all facility staff on CCLD, CDC, CDPH, and County COVID-19 Safety Guidelines and will train all staff on proper mask-wearing. To be submitted by 11:59PM on Tuesday 02/16/2021.

narrative:
At 9:51AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont traveled to the home above to conduct an unannounced Required Annual Inspection. LPA met with Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance were LPA AmyLe Tran and Morning Star Assistant Administrator Irma Battung. Currently in care are 5 ambulatory clients. During this inspection, 0 clients and 6 staff were present in the home. 5 clients arrived as LPAs were leaving the home. LPAs toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied, and has two double occupancy bedrooms and one single occupancy bedroom. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings, desks and chairs, and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. The home has a living room and a family room which are equipped with couches and chairs for clients. The home has a dining room with enough chairs for all clients to have meals together. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. The weekly menu was posted in the family room. LPAs observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. Chemicals and cleaning supplies are kept locked in a cabinet that is inaccessible to clients. No firearms on the premises. Facility had a supply of emergency food items in the garage. All medications are kept in a locked cabinet. Facility as 3 first aid kits with all required supplies. Fire extinguisher was observed in the garage, and all carbon monoxide and smoke detectors were tested and observed to be functional. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. LPAs observed extra linens in two closets in the hallway. All bathroom and kitchen faucets in use by clients were measured between 111-112 degrees Fahrenheit. Thermostat was set to 71 degrees Fahrenheit. Facility license, emergency plan, personal rights, client grievance policy, floor plan, and staff schedule are prominently posted. Sharps are kept locked and inaccessible to clients. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

The facility has a staff room that is kept locked and inaccessible to clients. Staff room has 3 beds for staff breaks, and a sliding glass door to the backyard that is also kept locked. LPAs toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. There are two play structures which are anchored to the ground, and a sitting area in the backyard. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. Ground under the play structures is covered in tanbark for client safety if falls occur. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is kept gated at all times and inaccessible to clients. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. All window screens are in good condition. The facility has a fireplace which is not in use, and has a grate as well as a couch backed up to the front to ensure clients cannot access the fireplace. Facility has comfortable furnishings, accommodations, and ample lighting. All client and staff records are complete with all of the required documentation. During this inspection, LPA obtained copies of the facility's client roster, staff roster (LIC500), staff schedule, and immunization records for 2 clients. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung.

At 3:08PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madi Fremont met with the home above over Microsoft Teams to conduct a Regional Office Meeting. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss elements of the home's Noncompliance Plan, which was initiated on 03/18/2021. LPA met with Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung, who helped facilitate this inspection. Also in attendance was Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Helga Wong. Currently in care are 5 ambulatory clients. On 03/18/2021, as part of the home's Noncompliance Plan requirements, the Licensee was asked to hire a new qualified Administrator to assist with daily operations and administrative duties for a minimum of 20 hours per week. The deadline for this requirement was set as June 1, 2021. The licensee has requested an extension for this deadline due to difficulties in the hiring process. During this meeting, it was discussed that the home would be granted an extension on this deadline, now set for Monday, October 4th, 2021. The licensee will provide regular updates on their progress in fulfilling this requirement. LPA Fremont will also reach out to the licensee periodically to check in on progress and provide any needed support. While the Licensee continues the process of hiring a new administrator, they have agreed to hire a qualified consultant to come to the home for 2-3 hours every week to provide technical assistance and improve the following areas: -Administrative organization and applicable regulations -Streamlining paperwork -Day-to-day operations -Staff schedules -Staff communication with outside agencies, authorized representatives, and other staff If the Licensee is not able to hire a new administrator by the 10/04/2021 deadline, it has been discussed that the two current assistant administrators, Irma Battung and Gilbert Battung, may step in after qualifications are verified. If this is the case, the consultant mentioned above will lead training for the new administrator. At this time, no deficiencies are being cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung to be signed and returned for the home's facility file.

At 1:15PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Madi Fremont and Alyssa Ng traveled to the home above for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Case Management - Legal/Noncompliance inspection. LPAs me with Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung who helped facilitate this inspection. Currently in care are 5 ambulatory clients. One client was present at the time of this inspection. The purpose of this inspection was to review the home's compliance as part of their Noncompliance Plan initiated in March 2021 (Please reference LIC9111 - Noncompliance Conference Summary dated 03/18/2021 for details). As part of this Department's review of this home's compliance, LPA asked to see the following documentation which is to be submitted upon request by the Licensing Agent per the Noncompliance Plan issued 03/18/2021: - Supervision and Staff Ratios: Administrator will document weekly hours for time performing Administrative duties and not Direct Care duties. Weekly hours will be readily available either electronically or in person upon request by Community Care Licensing (CCL). - Reporting Requirements: The licensee shall track trends and frequency of incidents through ongoing internal audit. Will be made readily available either electronically or in person upon request by CCL. - Health-Related Services: The licensee will create a monthly log of self-injurious behaviors, including antecedents to the incident, de-escalation techniques used, and any injuries sustained during the incidents. Monthly logs will be made readily available either electronically or in person upon request by CCL. (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

- Administration: The licensee will schedule Monthly Review Meetings with each clients' authorized representatives regarding their plan of care, services, and needs. Summary of review meetings will be made readily available either electronically or in-person upon request by CCL. - Administration: The administrator will be present and working in the facility for at least 20 hours per week. Hours will be made readily available either electronically or in person upon request by CCL. Upon this request, the Licensee was unable to produce proof of compliance with the aforementioned "upon request" requirements of their Noncompliance Plan. Next, LPA Fremont inquired about missed documentation submission deadlines for the following requirements of the facility's Noncompliance Plan: - Supervision and Staff Ratios: - Updated LIC500 Staff Schedule every 6 months starting June 1, 2021 through June 1, 2023. - 5PM, June 1, 2021 - received during annual inspection on 06/16/2021 - 5PM, December 1, 2021 - not received - Updated 1:1 staff assignments every 6 months starting June 1, 2021 through June 1, 2023. - 5PM, June 1, 2021 - not received - 5PM, December 1, 2021 - not received - Education: - Beginning April 1, 2021 through April 1, 2023, the Licensee shall submit quarterly summaries of progress, challenges, and barriers to clients' education: - 5PM, April 1, 2021 - overdue (submitted 04/06/2021 at 12:38PM with no extension request) - 5PM, July 7, 2021 - submitted early (06/17/2021 at 11:40PM) - 5PM, October 1, 2021 - not received - 5PM, January 2, 2022 - extension requested 02/15/2022, not submitted) (CONTINUED ON LIC809-C)

- Staff Training: - Beginning April 7, 2021 and continuing quarterly through April 7, 2023, the Licensee shall submit training sign-in sheets as well as training materials for all topics identified during Noncompliance Conference on 03/18/2021. - 5PM, April 7, 2021 - overdue (submitted 04/09/2021 at 5:03PM, no extension requested) - 5PM, July 7, 2021 - not received - 5PM, October 7, 2021 - not received - 5PM, January 7, 2022 - not received Upon request for aforementioned submissions, the Licensee could not provide LPAs with the requested documentation. When asked why the Licensee did not have this documentation available for review by this Licensing Agency, the Licensee stated they did not know who to submit documentation to (LPA Fremont transferred from San Bruno to San Jose Regional Office on October 1, 2021, but had informed licensee by email that any submissions, questions, or concerns could be communicated through LPA Fremont, LPM Helga Wong, LPM Zaid Hakim, or RM Nelson Martinez while the department hired a new LPA to take LPA Fremont's Place - email sent 09/30/2021, 4:01PM) Because no documentation could be produced at the time of this inspection, nor did LPA's receive any documentation submissions for the deadlines listed above, LPA Fremont could not proceed with this Noncompliance/Legal Case Management Inspection. LPA Fremont requested that all documentation listed above be provided over email no later than 5PM on Friday 02/25/2021. Licensee agreed to this deadline and stated they would requested a deadline extension before this deadline, if needed. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung, whose signature on this form confirms receupt.

On Friday June 17, 2022 at 10AM, San Jose Children's Residential Program Regional Manager Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers (LPMs) Helga Wong and Carolyn Flynn, and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Madeleine Fremont conducted an in-person Regional Office meeting with Morning Star Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung and Facility Manager Irma Battung. East Bay Regional Center representatives Derrick Levingston and Michael Minton joined virtually via Microsoft Teams. The purpose of this meeting was to discuss the following: - Non-Compliance Meeting conducted on 03/18/2021 where the home was placed on a two-year non-compliance plan. - Licensee/Administrator not completing or submitting their Non-Compliance Plan requirements. - The home continuing to have similar deficiencies and complaints. - The Licensee/Administrator not submitting Plans of Correction for previously-cited deficiencies. - Discussion of unprofessional conduct from the Licensee/Administrator, other facility personnel and CCL staff. - CCLD Inspection Authority - Administrative Action Through the first year of the Licensee's Non-Compliance Plan the Licensee has continued to be cited for similar issued and has not fulfilled the qualifications of their non-compliance plan. The Licensee will be referred to Community Care Licensing's Legal Department for revocation of licensure or decertification of the Administrator(s). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was sent to Licensee Reggieanne Villar-Battung, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 6/24/2022 at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Alyssa Ng and Lisette Valenzuela made an unannounced case management to this facility. The purpose of the inspection was to review the facilities Non-Compliance. On 06/17/22 at 10:30 AM, an office meeting was held, and the facility had a plan in place, and are submitting all documents to the Department by 4:59 PM today. During facility visit, the following was discussed: Supervision and Staff Ratios: -LIC500 to be submitted directly to CCL every 6 months, starting June 1, 2021 through June 1, 2023. The licensee will keep an ongoing updated weekly schedule to ensure full staff coverage. Every 6 months, beginning June 1, 2021 and continuing through June 1, 2023, the licensee will submit updated staff assignments for each child requiring 1:1 supervision. -Administrator will document weekly hours for time performing Administrative duties and not direct care duties. Weekly hours will be made readily available upon request by CCL. Education: -The licensee/staff must communicate with each client's educators when requested by the school -The licensee/staff must report to school when clients are absent on the day of their absence before the session begins. -Licensee/staff must work with educators and responsible parties on their education plan and progress. -The licensee/staff must participate in IEP meetings for each client when scheduled. -Staff must be present at all times to assist with online education. -Beginning April 1, 2021 through April 1, 2023, the licensee will submit quarterly summary of progress as well as challenges/barriers to education.

Staff Training: -Retrain all facility staff on providing care and supervision, personal rights, duties and responsibilities, health related services, reporting requirements, communication, providing education, ensuring the health and safety of the clients, and computer/technology/IT skills. (1 hour for each training topic). -Beginning April 7, 2021 and continuing quarterly through April 7, 2023, the licensee will submit training sign-in sheets as well as training materials for the above-mentioned topics to CCL. By June 24, 2022 at 4:59 PM, the licensee will submit a training timeline to CCL that includes topics, dates, and trainer information. Personnel Requirements and Duties: -The facility will hire a qualified administrator to assist with daily operations and administrative duties for a minimum of 20 hours per week. Deadline for this requirement is set as June 24, 2022 at 4:59 PM. Reporting Requirements: -The licensee will start evaluating unusual incidents on an individual basis to ensure that all parties are informed of incidents in a timely manner consistent with CCR 80061 - Reporting Requirements. -The Licensee will track trends and frequency of incidents through ongoing internal audit, and will make available upon request by this agency. Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung agreed to submit all of the following no later than today by 4:59 PM. No Title 22 deficiencies were cited at today’s inspection. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was left with the facility.

On 6/24/22 at 12:06 PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Alyssa Ng and Lisette Valenzuela made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 5 clients. During this inspection,1 clients and 3 staff were present in the home. LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied, and has two double occupancy bedrooms and one single occupancy bedroom. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings, desks and chairs, and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 110 degrees F. The thermostat measured 78 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. The weekly menu was posted in the family room. The facility has a fireplace which is not in use, and has a grate as well as a couch backed up to the front to ensure clients cannot access the fireplace. LPA's observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors and fire extinguishers are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA's observed extra linens in two closets in the hallway. LPA's toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. There are two play structures which are anchored to the ground, and a sitting area in the backyard. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is kept gated at all times and inaccessible to clients. ----------CONT. ON 809C------

All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client has their own separate binder of all required documents. Each psychotropic medication was observed to have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR), as well as individual Centrally Stored Medication Destruction Records (CSMDR). All medications were consistent with these records. Staff has a centralized binder that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. LPA looked through all binders and were complete with all the required documentation. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung.

investigation_findings: 13On 6/24/2022 at 10:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng conducted a follow-up complaint inspection at Morning Star and spoke with Administrator/Licensee Reggieanne Villar-Battung and Facility Manager Irma Battung. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During investigation, incident reports and records were reviewed, and confidential interviews were conducted. Based on interviews and record review, Morning Star conducted two sessions on August 19th and 20th for C1 in 2021. Other than that, Morning Star did not conduct any Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) sessions in the facility. ABA sessions has been taken place at C1 and C2's fathers or grandmothers house. C1 and C2 have a maximum of 15 hours of ABA a week. They are currently using 6-9 hours a week. Based on LPAs observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation, Facility is not meeting minor's medical needs is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations,Title 22, Division 6 & Chapter 1, Health Related Services, 80075 (a) are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights prvoded and discussed, and a copy of this report was given to Reggieanne Villar-Battung, Administrator/Licensee.

deficiencies.description:
84078 Responsibility for Providing Care and Supervision: (b) The licensee shall provide those services identified in each child's needs and services plan and in individualized health care plan for each child with special health care needs as necessary to meet the child's needs. 
This requirement was not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and review of facility records, the licensee is denying C1 and C2's medically necessary Applied Behavior Analysis therapy, which was ordered by a healthcare professional and is in the clients' needs and services plan. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will submit a plan to train facility staff on assisting with ABA in the home in conjunction with RCEB and KYO, and a plan to integrate ABA back into the facility's service plan. Licensee will create a plan of when ABA can take place inside the group home to fulfill the maximum hours of ABA the clients need. This will be submitted to the Department by 11:59PM on 7/1/2022.

On 6/20/23 at 10:40 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Ng made an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are 5 clients. During this inspection, 0 clients and 3 staff were present in the home. Safety precautions were taken, including screening call, hand hygiene, and mask-wearing. LPA Ng toured the facility inside and out. The home is single storied, and has two double occupancy bedrooms and one single occupancy bedroom. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings, desks and chairs, and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 109 degrees F. The thermostat measured 67 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. The weekly menu was posted in the family room. The facility has a fireplace which is not in use, and has a gate as well as a couch backed up to the front to ensure clients cannot access the fireplace. LPA's observed at least 2 days of perishable foods and 7 days of nonperishable foods. The smoke detectors and fire extinguishers are in working order. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPA's observed extra linens in two closets in the hallway. LPA's toured the backyard and observed it to be free from hazards. There are two play structures which are anchored to the ground, and a sitting area in the backyard. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. Facility is in the process of taking down a play structure due to the clients getting older. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is kept gated at all times and inaccessible to clients. All client records complete with all of the required documentation. Each client has their own separate binder of all required documents. Each psychotropic medication was observed to have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR), as well as individual Centrally Stored Medication Destruction Records (CSMDR).

All medications were consistent with these records. Staff has a centralized binder that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. LPA looked through all binders and were complete with all the required documentation. At this time, no deficiencies were observed or cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was emailed to Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung.

On 6/10/24 at 9:48 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam and LPA Shikya Belfield conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection to listed facility. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are four clients. During this inspection, 4 clients and 5 staffs were present in the home. LPA Lam and LPA Belfield toured the facility inside and out. The home is a single story, and has two double occupancy bedrooms and one single occupancy bedroom. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and twin sized beds. One double occupancy bedroom include a desk and a chair. One single occupancy bedroom includes a sofa. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. Each bedroom contained a dual smoke and carbon monoxide detector is placed on the hallway ceiling and in each client bedroom. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 109.9 degrees F. The thermostat measured 72 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were located in a locked cabinet. The weekly menu was posted on the side of the refrigerator in the kitchen. The facility has a fireplace which is not in use, and has a gate as well as a couch backed up to the front to ensure clients cannot access the fireplace. LPA interviewed three staff. No clients were interviewed as they are all non-verbal.

LPAs observed at least 2 days of perishable foods that are dated and 7 days of nonperishable foods. Fire extinguishers are in working order and located in the garage. Two refrigerators were observed in the garage as well as a washer and a dryer. Garage contains locked storage of soaps and detergents and cleaning supplies. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPAs observed extra linens and towels in the hallway closet. LPAs toured the backyard and observed two play structures which are anchored to the ground, and a sitting area in the backyard with a grill. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. LPAs observed a swing set and a play structure in the backyard. At 10:24 AM, LPAs observed objects under one of the play structure, there was no cushion or padding, and objects around the backyard that could pose a potential hazard. A technical assistance advisory is being issued for section 84087.2(b) Outdoor Activity Space, of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six. Facility is in the process of replacing play structure with a trampoline. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is kept gated at all times and inaccessible to clients. Staff have two centralized binders, that contained their training, qualifications, and other personal information. At 1:10 PM, LPAs observed staff schedule. LPAs observed one staff member without a criminal record clearance. LPA's reviewed four staff files and one client file. Three staff were interviewed. All clients in the facility are nonverbal and could not be interviewed. Each psychotropic medication was observed to have its own Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR). More information and file review is needed and a follow-up visit is required to complete this annual inspection. At this time, a technical assistance was given for 84087.2(b) Outdoor Activity Space. One deficiency was cited at the visit (refer to LIC809-D). The citation include 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. The facility is being issued a civil penalty. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided Licensee/Administrator Reggieanne Villar-Battung prior to leaving the facility.

On 7/1/24 at 12:35 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mona Lam and LPA Shikya Belfield conducted an unannounced annual/required continuation inspection to the above listed facility. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are four clients. During this inspection, 4 clients and 4 staff were present in the home. During this inspection LPA's reviewed the remaining files for clients. A walk through of the facility was conducted with Reggieanne Villar-Battung. During a review of client files, four out of four clients were observed to not have record of cash resources and banking information for client money. Facility issued a Technical Violation Advisory for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 80026(h)(1) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables of Residents. During the client file review it was observed that two of four clients did not have information in their needs and services plan regarding their ability to handle money. Facility issued a Technical Assistance Advisory for California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84068.2(b)(6) Needs and Services Plan. During a walk through of the facility on 6/10/2024, it was observed that two clients ( C2 and C4 see lic 811 dated 7/1/2024) are sharing a bedroom. There is currently no documentation of compatibility and there is no exception request filed by the facility. Facility is being cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Section 84087(b)(6)(B) Buildings and Grounds, as described on the following page 809D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights will be left with Licensee Reggieanne Villar-Battung

deficiencies.description: If two children have been sharing a bedroom and one of them turns 18 they may continue to share the bedroom as long as they remain compatible and the licensing agency has granted an exception pursuant to Section 80024. This requirement was not met as evidenced by, During a walk through of the facility on 6/10/2024, it was observed that two clients ( C2 and C4) are sharing a bedroom. There is currently no documentation of compatibility and there is no exception request filed by the facility. This poses a potential Health,Safety, or Person RIghts risk to the clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee agrees to submit an exception request and supportive documentation for the room sharing. This will be submitted to the department by the plan of correction due date of 7/12/2024.

narrative:
On 8-19-24 10:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) George Karkazis conducted an unannounced Case Management Non-Compliance Conference (NCC) inspection at Morning Star , and met with Reggieanne Villar-Battung, Administrator. On 3-18-2021, Community Care Licensing held a Non-Compliance Conference. The purpose of today's inspection was to review the progress of the facility since they had their NCC. Inspections shall occur quarterly. A short discussion transpired regarding the future conversion of this facility to an Adult Residential Facility (ARF) and to open another children's residential facility in the Hayward area. Present were two staff and no clients. The following conditions were stated and discussed during today's inspection and also during the NCC: Supervision and Staff Ratios: -LIC500 to be submitted directly to CCL every 6 months, starting June 1, 2021 through June 1, 2023. The licensee will keep an ongoing updated weekly schedule to ensure full staff coverage. Every 6 months, beginning June 1, 2021 and continuing through June 1, 2023, the licensee will submit updated staff assignments for each child requiring 1:1 supervision. -Administrator will document weekly hours for time performing Administrative duties and not direct care duties. Weekly hours will be made readily available upon request by CCL. LPA Karkazis reviewed posted schedule. Administrator participates in client IEP's, coordinate medications, meets with behaviorist, quality assurance with Regional Center, Licensing, and staff training. The conditions have been met and fulfilled. Education: -The licensee/staff must communicate with each client's educators when requested by the school -The licensee/staff must report to school when clients are absent on the day of their absence before the session begins. -Licensee/staff must work with educators and responsible parties on their education plan and progress. -The licensee/staff must participate in IEP meetings for each client when scheduled. -Staff must be present at all times to assist with online education. -Beginning April 1, 2021 through April 1, 2023, the licensee will submit quarterly summary of progress as well as challenges/barriers to education. LPA viewed IEP reports and educational progress. continued on LIC 809-C

continued from LIC 809 This condition has been met and fulfilled. Staff Training: -Retrain all facility staff on providing care and supervision, personal rights, duties and responsibilities, health related services, reporting requirements, communication, providing education, ensuring the health and safety of the clients, and computer/technology/IT skills. (1 hour for each training topic). -Beginning April 7, 2021 and continuing quarterly through April 7, 2023, the licensee will submit training sign-in sheets as well as training materials for the above-mentioned topics to CCL. By April 1, 2021, the licensee will submit a training timeline to CCL that includes topics, dates, and trainer information. LPA viewed training logs and certificates for summer months of 2024, PPE, HCBS Training- helping to understand clients' individual needs and how to provide them. This condition has been met and fulfilled. Personnel Requirements and Duties: -The facility will hire a qualified administrator to assist with daily operations and administrative duties for a minimum of 20 hours per week. Deadline for this requirement is set as June 1, 2021. LPA viewed staff schedule, Administrator Reggieanne VIllar-Battung works at least 20 hours per week. This condition has been met and fulfilled. Reporting Requirements: -The licensee will start evaluating unusual incidents on an individual basis to ensure that all parties are informed of incidents in a timely manner consistent with CCR 80061 - Reporting Requirements. -The Licensee will track trends and frequency of incidents through ongoing internal audit, and will make available upon request by this agency. LPA viewed ISP Annual Report which shows all incident reports, annual status summary, shared with Regional Center and client representatives. This condition has been met and fulfilled. Health Related Services: -The licensee will update the facility's Plan of Operation and staff training regarding obtaining medical assessments or services in cases where an unusual incident threatens the health or safety of a client. To be submitted to CCL no later than 5PM on Monday, May 3, 2021. -Licensee will ensure space is made available for outside services to come into the home. If space cannot be made available, accommodations will be made to have the service provided outside of the home with trained facility staff sent out to assist with the service. Plan will be submitted no later than Monday, May 17, 2021 at 5PM. -The licensee will create a monthly log of self injurious behaviors, including antecedents to the incident, de-escalation techniques used, and any injuries sustained during the episodes. continued on LIC 809-C

continued from LIC 809 Personal Rights: -The Licensee will meet quarterly with responsible parties and clients to review each child's personal rights to identify any concerns, issues, or violations of rights. Summary of meetings with each responsible party will be submitted to CCL on a quarterly basis beginning July 1, 2021 and continuing for 2 years. -Update facility visitation plan to allow for planned visitation from visitors, to be submitted no later than 5PM on March 31, 2021. Visitation plan is on file. This condition has been met and fulfilled. The facility has met all conditions of the Non-Compliance Conference which started on 3-18-2021. Quarterly inspections shall cease and Morning Star is no longer on compliance as of 8-19-24. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Reggieanne Villar-Battung, Administrator.

continued from LIC 809 -Monthly logs will be made available at the request of CCL representatives for audit. LPA viewed a monthly log of self injurious behaviors, de-escalation techniques used, and injuries. This condition has been met and fulfilled. Administration: -The Licensee will provide proof of follow-through for all POCs issued for complaints on 02/12/2021, as well as POCs for deficiencies cited during Case Management on 03/18/2021. -Proof of POC follow-through will be submitted no later than 5PM on June 1, 2021. -The Licensee will schedule Monthly Review Meetings with each client's authorized representatives regarding their plan of care, services, and needs. Summary of review meetings will be made available for audit at the request of CCL. -The Licensee will update their Plan of Operation to reflect changes in communication procedures, including prompt communication with authorized representatives, teachers, therapists, etc. (set time frame), as well as staff in charge of communication. Revisions to be submitted no later than 5PM on May 3, 2021. -The Licensee will submit administrator qualifications (Administrator Certificate, LIC501, LIC503, LIC508, transcripts, other certificates, work history/resume) for each of the three assistant administrators to ensure compliance with Administrator Qualifications Section 80064. To be submitted no later than 5PM on April 12, 2021. -Licensee/administrators will ensure that all deadlines set by CCL are followed through with and will request additional time for deadlines if needed, prior to the originally set deadline. -Licensee will submit Policy and Procedures for how POCs will be submitted on time, no later than 5PM, May 3, 2021. -Administrator will be present and working in the facility for at least 20 hours per week. Hours will be made available at the request of CCL. All Plan of Corrections (POC) and Plan of Operation updates are on file. Administrator is licensed and working at the facility for at least 20 hours per week This condition has been met and fulfilled. continued on LIC 809-C

On 10/30/24, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jonathan Medina and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Carolyn Flynn conducted a quarterly case management inspection, per the agreed upon terms of the 10/06/23 STIPULATION AND WAIVER; AND ORDER. At the start of the visit no clients were present, but all four clients arrived by the end. There were six staff present during the visit. LPA and LPM toured the facility and observed the back yard, kitchen, garage, three bedrooms, living room, and two bathrooms. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA and LPM reviewed the stipulations with the Facility Managers section by section. At this time there are no California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6 Chapter 5 deficiencies observed. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was given to Facility Managers Reggieanne Villar-Battung and Irma Battung whose signature on this form confirms receipt of these documents .

On July 8th, 2025 at 9:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Hanako Primer and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Joel Segura conducted a quarterly case management inspection pursuant to the agreed-upon terms of the 10/06/23 STIPULATION AND WAIVER; AND ORDER. LPA and LPM met Reggieanne Villar-Battung, Facility Manager, and Irma Battung, Facility Manager. LPA and LPM informed the facility managers of the purpose of the visit. LPA issued one Technical Assistance under 84064(c) Administrator Qualifications. See LIC9102. LPA observed on LIC500 new administrator had been hired, and advised facility to submit required documents to Community Care Licensing.

No deficiencies were cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Reggieanne Villar-Battung, Facility Manager. Reggieanne Villar-Battung's signature on this form confirms receipt of the document.

On 08/05/25 at 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Simran Nayyar and Hanako Primer conducted an unannounced annual/required inspection of the listed facility. The facility is licensed for six residents, and currently in placement are four clients. During this inspection, four (4) clients and six (6) staff were present in the home. LPA Nayyar and LPA Primer toured the facility inside and out. LPAs inspected three (3) client bedrooms. All client bedrooms were equipped with comfortable furnishings which included ample storage space for clients' belongings and twin sized beds. Each bedroom has a closet with sliding doors for extra storage space. A dual smoke and carbon monoxide detector is placed on the hallway ceiling and in each client bedroom. Client bathroom was clean and furnished with hygiene supplies for each client. The water temperature measured 119.2 degrees F. The thermostat measured 70 degrees. The facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The kitchen was observed to be clean and free of hazards or chemicals. Sharps were in a locked cabinet. The weekly menu was posted on the side of the refrigerator in the kitchen. The facility has a fireplace which is not in use and has a gate as well as a couch backed up to the front to ensure clients cannot access the fireplace. LPAs interviewed two staff. No clients were interviewed as they are all non-verbal. (Continued on LIC809-C)

LPAs observed at least 2 days of perishable foods that are dated and 7 days of nonperishable foods. Fire extinguishers are in working order and located in the garage. Two refrigerators were observed in the garage as well as a washer and a dryer. Garage contains locked storage of soaps and detergents and cleaning supplies. No bodies of water on the premises. All walkways were free from debris or hazards. LPAs observed extra linens and towels in the hallway closet. LPAs toured the backyard and observed a sitting area in the backyard with a grill. The backyard is surrounded by a wooden fence with locked gates. LPAs observed a swing set anchored to the ground. LPAs observed there was no cushion or padding under the swing set, which could pose a potential health and safety risk to the clients. One (1) Type B violation is being issued for section 84087.2(b) Outdoor Activity Space, of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six. The facility has a centralized AC unit in the side yard which is kept gated at all times and inaccessible to clients. Staff have two centralized binders, that contained their training, qualifications, and other personnel information. LPAs observed staff schedules and reviewed five (5) staff files. During the staff file review LPAs observed staff training certificates, health screening reports, CPR certificates, and personnel record in five out of five staff files. LPAs observed that five out five staff files did not contain an assessment to prove that each childcare staff can understand and apply the initial training. One (1) Technical Violation is being issued under 84065(i)(1)(D) Personnel Requirements of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six. More information and file review are needed and a follow-up visit is required to complete this annual inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Facility Manager, Reggieanne Villar-Battung prior to leaving the facility.

On 08/07/25 at 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Simran Nayyar and Hanako Primer conducted an unannounced annual/required continuation inspection to the above listed facility. The facility is licensed for six (6) clients, and currently in placement are four (4) clients. During this inspection, four (4) clients and five (5) staff were present in the home. During this inspection LPA's reviewed four (4) out of four (4) client files and the Emergency Intervention records. During the client file review LPAs observed the Admission Agreement forms, Appraisal forms, Needs and Services Plans, Cash Resources, Initial Medical Assessments, Medication Administration Records, and Bedroom Sharing Agreement forms. During the review LPAs observed psychotropic medication logs and non-psychotropic medication logs were not kept separate. Psychotropic medications were recorded on two (2) out four (4) clients' Medication Administration Records. At this time one (1) Technical Violation is being issued under 84070(b)(16) Children's Records of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six. While reviewing the Emergency Intervention Records LPAs observed competency tests were not conducted as part of Emergency Intervention Training. At this time one (1) Technical Assistance is being issued under 84365(d)(1)(C) Emergency Intervention Staff Training of the California Code of Regulations. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with appeal rights was left with Facility Manager, Reggieanne Villar-Battung whose signature on this report confirms receipt.

On February 03, 2022 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager Gia Williams, and together a tour of the entire facility. The facility is licensed for 5 developmentally disable children ages 11 through 17 years old, Ambulatory only. Currently there is one (1) minor and two (2) male NonMinor Dependents (NMD) in placement by Westside Regional Centers. LPA observed that there are no bodies on water on the premises. The Administrator confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The Group Home Overview: This is a one (1) story home located in a residential neighborhood. There is a Living room; Dining room, Kitchen. There is a locked two (2) car garage, currently utilized as a storage and other miscellaneous item. The Hot Water Heater is strapped located out of the house. There is one (1) vehicle parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition (The vehicles car was checked for tires, headlights, tail lights, turn signals, horn and windshield wipers). Car #1 Make and Model 2018 540 BMW; Proof of Insurance (GICO 2/20/2022); Car Registration (Expiration 11/23) and current Driver’s License. The Licensee ensured that no smoking is allowed in the vehicles. BEDROOMS: All three (3) bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin bed, comfortable mattress, linen, blanket and pillows; adequate drawer space and a closet. Bedroom #1: Occupied by a minor C1; Bedroom #2: Occupied by C2- NMD. This bedroom is equipped with two (2) twins sized beds. There is an exit that leads to the backyard. Bedroom #3: Occupied by C3- NMD BATHROOMS: Bathroom #1 and #2 All were inspected and found to be clean. LPA test the water temperature, bathroom sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. The water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit.

Living room: Is equipped with a two (2) recliner chairs. A sofa, a television that is mounted in the wall; entertainment stand filled with age appropriate books and games. Kitchen: Is equipped with a four (4) burner gas stove/oven, refrigerator/freezer, a microwave, and a dishwasher that is not operable. investigation_findings: 13On September 29, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) C. White made an unannounced visit to Mosaic of Friends IV, located at 7344 87th Street Westchester, CA. 90045 for the purpose of delivering findings on the above complaint allegation. LPA met with Administrator, Gia Williams and discussed the investigation. During the course of this investigation, confidential interviews were conducted with pertinent parties. Interviews did not produce corroborating evidence to support the allegation. LPA was unable to interview Client #1 as client was replaced with family. Additionally, there was no evidence or witnesses to support the allegation that minor sustained injuries while in care. Based on information obtained, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. No deficiencies cited. Exit interview completed and a copy of this report was left with the Administrator.

On May 30, 2025, at 11:35 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Rosslyn arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting a Case Management-Other inspection. LPA met with Administrator Assistant Gia Griffin. A health and risk assessment were conducted. During a complaint investigation, LPA reviewed facility staff associations and observed that Staff #3 is not associated to the facility. Review of Staff #3 personnel file indicates that they have worked in the facility since January 1, 2025. Incident Reports dated May 19th - May 22nd, 2025, indicate that Staff #3 was present working in the facility without a criminal record clearance and/or clearance transfer. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 80019(a)(D) Criminal Record Clearance. Documentation indicates that Staff #3 worked in facility May 19th - May 22nd, 2025, without a criminal record clearance and/or clearance transfer. Exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and Appeal Rights were provided to the Administrator Gia Griffin.

deficiencies.description: Criminal Record Clearance. (e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility: (2) Obtain a California clearance or a criminal record exemption asrequired by the Department or.. This requirement is not evidenced by: Based on documentary evidence Staff #3 was working in the facility providing care and supervision May 19th – May 22nd, 2025. Staff #3 is not associated to facility and fingerprint clearance is pending.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Deficiency was discussed with the Administrator Gia Griffin. The Facility will submit a written plan of correction regarding policy and procedure to ensure all staff will have a criminal record clearance before beginning work, no later than June 13, 2025. Staff #3 were immediately removed from the scheduled until fingerprint clearance was completed.

deficiencies.description: Civil Penalties: Not obtaining the fingerprint clearances required for licensure by Health and Safety Code section 1522, subsection (b) as stated in Section 89219, Criminal Record Clearance.  Civil penalties shall be assessed as specified in Health and Safety Code section 1522, subsection (c).  A civil penalty assessment was made for Staff #3 who was working in the facility providing care and supervision May 19th – May 22nd, 2025. Staff #3 is not associated to facility and fingerprint clearance is pending.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
An invoice will be mailed out to the facility. All civil penalties are due and payable upon receipt of notice for payment, and shall be paid only by check or money order made payable to 
the agency indicated in the notice.

narrative:
On January 26, 2022 at 11:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray arrived at the above facility for the purpose of conducting Annual Required Inspection. LPA met with Facility Manager Gia Griffin, and together a tour of the entire facility. The facility is licensed for 5 developmentally disable children ages 11 through 17 years old, Ambulatory only. Clients are currently placed by Westside; South Central Regional Centers. Currently there a three (3) male NonMinor Dependents (NMD) in placement. LPA observed that there are no bodies on water on the premises. The Licensee confirmed that there are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the facility. The Group Home Overview: This is a two (2) story home located in a residential neighborhood. There is a Living room; Dining room, Kitchen. There is a locked two (2) car garage, currently utilized as a storage and other miscellaneous item. The Hot Water Heater is strapped. There are two (2) vehicle parked outside inspected to be in good operating condition (The vehicles car was checked for tires, headlights, tail lights, turn signals, horn and windshield wipers). Car #1 Make and Model 2018 540 BMW; Proof of Insurance (GICO 02/20/2022); Car Registration (Expiration 11/23) and current Driver’s License. Car # Make and Model (2018 330 BMW) Proof of Insurance (Farmers 06/14/2022); Car Registration (Expiration 09/28/2022 and current Driver’s License. The Licensee ensured that no smoking is allowed in the vehicles. BEDROOMS: All three (3) bedrooms are equipped with one (1) twin bed, comfortable mattress, linen, blanket and pillows; adequate drawer space and a closet. Bedroom #1: Bedroom #2: Bedroom #3: are all occupied. Bedroom 4: is located on the second floor is not occupied, and it is utilized as a staffing office. LIC 809 PAGE 1 OF 3

BATHROOMS: Bathroom #1 and #2 are located on the 1st floor. All were inspected and found to be clean. LPA test the water temperature, bathroom sinks and ensured that all toilets flushed. The water temperature measured within safe temperatures, at not less than 105 and did not exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Bathroom #1: located in the hallway between bedroom #1 and bedroom #2. The door is broken, but in operable condition. Bathroom #2: is attached to bedroom #3, it is also accessible through a door located off the laundry area. Living room: Is equipped with a two (2) sofas, a television that is mounted in the wall. A book shelf, a non-operational fireplace with a screen, and a wall furnace heater is operable with recent maintenance. Staff ensured that it is safe and not hot to the touch and that the temperature gage does not exceed 70 degrees. Dining Room Table: Is damaged and is schedule to be replaced. Kitchen: Is equipped with a gas stove/oven, refrigerator/freezer, a microwave, and a dishwasher. The facility has adequate perishable/nonperishable supply of food. Facility staff provide nutritious meals and snacks. Two (2) hot meals are prepared per day. The kitchen trash has a lid cover. All knives, medications, cleaning supplies, and hazardous materials are kept locked and inaccessible to clients in care. There is adequate hygiene and grooming supplies and ample amount of extra clean linen. Laundry room: is located off the kitchen is equipped with a washer and dryer and observed to be in good condition. There is an operable facility telephone readily accessible to clients. LPA observed combined Smoke detector and Carbon Monoxide; tested to be operable. All the prescribed medications; medication logs, files and are locked key in the office on the second floor. The First Aid kit is in the kitchen area cabinet. It has the required items inside (age-appropriate, and scissors, tweezers, thermometer, and gauzes, antiseptic and First Aid Manual Guide. Outdoor Area: The outdoor perimeter front yard, and backyard were inspected and found cleared of debris and hazards materials. The stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. LPA observed a broken wooden gate that leads to the side of the house that is obstructed and does not meet regulations and is schedule to be repaired. LPA observed two (2) missing window screens and one (1) ripped window screen that did not meet regulations are scheduled to be replaced. There were no security bars on the windows. Blinds and drapes from the inside and outside were observed to be in good condition. Report continued on LIC809C 2 of 3

LPA observed utility shut-off valves for gas and water located on side of house. Clients in care are supervised, protected, and are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. The facility staff ensures that the clients are transported to school and accompany to extracurricular, cultural and personal enrichment activities. The facility met all posting requirements and operates within license capacity and limitations. LPA observed that Licensee ensures that CDC Guidelines are implemented in effort to prevents other from contracting the COVID-19 virus (i.e wash hands with alcohol based, wipes, hand sanitizes and gloves) and signs posted. The Licensee will report changes in the plan of operation affecting service to clients. Client Records: Three (3) clients in care. Staff Records: Three (3) staff. LPA obtained the Facility Profile and Personnel Report and confirmed that the Licensee have required criminal record clearance. DOJ, FBI and Child Abuse Response; which meet qualification. Staff Interviews: LPA conducted a confidential interview with the Licensee Administrator and two (2) other staff. LPA observed deficiencies in the physical plant that did not meet regulations and the facility was cited. LPA’s concluded the Annual Required Inspection. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the at the Licensee on 01/26/2022

On February 25, 2022 at 2:15PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rosslyn Gray conducted a Plan of Correction (POC) virtual Case Management Inspection at the MOSAIC OF FRIENDS IV Group Home via FaceTime with the facility Administrator on January 26, 2022 an Annual inspection was conducted and the facility was cited for several deficiencies of the physical environment that did not meet regulations. The purpose of conducting the Case Management inspection is to ensure that the deficiencies has been corrected. On this day LPA-Gray observed that the entire kitchen ceiling had been replaced with adequate lighting; the side yard wooden gate was repaired; all damaged window screens were replaced; a new dining table was ordered and was being assembled and the bathroom broken door was replaced. The Licensee complied with the California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation Cited ILS 84487(f)/ Buildings and Grounds 84487(f) states that “The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair at all times. There were no deficiencies cited at this time. LPA concluded the inspection, Cleared the POC and a copy of this report will be emailed to the licensee for signature.

On June 12, 2022, at 9:30 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olivia Rosas arrived at Mosaic of Friends IV unannounced for the purpose of conducting a SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection Visit. LPA Rosas met with Gia Williams, Administration Lead. Individuals mention in this report are identify on the Confidential Names List (LIC811) dated 07/12/22. LPA Rosas reviewed zero (0) client files and three (3) staff files. LPA Rosas conducted three (3) staff interviews and zero (0) client interview due to clients being Non-Minor Dependent and not meeting criteria for the SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Case Management- Medication Inspection. Currently there are three (3) clients residing in the above facility. This is a two-story home located in a residential area and equipped with three (3) bedrooms, (2) two bathrooms, living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry space, and an attach garage. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Common areas area clean and in good repair. Rooms are fully furnished with beds, and closet space. Outdoor space is free of obstructions. LPA Rosas observed the facility to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. LPA Rosas observed adequate staffing in the facility to provide care and supervision to children in care. LPA Rosas also observed medication to be stored in a cabinet that is kept locked and inaccessible to clients and unauthorized staff members. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores conducted a virtual case management inspection to follow up on an incident. Community Care Licensing received an incident report on 10/13/2020 detailing an incident that occurred on 10/05/2020 when foster child (FC) was involved in several restraints. FC was placed in 12 restraints beginning at 18:58 and ending at 20:05 with one restraint having to be conducted in a vehicle. LPA Walker-Flores discussed the incident with Rene van der Meer. No citations are being issued at this time. A follow up meeting to discuss restraints was scheduled for a later date.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative: On 10/29/2020 an informal conference was conducted virtually between Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives and Mountain Valley administration to discuss concerns regarding restraints. CCL representatives included Regional Manager Margo Castenda, Licensing Program Manager Daniel Allmon, Licensing Program Analyst Danielle Walker-Flores. Mountain Valley administration included Rene Van Der Meer Program Manager, Dan Petrie CEO, Michelle Bonner Program Director, and Jai Hanes Training Specialist. The concerns discussed include the following: The number of restraints being conducted – from 10/12/20 -10/16/20 14 restraint notifications with 47 restraints being reported; from 10/19/20 -10/23/20 17 restraint notifications with 51 restraints being reported. Agency stated that the high increase of restraints are due to specific clients that have violent behavior towards staff and other clients. Both clients have been given discharge notice and only one remains in the facility awaiting to be discharged. The intake process and compatibility procedures conducted prior accepting placement. Agency stated that the intake procedures are thorough and much consideration is given to accepting placement including if the client is a good fit for their program. The documentation included in Incident Reports (IR) should be trauma informed and contain all necessary information prior to and after the restraint is administered. De-escalation techniques utilized prior to the restraint should be clearly documented in the IR. Licensee agreed to include more detail in describing the behaviors that warranted a restraint. CCL and Licensee agreed to collaborate on an IR training. CCL requested that the use of solo restraints be removed from the program. The agency and CCL will have a follow up meeting to discuss progress.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
met_with: Rene Van Der Meer - Program Manager
narrative: On 01/19/2021 a second informal conference was conducted virtually between Community Care Licensing (CCL) representatives and Mountain Valley administration to discuss concerns regarding restraints. CCL representatives included Regional Manager Margo Castaneda, Licensing Program Manager Daniel Allmon, Licensing Program Analyst Danielle Walker-Flores and Licensing Program Analyst Kellie McKinely. Mountain Valley administration included Rene Van Der Meer Program Manager, Dan Petrie CEO, Michelle Bonner Program Director, Al Petrie Director of Program Development, and Jai Hanes Training Specialist. Stephanie Ivler from the Alliance and Aimee Foster Investigative Analyst Foster Care Ombudsman Office were also present. The concerns discussed include the following: Restraints -high number of restraints conducted in October and November. Licensee stated that the high number of restraints were due to a few clients and not a representation of the overall program. Staff S1 (see confidential names titled 01/21/21) S2, S3 and S4 being involved in more restraint incidents than the other staff. Licensee explained that often, specific staff will respond to a restraint call. S1, S2, S3, S4 also work in an area on the Ranch where the most restraints are conducted due to behavior of the clients. · Use of Supine restraint - Licensee agreed to submit an addendum to their program statement and add in the Supine restraint. Emergency Intervention Plan Biannual Review. Licensee agreed to send CCL the reviews from 2019 and 2020. Documentation requested by CCL should include: 15 minute checklist, biannual review of 2019 and 2020, Debriefing checklist, addendum of program statement to include Supine. CCL requested the removal of the solo person basket restraint due to safety concerns. Licensee requested further review of regulation to continue the use of the solo person basket restraint. As of 02/11/21 there is no current identified regulation prohibiting the use of solo person restraint as long as the restraint is consistent with the height and weight ratio requirements specified in the program statement. The height and weight of the client and staff performing the single person basket restraint is to be submitted with the incident report if Licensee continues the use of the solo restraint.
