met_with: Rene Van Der Meer - Program Manager
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores conducted a case management inspection and interviewed client, C1 (see confidential names titled 02/12/21) via Microsoft Teams video conference. This inspection is to follow up on an incident report involving C1 and a restraint that resulted in injuries to the hand. Incident report states the injuries were self inflicted. LPA interviewed C1 and Rene Van Der Meer - Program Manager. Further investigation is needed to complete this case management.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
met_with: Rene Van Der Meer - Program Manager
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores arrived at the agency to conduct a case management inspection regarding an incident. Community Care Licensing was notified that foster child FC1 (see confidential names list titled 05/14/21) sustained a head laceration during an altercation with staff S1 on 05/10/2021. FC1 was taken to the emergency room and S1 was suspended immediately pending investigation. LPA reviewed video clip, interviewed Administrator, interviewed clients, and reviewed personnel file. Personnel documentation was unavailable during inspection. Program Manager agreed to send the requested documentation via email. Further information is needed to complete this case management.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
met_with: Rene Van Der Meer - Program Manager
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores arrived at the agency to conduct a case management inspection regarding an incident. Community Care Licensing was notified on 05/10/21 that foster child FC1 (see confidential names list titled 06/25/21) sustained a head laceration during an altercation with staff S1. FC1 was taken to the emergency room and the wound was closed with skin glue. S1 was suspended immediately pending investigation. LPA reviewed video clip and personnel file, interviewed Administrator, interviewed clients and previous staff that was involved in the incident. The video shows FC1 running at S1 with their arm out attempting to assault S1. S1 then pushes FC1 down on the ground with force and S1 hits the back of his head on the cement. Agency suspended S1 immediately and reviewed the video clip. After review, it was determined that S1 would be terminated, however, S1 resigned on 05/17/21. At this time, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights is being cited. Personal Rights: To be free of physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature including, but not limited to, interference with the daily living functions of eating, sleeping, or toileting, or withholding of shelter, clothing, or aids to physical functioning.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
met_with: Rene van der Meer - Program Manager
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores arrived at the agency on today's date to conduct a case management inspection regarding an incident that occurred on 08/11/21. During a basketball game, clients C1 and C2 (see confidential names list titled 09/02/21) were involved in an altercation which resulted in C1 choking C2 until C2 became discolored. C2 was taken to the Emergency Room where it was determined no structural damaged occurred. A safety plan was implemented which included C2 being moved to a different home. LPA interviewed two staff involved and C2. LPA determined staff responded appropriately. No deficiencies cited.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores arrived at the agency to conduct a case management inspection regarding an incident. Community Care Licensing was notified that foster child FC1 (see confidential names list titled 09/01/21) was in an altercation with staff S1 on 06/01/21 that resulted in S1 pushing FC1. FC1 was not injured. S1 was suspended immediately pending investigation. S1 was terminated after review of the video footage of the incident. LPA reviewed video clip and personnel file, interviewed Administrator, and interviewed client and that was involved in the incident. The video shows S1 pushing FC1 down to the ground and FC1 rolls onto his back and then to his knees, FC1 then stands up. At this time, Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87072(d)(11) Personal Rights is being cited. Civil penalty assessed for repeat violation.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
met_with: Rene van der Meer - Program Manager
narrative: Staff schedules show the facility is planned for minimum staffing ratios as outlined in the Interim Licensing Standards. Incident reports show several restraints requiring three to five staff; staff involved can be assigned from different homes located on the ranch. Incident reports also show a rise in incidents for the months of April and May with over thirty incidents reported to CCL for April; each incident involves one to five staff. Based on the information provided during interviews and gathered from documentation, it is determined the preponderance of evidence had been met therefore the allegation that facility is understaffed is substantiated. The Agency is cited under Section Cited CCR 84065.5(c) If a child requires special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty direct care staff shall be increased. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to Rene van der Meer - Program Manager via email.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores arrived at the agency on 08/31/21 and met with Rene van der Meer – Program Manager to deliver investigation findings for this complaint. LPA Walker-Flores conducted the complaint investigation. LPA interviewed six total clients, seven staff which included two former employees, and an Administrator. LPA interviewed staff (S1) on 05/06/21, S2 on 05/18/21, S3 on 05/25/21. Interviews were conducted with C1-C5 and administrator on 05/14/21. LPA interviewed S4-S6 and C6 on 07/20/21. LPA reviewed facility roster, staff schedule, daily activity calendars and incident reports. Complaint alleges that facility is understaffed. All six clients interviewed stated that the facility is understaffed. Consistent statements from clients indicate the clients feel that there are more serious incidents and a lack of activities, due to the facility not having enough staff. Consistent statements from staff indicate that the Agency does not provide enough staffing to meet the needs of the clients and staff are left out of ratio. Staff stated on several occasions they would be left alone to supervise a house of six clients. Both clients and staff stated they feel unsafe due to the facility being understaffed. Both clients and staff stated that incidents could be avoided if the facility were staffed properly. (continued on 9099C)

deficiencies.description:
Staff/Child Ratios: If the children require special care and supervision because of age, behavior or other factors, the number of on-duty direct care staff shall be increased.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentation, the facility staffs at the minimum ratio requirement, when the clients they serve behaviors' demand additional staff to support them. This is a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: This agency was impacted by COVID-19 and had several staff out on sick leave or in quarantine as a result.  Since the months of April and May, the client population has decreased by six clients, leaving sixteen clients total.  Agency is currently recruiting for more staff.  Rene van der Meer stated that new clients will not be accepted until current ones graduate or leave, keeping the total client population at sixteen.  Agency shall notify LPA Walker-Flores when they increase the total client population with a plan detailing what staff they will allocate to provide additional supervision of clients.  No further POC is necessary

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores arrived at the agency on today's date to conduct a case management inspection regarding an incident that occurred on 09/30/21. Client C1 (see confidential names titled 09/30/21) was attacking C2 with a skateboard which prompted staff to restrain C1. After the restraint, C1 complained of arm pain and was taken to the Emergency Room where he was diagnosed with a bruised wrist. LPA reviewed files and interviewed three staff and client. LPA also reviewed video footage of the restraint. It was determined that C1 had broken his arm a few months back which could have led to his arm being sore after the restraint. Agency has met with C1's treatment team and developed a safety plan around restraints and early interventions. Agency is going to revisit the treatment plan and meet with staff during weekly meetings and update staff through clinician's orders. No deficiency cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report provided via email.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Danielle Walker-Flores conducted a complaint investigation inspection met with Kamiko Lucas – Administrator to discuss the findings of the complaint investigation. LPA Danielle Walker-Flores conducted the complaint investigation. On 10/08/21 LPA interviewed witness (W1, see confidential names titled 03/04/22), reviewed video footage of the incident, conducted a file review and obtained documentation at the facility. The following documents were collected and reviewed during the investigation; foster child's intake information, Needs and Service plans, incident reports, discharge report and Mountain Valley investigative summary. LPA interviewed reporting party on 01/27/21. LPA interviewed client and witness (W2) on 02/08/22. LPA interviewed staff (S1) on 02/15/22. The complaint alleges staff physically abused minor. There was an incident involving staff and client that occurred on 09/02/21 when client threw a can of olives which hit staff in the face. The video shows staff stumbling back and client pushing staff into a hallway where the cameras did not reach. Complaint alleges staff hit minor while out of the view of cameras. Statements in interviews indicate the client then proceeded to choke staff. Statements were reviewed from staff who responded to the incident or observed the client after the incident. S1, S2, S3, S4 and the nurse who treated both staff and client involved submitted written statements. Statements regarding physical abuse were inconsistent during interviews. Based on interviews and documentation the preponderance of evidence has not been met, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview conducted and appeal rights provided.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative:
On 3/27/23, licensing Program Analysts, (LPAs) Uchenna Ajaero and Monica Roberts made an unannounced annual inspection visit to Mountain Valley Ranch Group Home in Nevada City. LPAs Ajaero and Roberts met Chris Whittaker, the Mental Health Supervisor and informed him of the purpose of the visit which is to conduct an annual inspection. The facility was toured inside and outside. This facility occupies a very large property. The tour began at about 11:15AM. During the tour, LPAs observed a shade of water pump right outside the main office, there was a propane tank placed near the nurses office in an open area and a locked refrigerator by sysco near the garage. There were two ponds on the property that were secured and locked. At 11:22AM LPAs observed a design workshop, several locked sheds were unlocked and opened for LPAs to observe, some of the sheds had old bike, there was a tack shed with horse rider equipments. The Supervisor Chris explained that they reused most of the old items to assist the residents in their crafts and arts activities. At 11:36AM LPAs observed more storage containers that had house furniture, beds, microwaves, office furniture, drawers, cabinets and wooden furniture. In an open area outside the shed there was a large water reservoir, three unconnected gas tanks. There was an open old milk barn with a notice that no youth should approach without staff. There was a secured cow hay and barn area, a chicken pen that is used to store more old bicycles. At 12:00 PM LPAs observed a log cabin that bordered the Janet Milhouse that had more furniture, it had 2 restrooms to the side. This structure has the redwood classroom which served as an onsite training classroom for staff, it had a current fire extinguisher, tables, desks, chairs, computers, exercise mat, television, fan an an empty plastic bin for storage.

At 12:12 LPAs observed a conservation team shed with rakes, broom, fire marshall hats, a Millhouse family garage filled with house properties, a car, with a secluded and locked swimming pool. Beside this property was the therapists' office. There were 5 therapists' offices in this building. At 12:15 PM LPAs Ajaero and Roberts visited teh Siera Classroom. LPAs observed the posted class schedule, fire extinguisher. LPAs met the instructor Rick Beberg and he explained that the students come with an IEP with which they are placed in their appropriate class level. A the time of our visit the students were on break and there was only one student in the class room. LPAs visited the Sierra house. It has 3-bedrooms and one full bathroom. There were 4- youths residing at this home. Sierra house has youths rights poster losted on the wall, menu, complaint procedure, grievance form, and emergency disaster plan. The house has a fridge, living room area, washer and dries and a small office like setting in the laundry area. LPAs observes another building which is the recreation hall, and it has pianos, guitars, games and arts supplies posted, arcade, fire extinguisher, office drawer and locked up cleaning supply cabinet. At 1:20 PM, LPAs met Marti Miernik the Mental Health Specialist and Animal Assisted therapist and Counselor. LPAs visited her office and observed schedules of activities posted for her sessions. LPA's were unable to review staff files or interview youths on this day; therefore, annual visit will be continued at a later date. There were no title 22 deficiencies cited. Exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights given.

On 3/28/2023 at 10:00 AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Uchenna Ajaero and Monica Roberts returned to the facility to continue the annual inspection from the day before. LPAs met Tim Dykes, the Housing Administrator of West Bunk. This location has the Yuba bunk, West bunk and Sierra house. LPAs requested a staff to bring the following for review and the Housing Administrator left to bring the documents. These include LIC 308 - designation of facility responsibility document, LIC 309 - Administration's organization document, LIC 610c - Emergency disaster plan, Fire clearance update, Control of property document (any expansions and property remodel or updates), The 2 most recent Board meetings, COA accreditation renewal status. Five staff members were interviewed. At 2:00 PM after the LPAs returned from lunch the staff had not yet showed up with the requested documents. The weather was getting worse, it was snowing and LPA's requested to wrap up the visit and return another day. No citations were issued.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative: On 8/1/23 about 10:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst, LPA Uchenna Ajaero paid an unannounced case management visit to the facility and met with the Special Education Teacher to discuss the Needs and Services plan for FC1. FC1 is a freshman, FC1 takes physical science, algebra, biology, health, language arts and other subjects including PE and career development. Career development includes gardening, wood chop, horse care - feeding, grooming and walking them. With better abilities some of the youths can ride the horses. FC1 has 5 academic and PE and career classes totaling 7- classes daily. Julian the House Administrator and Zachary the Therapist are not in the facility today So, we could not review FC1's Needs and Services Plan. Special Ed Teacher said the educational plan for FC1 is getting to school on time and solving daily problems while in the school. FC1 expresses mental challenge when they see work but FC1 is currently working with the Special ED Teacher to stay on task. When FC1 is anxious or stressed, FC1 will ask for a break or complain of headache, but returns and will try to rush through the rest of the work but Special Ed Teacher would slow FC1 down to set them back on track. Special ED Teacher is also working with FC1 to use complete sentences and articulate more words better. The teacher stated that FC1 has gotten better over time. Youth is not aggressive in the classroom and they do not experience FC1's behavioral problems or challenges. Teacher thinks FC1 respects the teachers and so the behaviors arise after school and on weekends. FC1's only behavior during school is FC1's trying not to get their school work completed. The teachers addresses these and FC1 sits very close to the teacher during school hours. No deficiencies were found during this visit. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with the facility.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative: Interviews were inconsistent regarding staff making inappropriate comments to minors. One staff member admitted to making a comment regarding how a minor is currently at the ranch because their previous education setting was unsuccessful, but the minor misinterpreted the comment as if they were there due to being “unsuccessful.” Staff tried to apologize and explain that is not what was meant by the comment. Two clients made vague references to staff at the facility being mean and judgmental. One client contradicted those statements, reporting staff were “overly helpful” and supportive. Records reviewed did not provide additional information about this allegation. Based on LPM’s interviews and LPA’s records reviews, although the allegation may have happened, or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violation did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegation is UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this LIC 9099 and 9099C report was provided to the facility along with appeal rights.

investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Aleza Ruiz arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA initiated the investigation with the facility on 10/11/2024 and met with Rene Vander Meer, Administrator and conducted a Health and Safety Inspection. During the course of the investigation, LPA interviewed one Program Administrator and four additional staff. Regarding the allegation the facility did not ensure laundering equipment was in good repair, three staff members denied this, two staff members agreed with this. The facility has several washers, records indicate one washer was replaced however the washer that had been replaced was not the washer in the photo that contained grime within it . Continued on 9099C

deficiencies.description:
Title 22, Division 6 80087(a)
The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.
This regulation was not met as evidenced by: Failure to ensure laundering equipment remained in good repair, posing a potential risk to the health, safety, and personal rights of clients in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will provide LPA with a receipt showing purchase of a new washer to replace the old washer. LPA will be provided with maintenance records showing the removal date of the old washer and installation date of the new washer.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
met_with: Rene Van der Meer, Program Manager
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Aleza Ruiz arrived unannounced at the facility for the purpose of following up on two incident reports (IR) received by the department on 1/15/2025 and 2/04/2025 (0001479-FN)involving restraints. No citation given at this time. Further investigation needed regarding the incident reports.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY-NEVADA CITY RANCH
narrative:
On 3/27/2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Aleza Ruiz and LPA Kellie Mckinley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Rene VanderMeer, Program Manager. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required, Two year Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 3/27/2023. The file was reviewed prior to conducting the inspection and the LIC 9233 completed. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant, and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility was clean and organized, and maintained an acceptable room temperature. The facility is equipped with 3 bunkhouses that hold a total of 18 client bedrooms, a large open plan kitchen/dining area, and separate locked staff offices throughout the facility. Each client had a closet and dresser in good repair. Mattresses and bedding were observed to be clean. Clients were able to decorate their rooms with their personal belongings. The open fields on the property are free from hazards, safely fenced, with a variety of sports equipment accessible to clients. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hotline, client personal rights, and emergency disaster plan. The facility has client bathrooms in every bunkhouse and one staff bathroom. All were observed to be clean and fully functioning. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, with additional food stored in the garage. LPA observed client files and client medications were stored in a locked file cabinet in the locked staff office. The facility has no outstanding fees. National accreditation certification was reviewed and will expire on 12/31/2025. Continued on 809C

Continued from 809 The facility currently has 12 clients, with a licensed maximum capacity of 26. Staff to client ratio is 3:1 AT A MAXIMUM OF 6:1 If necessary. LPA reviewed 3 staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearances and all required initial and annual training. All First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for staff. LPA interviewed 4 staff on site. LPA reviewed 3 client files. All clients had signed Admission Agreements on file. Client files had completed initial Needs and Service Treatment Plans, signed by clients and staff, and updated Needs and Service plans every 6 months. The facility had evidence of attempting to obtain signatures from authorized representatives. Needs and Service Plans detailed supportive services the facility provides to the clients. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. Several clients were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and parental consent on file. LPA interviewed 4 clients. Facility is issued a citation per 80068.2(c) Needs and Services Plan: The written Needs and Services Plan specified in Section 80068.2(a) shall be maintained in the client's file. A signed copy of this LIC-809 (and LIC-809C, and LIC 809D) report was provided to Rene VanderMeer.. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.

LPa introduced herself and explained the reason for the visit. LPA was given a tour of the facility both inside and out. The house has 6 bedrooms and 3 bath. LPA observed working smoke detectors through out the facility. LPA observed working smoke detectors. The facility has a back trailer on the property that is used for Therapy and staff. There is a barn on the property for maintenance tools which is always locked. there were no deficiencies at todays inspection. a copy of this report was left with Misty Jackson Program Manager

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced Post Licensing inspection at the facility. When LPA first arrived, all clients were at the Mountain Valley Gerber facility with all staff. Due to escalations from the clients and an AWOL at the time and staff who have called in, no staff were able to come to Bar Du to assist LPA with the inspection at the time. A Facility Manager would be arriving to work at 10:00 AM who would be able to assist LPA. Facility Manager (FM) De'jana Crockett arrived to assist LPA with the inspection at 10:00 AM. LPA and FM conducted a walk-through of the facility and LPA observed: four client rooms in clean/orderly condition, two client bathrooms with working toilets, sinks, and showers. Client's water sources measured at 108.8 degrees Fahrenheit, which is within the required range of 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. There were no sources of water dedicated to extreme heat. The carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were operational. There was an adequate amount of food for the required amount of time, both perishable and non-perishable foods. Items to make today's scheduled dinner were present in the facility. There was an adequate amount of silverware, dishware, and cooking items. The facility has a dishwasher, however it does not work, so they do clean the dishes appropriately with dish soap. There were extra bedding items, hygiene supplies, and personal items. All medications and cleaning supplies were locked and inaccessible to clients as required. The license and personal rights were posted as required. The staff office was locked and inaccessible to clients. The First Aid Kits met all requirements. The outdoor activity space met all requirements. There is a swing-set outside which had the required safety material underneath. The swing-set was anchored to the ground as required. There were no deficiencies regarding the physical plant/walk-through.

LPA reviewed the facility's Operations, Emergency Interventions, and Disaster Plans and found: The facility is conducting emergency drills as required. There was a client roster with clients' names, DOBs, Authorized Representative, and Medical Provider information. There is an Emergency Action Plan, however it does not meet the requirements. The facility did not have a copy of their Program Statement/Plan of Operation at the facility. The facility has a valid fire clearance. Board Meeting minutes were not obtained by the time LPA left the facility. There were partial client files at the facility which had clients' face sheets, consent forms, discipline policy, complaint procedures, foster youth bill of rights, emergency transfer procedures, immunization record, and medical benefits card. However, complete files are only maintained electronically, which there is no access to at the facility. No staff working physically in the facility have access to complete client files. There are some staff records kept at the facility, however these only consist of: supervision check-ins, Memos of Understanding (things that need to be worked on), Topics of Concern (write-ups), Performance Evaluations, and Topics of Merit (recognition for positive work). Complete staff files are also electronic and inaccessible at the facility. The Restraint Log is also digital only at not available at the moment. LPA called Administrator Kamiko Lucas to arrange for LPA to come to the Administrative Office to review electronic files. Before LPA left, Kamiko informed LPA that the Administrative Office is prepared for LPA to come tomorrow. LPA could not complete this inspection on this date, and will have to complete it at the Administrative Office located at 3353 Bradshaw Rd., Sacramento, CA 95827 on another date. LPA issued two Technical Violation advisory notes and one Technical Assistance advisory note, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report was left with her.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility to gather more information about multiple incidents of self-harm over the course of the past two months. LPA met with Facility Manager De'jana Crockett, who assisted with the inspection. LPA and FM conducted a walk-through of the facility and LPA observed there were no paper towels in either client bathroom, which FM did put in there during this inspection. Also during the inspection, one of the smoke detectors started beeping, so LPA advised FM to have the battery changed. LPA also advised that C1's rat tail comb, which is in their hygiene basket, only be given to C1 while supervised due to their self-harming propensity with similar objects. FM removed the comb from C1's basket and it will be used under supervision. LPA interviewed FM for this case management. LPA requested the following: - Clinician's behavior contracts for C1 and C2. - Sign in and sign out sheet of personal items. - C1's Needs and Services Plans from time of placement in May 2023, to present. - Hospital paperwork from each time C1 went to the hospital/ER/Urgent Care for self-harm behavior. Further information is needed in order to resolve this case management. An exit interview was conducted with FM and a copy of this report and confidential names list were provided to her.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM) De'jana Crockett, who assisted with the inspection. CCL received three Incident Reports from the facility dated 5/13/2024, 5/17/2024, and 5/20/2024 concerning two different clients C1 and C2 (see confidential names list dated 6/26/2024), in which LPA is investigating. On today's date LPA and LPM requested access to a staff file (S1) however, it was not accessible to staff or LPA and LPM. FM called Administrator Misty Jackson to see about getting access, however the HR personnel left the office at 2:00 PM due to an emergency, and no other individuals have access. Administrator stated she will provide the staff file to LPA by tomorrow 6/27/2024. This was addressed in the other LIC 809 dated 6/26/2024. There was also no facility manager present when LPA and LPM arrived. There were two clients being supervised by a staff who has been an employee at the facility for one month or less. Another staff was present on the grounds, however was not present in the facility. That staff was hired about 7 months ago. Neither staff had knowledge about licensing or how to get information. FM did return during this inspection and assisted LPA and LPM. This was addressed in the other LIC 809 dated 6/26/2024. LPA and LPM requested the following client documentation: 1. All CFTs or IEPs for C1 and C2, hospital paperwork for self-harm ingestion incidents dated above for C1 and C2, NSPs since placement for C1 and C2, all safety plans created for C1 and C2, and any behavioral contracts for C1 and C2. This will be submitted to CCL by tomorrow, 6/26/2024.

Collected: 1. One Treatment plan for C3 implemented 5/30/2023 which did not change within 6 months and was signed on 11/8/2023. 2. One Treatment plan for C1 implemented 7/21/2023 which did not change within 6 months and was signed on 6/12/2024. 3. One Treatment plan for C2 4. 12 months of Clinician's orders for C3, excluding the medication side-effects section. 5. 12 months of Clinician's orders for C1. 6. Two Clinician's orders for C2. LPA conducted and exit interview with FM and a copy of this report was provided to her.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Michelle Silvas and Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM), De'jana Crockett who assisted with the inspection. LPAs conducted a walk through of the facility with FM and observed the following: four client rooms in clean/orderly condition, two client bathrooms with working toilets, sinks, and showers. Clients' bathrooms sinks and showers were not clean. In one clients room there was a hole in the wall, which the maintenance staff filled in during this inspection. Client's water sources measured at 114.4 degrees Fahrenheit, which is within the required range of 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. There were no sources of water dedicated to extreme heat. The carbon monoxide detector and smoke detector were operational. There was an adequate amount of food for the required amount of time, both perishable and non-perishable foods. Items to make today's scheduled dinner were present in the facility. There was an adequate amount of silverware, dishware, and cooking items. There were extra bedding items, hygiene supplies, and personal items. All medications and cleaning supplies were locked and inaccessible to clients as required. The license and personal rights were posted as required. The staff office was locked and inaccessible to clients. The First Aid Kits met all requirements. The outdoor activity space met all requirements. There is a swing-set outside which had the required safety material underneath. The swing-set was anchored to the ground as required. LPAs reviewed the facility's Operations and found: Initially the Client roster was not complete but was completed and posted with clients' names, DOBs, Authorized Representative, and Medical Provider information by FM during this inspection. The facility has a valid fire clearance. Board Meeting minutes were provided which demonstrated that the board is meeting as required at least quarterly and discussing the required topics. Facility did not have current license posted, however LPAs provided it and it was posted.

All staff were fingerprint cleared and associated as required. LPAs reviewed one Facility Manager file and a partial Administrator file and found the following: FM had initial training as required, however we found the files are disorganized and inconsistent, which made it difficult to determine how many hours of training staff had. The Administrator's certificate expired last month, however Administrator has already paid for renewal and the process is pending. Administrator and Facility Manager both meet education and experience requirements. FM's first aid/CPR certificate expired on 10/6/2024, however during this inspection, FM completed the certification and provided the certificate. LPAs interviewed two Clients and found based on these interviews, that the facility is meeting their needs as far as food, therapy, clothes, telephone calls, school, allowance and activities. LPAs were unable to complete the inspection on this date and will return another day to complete. On this date, there were no citations issued. LPAs issued multiple Advisory Notes, which are not citations. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to FM.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Michelle Silvas and Alyssa Burgess made an unannounced annual inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM), De'jana Crockett who assisted with the inspection. LPAs reviewed two staff, the FM, the Clinician, and the Administrator files and found the following: All staff had medical screenings and TB tests completed as required. S1 had 19.75 hours of annual training, which is below the 20 hour minimum annual requirement. All other staff, FM, and Administrator met training hour requirements. Administrator's First Aid/CPR expired 9/30/2024, however she does not provide direct care to the clients. Administrator will be renewing the CPR/1st Aid. Additionally, FM's CPR/1st Aid expired 10/6/2024, and she completed the renewal training during yesterday's inspection on 10/29/2024. During the review of training records, the initial training records are maintained in multiple different documents: 13015A Initial Training Requirements, Relias, 13027 New Hire Training Procedure. The items listed are not titled in a way that would enable LPAs to evaluate whether all the required topics of this section have been trained on, and there were no training descriptions with contents attached. Staff are receiving many hours of training on different topics, however the titles do not all make clear what the contents of those training are. For example, "In Person Annual Part A" and "Part B" covers many topics, but they are not listed to evaluate. After being advised of this, the facility put together a sheet with most subsections of 84065(i)(3) in relation to their training titles, which demonstrated to LPAs that the topics are being covered. The facility will fine-tune this list, title it, and maintain it in each staff's file. The facility utilizes a newer Emergency Intervention program called "Ukeru: The Least Resistance Approach to Crisis Management." The facility needs to submit a program statement update to CCL for review of this new plan, and approval. This will be due in 60 days on 12/30/2024. LPAs also reviewed the disaster drill log and found that drills are being conducted as required, however they are all fire drills, and not a variety of disaster types as required. Additionally, there have not been drills for the overnight shift. LPA has discussed the process for completing these previously with Administrator Misty Jackson, and during this inspection with FM. The facility will begin to implement these additional drills as required for the overnight shifts.

LPAs reviewed the facility's Disaster/Mass Casualty Plan and found the following: there was no information regarding the provision for emergency power, no for storage of medication which would require refrigeration. Additionally, the phone numbers listed were out of date, confirmed by FM. LPAs reviewed four client files. One client (C4) was only placed for one week before returning home for an undetermined amount of time. C4 is still placed but has not been back at the facility for two months, therefore C4 does not have a medical assessment completed, TB test, signed Needs and Services Plan (NSP), and other required documents. If and when C4 returns to the facility, the facility will complete these requirements. C3 also did not have a TB test as there was confusion from the parents as to whether or not C3 already had one, so the facility will be completing that next week according to FM. All clients had an NSP with the required elements, however, there were no authorized representative signatures for all four NSPs. All clients had a face sheet with client information as required, however, C1's nickname was not listed as required, and four out of four clients did not have their preferred pronouns listed. All four clients take Psychotropic Medications, however four out of four clients were missing parental consent to take psychotropic medications as required. The facility did have general medical treatment consent forms, which were signed by the authorized representatives. C1 and C3 did not sign their personal rights forms. C1 also did not sign their discharge/transfer policy, complaint procedures, or discipline policy. LPAs reviewed all four clients' medications. The facility is maintaining Psychotropic Medication Administration Records (PMAR) with all psychotropic medications separate on their own PMARs as required. During the review, LPAs found the following: two pills of C4's Medication 1 (M1) were taken and not documented on the October 2024 PMAR. FM stated it was most likely documented on the September 2024 PMAR, which was not available for LPA to review due to being removed from the facility, and stored at the Gerber facility. FM informed LPA that no one at Gerber could access them to provide to LPA as the nurse is not available, and Administrator Kamiko Lucas is off-site.Due to this, LPA is unable to confirm that medication counts and PMARs are completed accurately. For C3, the same issue occurred where LPA could not accurately verify the medication counts due to September 2024 not being available at the time. FM was able to attain the September PMARs from the Administrator and provided them to LPAs. LPAs reviewed them and they did document that medications were administered in September, it still did not clarify when new bubble packs began and ended, and it was not possible to decipher accurate counts. C2's M2 PMAR stated the amount prescribed was 23, however 29 slots were signed off on as having taken a dose in the PMAR. For C2's M3,

the MAR stated there were 30 prescribed, however the bubble pack stated there were 31. C2's M4 was a 100 pill supply, however all 100 pill supply was not available for review, as the extras were with the nurse, and inaccessible on this date. LPA explained to FM the troubles they were having reviewing the medication and FM acknowledged the issues present. LPA advised FM of different ideas to help correct these issues. LPA Silvas interviewed two staff and found that they were knowledgeable about the clients, their roles, and mandated reporting. On this date the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6. Chapter 5, Sections: 84070(b)(16), 84070(c)(1) and Health and Safety Code Section 1565(a) on the attached LIC809-D page. LPAs also issued multiple Advisory Notes, which are not citations. LPA conducted an exit interview with FM and a copy of this report, confidential names list, and appeal rights were provided to her.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall made an unannounced case management inspection at the facility and met with Facility Manager (FM) De'jana Crockett, who assisted with the inspection. The purpose of this inspection is to complete the Case Management opened on 2/9/2024 pertaining to multiple reports of self-harm by client C1 (see Confidential Names List dated 6/26/2024). LPA investigated this case management by reviewing Incident Reports (IRs), hospital discharge paperwork, Needs and Services Plans (NSPs), a Safety Plan/Behavior Contract, the facility’s Program Statement, and by conducting confidential interviews with one client, two staff, and the Facility Manager (FM). On 2/9/2024 LPA requested all hospital paperwork from each time C1 went to the hospital/ER/Urgent Care for self-harm behavior from placement to present (at the time, 2/9/2024). Review of hospital paperwork and associated IRs showed that the facility did not submit all the requested hospital paperwork, nor did they submit any of the facility documents requested on 5/3/2024. On 6/5/2024, CCL sent a follow-up request for these documents, and CCL received them on 6/6/2024. Based on IRs and Hospital/ER Paperwork: For self-harm related incidents, C1 was taken to the ER at least 14 times between 9/10/2023 and 4/5/2024, was held for at least 24 hours for safety 12 of those times, had at least two X-Rays conducted, and had at least four endoscopy procedures to remove ingested foreign bodies while in placement. Sedation was used during endoscopic procedures. The 1/5/2024 hospital discharge paperwork advised C1 to have, “close watch supervision at group home,” and, “no access to sharp items for ingestion.” The facility IR for this incident stated that when C1 was discharged on 1/6/2024, C1 was placed on close watch, their room was searched,

and potentially harmful objects removed for safety. However, on 1/8/2024, C1 was able to ingest a broken pen and hard plastic reusable straw. When the two staff present for that incident were interviewed, neither could remember how it happened, and one staff stated C1 was on 1:1 supervision for that week. LPA was informed by the Facility Manager on 2/9/2024 that the facility recently implemented a sign-in/sign-out sheet for clients checking out items that need to be checked in, specifically in regard to C1. LPA received a copy of this form on 2/13/2024. However, on 2/26/2024, C1 was able to self-harm with an object staff failed to collect back from them. During the facility visit on 2/9/2024, while conducting the walk-through of the facility with FM, LPA observed a plastic rat-tail comb with a sharp-pointed end in C1's hygiene supplies, which fits the pattern of items C1 ingests. LPA advised FM to remove the rat-tail comb from C1's hygiene supplies. After reviewing C1’s Behavior Contract obtained on 2/13/2024 and 6/6/2024, LPA noted that there were no updates to the plan, no identified risks, sources of support, or documented coping strategies. Since placement in the facility, C1’s NSPs clearly stated C1’s self-harm behaviors have resulted in multiple hospitalizations. There was one NSP update in 2024 which had no meaningful updates to address C1’s continued dangerous self-harm behavior. For NSPs dated 11/17/2023 and 2/9/2024: for the sections concerning mental health and emotional needs, both the presenting issue and plan to address it were copied and pasted, unchanged. In the case of all NSPs for C1, the plans to address C1’s mental health and emotional needs never changed nor were updated. C1 had one Safety Plan for the duration of placement, which was undated, and was a copy of a safety plan from the ER. The facility’s Program Statement states in the Emergency Intervention Plan that, “When clients present an imminent or immediate risk to self or others by acting out physically, they are no longer thinking rationally so the strategy must change from deescalation to keeping everyone safe.” In nearly all incidents of this investigation, staff never switched from verbal intervention to body positioning, or any form of manual restraint, despite C1 being in imminent danger due to self-harm behaviors. In C1’s Clinician’s Orders dated 4/23/2024, it states that C1 should receive the appropriate level of restraint during self-harm incidents.

Additionally, Administrator Kamiko Lucas informed LPA they do not conduct Child and Family Team (CFT) meetings with the clients placed through the schools, but rather Individualized Education Plan (IEP) meetings. LPA reviewed the IEP for C1 and found that it is a meeting conducted annually, and the one on file was last updated on 5/4/2023, which pre-dates C1’s placement in Mountain Valley on 5/30/2023. Other IEPs were held during placement, however copies are maintained by the school district. The IEP mainly focused on school needs and progress, however also identified mental health needs and areas of concern for C1 as they relate to C1’s education and employment goals. The facility’s Program Statement states updates to NSPs take place during IEP Meetings at least once every 30 days of placement. Interviews with two staff revealed that staff would just watch clients self-harm and not physically intervene, due in part to management stating, “swallowing stuff wasn't imminent danger.” Also, a staff stated the administrators would call C1’s self-harming behavior, “attention-seeking.” One staff informed LPA that C1 was placed in the same house with another client who is a known trigger to C1. This was known by staff and management, yet the client was still placed at the facility temporarily which resulted in another self-harming incident on 11/29/2023. Based on LPA’s investigation, LPA found that there was a clearly demonstrated pattern and history of C1 becoming escalated and self-harming via ingestion of foreign bodies. C1 would often appear safe in one moment, and self-harm in the next moment. C1 repeatedly got access to harmful objects and self-harmed with them. Staff returned objects back to C1, some of which C1 had previously self-harmed with. Staff failed to ensure potentially harmful objects were collected from C1 on multiple occasions, leading to C1 ingesting them. Staff failed to increase the level of intervention in nearly all incidents, and failed to conduct IEP meetings as needed, failing to follow the facility’s Program Statement and Emergency Intervention Plan. The facility’s continuous negligence and inaction with interventions led to C1 being repeatedly harmed. An immediate civil penalty in the amount of $500 is being assessed for this serious deficiency on today’s date.

On today's date LPA and LPM requested access to a staff file (S1) however, it was not accessible to staff or LPA and LPM. FM called Administrator Misty Jackson to see about getting access, however the HR personnel left the office at 2:00 PM due to an emergency, and no other individuals have access. Administrator stated she will provide the staff file to LPA by tomorrow 6/27/2024. There was also no facility manager present when LPA and LPM arrived. There were two clients being supervised by a staff who has been an employee at the facility for one month or less. Another staff was present on the grounds, however was not present in the facility. That staff was hired about 7 months ago. Neither staff had knowledge about licensing or how to get information. FM did return during this inspection and assisted LPA and LPM. On this date, the facility is being cited for violations of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Sections 80078(a), 80022(k), 80044(c), 84068.3(a)(3), 84065(d). See attached D-Page. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator Misty Jackson by phone and FM in person and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to them.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) met with Administrators Kamiko Lucas and Misty Jackson to discuss the corrections made after the Case Management inspection dated 6/26/2024. The Plans of Corrections (POCs) from that Case Management were to have a meeting with CCL and the facility to discuss how they will come into compliance, and that is the purpose of this meeting today. Due to the appeal process, this meeting was delayed. LPA amended the citations on 5/27/2025 after the facility's appeal had been processed. LPA observed one section that needed to be amended still. LPA made that correction on today's date and provided the amended document to Administrators. For the Case Management on 6/26/2024, the facility was cited for 80078(a), 80022(k). On today's date, Administrators informed LPA of their changes and processes, satisfying the POCs. LPA cleared the citations on this date and provided Administrators with a copy of this report, the amended citation, and the clearance letters. Administrator will sign the LIC809s and return to LPA by COB today.

facility_name: MOUNTAIN VALLEY CHILD AND FAMILY SERVICES - BAR DU
met_with: Dominique Stephens, Michelle Millhous, Jenn Potts, Kamiko Lucas
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Alyssa Burgess made an announced Post Licensing inspection at the Administration Office located at 3353 Bradshaw Rd., Sacramento, CA 95827 and met with Nurse Dominique Stephens, HR Director Michelle Millhous, Clinician Jenn Potts, Senior Program Director (SPD) Kamiko Lucas who assisted with the inspection. LPA was sent the past year's worth of restraint logs after LPA left the facility yesterday. LPA reviewed them and found the facility is documenting the restraints. LPA reviewed four electronic client files with the assistance of Nurse Dominique Stephens, Therapist Jenn Potts, and HR Director Michelle Milhous (HR). LPA found there were the appropriate consents, including psychiatric medical consents. There were records of Mental Health Services being received by clients, which included their diagnoses and goals and objectives. All clients had separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Records as required for all their psychotropic mediations, with all required information. Two clients out of four have had a wellness exam as required, however only one has received a TB test or assessment as required. There have been issues with out of County insurances, however, one client is from Stockton, which is not unreasonable to drive to to take the client to a doctor's appointment. That client was placed in June 2023, and now has a doctor's appointment scheduled for October 2023. Three out of four clients have a record of vaccinations, and the fourth client does not as their parent has not sent it to the facility, despite the facility requesting it multiple times. The two clients who received a wellness appointment had paperwork from those visits that did not satisfy the requirements and were missing multiple required elements on them. LPA showed Nurse where to access CCL's LIC 602 form, which has all the required information on it. LPA recommended the nurse have the doctors fill that form out during wellness exams in the future. In the event a medical provider refuses to fill out a form, LPA is advising the facility document their efforts.

LPA found that one out of four clients had initial Needs and Services Plans. All clients have been placed longer than 30 days. However, there is no specific deadline for when to complete an initial NSP by in the regulations for Group Homes. A best-practice is completing it within 30 days of placement. LPA advised Therapist to complete them as soon as she can, and she agreed. LPA received the Board Meeting minutes for the last four quarters and found the Board is meeting as required. No clients had an Admission Agreement, and the facility stated they had never been asked for that for client placed through school or Managed Care. A bedroom sharing compatibility assessment is not documented for any clients who share bedrooms. SPD Kamiko Lucas stated that she, the assigned clinician, and the assigned house supervisor do this, however it is not documented. Regarding fingerprint clearances, only one staff is still In-Process on Mountain Valley Bar Du's old STRTP License. One staff's determination has been closed. CCL has held the old license open to allow In-Process fingerprints on the old license to go through and be able to transfer to the new Group Home license. HR agreed that the staff can be reprinted under the new license. LPA will the close out the old license HR agreed. HR also informed LPA that they do not have access to the new license in Guardian to be able to transfer associations to the new license. LPA witnessed this on HR's Guardian page; only the old Bar Du license was available. LPA advised HR to inform Guardian of this to have it addressed. Currently the agency is fingerprinting new hires under the Gerber license and will transfer the associations to the Bar Du Group Home license when they have access. LPA informed HR that those new staff cannot work at the Bar Du location until they are associated/transferred to Bar Du. HR agreed. All staff LPA reviewed on this date were associated as required. LPA reviewed five staff files, including one Administrator, one Clinician, one Facility Manager, and two staff. LPA found: The Facility Manager met experience/education requirements, however the dates of employment were missing from one of the reference checks. LPA and HR were able to find in the application the dates worked. LPA observed

the facility has a Facility Manager Training which meets requirements, however there was no evidence that any Facility Manager has taken it. There was no evidence of a Prudent Parent Standards training being given to staff who would be able to apply that to day-to-day decisions surrounding the clients. LPA observed that all staff received their TB tests, and Health Evaluation visits as required. All staff reviewed have received Emergency Intervention Training. All staff files have job descriptions, records of fingerprint clearances, training records, education or experience records if required, and records of first aid/CPR. On this date, the facility is being cited for a violation of the California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 5, Sections: 84065(d)(3), 84068.1(b)(4)(A), 80069(a), and 84069.1(a). LPA is issuing three Technical Violation Advisory Notes, which are not citations. LPA was unable to complete this inspection on this date. LPA will return to the facility on another date to complete medication review, cash resources review, and to interview staff and clients. An exit interview was conducted with SPD and HR. A copy of this report and appeal rights was left with them.

On 8/11/2025 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Aleza Ruiz and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Hillary Hall conducted an in person office meeting with Kamiko Lucas, Senior Program Director and Daniel Petrie, Chief Executive Officer. The purpose of the meeting was to convert the Mountain Valley Gerber STRTP to Mountain Valley Gerber Group Home by conducting the Component II meeting. LPA Ruiz explained the purpose of the meeting. Documents discussed during time of meeting were the following: LIC 200 LIC 401 LIC 401a LIC 403 LIC 403a LIC 503 LIC 999 Program Statement- Policy and Procedures discussed during time of meeting were the following Job Descriptions Medical/Dental Visitation Rules and Policy House Rules Complaints and Grievances

The Applicant has stated they will do the following and submit updated Program Statement and requested documentation by 9/15/2025. Program Statement: Applicant will submit to LPA Ruiz when it has been updated. To be updated by 9/15/2025 LPA Ruiz will do the following: Pre-licensing inspection scheduled for 9/25/2025: Will continue to follow up with the Applicant throughout the application/licensing process. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant.

On June 23, 2023, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki travelled to the facility listed above to conduct a pre-licensing and Component III inspection. The applicant submitted an application on 4/7/2023. The Program Statement has been reviewed and approved as meeting regulatory requirements. LPA met with Chief Executive Officer/Administrator, Scott Sowle. 1. Facility grounds inspected. Grounds are clean and free from observable hazard. The facility has a swimming pool that is properly fenced with a self closing/latching gate that opens away from the pool. Facility has a separate building housing a classroom and gym. 2. Adequate indoor activity space and materials observed, and outdoor activity space was observed. 3. Chemicals were appropriately locked 4. Procedures for Locked and centrally stored medications observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. A supply of extra linens available for bed changes. 8. The house has 3 bedrooms, double occupancy, located on a single floor. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Facility will add appropriate supply of foods upon placement of youth in the home. A supply of nonperishable foods were observed on this date. 10. Sample menu posted. 11. All appropriate forms posted within client view. 12. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 13. Facility has three restrooms for client use, one for staff use, all are operable Hot water measured 117 degrees on this date.

Applicant has personnel associated through Guardian. Administrator has been fingerprint cleared. Prior to initial license approval, all staff must be fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Prior to accepting clients for care, the facility shall ensure that all personnel who will have client contact are cleared and associated. Discussed Guardian process with the facility. Discussed with the facility the process for changing the facility Administrator. The following documents are required: 1. LIC 308 (Designation of Facility Responsibility) designating new administrator. 2. Current Personnel Record for new Administrator. 3. Verification of Education and/or experience for new administrator. 4. Copy of current administrator certificate. 5. Current (within one year) health screening and TB test. 6. Board Resolution granting administrative responsibility to the new administrator. 7. Fingerprint association transfer request (if the Administrator is not already associated to the facility) 8. Exception request (if the Administrator does not specifically meet regulatory requirements, i.e. experience is in a facility with a capacity of six or fewer). Discussed Incident reporting. An initial report for all reportable incidents is to be made by the next working day to CCLFresnoIncidents@dss.ca.gov. A full report is to be remitted within 7 days and may also be made to the incident reporting email. The currently assigned analyst for the facility will be Wayne Aoki. Wayne.Aoki@dss.ca.gov or at (559) 978-9486. The facility will be approved for initial licensure, pending verification of guardian clearance and association for the Licensee and Administrator and Financial Verification for the facility.. Initial license will be issued on a provisional basis, expiring one year from effective date. License will be valid for up to 6 male and/or female youth ages 12 through 17.

On June 23, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki travelled to Muir Wood-Auberry Road to conduct the Component II interview. LPA was met by facility Chief Executive Officer/Administrator, Scott Sowle. LPA discussed the following with the Mr. Sowle: Forms that the facility uses and will continue to use. Corporate organization - Including chain of command and roles of staff Written plans, policies or procedures that was submitted with the application. Administrator/Director qualifications and duties. Finances of the facility (CCL currently is waiting for the financial verification from their financial institute. Muir Wood currently operates 10 licensed facilities (64 beds) in California. Mr. Sowle informed this LPA that he will be the Administrator for Muir Wood - Auberry Road when the facility is licensed, Mr. Sowle indicated that all 10 facilities that are licensed have specific Administrators/Facility Managers assigned to each facility. Mr. Sowle will be residing in the area until Kerry Figeuroa is certified as an Administrator. Ms. Figeuroa is scheduled to take the Administrator's test on June 28, 2023. A copy of this report was provided to Mr. Sowle.

On June 12, 2024, an informal office conference was held at the San Jose Children's Program, Fresno Office. Present with Community Care Licensing Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Managers Juanita Arroyo, Lourey Bartolome and Isabel Diego, and Licensing Program Analysts Cheyenne McCanbridge, Briana Placencia and Angelica Borja. Present with Muir Wood Auberry Road are Program Administrator Scott Sowle and Chief Compliance Officer Brent Bowers. During this meeting, the following items were discussed: 1. LIC 500-Administrator/Staff 2. Deficiencies cited on May 29, 2024 during Post Licensing 3. Appeal being denied 4. Review Needs and Services Plan 5. Fingerprinting, Associations and Waiver need to be corrected immediately 6. Safeguarding Cash Resources 7. Facility Contact Landline phone number/flip phone that are used by clients 8. Program Statement- Consistency with all Regional Offices 9. New Citations 10. Personal Rights

deficiencies.description:
84072   Personal Rights
(c)  At admission, each child, and his/her authorized representative, shall be personally advised of and given a copy of the child’s rights as specified in Subsection d below:

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based off records reviewed, the licensee failed to ensure clients personal rights, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Licensee states once they have the right forms, they'll have the kids sign by Friday. For parents we'll have forms signed early next week and will submit forms to LPA Borja by these dates via email.

In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:
(8) To make and receive confidential telephone calls, unless prohibited by court order.


This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based off records reviewed, the licensee failed to make and receive confidential telephone calls, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based off records reviewed, the licensee failed to make and receive confidential telephone calls, which poses an immediate health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

narrative: On May 29, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Angelica Borja and Briana Placencia conducted an unannounced Post Licensing inspection at the facility. LPAs met with Rosie Samarjian. An inspection of the facility was conducted and the following was observed: LPAs reviewed four client files. LPAs interviewed two clients, LPAs interviewed one staff. The facility was inspected indoors and outdoors. Hot water temperature measured at 105.0 degrees. LPAs observed at least one week supply of nonperishable and at least a five day supply of perishable foods. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Cleaning chemicals inaccessible to clients. The facility is maintained at 71 degrees. All facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced in January 2024. LPAs reviewed the outcome of post licensing thus far. LPAs will need to return at a later day to complete the post licensing. LPAs advised Administrator that Licensing is requesting an in person informal meeting next week to discuss concerns addressed at this post licensing inspection. Medications centrally stored and locked. Per Licensee, there are no weapons at the facility. Three deficiencies are being issued for today's findings. A copy of this report and appeal rights was left at the facility.

narrative: On June 21, 2024 Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Angelica Borja and Briana Placencia conducted a continued Post Licensing inspection at the facility. LPAs met with Rosie Samarjian. An inspection of the facility was conducted and the following was observed: LPAs reviewed six staff files. LPAs interviewed three clients, LPAs interviewed four staff. The facility was inspected indoors and outdoors. LPAs observed at least one week supply of nonperishable and at least a five day supply of perishable foods. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens and are in good repair. Cleaning chemicals inaccessible to clients. All facility smoke and carbon monoxide detectors appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced in January 2024. LPA's observed fire clearance that was completed on 05/18/23. Medications centrally stored and locked. Per Licensee, there are no weapons at the facility. Two deficiencies are being issued for today's findings. A copy of this report and appeal rights was left at the facility.

On July 31, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Reyna Martinez and Angelica Borja conducted an unannounced Annual/Required inspection at the facility. LPAs met with Jessica Beutler. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. 5 Staff files and staff training's were reviewed. 5 records of clients were reviewed. Emergency intervention plan reviewed. Staff and Client files did not meet all regulatory requirements. Additional follow up required for annual inspection to complete physical plant inspection, review operations, and review disaster preparedness. Deficiencies were cited on today's visit on the attached LIC 809-D Page. A copy of this report was left at the facility, along with appeal rights.

On September 25, 2024, an informal office conference was held at the Fresno Children's Residential Program, Fresno Office. Present with Community Care Licensing Regional Manager, Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Manager Tamara Melikian and Licensing Program Analyst Reyna Martinez. Present with Muir Wood Auberry Road are Program Administrator-CEO Scott Sowle and Chief Compliance Officer Brent Bowers. Based on documentation obtained by Law Enforcement Agency and confidential interviews, the facility has failed to report incidents that meet CCL reporting requirements to the department. Based on the information obtained, the Group Home is being issued a deficiency under Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, 80061(b) Reporting Requirements on the attached LIC809-D. A copy of this report and appeal rights was left with Program Administrator-CEO Scott Sowle.

deficiencies.description:
80061 Reporting Requirements (b) Upon the occurrence, during the operation of the facility, of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made to the licensing agency within the agency's next working day during its normal business hours.  In addition, a written report containing the information specified in (2) below shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days following the occurrence of such event.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and record review, the licensee failed to report multiple reportable incidents involving clients in care to community care licensing, which poses a potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.

On May 23, 2025, an informal office conference was held at the Fresno Children's Residential Program, Fresno Office. Present with Community Care Licensing are Regional Manager Nelson Martinez, Licensing Program Manager Tamara Melikian and Licensing Program Analyst Danny Macias. Present with Muir Wood Auberry Road is Chief Operating Officer (COO) Bryan Bowen and Director of Compliance (DC) Misty Mejia. The purpose of the conference is to address incident reporting, update of the administrator, and the program statement updates. Facility will be training group home staff on incident reporting and implementing a process to submit incident reports in a timely manner. Facility will submit remaining incident reports to LPA in the coming weeks. In addition, the services of the Technical Support Program was offered and the licensee is interested in this referral being completed for them. Facility will provide LPA an update for the administrator of record and updates to the organization will be forwarded by the licensee within the next week. Facility will submit latest revisions and updates to the program statement in the coming weeks. A copy of this report was left with COO Bryan Bowen.

Forms from Section A requested were submitted. Part 1 documents and Part 3 Program Description were submitted. All documents will be review to current licensing standards and the licensee will be notified if any further updates or correction are needed or the the information Meets Standards. A discussion on the current status of programs and applications in the state and area was discussed. Current processes and reviews for state wide applications were discussed along with the purpose and goals of Muir Wood and the services they provide. LPA, will review the entire application and notify the licensee.

On May 5, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Danny Macias and Leslie Inouye travelled to Muir Wood Auberry West to conduct a pre-licensing inspection. LPAs met with Chief Operating Officer (COO) Bryan Bowen. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks. Adequate indoor and outdoor activity space and materials observed. The facility is maintained at 68 degrees. All facility smoke detectors are in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced in April 2025. Facility maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All required forms are posted. Medications will be locked and centrally stored. Individual beds were observed in all bedrooms. There are no bodies of water on the property. Per COO, no firearms or weapons are in the facility. There are no pets at the facility. LPAs discussed two areas in the back yard requiring clean-up. The facility is having the gardening staff perform clean-up in the following 2 weeks. LPAs left a copy of this report with COO at the conclusion.

A Case Management visit was conducted to discuss the Program Statement revisions. Bryan has reviews to be completed and is in the process of review and submission. A review is expected to be submitted by 5/16/25. If any questions or clarifications are needed Bryan will contact LPA Les Inouye.

On October 9, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wayne Aoki travelled to Muir Wood - Auberry South to conduct the Component II interview. LPA was met by facility Chief Executive Officer/Administrator, Scott Sowle. LPA discussed the following with the Mr. Sowle: Forms that the facility uses and will continue to use. Corporate organization - Including chain of command and roles of staff Written plans, policies or procedures that was submitted with the application. Administrator/Director qualifications and duties. Muir Wood currently operates 13 licensed facilities (82 beds) in California. Mr. Sowle informed this LPA that he will be the Administrator for Muir Wood - Auberry South when the facility is licensed, Mr. Sowle indicated that all 13 facilities that are licensed have specific Administrators/Facility Managers assigned to each facility. Mr. Sowle will continue with Administrative duties until Rosie Samarjian receives her Administrator's Certificate. 1. Facility grounds inspected. Grounds are clean and free from observable hazard. The facility has a swimming pool that is properly fenced with a self closing/latching gate that opens away from the pool. 2. Adequate indoor activity space and materials observed, and outdoor activity space was observed. 3. Chemicals were appropriately locked 4. Procedures for Locked and centrally stored medications observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. A supply of extra linens available for bed changes.

8. The house has 3 bedrooms, double occupancy, located on a single floor. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Facility will add appropriate supply of foods upon placement of youth in the home. A supply of nonperishable foods were observed on this date. 10. Sample menu posted. 11. All appropriate forms posted within client view. 12. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 13. Facility has three restrooms for client use, one for staff use, all are operable Hot water measured 117 degrees on this date. Applicant has personnel associated through Guardian. Administrator has been fingerprint cleared. Prior to initial license approval, all staff must be fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Prior to accepting clients for care, the facility shall ensure that all personnel who will have client contact are cleared and associated. Discussed Guardian process with the facility. Discussed with the facility the process for changing the facility Administrator. The following documents are required: 1. LIC 308 (Designation of Facility Responsibility) designating new administrator. 2. Current Personnel Record for new Administrator. 3. Verification of Education and/or experience for new administrator. 4. Copy of current administrator certificate. 5. Current (within one year) health screening and TB test. 6. Board Resolution granting administrative responsibility to the new administrator. 7. Fingerprint association transfer request (if the Administrator is not already associated to the facility) 8. Exception request (if the Administrator does not specifically meet regulatory requirements, i.e. experience is in a facility with a capacity of six or fewer). Discussed Incident reporting. An initial report for all reportable incidents is to be made by the next working day to CCLFresnoIncidents@dss.ca.gov. A full report is to be remitted within 7 days and may also be made to the incident reporting email. The currently assigned analyst for the facility will be Wayne Aoki. Wayne.Aoki@dss.ca.gov or at (559) 978-9486. The facility will be approved for initial Licensure, pending verification of guardian clearance and association for the Licensee and Administrator. Initial license will be issued on a provisional basis, expiring one year from effective date. License will be valid for up to 6 male and/or female youth ages 12 through 17. A copy of this report was provided to Mr. Sowle.

A copy of this report and appeal rights was left with Program Administrator-CEO Scott Sowle.

On December 10, 2024, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Danny Macias and Melissa Renovato continued a required annual inspection at Muir Wood Auberry South Group Home located in Clovis CA.
