On December 14, 2023 at 11:45 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Leslie Covarrubias and Cynthia Velasquez conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection. LPAs met with Applicant/Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Scott Sowle, Chief Clinician Officer, Tara Krueger, Chief Compliance Officer, Brent Bowers. The facility is a three client bedroom three client bathroom single-family, two-story home. The applicant is applying for a group home with the capacity of six ambulatory clients aged between 12-17 years old. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Clients will use a cordless telephone to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The water temperature in bathroom #1 located in cirtus room measured to be 116 Degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature inside lilian grace room measured to be 115.7 Degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature next to roubidoux room was measured to be 117.6 Degrees Fahrenheit. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Medication will be locked in the locked cabinet in the Medication room. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked kicthen cabinet. The staff and client files will be maintained on the computer database via Kipu. LPA's advised CEO, Scott Sowle, that staff and client files to be accessible to Community Care Licensing (CCL) at any time. The following required forms were posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsmen Poster and Disaster plans were posted. (Continue on next page...)

The downstairs area is set up as follows Group Room, dining room, living room, a kicthen, laundry room, two staff offices and two staff bathrooms. The upstairs are set up as follows: Citrus Bedroom: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space with one bathroom. Lilian Grace Bedroom: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space with one bathroom. Roubidoux Bedroom: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers and closet space. Care coordinator office , and a den area. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. The Backyard is set up as follows: The facility has one nursing office and a learning center with a recovery counselor office. The facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with an iron wrought fence. The enclosure was measured to five-and a half feet high. The Applicant/CEO Scott Sowle stated that the clients and staff will not have access to the swimming pool. The facility has a barn house area equipped with a group room, three clinician offices, one clinical director office, and one staff bathroom. (Continue on next page...)

All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant/CEO on this date. LPA explained that once the license is approved, all employees shall have an approved criminal record clearance for CCL and be associated to this facility. The fire clearance has been approved. Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility is ready for licensure.

On 12/05/2023 at 2:14 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith conducted a Component II meeting via Microsoft Teams with Applicant (CEO) Scott Sowle. Also present were Chief Compliance Officer Brent Bower, Care Coordinator Manager Melissa Gaviria, Care Coordinator Manager Jeff Denison, and Operations Manager Ashley Mitchell. The Administrator for this facility will be Jeff Denison. During the meeting the following was discussed: *Background and experience with group homes. *An overview of the program applicant is offering. *The structure for the program. *Program and services. *Neighborhood complaint procedure. *Pool on property will not be used by any staff or clients. *Administrator's qualification. After the review of the application and program statement, LPA and LPM have determined the following missing documents or documents that need to be revised. The documents are to be submitted by 12/13/2023: *Need a copy of administrator’s college degree. *Group Home Administrator 40-hour training certificate, health screening, TB clearance, first aid/CPR certification. (Continued on LIC 809c)

*Administrative Organization (LIC 309) for board member Chris Laitala needs to have an updated address with the suite number. *Board of Director or Governing Body Statement (LIC 9165) for board member Chris Laitala needs to have an updated address with the suite number. *Personnel Report (LIC 500) needs to be updated to show the name of the Administrator and work hours. *Job description for all positions at the facility. A pre-licensing visit and component III has been scheduled for 12/14/2023. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the appeal rights were emailed to Applicant Scott Sowle for original signature and a copy will be placed in the facility file.

On January 30, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Toni Castillo conducted an annual inspection at the Group Home. LPA met with the Sam Worrall, Clinical Director. LPA completed a health and safety assessment of the facility grounds. Group home is a two-story residence with three bedrooms, two bathrooms and facility staff office with additional storage. Seven administrative offices were on grounds and toured. The home was approved for 6 ambulatory male clients ages 12-17. There are currently three clients in care. The bedrooms were arranged so that there is one individual bed per client. Beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. There are adequate hygiene supplies stocked in the home available for clients. This home contains 2 group therapy rooms and a learning center on grounds to provide educational needs. Facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There was adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. LPA observed a swimming pool which is locked, fenced, and inaccessible to clients. The pool is surrounded by a iron fence measured over 5 feet tall. Sports equipment/games/ books were observed for children’s recreation time. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were in appropriate working order, fire extinguishers were properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The kitchen had adequate cooking supplies and utensils. All required forms were posted including the Grievance Procedure, Personal Rights form, and the Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are centrally stored in a lockbox located in a locked nursing office. The group home does not have cameras in common areas of the facility. Per clinical director, there were no firearms or weapons in the facility (Continuation on next page 809-C)

Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel files are maintained electronically through Paylocity System. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index checks clearances and exemptions. Three client files were reviewed electronically through Aura system. LPA completed a review of medications dispensed and charting. Three clients and four staff were interviewed. LPA reviewed copes of the fire and disaster drill log, current LIC 500 personnel record, grievance procedures and emergency intervention plan. Currently this facility does not use any forms of restraints. Staff is trained to use verbal de escalation and verbal redirection techniques. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to Sam Worrall, Clinical Director along with a Confidential Names List (LIC811).

A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. Clients will use a cordless telephone to make and receive confidential telephone calls. The water temperature in bathroom #1 located between arroyo room and oak room measured to be 106.8 Degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature inside oak room measured to be 111 and 113 Degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature in the bathroom located next to the kitchen was measured to be 116 Degrees Fahrenheit. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Medication will be locked in the locked cabinet in the Care Coordinator's Office. The facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors tested and were observed to be in working order; the fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced. The facility has a fully equipped first aid kit and first aid manual. The applicants stated there were no weapons in the facility. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions will be stored and locked. Sharp knives will be stored in a locked kicthen cabinet. The staff and client files will be maintained on the computer database via Kipu. LPA's advised CEO, Scott Sowle, that staff and client files to be accessible to Community Care Licensing (CCL) at any time. The following required forms were posted in the facility: Personal Rights form, Foster Care Ombudsmen Poster and Disaster plans were posted. (Continue on next page...)

The downstairs area is set up as follows: Two clinician offices, two staff bathrooms, and a group therapy room. The ground level area is set up as follows: Care coordinator office, dining room, living room, and a kitchen, one client bathroom. The upstairs are set up as follows: One staff’s lounge. Citrus Bedroom: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. Arroyo Bedroom: designated for two clients, two twin beds, one dresser with four drawers, and closet space. Oak Bedroom: designated for two clients, two full beds, one dresser with four drawers and closet space with one bathroom. Each room has adequate clean linens, pillows, blankets, comforters, mattress pads, and mattresses. The Backyard is set up as follows: The facility has one nursing office and a learning center. The facility has a pool which is appropriately fenced and secured with an iron wrought fence. The enclosure was measured to five-foot- three inches high. The Applicant/CEO Scott Sowle stated that the clients and staff will not have access to the swimming pool. The backyard is fully fenced and there is a covered patio with patio furniture. The facility has a enclosed fenced volleyball court. (Continue on next page...)

All special incident reports (SIR's) will be sent via e-mail to: cclpaccr@dss.ca.gov. The reporting requirements were reviewed with the Applicant/CEO on this date. Based on the facility pre-licensing inspection, the facility is ready for licensure.

On 12/05/2023 at 2:00 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sarah Lo and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jennifer Smith conducted a Component II meeting via Microsoft Teams with Applicant (CEO) Scott Sowle. Also present was Chief Compliance Officer Brent Bower, Care Coordinator Manager Melissa Gaviria, Care Coordinator Manager Jeff Denison, and Operations Manager Ashley Mitchell. The Administrator for this facility will be Ashley Mitchell. During the meeting the following was discussed: *Background and experience with group homes. *An overview of the program applicant is offering. *The structure for the program. *Program and services. *Neighborhood complaint procedure. *Pool on property will not be used by any staff or clients. *Administrator's qualification. *The Administrator explained her past work experiences for qualifications to work as a Group Home (GH) Administrator. After the review of the application and program statement, LPA and LPM have determined the following missing documents or documents that need to be revised. The documents are to be submitted by 12/13/2023: *Need a copy of administrator’s college degree. *continued on LIC 809-c*

*Group Home Administrator 40-hour training certificate, health screening, TB clearance, first aid/CPR certification. *Administrative Organization (LIC 309) for board member Chris Laitala needs to have an updated address with the suite number. *Board of Director or Governing Body Statement (LIC 9165) for board member Chris Laitala needs to have an updated address with the suite number. *Personnel Report (LIC 500) needs to be updated to show the name of the Administrator and work hours. *Job description for all positions at the facility. A pre-licensing visit and component III has been scheduled for 12/14/2023. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and the appeal rights were emailed to Applicant Scott Sowle for original signature and a copy will be placed in the facility file.

On January 23, 2025, Licensing Program Analysts (LPA), Toni Castillo conducted an annual inspection at the Group Home. LPA met with the Operations Manager, Melissa Gaviria. LPA completed a health and safety assessment of the facility grounds. Group home is a two-story residence with three bedrooms, five bathrooms and facility staff office with additional storage. Three administrative offices were on grounds and toured. The home was approved for 6 ambulatory female clients ages 12-17. There are currently zero clients in care. The bedrooms were arranged so that there is one individual bed per client. Beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. There are adequate hygiene supplies stocked in the home available for clients. This home contains 2 therapist offices, 1 group therapy room and 2 staff offices. Facility grounds were clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There was adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. LPA observed a swimming pool which is locked, fenced, and inaccessible to clients. The pool is surrounded by a iron fence measured over 5 feet tall. Sports equipment/games/ books were observed for children’s recreation time. Facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were in appropriate working order, fire extinguishers were properly charged and serviced. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. The hot water was measured to be 101.3 F degrees. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The kitchen had adequate cooking supplies and utensils. All required forms were posted including the Grievance Procedure, Personal Rights form, and the Foster Care Ombudsman poster. Medications are centrally stored in a lockbox located in a locked nursing office. The group home does not have cameras in common areas of the facility. Per Operations Manager, there were no firearms or weapons in the facility (Continuation on next page 809-C)

Personnel files were reviewed to ensure they contained all required documentation per Title 22 Regulations. Personnel files are maintained electronically through Paylocity System. All appropriate personnel who require caregiver background checks have received criminal record and child abuse index checks clearances and exemptions. There are no clients currently placed in this home therefore a review of client records was not completed.. LPA reviewed an electronic copy of the fire and disaster drill log, current LIC 500 personnel records, grievance procedures and emergency intervention plan. Currently this facility does not use any forms of restraints. Staff is trained to use verbal de escalation and verbal redirection techniques. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to the Operations Manager Melissa Gaviria along with a Confidential Names List (LIC811).

On January 8, 2024 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Leslie Covarrubias and Sarah Lo conducted an announced inspection visit for the purpose of inspecting the correction of the facility's pools fence and to inspect the facility's basement. LPA's met with Chief Compliance Officer, Brent Bowers. LPA's measured the wrought iron fence to be five feet tall, two feet from the bottom of the fence to the floor, and 45 inches space between the bars. The fence was also observed to have two self closing doors, one located in front of the pool with a latch five inches from the top of the fence. There is another self closing door with a latch measured to be four and half inches from the top of the fence located diagonal of the the pond. The fence encloses a pool, and pond that will not be used by clients or staff. LPA's inspected the utility basement located on the north west side of the facility. The basement has a door which will remain locked at all times and inaccessible to both clients and staff. LPA Covarrubias measured an 18 foot six inch walk way that was five feet nine inches in height. Surrounding the walkway LPA Covarrubias measured a crawl space two feet in height which is used for the under ground foundation. LPA's observed the empty fish pond or similar body of water that was filled in with rock to measure three and a half inches from the deepest point. LPA's stated the depth should be no more than two inches of depth to prevent drowning. The area was filled in with more rock during the inspection and corrected to measure two inches in depth. Per Chief Compliance Officer, Brent Bowers and Facility Manger, Armando Vergara the area also has drains that allow the water to drain out, which are located under the rock. (Continue on next page...)

LPA's inspected the garage space located separate, on the southwest of the facility to be used as a storage/ shed which will not be accessible to staff or clients (only the facility manager will have keys with access). Based on the facility inspection, the facility is ready for licensure, pending management review. LPA's Covarrubias and Lo conducted an exit interview, and a copy of this report was provided to Chief Compliance Officer, Brent Bowers.

On February 6, at 9:03 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Karen Beal and Julian Lucas and Licensing Program Manager, Cheraki Davis, conducted an unannounced annual inspection at Muir Wood Edge Wild Group Home. LPAs and LPM met with the facility by Operation Manager, Mellissa Gaviria at 9:20 AM. LPAs and LPM began a physical plant inspection at 9:45 AM assisted by Operation Manager. There are currently three clients. The physical plant inspection included the following checks: A physical plant inspection was completed and included the facilities formal entry, kitchen area, dining room, refrigerator/freezers, food storage areas, group room, two staff bathrooms, and two staff offices. There are three client bedrooms, one Nurse Office, client bathroom, Medication Room, Clinical Office, Care Coordinator Office, Therapy Office, TV/Group Room, Office Space, and an Admissions area. There is an additional dwelling that includes Operations Manager office, Learning Center, staff kitchen, two storage closets, and an office space. Facility is gated with an intercom system to obtain access. In this area the children are under constant supervision and never left alone. There were multiple green grassy areas throughout the grounds and various fruit trees throughout the facility. The roads surrounding the facility are covered with gravel and has an around about in the front entrance of the facility. Near the outside of the home there is a patio and a non-operable fireplace and grill. There is a storage shed on the right side of the facility with a garden on the outside of the shed that is used for storage with an art studio inaccessible to clients. Per Operations Manager, there are no guns or weapons on facility grounds. Cleansers and chemicals are inaccessible to clients. Cleaners and chemicals are locked under the sink and in a locked in a closet. Knives are not used at the facility due to lunch and dinner being catered and all food are prep before arriving to the facility. Staff cooks breakfast and snacks are provided. Continued to LIC 809-C

Continued from 809 Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. LPAs observed the following postings: food menu, the facility license, Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies and Personal Rights form. Age-appropriate toys, games and books were observed for client’s recreation time. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, and all exits were free from obstruction, debris, and observable hazards. LPAs observed the facility pool in the backyard to be inaccessible clients. The fence around the pool has a self-latching gate that swings outward and measured over five feet tall. The pool is clean and well maintained, gated pond with koi fish and a green grassy area for recreation. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order and located throughout the facility. Fire extinguishers are properly charged and serviced and located throughout the facility. Medications are centrally stored Medication Office and locked in a cabinet and refrigerator. The washer and dryer are located inside the Case Coordinator room. All detergents are kept locked in a cabinet and are inaccessible to clients. All bedrooms have individual beds, the facility ensures that there are two client per bedroom, with appropriate linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. There is adequate drawer space for each client’s belongings. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured in each bedroom and were within 105-120 degrees Fahrenheit. LPAs observed all containers, including movable bins, used for storage of solid wastes have tight-fitting covers kept on the containers are in good repair, leakproof, and rodent-proof. The facility has one vehicle and used to transport clients to appointments and recreational activities. The vehicle is maintained in a safe operating condition and insurance and registration is up to date. LPAs reviewed two client files with the assistance of the Clinical Director. LPAs conducted two client interviews. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Operations Manager, Mellissa Gavaria. *****This inspection will resume on another day.*****

On October 30, 2023 Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Monica Pavia met with Chief Executive Officer/Administrator, Scott Sowle, for a prelicensing inspection. LPA discussed the following with the Mr. Sowle: Forms that the facility uses and will continue to use. Corporate organization - Including chain of command and roles of staff Written plans, policies or procedures that was submitted with the application. Administrator/Director qualifications and duties. Mr. Sowle informed this LPA that he will be the Administrator for Muir Wood - Thompson Ranch when the facility is licensed. Mr. Sowle will submit Change of Administrator paperwork to the Santa Rosa office LPA, once facility is ready for placement's. 1. Facility grounds inspected. Grounds are clean and free from observable hazard. The facility does not have a swimming pool or any bodies of water. Firearms are not allowed on facility premises. 2. Adequate indoor activity space and materials observed, and outdoor activity space was observed. 3. Chemicals were appropriately locked 4. Procedures for Locked and centrally stored medications observed. 6. Adequate storage space observed. 7. Individual beds in good repair observed. A supply of extra linens available for bed changes. 8. The house has 3 client bedrooms, double occupancy, located on the second floor. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. 9. Adequate food storage space observed. Facility will add appropriate supply of foods upon placement of youth in the home. A supply of nonperishable foods were observed on this date. 10. Sample menu posted.

11. All appropriate forms posted within client view. 12. Dining room equipped with large table and chairs accommodating of all clients. 13. Facility has two restrooms for client use, one for staff use, all are operable Hot water measured 120 degrees on this date. Applicant is associated through Guardian and has been fingerprint cleared. Prior to accepting placement's, all staff must be fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility. Discussed Guardian process with the facility. Discussed with the facility the process for changing the facility Administrator. The following documents are required: 1. LIC 308 (Designation of Facility Responsibility) designating new administrator. 2. Current Personnel Record for new Administrator. 3. Verification of Education and/or experience for new administrator. 4. Copy of current administrator certificate. 5. Current (within one year) health screening and TB test. 6. Board Resolution granting administrative responsibility to the new administrator. 7. Fingerprint association transfer request (if the Administrator is not already associated to the facility) Discussed Incident reporting. An initial report for all reportable incidents is to be made by the next working day to crpincrohnertpark@dss.ca.gov. A full report is to be remitted within 7 days and may also be made to the incident reporting email. After licensure, you will receive a letter notifying you of your assigned LPA, from the Santa Rosa office. The facility will be approved for initial Licensure as of today, October 30, 2023. Initial license will be issued on a provisional basis, expiring one year from effective date. License will be valid for up to 6 male and/or female youth ages 12 through 17. A copy of this report was provided to Mr. Sowle.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett conducted a Pre-licensing inspection for a Group Home license and met with the Administrator Scott Sowle. The entire home was toured, inside and out. The application is to provide residential drug and alcohol and mental health treatment for six adolescents with substance abuse issues, private and insured placement, boys and girls ages 12 – 17 years. The facility/home interior and exterior inspection description: The home is 2 levels and also encompasses an additional unit as in the lower level of the main house with its own entrance, bedroom and bathroom. The separate unit is currently intended for use as a quarantine residence for possible COVID-19 purposes but census will not exceed 6 clients. The main house has 3 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms (2 client/1 staff), medications are stored in locked cabinets in the office of the main house. There is a kitchen, dining room, living room/group room, and an office in the main house. Facility utilizes a linen company and has a washer/dryer in the main house. Each bedroom is set up with 2 beds. All bedrooms have adequate dresser and closet space. On the property is a locked storage shed and 2 barn-like structures which will be locked or otherwise blocked to prevent client access.There are carbon monoxide and smoke detectors throughout the facility. There is one complete first-aid kit located in the office. Applicant understands that the hot water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105 – 120 degrees and was measure at 111F.The knives will be stored in a locked kitchen drawer designated for sharp objects. All required postings are clearly displayed in the main hallway.

deficiencies.description: 80019 Criminal Record Clearance (b)The following persons are exempt from the requirement to submit fingerprints: (1) A medical professional, as defined by the Department in regulations, who holds a valid license or certification from the individual's governing California medical care regulatory entity and who is not employed, retained, or contracted by the licensee...This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentation the facility has a contracted employee working at the facility without fingerprint clearance.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: The facility will submit fingerprint clearance for the employee. The staff member will also not be able to work until they are fingerprint cleared.

This department has investigated the allegations, and although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the above allegations are true; therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted with Chief Compliance Officer Brent Bowers and a copy of this report was sent to the facility.

13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge met with Administrator Scott Sowle and Cheif Operating Officer Bryan Bowen regarding a complaint investigation at the Group Home. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver the findings for the above allegation. The investigation was conducted by CCIB Investigator Megan Mullen. During the course of the investigation, the Investigator interviewed youth and staff and LPA reviewed records. It was during these confidential interviews that it was confirmed that there had been consensual inappropriate sexual activities between clients. Based on the information obtained, there is a preponderance of the evidence to prove that minors are engaging in inappropriate sexual activities while in care. Therefore, the above allegation is substantiated. Appeal Rights were provided and discussed, and Title 22 deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of the report was sent to the facility.

deficiencies.description: 84072 Personal Rights (d) The licensee shall ensure that each child, regardless of whether the child is in foster care, is accorded the personal rights....In addition, the licensee shall ensure that each child is accorded the following personal rights:(11) To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, and corporal punishment. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on interviews and documentation facility failed to keep sexual activities between two minors from happening while in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility will switch up time schedule for room checks to random times instead of having a set schedule. 
Facility is also going to conduct a refresher training for staff to be aware of clients behaviors.

Located on the 1st story is a staff office and staff bathroom, and a ½ client bathroom. Medications are stored in locked cabinets in the medication room on the 1st story. There is a kitchen, dining room, living room/group room, and an office on the first story. Facility utilizes a linen company and has a washer/dryer on the second story. 4 bedrooms are set up with 1 bed each and the 5th bedroom has 2 beds. There is one complete first-aid kit located in the office and 1 in the upstairs laundry room. Applicant understands that the hot water temperature must be maintained within the regulation range of 105 – 120 degrees and was measure at 112F. The knives will be stored in a locked kitchen drawer designated for sharp objects. All required postings are clearly displayed in the entrance hallway. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) David Hiett conducted a prelicensing inspection for a Group Home license and met with the Administrator Scott Sowle.. The entire home was toured, inside and out. The application is for providing substance dependent/abusing adolescents ages 12 – 17 years. Residents may have co-occurring disorders, anxiety disorders or mild trauma. In addition, residents may have issues concerning family dysfunction, low self-esteem, anger management and cross addictions. Residents may require intensive counseling, or different types of therapeutic services. The home is set up as follows: This is single-story with 3 bedrooms, two bathrooms, a living room/dining room, a group room/activity room and a staff office that also is used as a medication storage room. There were appropriate furnishings in the home. The bathrooms were checked and are in operating condition. The faucets that will be used by the children were tested and delivered hot water at a temperature of 117.5F. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide alarms and present are operable. The emergency telephone numbers were posted in a prominent location.

The home has a locked cabinet where medications will be stored. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were stored in a location that will be inaccessible to children. The first aid kit was checked and found to be complete. The front and backyard were inspected and found cleared of hazards. There were no pools and/or bodies of water on the premises. The applicant has a current health screening report with TB test. The applicant has current CPR and First Aid certificates and the appropriate training hours. The applicant stated that there are no guns and weapons in the home. The applicant stated that he has a valid California driver’s license, registration and insurance. The applicant was made aware that it is their responsibility to know Title 22 Regulations: · The applicant was informed that the household kitchen knives and appliances need to be locked or inaccessible to a child who is not of sufficient age or maturity to use such items. · Must maintain a separate, complete and current record or file for each child. · Report Unusual Incident/Injury (LIC 624) to Licensing and within 24 hours by phone, fax, or email; and seven days in writing. · Children are to be free from physical, sexual, emotional or other abuse, or corporal punishment. · Telephone service shall be readily accessible in the home at all times. · The home shall be clean, safe, and sanitary and in good repair at all times. · The applicant shall provide an orientation of the Children’s Personal Rights. · No more than two children shall share a room and there is one child per bed.

The following forms were discussed and/or given to the applicant: Unusual Incident/Injury Report (LIC 624) Identification and Emergency Information (LIC 601), Centrally Stored Medication and Destruction Record (LIC 622) Client/Resident Personal Property and Valuables (LIC 621) Children’s Personal Rights (LIC 613B) forms. The home is within Title 22 Regulation standards at this time. An exit interview conducted and a copy of the report was left with the applicant.

investigation_findings: 13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge met with Cheif Operating Officer Bryan Bowen regarding a complaint investigation at the group home. The purpose of the meeting was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Branch Special Investigator Jorge Martinez and included interviews with staff, current and former clients, and the reporting party. In addition Sonoma County's Sheriffs report and facility records and files were reviewed. Interviews with staff revealed no observed incidents of inappropriate touching by the clients. All clients stated the behavior was juvenile and immature, versus sexual in nature. Clients stated staff were always present, engaged, and never allowed any inappropriate behavior. Per clients, staff promptly redirected any inappropriate behavior and documented all incidents. Any behavior unacceptable did not go without redirection, additional treatotnent, or a consequence. All clients said staff provided a safe environment and were swift to correct unsafe behavior.

13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge met with Cheif Operating Officer Bryan Bowen regarding a complaint investigation at the group home. The purpose of the meeting was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigations Branch Special Investigator Shannan Borton in addition to Licensing Program Analyst Cheyenne McCambridge and included interviews with staff, current and former clients, and the reporting party. In addition Sonoma County's Sheriffs report and facility records and files were reviewed. Interviews with staff revealed no observed incidents of inappropriate touching by the clients. The victim did not wish to be interviewed or speak about the incident. Other youth stated that the incident never occurred and it was stated that the victim would do anything no to be at the facility. There is a lack of clear evidence to make a determination as to whether a regulatory violation did occur. This department has investigated the allegations, and although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that minor was sexually assaulted by another minor in care; therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. Appeal rights were provided and discussed, and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was sent to the facility.

13On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Brian Bertoli initiated an investigation with the Group Home and spoke with Administrator Scott Sowle. The purpose of the inspection was to inform the facility that an investigation is being conducted regarding the above allegations. LPA Bertoli and Administrator Sowle discussed that an Investigations Branch Investigator Joseph Balarie has completed this investigation. During the course of the investigation, Investigator Balarie interviewed staff and youth, and reviewed records. There was no indication that the allegations occurred other than statements from client. There is a lack of clear evidence to make a determination as to whether a regulatory violation did occur. This department has investigated the allegations, and although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that Staff sexually abused client or of Staff showing inappropriate photos to client. Therefore, the above allegation is unsubstantiated. Appeal rights were provided and discussed, and no deficiencies were cited. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of the report was given to the facility.

narrative: On the above date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cheyenne McCambridge conducted a Case Management visit to discuss issues that came up during a recent investigation, control number 21-CR-20230905113837. LPA met with Director of Operations Kelli Azevedo. Based on review of documentation submitted by the facility they were missing the visitation policy/plan in the clients' needs and services plan. LPA provided a copy of the CDSS LIC 625 and a copy of the Title 22 regulations of what is to be included in the clients' needs and services plan. LPA McCambridge issued a type B deficiency per Title 22 Regulations for section 84068.2 Needs and Services Plan (b)(6). An exit interview was conducted and Appeal Rights were provided. The LIC809 Evaluation Report and deficiency page were sent to the Director of Operations.

deficiencies.description: 84068.2 Needs and Services Plan (b) The needs and services plan shall identify the child's needs in the following areas: (6) Visitation, including the frequency of and any other limitations on visits to the family residence and other visits inside and outside the facility. This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on record review this was not included in the clients' needs and services plan  which poses an potential health, safety, or personal rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility will send updated section of treatment plan to LPA.

narrative: On March 30, 2022 at approximately 9:30 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted an announced visit at the facility for the purposes of a capacity increase inspection. LPA met with Lead Counselor Supervisor Sergio Castaneda and discussed the purpose of the visit. The facility is situated on a large campus that currently operates multiple children's residential programs under the same ownership.This facility is currently licensed for a capacity of 60 clients and is requesting an increase to 72. There are six separate cottages under the current license and each cottage contains five bedrooms that can sleep two clients each. The Licensee is requesting to utilize another vacant cottage (Tarr) that was formerly used for a different program, to house additional clients under this facility license. The Licensee is also requesting to convert a staff office in one of the current cottages (Gillette) into a bedroom that can sleep two clients. A walk-through of the vacant cottage, was conducted by LPA and Castaneda. The cottage is situated directly next to the cottages that are currently under this facility license. During the walk-through, LPA observed the cottage to be clean and orderly. A total of five client bedrooms were each furnished with two beds, separate closets, dressers, desks, and light fixtures. There are three bathrooms for client use and all were stocked with appropriate hygiene supplies. There is one staff office where client medication and all other supplies can be secured as well as a bathroom for staff use. The cottage uses a open floor layout with the living room on one side, an activity area in the middle, and the dining area on the other side. The kitchen was observed to be clean, sanitary, and stocked with a supply of non-perishable foods. Fire extinguisher(s) were observed to have been serviced in March 2022. Required postings were observed throughout the walls of the cottage. In the Gillette cottage, LPA observed the former staff office to be the same as the other bedrooms in the cottage. The room was furnished with two separate beds, closets, dressers, and desks. With approval, this cottage would have six bedrooms and three bathrooms for client use. The Licensee's request is pending approval of a fire inspection conducted by the local fire department and from this department's management review. No deficiencies were observed during today's visit. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to the Licensee.

On April 11, 2022 at approximately 12:45 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted a visit at the facility for the purposes of initiating a 2 Year Required inspection. LPA met with the representative listed above and discussed the purpose of the visit. During the visit, a walk-through of the facility was conducted. The facility is currently vacant and the last client moved out approximately 2 years ago according to the Administrator. PHYSICAL PLANT A walk-through of the physical plant was conducted at approximately 12:45 PM. The facility is situated on a large campus that currently operates multiple children's residential programs under the same ownership. This facility is currently licensed for a capacity of 60 clients. There are six separate cottages under the current license and each cottage contains five bedrooms that can sleep two clients each. A walk-through of the cottages was conducted by LPA and Castaneda. During the walk-through, LPA observed the cottages to be clean and orderly. Client bedrooms were each furnished with two beds, separate closets, dressers, desks, and light fixtures. Bathrooms for client use and all were stocked with appropriate hygiene supplies, including soap and paper towels. All sharp objects, chemicals, and medication were stored in secured staff offices. All required postings were observed in common areas and all items in the cottages were observed to be in good repair. The kitchen was observed to be clean, sanitary, and stocked with a supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. Fire extinguisher(s) were observed to have been serviced in March 2022. There was an enclosed pool at the center of the campus utilized by all programs. The enclosed fence was observed to be at least 5 feet tall. All other common areas were observed to be in good repair. All indoor and outdoor passageways were free from obstruction. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were observed to be in working order across all cottages. LPA advised that an annual continuation visit would be conducted. No deficiencies were observed or cited on this date.

On 04/21/2023, the Department received a complaint alleging allegations of personal rights toward clients. It was alleged that clients are not being treated fairly by staff, staff are threatening the clients using a point system to delay their unification, and staff are interfering with religious services towards a specific client population of not being taken to a Mosque. The Facility Senior Lead Supervisor (FLS) and other staff workers denied the allegations. FLS stated that all clients are treated equally and with respect. FLS stated that the facility uses a point system but never affects the client’s reunification process. FLS stated that it is impossible to threaten a client to delay reunification with family members or with a sponsor. FLS and other staff workers provided consistent statements and denied interfering with the clients’ religious practice of attending a Mosque. FLS stated that clients that requested to attend a Mosque were honored before, during, and after Ramadan. FLS disclosed that all clients are being accommodated based on their needs, such as food service, clothing, and other religious services. In confidential interviews, LPA Vargas interviewed clients of different ethnicities from different cottages. All clients that were interviewed provided consistent statements and denied the allegations. One Individual identified as other who had specific information about the allegations reported could not be contacted after several attempts were made to obtain a statement. U.S. Federal Field Specialist (FFS) denied all of the allegations reported. FFS stated that she meets with a wide variety of clients of different ethnicities and religious beliefs, and they (clients) have never made any complaints to her about the staff at New Beginnings. FFS commented that the facility representative and others have experienced some form of interpersonal communication. FFS has no concerns with the care and supervision of the clients at New Beginnings. Interviews and documentary evidence produced do not corroborate evidence to support the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the agency representative and copies of all licensing reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection.
investigation_findings: 13On 06/08/2023 at 01:45 PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Joseph Vargas conducted a follow-up inspection for the purpose of providing findings for the above complaint. Reference confidential names list LIC811 dated 06/08/2023. narrative: On 11/30/2023, the Department received a complaint alleging allegations of personal rights towards one client. It was alleged that the client was being denied religious services, and facility staff were not ensuring that the client attended on-campus school, including that the client was being denied to make confidential phone calls. The Facility Assistant Director (S1) and one staff worker denied the allegations. S1 disclosed that the client has access to religious services on campus, including other times going off-site to a Mosque. S1 denied the allegation that C1 is not being encouraged to attend on-campus schooling. S1 explained that C1 at first was participating but then stopped attending school and has refused to attend classes. The facility in collaboration with the U.S. Federal Field Specialist (FFS) is arranging to provide an independent education program to the client where he will learn from his assigned facility cottage. S1 denied the allegation the focused client identified in the report is not allowed to have confidential phone calls. S1 disclosed that all clients, including the focused client, have privacy when making confidential phone calls using a dedicated phone room. S1 explained that the client has demanded his own cellular phone which is not allowed in this particular program for safety and confidential reasons. In confidential interviews, the focused client provided inconsistent statements and stated that the allegations when first reported was accurate information but has recanted the allegations and stated that everything is okay. The focused client (FC) has denied the allegations. FC stated that he has attended religious services but on his own accord, he has declined to attend religious services off-site when offered, including on-site. The client stated that the staff working at the facility has always encouraged him to attend school and has admitted that he made the decision not to participate in attending classes. The client stated that he has access to a telephone room to make confidential phone calls but has requested to have his own cellular phone. The client disclosed that having his own cellular phone is not allowed. U.S. Federal Field Specialist (FFS) denied the allegations reported. FFS stated that she has encouraged the client to participate in the program as it is part of his expectations. FFS does not see indicators that the facility has violated the client's rights. FFS stated that she would closely monitor the situation. The individual identified as other stated that the allegations when first disclosed is accurate information. Interviews and documentary evidence produced do not corroborate evidence to support the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are determined unsubstantiated at this time. A finding that the complaint is unsubstantiated means that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged abuse occurred. The resolution to this complaint was discussed with the agency representative and copies of all licensing reports were provided at the conclusion of the inspection.

narrative: Continue from page 1 . . . The staff stated that the food is label with dates of receiving date and expiration date and then is stored away. The staff stated that the food is checked by the staff on each shift. The staff stated that the food is thrown away when it is noticed. The staff stated that the cottages received the food for the weekend on each Friday and the cottage staff checks it and puts it away. The confidential interviews from different cottage clients indicated that the clients have not received outdated, spoil or rotten food items from the staff. The confidential interviews revealed that the staff cooks breakfast for the clients and the clients eat lunch at the campus cafeteria and then have dinner that was prepared by the kitchen staff. LPA conducted cottages inspections with facility staff (S1) and admitted to items being expired. LPA and S1 conducted the inspection and found expired items on the cottages: chicken strips, danish, pork, bacon, mini tacos, salsas, jalapenos, pineapple, berries and cheese. deficiencies.description: 80076 (a)(1) FOOD SERVICES: (a) In facilities providing meals to clients, the following shall apply:(1) All food shall be safe and of the quality and in the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. This requirement was not met as evidenced by: LPA and facilty staff observed expired food items during an unannounced inspection by the Department on 06/21/24 which poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: POC: The licensee will implement a plan to ensure that no expired food items are kept at the facility. Details of the plan will be submitted in writing to CCL. Licensee will conduct in house training to staff regarding food handling and safety. Licensee will provide proof of training to CCL by the plan of correction date, including sign in sheet and topic covered. Heriberto.Perez@dss.ca.gov

narrative:
Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) T. Davis and Caitlin Chambers went to New Beginnings on September 05, 2024 at 9:15am for the purposes of a Required Two Year inspection. LPAs met with Enrique Garate, Supervisor, and discussed the nature of the inspection. The group home is located in a residential neighborhood and currently has fifty-two youth in placement. The facility has a total of seven cottages for placement purposes. Six of the cottages have clients placed in them and the seventh one is vacant at this time. LPA Davis and the Supervisor toured the facility as part of the inspection. During the inspection, LPA observed that the bedrooms in the cottages contained two twin beds, dressers, and closet space. Each cottage has an inoperable fireplace. LPA observed the bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Sharp knives, chemicals, medications, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to clients. LPA observed several fully charged fire extinguishers in the cottages. Smoke alarms were operable and exit signs were posted throughout each cottage. LPA observed a copy of the Emergency Disaster Plan, facility license, and a facility sketch in each cottage. A menu was also posted in each cottage as well. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe, and well maintained. The kitchen in each cottage was cleaned and equipped with fully stocked refrigerators. There were adequate perishable and non-perishable food supply in each cottage. The Supervisor stated that the facility has eight vans available for client transportation needs. LPAs observed a secured in-ground swimming pool on the premises enclosed with a self-latching gate. There is adequate seating in the dining areas and the living room. There are separate phone booths/areas for the clients' use. The facility has an on campus school for the clients' educational needs.

The Supervisor stated that there weren't any firearms or other weapons on the premises. The last fire drill occurred on August 16, 2024 at 9:00pm. The last earthquake drill occurred on August 07, 2024 at 4:00pm. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. Interviews were conducted with clients and staff, respectively. Each client appeared neat and well groomed. LPAs obtained a copy of the minutes relating to the most recent Board of Director's meeting that was held on May 30, 2024. LPAs reviewed files and found the reviewed files to be in order. LPAs also obtained an updated LIC500 (Personnel Report) and a client roster. LPA found no Title 22/ILS deficiencies on this date. Exit interview done LPA Davis discussed warm weather conditions and precautions with the Supervisor and provided him with the Department's website address (www.ccld.ca.gov).

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to New Beginnings on December 12, 2024 at 12:05pm in order to conclude the follow up on an incident report that was received by Community Care Licensing on November 13, 2024. LPA met with Francisco Guerrero, Assistant Program Director, and discussed the incident. The incident report stated that child #1 (refer to Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated December 12, 2024) was experiencing medical neglect. Information obtained shows that the child had hurt his ankle and was observed playing soccer. Staff informed the client that he should not be playing soccer if he has a hurt ankle. The child informed the staff that he wanted to visit with the campus medical staff. The medical staff advised the client that he should rest his ankle and elevate it. Information gathered shows that the client wanted to go to an off campus doctor. Staff took the client to urgent care and the doctor informed the client that he needed to elevate his ankle. Client was transported back to the facility and proceeded to follow the doctor's medical orders. Based on a review of documentation, information, and facts obtained in this matter, the Department has determined that there is no evidence or information to show that the facility neglected the child's injury or concerns. The Department has concluded that the situation has been stabilized and no further follow up is necessary. Exit interview done

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to New Beginnings on February 14, 2025, at 12:10pm to conclude the follow up on an incident report that was received by Community Care Licensing (CCL) on October 07, 2024. LPA met with Francisco Guerrero, Assistant Program Director (APD), and discussed the matter. The SIR stated that child #1 (see Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated February 14, 2025) was administered incorrect medication by Staff #1 (811). Information shows that child #1 was administered a Metronidazole 500 mg tablet in error. Evidence shows that the no additional medications were distributed to the child by Staff #1 on the day of the incident. The facility contacted medical staff and the child was encouraged to drink plenty of water to help flush the medication from their system. The child was also placed on a twenty-four hour adverse reaction watch. Information obtained shows that the child did not have any adverse reactions, nor any side effects due to the medication error. Based on information and facts obtained in this matter, the Department has determined that staff failed to perform their duties as assigned which resulted in child #1 being administered the incorrect medication. Therefore, the facility will be cited under section 80075(b)(5)(B) per California Code of Regulations, Title 22: (see LIC809D). Exit interview done. Appeal Rights given.

deficiencies.description:
HEALTH RELATED SERVICES:
Medications shall be given according to physician's directions.  Staff failed to 
administer proper medication to child #1.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Staff #1 was provided training on the importance of client medication and proper medication dispensing.  The individual also met with the Medical Department for three days upon the start of their shift and administered medications under the supervision of the Medical Coordinator. Licensee provided CCL with a copy of the training agenda/Med Training Record and a copy of the Employee Performance Reminder.

narrative: On 10/21/24 the Department received a complaint alleging facility staff do not ensure an adequate supply of food is available for clients in care. The facility staff indicated the facility does not run out of food and always has adequate amounts of food. Clients interviewed indicated there is always food at the facility and clients are not denied food. LPA during the initial inspection of the facility observed adequate amounts of food in the client’s cottages and in the cafeteria. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is/are found unsubstantiated. narrative: The staff denied the allegation and stated that clients are provided a variety of food. The staff reported that there was no information indicating that food was causing stomach issues to a client and that if it was reported that staff would work to take care of it. The staff reported that clients get three meals per day plus snacks and that the clients can get alternative food if the main dish is not to the client's liking. The staff reported that the facility is working on proving more food variety to clients of different backgrounds. The confidential interviews that the clients get a variety of food and are able to get alternative food if they don't want the main dish. The information from confidential interviews revealed that some clients like the food and some did not but were able to get a second choice of food. The confidential interviews reported that the clients got enough to eat and that client did not go to bed hungry but would like more variety of food. The information indicated that the clients have meals and snacks available. The majority of the statements did not report stomach issues from the facility food. narrative: The minor received dental care on 7/23/24 and follow-up dental care visits were completed on 7/29/24 and 8/21/24. A serious medical procedure request had to be submitted by the facility to the Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR) on 8/29/24 due to minor needing additional treatment for wisdom tooth extraction. The process for the wisdom tooth extraction took longer because the request was initially denied and when it was approved, there were challenges in obtaining the earliest available dates for an oral surgeon. Throughout the process, the minor was informed of ongoing daily contacts by the facility with ORR and dental providers so minor understood the protocol involved in ensuring his medical need is met. Minor's wisdom tooth extraction was completed on 10/24/24. The minor reported eye irritation to staff on 9/19/24. However, on 9/20/24, the minor denied any eye pain or irritation when a facility medical assistant followed up with the minor regarding the reported symptom. The facility still submitted a treatment authorization request to ORR on 9/24/24, so the minor can be seen by an optometrist. The facility obtained a vision appointment for the minor and was seen on 10/1/24. The minor was given a prescription for glasses. Confidential interviews supported the information from documents reviewed. Minor was only concerned about the length of time the dental issue was resolved and denied that other medical needs were not met by the facility. Based on information obtained during the investigation, the allegation is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is no preponderance of evidence found to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The following reports were provided to the facility representative at the conclusion of today’s inspection: LIC9099, LIC9099-C and LIC811 Confidential Names. Appeal rights forms were also given and explained. There was no deficiency citation issued.

narrative: On 10/16/24 the Department received a complaint alleging clients are being recorded, clients videos are being posted on social media, drugs are being bought into the facility and clients are using drugs in the facility. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, facility staff indicated clients had obtained cell phones that were in a file in the office. Staff had reported client#2 had asked staff he needed help and staff walked away from office without locking the file cabinet where the phones were located in the file cabinet and client#3 walked into the office and grabbed phones. The facility staff indicated there was no proof anyone posted any video on line or that the phones had any service. Some clients interviewed stated they had phones for two days and they had no service and did not post anything on line. Client#1 stated he had crystal meth in a compartment in his shoe he had brought into the facility. During a room search a vape pen was found. Client#1 stated he had befriended another student at school and he told him to meet him by the window by his cottage to get the vape pen, but staff caught them during the exchange. Staff interviewed stated drug had not been used at the facility at any time. Confidential interviews could not corroborate the allegations due to contradicting statements being made during interviews. Clients interviewed indicated there is supervision and the phone incident was just some clients trying to use phones since they were taken away. Interviews also indicated staff that had left the file cabinet open with the phones was reprimanded for the incident. Other clients interviewed stated they felt safe at the facility and that client#2-3 had planned to get staff's attention and get the phones from the office. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegations. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

narrative: On 01/27/2025, the Department received a complaint alleging that Staff engaged in an inappropriate relationship with a minor in care and Staff confiscated minor's personal belongings. The information obtained from the facility management indicated that staff found a laptop on a client's room and was confiscated as minors are not allow to have electronic devices without staff supervision. It was discovered by the facility management that there was electronic communication via social media on several occasions by former facility staff with a client. The communication between the former facility staff and client was late at night and not during working hours. The electronic communication was not work related and were on a personal level. The facility management reported that based on the facility code of conduct policy staff can't have contact with clients before 21 years old and outside working hours. It was also reported by the facility management that the client's cell phone was taken from the client by the former staff to check on the usage of the client as there were issues with it. The facility management reported that the cell phone was not found and was determined lost but the facility gave a new cell phone to the client. The focused facility staff (S1) who was identified in the report, denied the allegations, and stated that the youth (C1) contacted him but there was nothing inappropriate with the communication. The staff stated that C1 contacted him after he had stop working for the facility and was working on a new job. The staff stated that he was contacted by C1 and C1 was venting about the facility. The staff stated that C1's cell phone was taken from the youth because the youth was not allow to have it at some point but he (S1) gave the phone to another staff prior to stop working for the facility and did not know what happened after that. Information obtained indicated that the staff last day of work was on 10/11/24 and the communication with the youth were from December 2024. The focus youth (C1) denied the social media contact with staff at first and after stated that he communicated with the staff a few times because he was having a hard time and the staff was a friend and nice guy. C1 stated that there was nothing inappropriate with the communication and just talked about the facility. C1 stated that there was no issue with his phone and the facility staff gave him a phone when his old one was lost. Based on the interviews and records reviewed, the allegations are found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegations. Copies of LIC9099, LIC9099C, LIC811 and Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.
