met_with: Francisco Guerrero, Assistant Program Director and Gerardo Salazar, Lead Counselor Supervisor
narrative:
Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to New Beginnings on August 29, 2025 at 11:50am in order to conduct a Random Annual inspection. LPA met with Francisco Guerrero, Assistant Program Director (APD), and Gerardo Salazar, Lead Counselor Supervisor, and discussed the inspection in detail. The group home is located in a residential neighborhood and currently has six youth in placement. The facility has a total of four cottages available for placement purposes. Two of the cottages have clients placed in them and two are vacant at this time. LPA and the two staff toured the facility inside and outside as part of the inspection. Each bedroom contains two twin beds, dressers, and closet space. LPA observed the bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Sharp knives, chemicals, medications, and cleaning supplies are kept locked in areas inaccessible to clients. LPA observed several fully charged fire extinguishers in the cottages. Smoke alarms were operable and exit signs were posted throughout each cottage. There is a separate telephone room in each cottage for the clients to use. LPA observed a copy of the Emergency Disaster Plan, facility sketch, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, menus, facility license, Hotlines for Youth information, Recreation and Leisure Schedule, and a facility sketch posted in each cottage. Overall, the facility appeared clean, safe, and well maintained. LPA observed cameras in the common areas of each cottage. Licensee has CCL approvals for the use of video cameras on the premises. There is adequate seating in the dining areas and the living room. The kitchen in each cottage was equipped with perishable and non-perishable food supply. LPA observed personal hygiene items for the clients as well as an ample supply of linen. The APD stated that the facility has six vans available for client transportation needs. LPA observed a secure in-ground swimming pool on the premises enclosed with a self-latching gate. The pool area appeared neat and well maintained.

LPA observed fully stocked First Aid Kits in each cottage. The facility has an on campus school for the clients' educational needs. LPA visited the cafeteria and found the areas inside to be neat and tidy. There is ample food supply for the clients' meal needs as well as sufficient dining space. The APD stated that there weren't any firearms or other weapons on the premises. The last fire drill occurred on August 06, 2025 at 3:45pm. The outdoor areas were observed to be free of debris and hazards. Interviews were conducted with clients and staff, respectively. Each client appeared neat and well groomed. LPA reviewed staff and client files and found the reviewed files to be in order. LPA obtained an updated LIC500 (Personnel Report) and a client roster. LPA also obtained a copy of the minutes relating to the most recent Board of Director's meeting that was held on May 29, 2025. LPA found no Title 22/ILS deficiencies on this date. Exit interview done LPA discussed warm weather/extreme heat conditions and precautions with the APD and provided him with the Department's website address (www.ccld.ca.gov).

met_with: Francisco Guerrero, Assistant Program Director and Gerardo Salazar, Lead Counselor Supervisor
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) T. Davis went to New Beginnings on August 29, 2025 at 11:50am in order to conclude the follow up on an incident report that was received by Community Care Licensing on May 23, 2025. Various follow ups were done to obtain additional facts and information. LPA met with Francisco Guerrero, Assistant Program Director and Gerardo Salazar, Lead Counselor Supervisor, and discussed the incident. The incident report stated that another minor touched minor's private area. During the course of the investigation, LPA obtained information that the incident allegedly occurred at school in 2024. The facility was made aware of the incident May 2025 and reported it forthright. The investigation revealed that child #1 (refer to Confidential Names form (LIC 811) dated August 29, 2025) was sitting in the basketball area during a school restroom break and child #2 (LIC 811) allegedly touched child #1 in the groin area with a closed fist. Child #1 reportedly informed school officials. Information obtained indicates that the incident was not observed by any school personnel. School officials decided to make classroom adjustments. Based on a review of documentation, information, and facts obtained in this matter, the Department has determined that there is no evidence or information that the facility failed in its responsibility to provide care and supervision. School officials, out of an abundance of caution, made classroom changes and made sure that the two children maintained their distance from one another. Both minors are no longer placed at the facility. The Department has concluded that the situation has been stabilized and no further follow up is necessary. Exit interview done

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Jodean Hall conducted an office meeting and met with Kasey Avery, Compliance Director, and Ross Morton, Chief Executive Officer to discuss the application. LPA Hill and LPM Hall discussed the following: * Purpose of the meeting in that the meeting was to discuss the structure of the facility and the application. The application indicates two separate addresses and it was discussed that Community Care Licensing can only license one side and if the licensee would like to license the other side, they would need to obtain approval from the county planning per the over concentration requirements, H&S 1520.5. * Facility sketch was discussed as it is not clear on the sketch submitted with the application. Licensee provided an updated and clear sketch. * Administrator - the named administrator is currently associated to eight different facilities as the administrator six others indicated associations as staff. In addition, the resume in the application indicates additional working relationships. * LPA Hill requested that the facility address all qualifications in the application to ensure that all up to date. * Orientations certificates for CEO and named individual approved by the board to submit the application are required but not included in the application. * Licensing requirements differing between DHCS and CCLD. LPA Hall discussed licensing requirements and how they differ from each department. * Exemption for the side by side licensure as the licensee wishes to license both sides as group homes in the future. * Changing the current application to only one side and decreasing the capacity from 11 to 6 at this time. The other side will stay DHCS licensed until city planning discussion is resolved. End of discussion.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill met with applicant Kasey Avery, Director of Compliance, Ross Morton, CEO, and Diane McGill to discuss the application for licensure. LPA Hill discussed the application requirements in depth and did discuss expectations of the operation of the facility. LPA Hill talked about application documents, requirements for Neighborhood Complaint Policies, postings required in the facility, and other topics during the meeting. LPA Hill emphasized that the agency needs to have a thorough training plan and have adequate staffing to meet the needs of the youth in care. LPA Hill and the agency set a date for the corrections to be turned in by 6/21/24. Ms. Avery states that the Department will need to request another fire clearance due to the first one being denied. LPA Hill and the agency discussed other things related to the operation of the facility. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill conducted an announced Prelicensing inspection on 12/19/24 at 9:30 am and met with Diane McGill, Administrator. LPA Hill started the inspection but quickly realized that while the bedrooms were set up and ready for clients to be accepted, the agency did not have the following minimum required items: No locking medication storage cabinet was present. No dishes were present outside of cups and utensils. No storage for chemicals or cleaning supplies. No nonperishable food supply was present. No postings were observed. Upon pointing out these missing items, the agency requested that the Prelicensing inspection be rescheduled until the facility could be ready for the Prelicensing inspection to be conducted. LPA Hill provided dates and times during the inspection and Ms. McGill will work with the agency to find a new date for the Prelicensing inspection when the facility will be ready for inspection. Signature obtained and exit interview was conducted.

met_with: Kasey Avery, Diane McGill, and Saira Ahmed
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an announced pre-licensing inspection 1/6/25 at 2:00 PM and met with Kasey Avery, Compliance Director, Diane McGill, Administrator, and Saira Ahmed, Compliance Coordinator to tour the facility inside and out. LPA Hill toured the facility and observed that the facility is ready for licensure. LPA Hill observed that there are three dual occupancy bedrooms, two client bathrooms, a dining area, kitchen, extra room, office area. LPA Hill observed the office is equipped with the medication cabinet and chemicals cabinet, both with locks to ensure dual inaccessibility. LPA Hill observed that there are two fire extinguishers in the kitchen area that are accessible and was last serviced on 12/10/24. LPA Hill observed a carbon monoxide detector in the hallway that is working as required. LPA Hill also observed that the smoke detectors in the facility were operating as required. LPA Hill observed that there is a two day supply of perishable food and seven day of canned goods accessible when clients are admitted. LPA Hill also observed that there are laundry facilities for clients. The outdoor of the facility appears to be safe for clients in care. LPA Hill advised the facility that they are to notify the Department upon admission of their first client. LPA Hill also advised that upon acceptance of the last sections of the program statement approval, the Licensee shall submit a final binder of the approved Program Statement to the Department, tabbed and in a binder. LPA Hill conducted and exit interview and provided the documentation to the facility.

The allegation is deemed to be unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are cited regarding the above allegation. An exit interview was held and a copy of this report and appeal rights provided during the exit interview. The allegation is deemed to be unsubstantiated. No deficiencies are cited regarding the above allegation. An exit interview was held and a copy of this report and appeal rights provided during the exit interview.
investigation_findings: 13On 12/24/20, at 9:35 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer conducted a follow-up complaint telephone call to Administrator, Ms. Powell. The purpose of the call was to discuss and deliver this complaint investigation findings. On 1/29/20, LPA interviewed four (4) residents and the Administrator. On 3/11/20, 3/13/20, and 3/18/20 LPA spoke with the client’s County Social Worker (CSW) by telephone and email. One of the clients stated she's not usually at the group home when the allowance is given, and when she returns, she doesn't ask for it. Two of the clients stated they haven’t received an allowance since being placed at this group home. During a file review, LPA did not observe any supporting documentation at facility of the separate account where the client allowances are maintained nor any justification explaining why the clients did not receive an allowance. During an interview, the Administrator said she will not give a child an allowance if they are not following the rules. The Administrator further stated that doing so would be rewarding negative behavior and teaching the youth that no matter what they say or do, they are still entitled to an award. LPA finds the above allegation to be true and have been substantiated it. The following deficiency was cited per Title 22 section 84026 (c) (1) (2) see 9099 (D)

deficiencies.description:
84026(C)(1)(2) Safeguards for Cash Resources, Personal Property, and Valuables.  The licensee shall ensure that a child's cash resources are not taken in the form of fines unless the following requirements are met:  All fines levied shall be recorded and explained in the child's file, including the amount of the fine and the reason for the fine.  Such fines shall be maintained in an account separate from the person or business accounts of the licensee or facility. This requirement is not met as evidence by:

Based on information obtained during confidential interviews, documentation that was reviewed, and statements from the facility Administrator stating she doesn't give clients allowance if they aren't following the facility rules.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
As per the Administrator, the girls placed at this group home need to know that rules are to be followed and if they don't follow the rules there are consequences.

See attached statement from Administrator.

narrative:
On 09/16/21 at 10:20 AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Pamela Silva and Zeyda Loera conducted an unannounced Post Licensing Inspection at the facility. LPAs met with Dr. Catherine Powell, Administrator. The facility currently has a provisional Short Term Residential Therapeutic Program (STRTP) license. The STRTP’s Mental Health Program Application is pending approval. The STRTP has a pending application for National Accreditation. This STRTP is licensed to serve up to six (6) ambulatory children ages 12-17 years of age. The facility also provides services to non-minor dependents pursuant to W&I Code 16501.1 (C)(1). There are three (3) ambulatory minors and one (1) ambulatory non-minor dependent currently in placement. The LPAs requested the following: Personnel Report LIC500, Client Roster, Board of Meeting Minutes, Clients and Staff Files. This facility is a two-story home with four (4) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, a staff office, kitchen, dining, a living room, a family room and a laundry room. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no firearms or ammunitions in the facility. At 10:40 AM, LPAs conducted a walkthrough of the entire facility. Physical Plant The license, facility sketch, personal rights, emergency disaster form, complaints poster, emergency phone numbers and food menu are posted in a prominent, publicly accessible location in the facility. Disinfectants, cleaning solutions and sharps are kept inaccessible in a locked closet. Facility has non-perishable food for at least one week and perishable food for at least two days. Medications are centrally stored in a locked storage room. Smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and in proper working order. Fire extinguishers were fully charged. First Aid Kits were checked and found to be complete. Room temperatures are maintained at 76 degrees F. The hot water temperature was tested and measured at 110 degrees F. All sinks, showers and toilets were in working order. No more than 2 children share a bedroom. All beds are in good repair; equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows. Adequate supply of beddings and linens

were observed. Facility provides age-appropriate clothing items and hygiene products. Overall, facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Operations Facility maintains a register of clients and the register is available upon request. The board of directors regularly conducts meeting to review and discuss the STRTP's operation. The facility administrator and manager are the responsible and capable staff for communicating with emergency personnel in the facility. The facility has developed, maintained and implemented written complaint procedures. Client Records LPAs reviewed four (4) client records. All client records are available to the licensing agency to inspect, audit and copy upon demand. Client records contain required information including, but not limited to, consent forms, court orders, needs and services plan, removal/discipline/complaint procedures; medical assessment; safeguards for cash resources, personal property and valuables; education records; personal rights forms; and medication administration records. LPAs found that Needs and Services Plan (NSP) were not signed by authorized representatives. Staff Records LPAs reviewed three (3) staff records. All staff have been subjected to criminal records review and have been fingerprinted and cleared with DOJ, FBI and CACI. The administrator meets the required qualifications and/or experience. Documentation of the required education and experience requirements are maintained in the personnel file. Facility Managers meet requirements. LPAs were unable to verify 40 hours of annual training for direct care staff. Core/Therapeutic Services Facility provides core services and supports to children and non-minor dependents as appropriate or necessary that are trauma informed, culturally relevant, age and developmentally appropriate and include the following: Medi-Cal specialty mental health services; transition support services; educational and physical, behavioral, and mental health supports; activities to support children and non-minor dependents and services to achieve permanency.

Disaster Preparedness Plan Facility maintains a current, written disaster and mass casualty plan of action. Facility conducts disaster drill at least quarterly for each shift. The drills are documented, and the documentation is maintained in the facility for at least a year. Facility maintains an emergency and disaster plan, register of clients, Needs and Services Plan for each client, medication records, and contact information for each client's responsible party and physician. LPAs interviewed one (1) client and two (2) staff members. At the conclusion of the inspection, LPAs discussed the findings with the facility administrator. LPAs issued two (2) Advisory Notes Technical Assistance, LIC9102TA. LPAs agreed to work with the facility administrator to collaborate with guidance to get the facility in compliance with ILS and Title 22 regulations. The administrator was provided information on where to locate the Provider Information Notices (PINs), guidance to the new CARE Tools inspection process and Guardian. An exit interview was conducted, and a signed copy of this report, LIC811, LIC9102TA and appeal rights were provided to the facility administrator.

It was alleged that staff use excessive discipline on group home client. It was also alleged that staff confiscates client’s personal possessions. It was alleged that staff member speaks inappropriately to clients. It was also alleged that staff inappropriately handled group home minor. All facility staff interviewed denied all of the above allegations. There were five clients living in the home, four of the clients denied all of the above allegations, one client stated that all of the above allegations occurred. Based on confidential interviews, staff does not use excessive discipline and does not confiscate personal belongings. Confidential interviews also revealed that staff are always nice, respectful and do not tell client’s to “shut up”. Based on confidential interviews, there are no witnesses to staff physically handling a client inappropriately. Although the allegations may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were provided to the facility representative.

Confidential interviews were also conducted with Staff 1 (S1), Staff 2 (S2), Staff 3 (S3), Staff 4(S4) and Staff 5 (S5) on 10/4/21 (See Confidential Names List Form LIC 811 dated October 7, 2021).

On 05/23/2022 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ina Yeung and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an informal virtual meeting via Teams with the licensee representatives and other participants listed below: - Licensee Representatives - Director Catherine Powell, Board Members Jamal Powell and Clifford Manning - Catalyst Center Representative – Dr. Kelsie Tatum-Martinez, Clinical Senior Adviser - County Representatives - CSW Maria Garcia-Martinez of Riverside County and CSW Danine Saff of Madera County The purpose of the meeting was to notify the licensee and placement agencies that the provisional license will expire in October 2022. Per AB2944, the Department will only be able to extend the provisional license to a maximum of 24 months in order for the licensee to obtain Accreditation, MediCal Certification, Mental Health Approval from County and Mental Health Contract with DHCS so that the licensee can obtain a permanent license. Currently, the licensee is unable to locate any county to work on a Mental Health Approval with them and this will result in possible closure of the facility. During this meeting, LPM Yeung urged licensee and placement county representatives to work together and reach out to their respective mental health department to provide a mental health contract to licensee to avoid the need to provide a closure plan in September.

Since issuance of provisional license, New Destiny has worked to secure a Mental Health contract and Medi-Cal Certification with no success in or out of their host county. Currently, the facility is providing Mental Health services through the Presumptive Transfer process. Follow up actions were discussed during the meeting as follows: - Dr. Powell will follow-up specific contacts with counties. New Destiny will initiate meetings with counties and Dr. Tatum-Martinez can help facilitate the meetings to help move the contracting process. - Dr. Tatum-Martinez will follow-up meeting with Kern County to discuss feedback and barriers that New Destiny is facing in obtaining mental health contract. - County Representatives, Ms. Garcia-Martinez and Ms. Saff will follow-up with their team in Behavioral Health for opportunities for contracting mental health with New Destiny. During the meeting, it was discussed and agreed that licensee will provide an update to this department by the end of the following week (5/27/2022). The licensee will initiate contacts and meetings with mental health departments of all possible counties they work with to obtain mental health contract and will notify LPA Silva if there are future meetings so that CCL and Catalyst Center representative can participate and provide support. A copy of this report was provided to NDYF’s Director, Dr. Catherine Powell, after the meeting.

On 03/06/23 at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tira Logan and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Pamela Silva conducted an informal virtual meeting via Teams with the licensee’s director, Cathy Powell and two (2) representatives from Catalyst Center, Kelsie Tatum-Martinez and Misty Berard. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the facility’s plans should it fail to obtain a mental health contract by the end of the Waiver of Time which ends in June 30, 2023. Since issuance of provisional license, New Destiny has worked to secure a Mental Health contract and Medi-Cal Certification with no success in or out of their host county. Currently, the facility is providing Mental Health services through the Presumptive Transfer process. The facility currently has four (4) minors in placement, three (3) from San Bernardino and one (1) from Santa Clara. Initially, Dr. Powell stated that they have not created a plan in the event, that a mental health contract is not obtained by the expiration of the Waiver of Time. Per Dr. Powell, Madera County has yet to move forward with contracting mental health. During the meeting, Dr. Kelsie suggested for Dr. Powell to contact Santa Clara County to inquire about possibilities for contracting mental health. Dr. Kelsie will set up a meeting with San Bernardino again for other opportunities for contracting mental health and inquire about possible exemption to their 50-mile radius restriction. Last year, New Destiny’s mental health proposal was rejected by San Bernardino due to facility not being located within the 50-mile radius from the border. LPA will conduct follow-up calls with provider and Catalyst Center regarding updates on these meetings. The meeting ended at 10:45 AM. A copy of this report was provided via email to the facility’s director, Dr. Cathy Powell.

On 06/17/2021 at 12: 00 PM., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez and Kendal Zirbes conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility above. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Director of Operations (DOO) Dru Adams. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a required annual. DOO Adams led LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPA Zirbes on a tour of the facility’s interior and exterior. There were four clients residing at this facility. The facility is a single-story residence with four bedrooms, two bathrooms, one living room, kitchen, dining room, , laundry area, and pool. The facility has been operating with a capacity of six males from ages 8 years old to 17 years old. Currently there are four clients in care. Two bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two client share a room with two twin beds in each room. Two bedroom are arranged so that no more than one client in the room with one twin be in each room. Each bedroom includes adequate drawers and closet space for client’s belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be 117.0 degrees. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The living room has a TV. The hallway has three closets: one for linen, second for cleaning supplies and the third for medication, medical log, and hygiene products for clients. The smoke detectors were check and are operable. The carbon monoxide were checked and are operable. The fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility has seven days of non-perishable and two perishable of food. The menu is posted on the refrigerator. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, and Personal Rights form. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. See LIC809C page 2

The facility has a pool which is fenced and secured with two wrought iron gates and wooden fencing. The pool fencing was over five feet tall, with a self-latching and self-closing gate that swings outward with a lock. The bottom of the fence is no more than 4’ from the concrete. The bars of the fence are no more than 4” apart. There are no items that surround the pool that will be climbable. The pool is clean and well maintained. Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. LPA Meza-Gonzalez and LPA Zirbes reviewed 12 staff files and four client files (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated 06/17/2021). The staff files have the acknowledge of child abuse reporting requirements, criminal record clearances, staff qualifications, and trainings requirement. Clients' records has a current needs and services plan for each client. Clients’ records contain authorization for emergency medical care signed by each child's authorized representative. The facility has record of cash resources, personal property and valuables. DOO present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. No clients were present to interview. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Based on observations made during the inspection and file reviews no deficiencies observed during today’s inspection, 06/17/21. An exit interview was conducted, and this report was reviewed with DOO Adams and a copy of this report was provided.

On March 4, 2022 at 1:40 PM, an unannounced SB 484 Psychotropic Medication Inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Val Wilson. During the inspection, LPA Wilson met with Dru Adams, Operations Director/Facility Administrator for the Group Home, New Haven- Connie Gayle, and inspected the facility inside and out. During the tour of the facility, LPA Wilson observed the office holding the medication and the medication cart were locked. LPA Wilson interviewed two staff on site at 2:25 PM and 2:43 PM. LPA Wilson reviewed two staff personnel files on site at 3:000 PM. LPA reviewed five clients' records on site at the facility beginning at 2:00 PM. LPA reviewed five of five of child’s psychotropic medications and medication records at 2:10 PM. LPA conducted exit interview with Dru Adams, Operations Director/Facility Administrator at 4:20 PM. LPA provided the Summary Report to Dru Adams upon completion. No deficiencies are being cited at this time. LPA conducted exit interview with Dru Adams at 4:25PM.

On August 30,2023 at 10:20 A.M., Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Carol Anderson and Jacob Salem conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility above. LPAs Anderson and Salem met with Director of Operations (DOO) Julia Savoy. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct a required annual. LPAs Anderson and Salem inspected the facility’s interior and exterior. There were five clients residing at this facility. LPAs interviewed two clients and two staff. The facility is a single-story residence with four bedrooms, two bathrooms, one living room, kitchen, dining room. laundry area, and pool. Two bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room with two twin beds in each room. Two bedrooms are arranged so that no more than one client in the room with one twin in each room. Each bedroom includes adequate drawers and closet space for client’s belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be at 105 degrees. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The living room has a TV. The hallway has three closets: one for linen, second for cleaning supplies and the third for medication, medical log, and hygiene products for clients. The smoke detectors were checked and are operable. The carbon monoxides were checked and are operable. The fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility has seven days of non-perishable and two perishables of food. The menu is posted on the refrigerator. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, and Personal Rights form. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. Per DOO Savoy, there are no firearms or weapons allowed in the facility.

The facility has a pool which is fenced and secured with two wrought iron gates and wooden fencing. The pool fencing was over five feet tall, with a combination lock on the gate that swings outward. The bottom of the fence is no more than 4’ from the concrete. The bars of the fence are no more than 4” apart. There are no items that surround the pool that will be climbable. The pool is clean and well maintained. LPAs reviewed five staff files and five client files. The staff files have the acknowledgement of child abuse reporting requirements, criminal record clearances, staff qualifications, and training requirement. Clients' records have a current needs and services plan for each client. Clients’ records contain authorization for emergency medical care signed by each child's authorized representative. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements of where the alcohol was consumed; some statements indicate the children drank at school while other interviews state that it happened at the facility. In regards to staff not ensuring hazards were inaccessible, it was stated that C1 self harmed with a sharp object on multiple occasions. Confidential interviews revealed that razors and other sharp objects are locked in a cabinet in the staff’s office. However, it is unknown where C1 obtained the sharp objects. There were no witnesses to the incidents. Based on confidential interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the allegation that staff do not adequately supervise C1 in care, and staff did not ensure that hazardous items were inaccessible to children in care may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by the evidence gathered. Therefore, the allegation is determined to be unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted appeal rights were provided and a copy of this report was provided to Program Specialist/Facility Administrator Julia Savoy.
investigation_findings: 13On September 15, 2023, at 10:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson completed the investigation into the above allegation. LPA met with Program Specialist/Facility Administrator Julia Savoy. During the complaint investigation LPA interviewed four of seven Staff (S1 – S4), and one of six Clients (C1), C2-C6 were unavailable to be interviewed as they are no longer residing at the facility and did not return LPA’s calls. LPA made several attempts to interview S5- S7, however, they did not return the call and/or they no longer work for the facility. LPA reviewed Client 1 (C1) file which included C1’s Service Plan, Medical log, as well as Special Incident Report. The Department received a complaint on February 7, 2023, staff do not adequately supervise children in care, and staff did not ensure that hazardous items were inaccessible to children in care. It was stated that C1 and C2 were drinking alcohol at the facility. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was under the influence of alcohol and vomited in the trash can in C1’s bedroom at the facility.

narrative: Due to being unable to interview all individuals, confidential interviews did not corroborate the allegation with a preponderance of evidence. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed the allegation that S1 engaged in inappropriate interactions with C1, which may have occurred, however, it is not supported or proven by the evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights explained, and a copy of this report was reviewed with Julia Savoy. Due to printer malfunction, a copy of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights were emailed to Julia Savoy. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.
investigation_findings: 13On March 27, 2024, at 12:00 pm , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Julia Savoy, Director of Operations, to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA conducted an inspection of the facility on January 23, 2024, at 1:00 pm and no deficiencies were observed. LPA Linley interviewed one client (C1), and two staff (S2, S3), and attempted to interview one staff (S1), however, was unable to contact them despite multiple attempts. LPA reviewed the following documents during the investigation: S1's Employee Application, S1's Termination Notice, text messages and videos from S1 to C1 and Simi Valley Law Enforcement Incident Report. On January 18, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation that staff member engaged in inappropriate interactions with a minor. It was reported that S1 had inappropriate communication with C1. Confidential interviews revealed conflicting statements. Some interviews indicated that S1 communicated with C1 via cell phone, social media messages, and videos after they left the facility. ***CONTINUED ON NEXT PAGE

narrative: During the investigation LPA Anderson interviewed clients (C1-C6), staff (S1-S5), and reviewed pertinent facility records. In reference to the allegation that staff grabbed minor’s arm, one confidential interview revealed S1 grabbed C6’s arm once, however, there was no additional information, or details provided regarding the matter. A confidential interview revealed S1 has never been seen grabbing any clients in care, and a confidential interview denied S1 grabbed C6. Multiple confidential interviews revealed staff at the facility have not been seen grabbing or touching clients in care. In reference to the allegation that staff threatened minors, a confidential interview revealed that S1 once threatened C2, but no additional information or details were provided. Confidential interviews did not reveal that S1 has used out of state care as a form of threat or has threatened to take away cellphones. Confidential interviews and a review of records revealed that a client at the facility was placed in out of state care and had their cellphone taken away due to concerns with the use and distribution of illicit substances. Additionally, a confidential interview confirmed that S1 does not have the authority to make those decisions. Confidential interviews revealed that staff have not been heard or observed to threaten clients in care. In reference to the allegation that staff yelled at minors, a confidential interview disclosed that S1 yelled at C1, but no additional information or details were provided. Confidential interviews revealed that facility staff have not been heard or seen yelling at clients in care. Confidential interviews did, however, reveal that a school teacher has yelled at clients, but the teacher is not part of the residential program. Based on interviews, and records review, the allegations that staff grabbed minor’s arm, staff threatened minors and staff yelled at minors are unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Doreen Quinn, Chief Executive Officer. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Doreen Quinn, Chief Executive Officer, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.
investigation_findings: 13On January 3, 2025, at 10:03 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abby Saeteurn made an unannounced visit to New Haven – Connie Gayle and met with Doreen Quinn, Chief Executive Officer, to deliver findings for the above stated allegations. LPA Carol Anderson initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on January 23, 2024, at 12:35 PM and no immediate deficiencies were observed. On January 19, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff grabbed minor’s arm, staff threatened minors and staff yelled at minors. It was reported S1 once grabbed a client by the arm to prevent them from leaving the facility and threatens minors by telling them they will be placed in out of state facilities and will take away their phones. Additionally, it was reported that S1 yells and manipulates minors and S2 once interrupted a client and got in their face. CONTINUED...

narrative: Confidential interviews revealed C2 once broke a window in the facility. A confidential interview detailed that staff contacted law enforcement after this incident and a Special Incident Report submitted to CCL, dated 01/29/2024, confirmed the disclosed incident. The Special Incident Report also revealed that police were present prior to the incident clearing C1 from returning from unauthorized leave. Furthermore, the Special Incident Report revealed that C1 engaged in property damage when emotionally deregulated, and staff continued with supervision and routine care allowing for C1 to return to baseline. A confidential interview revealed that C2 once made inappropriate comments regarding sexual assault to minors in care, however, additional confidential interviews did not confirm or reveal any information on an incident of this nature occurring. Furthermore, a review of facility records did not reveal any Special Incident Reports submitted to CCL that would corroborate the incident occurred. Additionally, confidential interviews and a review of pertinent facility records revealed C2 was known to bring illicit substances into the facility. A review of pertinent records revealed that the illicit substances were brought in by C2 after returning from unauthorized leaves of absence. Confidential interviews and review of facility pertinent records revealed staff increased supervision for C2 due to these concerns. Confidential interviews confirmed staff complete 15 minute check-ins on clients when in their rooms. A confidential interview and a review of the facility pertinent records revealed clients also receive consequences when engaging in inappropriate behavior. A confidential interview revealed that when clients are found with illicit substances, supervision is increased, and staff complete five minute check-ins on clients. Based on interviews and records review, the allegation that staff are not addressing minor’s behavior at the facility due to lack of supervision is unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Doreen Quinn, Chief Executive Officer. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Doreen Quinn, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.
investigation_findings: 13On January, 7, 2025 at 10:02 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abby Saeteurn made an unannounced visit to New Haven – Connie Gayle and met with Doreen Quinn, Chief Executive Officer, to deliver findings for the above stated allegation. LPA Carol Anderson initiated a complaint inspection at the facility on February 07, 2024, at 1:30 PM and no deficiencies were observed. During the investigation LPA Anderson interviewed clients (C1-C6), staff (S1-S5), and reviewed pertinent facility records. On February 07, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that staff are not addressing minor’s behavior at the facility due to lack of supervision. It was reported C2 has been breaking windows, is making sexual remarks, and is bringing illicit substances into the facility. CONTINUED...

narrative:
Additionally, it was also reported that staff at the facility have been seen video calling personal family and showing the faces of clients in care. Regarding the allegation that minors are not accorded dignity in their relationships with staff, confidential interviews revealed S1 has not been observed to treat C1 differently. Confidential interviews describe S1 as being strict with clients in care by enforcing the facility’s rules. One conflicting confidential interview did, however, reveal that S1 has been seen to single out C1 by yelling over C1. A confidential interview with C1 detailed that S1 and other facility staff have not singled out them or other clients in care. Confidential interviews also revealed staff maintain a work relationship with clients in care by providing help and support and revealed that when clients do not follow the rules of the facility, staff will inform clients of their loss of privileges. Regarding the allegation staff do not have planned activities for minors, confidential interviews and a review of records revealed the facility plans weekly activities for clients to participate in. Some confidential interviews revealed clients will sometime refuse to participate in the scheduled activities while other conflicting confidential interviews revealed that if one client is placed on consequence and is not allowed to participate, the activities will be canceled, and no clients are allowed to participate. Other confidential interviews revealed clients will sometimes decline to participate in the activities due to a lack of interest or in solidarity when a client is placed on consequence and cannot attend. Regarding the allegation staff are not according minors with privacy in the home, confidential interviews revealed staff have participated in answering personal video and phone calls while in the presence of clients in care. A confidential interview revealed that despite answering a personal call inside the facility, clients were not in sight. Other conflicting confidential interviews deny staff have ever been seen participating in taking personal video or phone calls while in the presence of clients in care. Confidential interviews reveal staff have been instructed not to take personal video or phone calls while in the presence of clients and have been instructed to take any personal calls outside of the facility and away from the presence of clients.

Based on interviews and review of records, the allegations, minors are not accorded dignity in their relationships with staff, staff do not have planned activities for minors and staff are not according minors with privacy in the home are all unsubstantiated. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted with Administrator, Julia Savoy. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided and reviewed with Julia Savoy, whose signature on this report confirms receipt of these documents.

met_with: Julia Savoy, Director of Residential Operations
narrative:
On July 11, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Velasquez, conducted an annual inspection of the facility. The facility was toured inside and out with Julia Savoy, Director of Residential Operations. The home is a one-story residence with 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. There are 3 clients on census and were not available at the time of inspection due to being in school. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is an adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The two bathrooms were clean and in good repair. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the staff office. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the secured area across from the office. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the office/medication room. The First Aid Kit is in the staff office and contains all required supplies and equipment. The facility has no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by staff. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Ombudsman Poster, Visitation policies, and current menu. There are 3 closets within the home. Closet 1 contains the medications and med books, a First Aid kit, and office/staff desk and supplies. Closet 2 contains paper towels, toilet paper, mops, cleaning supplies, dish soap, and clothes soap. Closet 3 has hand/bath towels, hygiene baskets, and extra comforters. The clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in office/medication room. The medication logs are kept updated and the dispensing records had no discrepancies.

LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 3-day perishable supply of food while reviewing the refrigerator and freezer. There is a meal preparer for the campus, and meal menus are up to date. There are 8 seating areas in the kitchen, fresh fruit options on the table, with placemats. There are a variety of snacks available for clients. The family room/visiting area has 2 couches, 3 bean bags, board games, books, and donated comic books for reading. There are programs for clients in care to read, lift weights, and go jogging. Additionally, there is a separate music room for clients, and a Sensory Room is being refurbished that will enhance meditation, health, and wellness. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Laundry facilities are outside and easily accessible by the exit door. There is a Healing Garden where clients in care are able to sit among trees and flowered shrubs for quiet time. There is a swimming pool located on the west side of the facility, which is locked, fenced, and inaccessible to clients. All staff are required to have a certificate in water safety. Other outside amenities are a Pickleball-Basketball-Volleyball Court, Badminton, a Field Track, and Ping Pong. A sample of client and staff files were reviewed during the inspection. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances, Educational Studies, and Identification. CPR certificates are all up to date. A review of administrative records indicates that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to the facility representative, Julia Savoy, Director of Residential Operations, along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811).

Other witness interviews indicated that they did not believe S1 brought the candy into the facility. Based on confidential interviews and information gathered during the investigation, the allegation that S1 provided C1 and C2 with Cannabis candy edibles, may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to CEO Doreen Quinn.
investigation_findings: 13On March 26, 2021 at 1:30PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Carol Anderson met with CEO Doreen Quinn to deliver finding of the above allegation. The investigation was conducted by Senior Special Investigator Lucius Charlemagne of the Community Care Licensing (CCL) Investigation Branch. Special Investigator Lucius Charlemagne interviewed four staff and five clients. The investigation included a review of San Diego Sheriff’s investigative report. On October 6, 2020, the Department received an allegation that staff provided clients with Cannabis candy edibles. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was given cannabis (marijuana) “edibles” Skittle candy containing a marijuana compound called THC in it and C1 ate it. Confidential interviews revealed that C2 went into the house candy container and removed a bag of Nerds Rope candy from the container and it contained THC in it. Confidential interviews revealed that S1 admitted to giving Hershey’s candy bars to C1 for a special occasion, but not candy containing marijuana or THC. S1 denied bringing the edibles into the facility and giving it to any clients. (See LIC 9099C dated 3/26/21)

narrative: On 06/17/2021 at 10:15 A.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez and Kendal Zirbes conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility above. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Director of Operations (DOO) Dru Adams. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct an annual continuation. The staff files have the acknowledge of child abuse reporting requirements, criminal record clearances, staff qualifications, and trainings requirement. Clients' records has a current needs and services plan for each client. Clients’ records contain authorization for emergency medical care signed by each child's authorized representative. The facility has record of cash resources, personal property and valuables. Based on observations made during the inspection and file reviews no deficiencies observed during today’s inspection, 06/17/21. On 06/16/2021 at 11:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gloria Meza-Gonzalez conducted an unannounced inspection at the facility above. LPA Meza-Gonzalez met with Program Specialist (PS) Michele Folk. The purpose of the inspection is to conduct a required annual. PS Folk led LPA Meza-Gonzalez on a tour of the facility’s interior and exterior. There were two male clients residing at this facility. The facility is a single-story residence with four bedrooms, three bathrooms, one living room, kitchen, dining room, game room, laundry room, and garage. The facility has been operating with a capacity of six males from ages 8 years old to 17 years old. Currently there are two clients in care. Two bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two client share a room with two twin beds in each room. Two bedroom are arranged so that no more than one client in the room with one twin bed in each room. Each bedroom includes adequate drawers and closet space for client’s belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The hot water in the client’s bathroom was measured to be 106.0 degrees. A physical plant inspection was completed and included the following checks: Facility grounds are clean and free of debris and observable hazards. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. The front of the garage has a basketball hoop and in a gym is set up in the garage. The living room has books, Legos, and a TV. The hallway has three closets: one for linen, cleaning supplies and personal hygiene for the clients. The game room is set up with games and TV with an Xbox. The facility has seven smoke detectors: one smoke detector in each bedroom, hallway, living room and game room. The smoke detectors were check and are operable. The facility has two carbon monoxide detectors, one in the hallway and the second in the game room. The carbon monoxide were checked and are operable. The fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. The facility has seven days of non-perishable and two perishable of food. The menu is posted on the refrigerator. All required forms are posted including the Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Foster Youth Bill of Rights and Personal Rights form. Medications are locked and centrally stored in a locked cabinet in the staff office. See LIC 809C page 2.

Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. Facility appears to be meeting the terms and conditions of their license. Child's records (see confidential name list, LIC811, dated: 06/16/2021) a current needs and services plan for each client. Child's records contain authorization for emergency medical care signed by each child's authorized representative. The facility has record of cash resources, personal property and valuables. PS Folk is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule. No clients were present to interview. One staff was present for interview. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. Based on observations made during the inspection there would be an annual continuation to inspect personnel files as they are kept off-site. An exit interview was conducted, and this report was reviewed with PS Folk and a copy of this report was provided.

Confidential interviews revealed that C1 was watching pornography on a computer at the facility and staff verbally directed C1 to close the computer which led C1 to yell and kicked S2 in the leg. Confidential interviews revealed C2 began yelling at C1 for physically assaulting S2. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 ran towards C2 while C2 was in the kitchen boiling hot water. Confidential interviews revealed C2 picked up the pot of boiling water and threw it on C1. Confidential interviews revealed that staff separated C1 and C2 during the incident. However, LPA was unable to interview witnesses to determine if a lack of supervision occurred during the incidents involving C1 and C2 that occurred at the facility. Regarding facility refuses to take minor back in placement after hospitalization, confidential interviews revealed that C1’s biological mother informed the facility therapist that C1 will not be returning to the facility when C1 is discharged from the hospital. However, LPA was unable to interview all witnesses regarding C1’s discharge plans once release from the hospital. Based on confidential interviews and documents reviewed during the investigation, the allegations that C1 and C2 engaged in an altercation due to staff neglecting to intervene, staff did not adequately supervise C1 and C2 and facility refuses to take C1 back in placement after hospitalization, may have occurred, however, is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was provided to Director of Operations Dru Adams.

facility_name: NEW MORNING YOUTH & FAMILY SERVICES, INC.
narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced telecommunication visit with the facility on 9/28/20 at 8:25 AM and spoke with Kristen Patterson, Assistant Administrator. LPA discussed an email that was received by Ms. Patterson and current administrator Annah Wilson on 9/24/20 from an anonymous source alleging an inappropriate contact between staff and an unnamed youth. LPA did obtain additional information not included in the original information/email. Ms. Patterson states that she feels that the anonymous source that sent the email to be S1 and/or S2 (see LIC811 dated 9/28/20) and did provide information regarding both employees. LPA did note that both individuals are still fingerprint cleared and associated to the facility as of 9/28/20. LPA did request additional information from Ms. Patterson for S1 and S2 to include: Dates of employment (beginning and ending) Contact information Copy of job application Ms. Patterson states that she will get the additional information regarding S1 and S2 by close of business 9/28/20. No citations were issued on this date and exit interview was conducted. Document was provided to Ms. Patterson via email for signature and return.

facility_name: NEW MORNING YOUTH & FAMILY SERVICES, INC.
narrative:
On 12-14-2020 date Licensing Program Analyst Dawn Eunice conducted a televisit, via Microsoft Teams and met with Kristen Patterson, Administrator, for a case management inspection. This inspection is regarding an incident report that alleged inappropriate contact between staff and a child received 9/24/2020. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced telecommunication case management inspection at New Morning Youth Services on 9/28/20 and met with Kristen Patterson, Assistant Administrator, regarding that incident report as well. New Morning Youth Services received an anonymous email on 09/24/2020, that there had been inappropriate contact between staff and an unnamed youth. LPA Hill conducted an initial interview of Ms. Patterson, obtained a copy of the anonymous e-mail, and obtained additional evidence which included: information contained in staff (S1 and S2’s) case files (dates of employment, contact information, employee action plan, resignation letters and job applications), and reports from the Licensing Information System. Additional evidence obtained was a response letter from CPS and a copy of the police report. CDSS Investigator Borton interviewed Kristen Patterson, Annah Wilson, and a Nevada County Social Worker Robyn Kleinhans.

Investigator Borton attempted to interview the anonymous complainant, S1, S2 and a youth. Multiple individuals were non responsive. There was no victim named in the anonymous e-mail and there was no response when Investigator Borton attempted contact with someone at the anonymous e-mail address. This LIC 809 is created to document this investigation. There are no Title 22 regulation, Interim Licensing Standards nor Health and Safety Code deficiencies cited. LPA Eunice delivered this report virtually, Via Microsoft Teams, on 12/14/2020.

facility_name: NEW MORNING YOUTH & FAMILY SERVICES, INC.
narrative:
photos obtained by the investigator. Discussions between C1 and S1 were about multiple sexual partners, attraction(s) between C1 and S1, "love being expansive and impossible to compartmentalize", being "fluid and undefinable at times", and C1 or S1 having emotionally involved communications between them. One of the messages uncovered stated "we have a connection & we care about each other". The allegation that staff engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of clients in the facility is related to this inappropriate contact, conversations and communications between C1 and S1. In addition, Investigator Burton received information that C1 and S1 were found by a third party sleeping clothed together in the same bed at least one time and a picture showing that C1 and S1 in clothed and in bed together (not the same incidents). S1 was told that C1 may have had a crush on S1 but S1 did not stop the inappropriate messages or communications and even admitted that communications between C1 and S1 were emotionally involved. As a result of the interviews conducted, documentation reviewed and investigation conducted, the allegation that staff had an inappropriate relationship with client in care and staff engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of clients in the facility are SUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation is valid because the preponderance of the evidence standard has been met. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22 Division Six, regulation 84072(d) Personal Rights. Investigation shows that S1 carried on an inappropriate relationship with C1 that appeared to be emotionally abusive in nature. These discussions included content of a sexual nature and were inappropriate as the nature of the relationship was that of care provider/mentor and youth in care. Facility cited for violation of Health and Safety §1569.58(a)(2) Officers, directors and employees of licensed facility... Investigation shows that staff engaged in conduct that is inimical to the health, morals, welfare or safety of an individual in or receiving services from the facility, or the people of the State of California as it relates to the inappropriate contact, conversations and communications between C1 and S1. Exit interview conducted with Ms. Patterson and document provided.

When interviewed, C1 alleged that the relationship between C1 and S1 was "intimate and very sexual" but denied there was sexual intercourse or penetration or other contact of a sexual nature. C1 denied that C1 and S1 ever kissed but did make statements about inappropriate touching over the clothing that could not be corroborated. As a result of the interviews conducted, documentation reviewed and investigation conducted, the allegation that staff had an inappropriate sexual relationship with a client in care is UNSUBSTANTIATED at this time meaning that the allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Exit interview was conducted and documentation was provided to Ms. Patterson.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Tamara Hill made an unannounced complaint inspection on 11/12/21 at 10:00 AM and met with Kristen Patterson, Administrator to discuss the findings of the complaint allegations. LPA informed Ms. Patterson that the complaint investigation included an initial inspection of the facility on 8/16/2021 by Investigator Shannan Borton, Investigations Branch, review of documentation provided by the facility for staff and previous staff, clients and previous clients. Interviews were conducted for current staff and clients, and other individuals relevant to the investigation from 8/6/21 through 10/21/21. LPA informed Ms. Patterson that the allegation that staff had an inappropriate relationship with a client in care is related to the relationship between C1 (see LIC811 dated 11/12/21) and S1. Investigation shows that S1 and their partner allowed C1 to move into their home through an independent living arrangement overseen by another licensed care provider. While C1 was in the home, investigation showed that there was inappropriate contact and conversations between C1 and S1 as demonstrated by text messages and

deficiencies.description: Personal Rights. The licensee shall ensure that each child...is accorded the personal rights specified in Welfare and Institutions Code section 16001.9 i.e. To be free from physical, sexual, emotional, or other abuse, corporal punishment, and exploitation. This standard was not met as evidenced by Investigation showed that S1 had an inappropriate relationship with C1 that appeared to be emotionally abusive in nature. Discussions included content of a sexual nature and were inappropriate as the nature of the relationship was that of care provider/mentor and youth in care which poses an immediate Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to residents in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility shall provide a written plan of correction related to the citation by POC date of 11/15/21. This POC shall address the immediate and the future compliance to ensure that the facility does not repeat violation(s) in the future.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Kellie McKinley and Katherine Deaton completed the annual inspection at the facility address listed above. The LPAs reviewed two staff files and attempted to interview the facility's only placement. This child is not a foster youth and is privately placed by the Far Northern Regional Center. The LPAs provided the facility with PPE per their request. The LPAs reviewed the following Advisory Notes - Technical Violations with the Administrator: Title 22 Section 84065(i)(2)(B), Title 22 Section 84065(j)(6), and Title 22 Section 80070(a). The LPAs explained that citations were not issued for these deficiencies because there is no immediate or potential risk to health or safety of the clients in care. The LPAs conducted an exit interview with the Administrator and will provide them with a copy of this report . [Title 22 Section 84065(i) Notwithstanding Sections 80065(f)(1) through (6), new child care staff hired on or after July 1, 1999, shall complete a minimum of 24 hours of initial training comprised of the 8 and 16 hour training as specified in (1) and (2) below: (2) Sixteen hours of training shall be completed by new child care staff within 90 days of hire. (B) Within 30 days of completion of the 16 hour training, the administrator or administrator's designee shall assess if each newly hired child care staff understands and can apply the training. Title 22 Section 84065(j)(6) Documentation of successful completion of training shall be maintained in the personnel record for each child care staff. Title 22 Section 80070(a) The licensee shall ensure that a separate, complete, and current record is maintained in the facility for each client.]

On 7/25/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility and met with Amber Watkins, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to conduct a Required Annual Inspection of the facility. The last Annual inspection for the facility was on 8/27/21. LPA utilized the CARE Tool to complete the Annual inspection. The facility is licensed to provide treatment services for children ages 7 to 17 years. The facility currently has one client, a Regional Center placement. One client was present during the inspection. The facility is licensed for a maximum capacity of 5. Staff to client ratio is 1:2. LPA conducted an inspection of the physical plant and checked for all necessary requirements. The facility had no noticeable odor and maintained an acceptable room temperature. There are a total of four bedrooms available for clients, with each client having their own bedroom, but one room is set up with two beds, and can occupy two clients. One bedroom is use for a playroom. LPA observed the client bedrooms, living room, kitchen, four bathrooms, the backyard, and the garage to be clean and organized. LPA observed each client bedroom to have a closet, a dresser, and a clean mattress. Sheets, blankets, and pillows were in good condition. Every bedroom was decorated with the client’s personal items. LPA observed a locked staff file located in the laundry room. Medications are stored in the kitchen in a locked cabinet. LPA observed the proper postings including: facility license, complaint hot-line, menu, and emergency disaster plan. Smoke alarms were in working order, fire extinguishers were current, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. The facility has no outstanding fees. LPA observed 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food in the kitchen and in the refrigerator. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions were inaccessible. LPA reviewed two client files, 1 was permanent and 1 was a respite who comes to stay occasionally. The permanent client were taking court ordered psychotropic medications and had current court authorization or parental consent on file. Report continued on 809c

Psychotropic medication logs for clients were written on separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Records. Clients were current on CHDP physical exams and dental exams. The client’s Needs and Services Plan/Individual Program Plan were complete and up to date. LPA reviewed four staff files. Staff files had completed criminal record clearance. All required initial and annual training were not completed and not up to date. All 4 of the staff files were missing current Emergency Intervention Training. First Aid and CPR certifications were up to date for all staff. Administrators Certificate was valid. LPA interviewed two staff on site. LPA was unable to interview the client, the client is non-verbal. Facility is issued a citation per California code of Regulations, Title 22 Regulations 84365(d): Emergency Intervention Staff Training, (d) The licensee must maintain a written record of the facility staff training. A signed copy of this LIC-809 (and LIC-809C, and LIC 809D) report was provided to Amber Watkins, Administrator.. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.

Based on LPA’s observations, interviews, and records reviewed, although the allegations may have happened, or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the violations did, or did not, occur. Therefore, the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. A signed copy of this report was provided to the facility. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights provided.
investigation_findings: 13Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Wendy Brown arrived unannounced at the facility on this date for the purpose of delivering findings for the complaint investigation. LPA met with Amber Watkins, Administrator and Melissa Johnson, Administrator. LPAs Misty Valencia and Lyta Vue conducted the complaint investigation. The investigation was opened with the facility on 07/13/2023. The following were interviewed: Reporting Party, two (2) Administrators, three (3) staff, and one (1) Regional Center case manager. On 7/13/2023, LPAs Valencia and Vue attempted to interview one (1) client, but the client does not use words to communicate. Six out of seven (6/7) individuals interviewed denied the allegations, reporting they have never heard of staff smoking marijuana at the facility. Six of those individuals interviewed also stated they never witnessed minors left unattended or in soiled diapers. While LPAs were conducting the health and safety inspection, LPAs did not smell any marijuana or urine odor. The facility was clean and organized. LPAs observed one client present who appeared clean and happy. Record review indicated no staff had been written up or terminated for drug use. The facility has a policy of no substance use at the facility and no staff shall be impaired by substances while working.

Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met regarding the allegation that the facility did not report incident as required, therefore the allegation is substantiated.
