investigation_findings: 13On February 5, 2021 at 3:11pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez made telephone contact with Program Manager Ellen Asquith of Newport Academy to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. Due to COVID 19 a tele-inspection was conducted. LPA conducted a tele-inspection with the facility on September 9, 2020 at 3:47pm. During the investigation LPA interviewed one Group Home staff (S1), and reviewed one Serious Incident Report (SIR) dated 07/27/2020. On August 31, 2020, the Department received an allegation that the facility did not report incident as required. It was reported that on 07/27/2020, an unidentified youth departed the facility in an ambulance operated by the Orange County Fire Department. Confidential interviews revealed that the facility did locate an SIR for the incident which was sent to the facility’s management for review. Confidential interviews and a review of the Department’s SIR database for the facility revealed that the SIR was not submitted to the Department within the required time frame. Cont. on 9099-C

deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence…of any of the events specified in (1) below, a report shall be made…within the agency's next working day during…business hours. In addition, a written report…shall be submitted to the licensing agency within seven days...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility failed to report the incident as required, by not submitting an SIR for the incident when youth was transported from the facility by ambulance.  This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Facility to provide log of Incident Reporting training to be conducted on 02/19/2021. Facility will continue to conduct Incident Reporting Training quarterly moving forward. Facility to provide Incident Report training log by 02/26/2021.

narrative: On May 18, 2022 at 11:49am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct a Required Two-Year Annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Program Manager Claudia Jaimes. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in one of the client bathrooms was measured at 117.6 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the medication room in the hallway. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a cabinet in one of the staff offices. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked food preparation room. The First Aid Kit is located in the medication room and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Program Manager Claudia Jaimes. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. The property contains a pool in the backyard which is covered by a safety net. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Due to the need to complete staff/client interviews and staff/client file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at later date. Based on the facility inspection, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to Program Manager Claudia Jaimes.

On May 20, 2022 at 10:27am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct an Annual Continuation of the Required Two-Year Annual inspection that began on 05/18/2022. LPA met with Program Manager Claudia Jaimes. During the inspection, LPA reviewed staff and client files. All the staff files are stored and secured at a different facility location (#306090011). Staff records are also accessible electronically via a secured records portal. LPA reviewed 10 staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. A sample of five client files were reviewed during the inspection. All client files had the required documents per Title 22 Regulations. All client files are maintained on a secured internet database. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operations, Emergency Intervention Plans, and Emergency Disaster Preparedness. During the inspection, interviews were conducted with three children, and three staff. Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to Program Manager Claudia Jaimes.

Therefore the medication was accessible to the client. Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met regarding the allegation that C1 had access to medications, therefore the allegation is found to be substantiated. California Code of Regulations, Title 22, 80075 (k)(1) Health-Related Services, are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with the appeal rights were explained to Program Manager Ellen Asquith. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Program Manager Ellen Asquith.

Confidential interviews resulted in inconclusive information as to how long C1 was left unattended in regard to whether it was age and developmentally inappropriate or not. Confidential interviews also revealed that C1 did not obtain the medication from the medication room at the facility. Based on confidential interviews, and records reviewed, the allegation that C1 overdosed while in care due to a lack of supervision is unsubstantiated. Meaning, although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violation did or did not occur, therefore the allegation is unsubstantiated. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with the appeal rights were explained to Program Manager Ellen Asquith. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Program Manager Ellen Asquith.
investigation_findings: 13On January 17, 2023, at 2:29pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Program Manager Ellen Asquith of Newport Academy to discuss the investigative finding for the allegation noted above. LPA conducted an inspection with the facility on November 17, 2022, at 10:11am, no deficiencies were noted. During the investigation LPA interviewed four children (C1, C3, C4, C5), one biological parent (BP5), and one facility staff (S1). During the investigation, LPA reviewed C1’s Needs and Services Plan, one Serious Incident Report (SIR) dated 10/30/2022, and the facility’s staff shift report dated 10/30/2022. On November 10, 2022, the Department received an allegation that a minor had access to medications. It was reported that C1 had obtained approximately 25 Tylenol pills while at the facility and was rushed to the emergency room. Confidential interviews revealed that C1 did not obtain the medication from the medication room at the facility, the medication was left unattended in the staff office which was not locked. Cont. on 9099-C

deficiencies.description:
80075 (k)(1) Health-Related Services. Medication shall be kept in a safe and locked place that is not accessible to persons other than employees responsible for the supervision of the centrally stored medication.

This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and records reviewed, the facility did not ensure that the medication was made inaccessible to the clients in care. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to the children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction:
Facility has since made all staff offices self-latching.
Program Manager stated that the facility will provide a medication training to facility staff. Facility will submit training documentation by 02/03/2023.

narrative:
On 03/06/2025 at 10:05 AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu arrived at the facility for the purposes of performing an Annual Inspection for a Group Home. At 10:10 AM LPA was met by Residential Director, Amanda Seymor. LPA identified herself and disclosed the purpose of the inspection. LPA was granted entry into the facility by the Director. LPA provided Facility Checklist to Residential Director. Present in the home were the Residential Director, six clients and nine staff at the time of the inspection. The six-bedroom, four-bathroom, two story home includes an entry way, family room, kitchen, laundry room, living room, and dining room. The facility is licensed to serve up to six ambulatory clients, ages 12-17 years of age and have a census of six clients. The Residential Director accompanied LPA inside the facility during the visit. At 10:43 AM the Residential Director (RD) provided updated Personnel Report and updated Client Roster to LPA. At 10:45 AM, LPA began the tour on the north side of the facility and was accompanied by the RD. LPA observed locked Care Coordinator office with stored sharps. LPA observed medication room was locked and all medication was locked in cabinets within the medication room. LPA observed locked hygiene closet had a surplus of hygiene and grooming products available to clients. A locked storage closet is available to clients to safeguard valuables. LPA toured the den and observed a L-shaped couch with seating for six clients plus two chairs and a high-top dining table with six chairs to accommodate six clients plus additional seating for visitors. The den has a television plus activities, and a refrigerator to store food surplus. LPA toured the second floor located only on the north side of the home which is being used for staff purposes: client therapy sessions and staff bathroom, which remains locked when not in use. LPA toured the Family Therapy session room near the facility entrance. LPA observed client bedroom #1 having a twin-size bed, walk in closest, a six-drawer dresser, one night stand, and a desk. Client bedroom #2 is now being used as the therapist’s office. Client bedroom #3 had two full size beds, a walk-in closet, two chairs, two desks, and two four drawer dressers. Page 1

LPA observed the south side of the home beginning in the hallway. LPA observed the hallway had overhead lighting, hallway closets contained a snack pantry and food pantry, a bathroom, a bookcase with books and craft/activities available for client use, the entrance to the chef’s kitchen, and the chef’s office. The room temperature met Title 22 Regulations of 65 degrees Fahrenheit (F) to 85 degrees F with a temperature of 70 degrees F per facility thermostat located in the hallway. LPA toured the main living room and observed two couches, a sofa chair, two chairs along with a picnic style dining room table. LPA observed a refrigerator and small kitchen used by clients and staff for breakfast and snacks. Small kitchen included client’s dishes and utensils, and a locked cabinet to store cleaning supplies. All required posting were displayed in a prominent place in the main living room. LPA observed a television and arts and crafts for client’s leisure. LPA toured bedroom four and observed a twin bed, five drawer dresser, one night stand, a desk, and private bathroom. LPA toured Client bedroom #3 and observed two twin beds, two seven drawer dressers, two desks. and chairs. LPA observed client bathrooms. All chemicals and cleaners were inaccessible to clients in a locked cabinet in the small kitchen and laundry room. The bathrooms were free from dirt, debris, and pests. There was a drawer for each client to use. The toilets, showers and sinks were found to be operational. Bathrooms one and two water temperature on the north side of the building was measured between 94.6- and 96.3 degrees F due to pipes being replaced on the north side of the building. Per Residential DR, and maintenance personnel repairs will be completed next week at the latest. LPA reminded RD to advise assigned LPA prior to any repairs or construction. Bathrooms three, four, and five water temperature were between 105 degrees F and 120 degrees F with a temperature reading of 112.6 which is in compliance per Title 22 regulations. LPA toured the chef/main kitchen, walk in freezer, walk in refrigerator, and prepping kitchen all areas were found to be within regulations. LPA observed kitchen to be well lit, disinfected, organized, free of dirt, pests, and odor. Food was stored in tight fitting containers, expiration dates were current, there was perishable items for two days and non-perishable items for three days. A weekly menu was posted in the kitchen. The laundry room is located next to the prepping kitchen. The laundry room has a washer and dryer for client use and all laundry detergent and chemicals are padlock in a storage closets. The backyard was toured and found to be with in regulations. The backyard was free of hazards, provided a shaded area to play or rest, the grass and garden was maintained, and enclosed. Page 2

LPA observed workout equipment, a fuze-ball table, a pool table, a skate ramp, and skee ball. There is a pool located in the backyard that is enclosed by a 5-foot fence that is locked and meets per Title 22 regulations. When pool is in use there are staff members present at all times. Per RD there are no firearms or weapons on premises and smoking is prohibited. LPA reviewed five out twenty-eight staff (S1 - S5) files, and six of six client (C1 - C6) files. Due to time constraints, LPA will return to the facility to conduct staff and client interviews. No deficiencies cited. An exit interview was conducted, the report and appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Residential Director at the time of visit. Page 3

On May 19, 2025, at 10:00 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jacqueline Garcia conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection at the facility and met with Residential Director, Amanda Seymour, regarding Incident Report (IR) that occurred on 5/16/25. The Department received the IR on 5/16/25. The incident involved medication error involving staff (S1) and client (C1). LPA reviewed staff (C1) and client (C1) records and obtained records. LPA interviewed one client (C1). Due to further review needed, this Case Management is is being extended. No deficiencies were noted at this time. An exit interview was conducted, a copy of this report along with LIC 811 was reviewed and given to Residential Supervisor, Amanda Seymour.

It was also reported that the residents were driving a rented four-seater bicycle pedal cart in an unauthorized area of the park and intentionally and maliciously ran over two children. Investigator received inconsistent information during the investigation. Confidential interviews do not support the allegation that this incident was the result of a lack of care and supervision by the facility staff. Confidential interviews revealed that the bike that ran over the two children was being driven by a client and was occupied by facility staff as well. Confidential interviews also revealed that the incident was not intentional or malicious by the client driving the bike. Confidential interviews revealed that there were three facility staff present with five clients at the park. A review of the investigative narrative also indicates that the family of the two children ran over decline to participate in the investigation. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegation of a lack of supervision of clients on an outing resulting in injuries to community members, may have occurred, however is not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, along with appeal rights were explained and emailed to Residential Supervisor Taralyn McDevitt for signature. Original signed reports will be placed in facility file.

narrative:
On May 27, 2022 at 11:14am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct a Required Two-Year Annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Residential Supervisor Benji Benitez. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the kitchen sink was measured at 113.5 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the medication room in the hallway. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a cabinet in the garage, and also in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked drawer in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the medication room and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Residential Supervisor Benji Benitez. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Due to the need to complete staff/client interviews and staff file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at later date. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operations, and Emergency Disaster Preparedness. A sample of five client files were reviewed during the inspection. All client files had the required documents per Title 22 Regulations. All client files are maintained on a secured internet database. Cont. on 809-C

Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to Residential Supervisor Benji Benitez.

On May 31, 2022 at 11:25am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct an Annual Continuation of the Required Two-Year Annual inspection that began on 05/27/2022. LPA met with Director Amanda Seymour. During the inspection, LPA reviewed staff files. All the staff files are stored and secured at a different facility location (#306090011). Staff records are also accessible electronically via a secured records portal. LPA reviewed 10 staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. LPA discussed and reviewed the following inspection components; Operations, and Emergency Intervention Plans. During the inspection, interviews were conducted with three children, and four staff. Three children declined to be interviewed. Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to Director Amanda Seymour.

Confidential interviews revealed that the facility did locate an SIR for the incident. Confidential interviews and a review of the Department’s SIR database for the facility revealed that the SIR was not submitted to the Department within the required time frame. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met regarding the allegation that staff did not properly report an incident, therefore the allegation is substantiated. This poses a potential Health, Safety or Personal Rights risk to the children in care. The facility will be cited for violating California Code of Regulations, Title 22, 80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, a Confidential Names List (LIC 811) along with the appeal rights were explained and provided to Program Manager Claudia Jaimes.
investigation_findings: 13On June 30, 2022, at 1:42pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced to the facility and met with Program Manager Claudia Jaimes of Newport Academy to discuss the investigative findings for the allegation noted above. LPA conducted an inspection with the facility on December 8, 2021 at 1:29pm. No deficiencies were observed. During the investigation, LPA interviewed one Group Home staff (S1), one biological parent (A2), and sixa clients (C2, C3, C4, C5, C6, C7). LPA also reviewed one Serious Incident Report (SIR) dated November 16, 2021. C1 declined to be interviewed. On November 29, 2021, the Department received an allegation that staff did not properly report an incident. It was reported that on 11/16/2021 between 6:30pm and 7:00pm, it is believed that at least one youth ran away from the facility resulting in Law Enforcement (LE) and paramedics involvement. It was also reported that a youth was observed being removed from the facility on a gurney. Cont. on 9099-C

deficiencies.description:
80061(b) Reporting Requirements. Upon the occurrence…of any of the events specified...below, a report shall be made…within the agency's next working day...a written report…shall be submitted...within seven days...
This requirement is not met as evidenced by: Based on confidential interviews and record review, the facility did not ensure that an SIR was submitted as required for the incident when youth AWOL’d from the facility involving Law Enforcement. This poses a potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care.
deficiencies.plan_of_correction: Program Manager stated that a Incident Reporting training will be conducted on 07/13/2022 with facility staff. Program Manager will submit list of topics covered and staff in attendance on 07/13/2022 to the Department.

narrative:
On March 12, 2025, at 9:50 AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu met with Residential Director, Amanda Seymour Residential Supervisor (RS), Marcos Medina and Facility Administrator (FA), Monica Garcia for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection of the facility. The Facility is licensed to serve six (6) ambulatory children ages 12-17 years old. The current census is four (4) children. A physical plant inspection was completed with Residential Supervisor and included the following checks: three bedrooms, Kitchen, five bathrooms (three client, two staff), medication room, dining room, living room, family room, four staff offices, and outdoor living space. All required forms are posted including Grievance Procedures, Visitation Policies, Personal Rights form, and Foster Care Ombudsman poster, the Emergency Disaster Plan was also posted. Clients’ medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in medication room. LPA observed one Ring Doorbell camera at the facility in the front of the home. Facility grounds are clean and free of debris. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced on 03/07/2025. Fire clearance inspection was completed on 02/05/2025 and LPA received a copy of the approved Fire Clearance to place in facility file. Licensee maintains an adequate supply of perishable and non-perishable foods to prepare the items on the posted menu. LPA observed a minimum seven-day non-perishable and two-day perishable supply of food. Individual beds were observed with clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattress in good repair. All three bedrooms contain two twin beds. The facility has three client bathrooms. The water temperature was tested in bathroom one which measured 113.4 degrees Fahrenheit which is within the appropriate range of 105 degrees to 120 degrees Fahrenheit.

Per facility staff, no firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. No deficiencies cited during today’s inspection. Due to time constraints LPA will return on another day to conduct client and staff interviews, and client and staff file reviews. The licensing fee payments are current. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to Amanda Seymour. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file.

Other confidential interviews resulted in conflicting statements that clients are not allowed phone calls for the first 72 hours of admission at the facility. In regard to the allegation that resident did not have access to personal belongings, information was received that a group of clients were observed walking in the neighborhood and at least one was barefoot. Confidential interviews revealed that clients are allowed their shoes at the facility throughout their placement at the facility. Other confidential interviews resulted in conflicting statements that clients are not allowed their shoes during the first 72 hours of placement. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that resident's rights were violated, and resident did not have access to personal belongings, may have occurred, however are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Dahl Larios conducted a case management inspection June 9, 2022 at 9:34 am based on the number of relevant law enforcement contacts reported by the facility, pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 1538.7. During this inspection,10 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth files were reviewed. 5 out of 10 Direct Care Staff and 5 out of 5 youth were interviewed. (See the Confidential Names List, LIC 811, dated June 9, 2022). The Plan of Operation including policies and procedures were reviewed. Minutes from the board of directors’ meetings related to the facility’s incidents involving contact with law enforcement were reviewed. Based on the analysis of the confidential interviews and youth file review including the needs and service assessments, youth case plans, quarterly assessments, and crisis intervention plans, the licensee uses trauma-informed and evidence-based de-escalation and intervention techniques when staff is responding to the behavior of a youth residing in the facility. Interviews with youth and staff indicate the licensee prohibits calls or threats to call law enforcement as a form of discipline. LPA Dahl Larios observed documentation of completed training on policies and procedures on when and how to involve law enforcement in response to an incident. Training records show staff have been trained on Emergency Intervention as required. The licensee is contacting law enforcement in accordance to their Emergency Intervention Plan when there is an immediate risk of serious harm to a child or others. There are no deficiencies cited at this time. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to Director of Residential Amanda Seymour.

On June 29, 2022 at 11:46am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct a Required Two-Year Annual inspection of the facility. The facility was inspected inside and out with Program Manager Claudia Jaimes. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client’s belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in one of the client bathrooms was measured at 117.8 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will not have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the medication room in the hallway. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked drawer in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the medication room and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke/carbon monoxide detectors in the hallways were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Program Manager Claudia Jaimes. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, Emergency Disaster Plan and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Due to time constraints and the need to complete client interviews and client file reviews, this inspection will need to be continued at a later date. All the staff files are stored and secured at a different facility location (#306090011). Staff records are also accessible electronically via a secured records portal. LPA reviewed 9 staff files. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. Cont. on 809-C

Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to Program Manager Claudia Jaimes.

On November 10, 2022, at 2:47pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez conducted an inspection with the facility for the purposes of initiating a complaint investigation. LPA met with Residential Supervisor Monica Garcia, and conducted a safety inspection of the facility. During the inspection it was confirmed that the incident surrounding the allegations occurred at a different facility location. No deficiencies were observed. An exit interview was conducted and this report was explained to Residential Supervisor Monica Garcia. Due to printer malfunction, this report will be emailed to Residential Supervisor Monica Garcia.

On February 19, 2005 at 10:15am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Gilbert Marquez conducted an inspection with the facility for the purposes of doing an annual inspection. LPA Marquez met with Program Manager Monica Garcia, and conducted a full plant inspection of the facility buildings and grounds. The census is 0 and there were no youths who were residing on the premises.According to Joe Viccaro, Executive Director, the facility ceased intake of clients as of December 27, 2024. LPA Marquez stated that Community Care Licensing (CCL) had not been given a written notice that the facility was pausing its operations. A written statement from the LIcensee is required to state the date the "pause in intake" occurred, and give the expected date of resuming intake of youth to be served at this facility. The physical plant inspection started with the "UR Building" where youth can have space for downtime and a break. Currently the back yard is not available due to painting renovations at the "Main Building." The UR building has a bottom floor where the youth bathroom is located. The bathroom hot water temperature was measured at 105.8 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible in areas where clients will not have access. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in a locked cabinet in one of the locked staff offices. The First Aid Kit is located on the second floor and contained all required supplies; the tweezers are located in the locked staff office downstairs. The building had one smoke/carbon monoxide detector in the hallway, and were checked and were operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Program Manager. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Facility License, Grievance Procedures and Personal Rights. The disaster plan and visitor policies were in storage at Main building due to the renovation painting. Emergency exits were free from obstruction in the UR building. Cont. on 809-C

The backyard was not available to youth during the painting renovation. However LPA Marquez and Program Manager Garcia did a walk through of the yard space. LPA observed that there are no signs giving caution about the prominent eastern hillside on facility grounds, and neither are there hand rails. LPA and Program Manager inspected the "old tree house" and the abandoned chicken coop. Both small buildings are accessible by walking on a steep upward hill walkway made from both wooden beams on the ground and large rock tiles. The facility will be given a type B deficiency and asked to have a Plan of Correction submitted to LPA Marquez to resolve this issue, see LIC809-D for specific regulation and deficiency summary. The Main Building was inspected and LPA Marquez observed that all rooms were being repainted, and all cabinets were being repainted. The courtyard of the Main Building was not an accessible walkway due to being currently renovated. Its renovation will be completed in the near future and before clients are residing in the Main Building. All the staff files are stored and secured digitally. LPA reviewed 3 staff files. One staff, Program Manager Monica Garcia was interviewed. All the staff have met the training and qualification requirements per regulation requirements. Per a review of the Community Care Licensing Information System (LIS), all staff met DOJ/FBI criminal record clearances and Child Abuse Index Check requirements. Based on the facility inspection, and files reviewed there was one deficiency, type B given for hazardous area accessible in the backyard of the facility. An exit interview was conducted with Program Manager Monica Garcia, and a copy of this report was explained and provided to her, and emailed to Crystal Goodwin, Regional Licensing and Compliance Manager of Newport Healthcare.
